CODE OF ORDINANCES OF THE CITY OF EUNICE, LOUISIANA 
____________ 
Published in June, 1978 by Order of the Mayor and Board of Aldermen 
> 

> 
INTRODUCTION 
    This publication represents the first comprehensive revision and compilation of the general ordinances, resolutions and other legislative enactments of the City of Eunice, Louisiana. Under the authority granted by LRS 33:1361 et seq., the Mayor and Board of Aldermen directed that this codification be prepared for the general use and benefit of the citizens of the Eunice community. The Code was prepared under the general supervision of Mr. Wesley H. Clanton, City Attorney and Mr. James S. Duos, City Clerk, with research and editorial assistance provided by Marvin L. Lyons and Associates, Inc. 
    This Code contains all of the general and permanent ordinances and other legislative enactments of the City's governing body. In adopting this document, the Mayor and Board of Aldermen expressed its intent to repeal all general ordinances which were not included herein, save and except those whose repeal was specifically exempted in the Adopting Ordinance. Ordinances relating to special purposes, or having a limited life, such as enactments levying taxes or special assessments, providing for bond issues, vacating specified streets, etc. were not included. An enumeration of the types of ordinances which were not included and are therefore not affected is set forth in Section Four of the Adopting Ordinance. 
    In addition to local legislation, certain self-operative provisions of the Louisiana Revised Statutes and other state legislative material adopted by the City by reference were also included where such material added to the City laws on a particular subject or was needed to clarify an issue. 
    One of the main directives that the Mayor and Board of Aldermen gave to the staff engaged in this project was that it develop a publication that was not only factually correct and up to date, but also one that could be conveniently used by those trained in the law and lay persons as well. In responding to that directive, several things were done. 
    First, all of the minutes of the City's governing body were researched, back to the time of the City's incorporation. Material gathered from the records was then checked against state laws, court decisions and opinions of the Louisiana Attorney General for agreement and compliance. In some instances, new ordinances were adopted before the Code was finally enacted to bring the City's laws into compliance with state authority relating to the matter. 
    The material was then divided into subject matter groupings and those groupings were developed into chapters. The chapters were further divided into sub-chapters, parts, and sections in a manner intended to provide a logical sequence of provisions. Each chapter, sub-chapter and section was then appropriately titled or provided with a heading to facilitate easy reference and identification of the subject matter contained therein. 
    Following each section, in parentheses, is a note indicating the legislative source of the material therein contained. The source notes for the local legislation indicate the date the legislation was adopted, the section number within the legislation, if section numbers were employed, and a brief historical note explaining if the original enactment had ever been amended. Source notes which contain an LRS number mean that the material in that section was derived from the Louisiana Revised Statutes. The numbers that follow the LRS designation indicate the title and section from which the material was obtained. 
    Many chapter and sub-chapter titles, and sections are also followed by a "Comment" note. These notes were employed by the staff to cross reference sections of the code which related to one another, to refer the reader to the general source of authority by which the City had the power to enact such a provision and to otherwise add or provide information to the reader on a particular matter. These notes were especially prepared to save the user valuable time and effort in researching various provisions of the City's laws and to aid in construction and interpretation. 
    The numbering system used in this Code is similar to that followed in the Louisiana Revised Statutes. Each section number consists of the two parts, separated by a colon. The first part of the number refers to the chapter in which the material is located, and the second part, to the specific location of the material in the chapter. Thus, the first section in Chapter 1 is numbered Section 1:1, and the third section in Chapter 15 is numbered Section 15:3. The system was devised to enable the reader to more easily cite material, and/or locate material so cited. 
    The reader will also notice that occasionally, the editors have reserved certain section numbers within chapters, and always between sub-chapters. This was done to facilitate the inclusion of new material as such material is enacted in the future. Page numbers following sub-chapters and chapters have also been reserved for the same reason. 
    The Code also contains a comprehensively developed Word Index. Most of the provisions in the Code have been listed under several different headings in the Index to make the location of material as easy as possible. 
    The attention of the reader is also called to the special looseleaf format of this publication. This format was employed, also, to facilitate the inclusion and addition of new legislative material. Municipal governments are not static creatures, and from time to time, new ordinances will need to be adopted, and existing laws will need to be changed. As new legislation is enacted, supplements will be prepared and made available containing the new material. Holders of the Code are therefore urged to check with City officials from time to time concerning the availability of such supplements. 
    Finally, the Mayor and Board of Aldermen would like to take this opportunity to express its appreciation to Mr. Wesley H. Clanton, its City Attorney, Mr. James S. Duos, its City Clerk and to the officers and staff of Marvin L. Lyons and Associates, Inc. for the time and effort they put into this project. In particular, we would like to thank Mr. Marvin Lyons and Mr. William T. Kivett of the MLL staff, who served as project directors and editors; Mr. William J. Doran, Jr., attorney for MLL and editorial assistants, Lynne Hotstream, Sherry Buzzell and Jeannie Comeaux. 
Respectfully submitted, 
Wilson J. Moosa, Mayor

ORDINANCE NO. 8-86 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a Codification and Revision of the Ordinances, Resolutions and Other Legislative Actions of a General and Permanent Nature of the City of Eunice, Louisiana; Providing for the Repeal of Obsolete and Conflicting Legislation Not Included Therein; Providing a Penalty for the Violation of Such Codified and Revised Ordinances; and Otherwise Providing with Respect Thereto. 
    WHEREAS, it is a matter of significant public importance that the ordinances, resolutions and other legislative actions of a general and permanent nature of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, should be revised, their language simplified, their incongruities corrected, their deficiencies supplied, and the whole arranged in order, the sections thereof being numbered so as to provide for additions and amendments, and reduced to one connected text with a view to the end that all may know the law of this municipality; and 
    WHEREAS, Sections 33:1361 through 33:1363 and 33:1364 through 33:1370 of the Louisiana Revised Statutes authorize local governments to generally revise, update and codify their ordinances and other general legislative enactments, and to adopt and promulgate such compilations; and 
    WHEREAS, the Mayor and Board of Aldermen, desiring to take advantage of the above-cited legal authority has authorized such a revision to be undertaken and a compilation to be prepared under the supervision of Mr. Winston Ardoin, City Attorney and Mr. Shirley F. Vige', Sr., City Clerk, with research and editorial assistance to be provided by Municipal Code Corporation; and 
    WHEREAS, the work on this project has been completed, and a compilation prepared under the designation the "Code of Ordinances of the City of Eunice, Louisiana," dated December, 1985, which said "Code" has been presented to, examined, and approved by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen; and 
    WHEREAS, it is the desire of the Mayor and Board of Aldermen that this "Code of Ordinances" be officially adopted; 
    NOW THEREFORE BE IT ORDAINED by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, assembled in regular session as follows: 
    Section 1. The Code of Ordinances of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, prepared under the supervision of Mr. Winston Ardoin, City Attorney and Mr. Shirley F. Vige', Sr., City Clerk, with editorial and research assistance provided by Municipal Code Corporation, dated December, 1985, a certified copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, is hereby adopted. 
    Section 2. The Code of Ordinances herein adopted contains all of the ordinances, resolutions and other legislative actions of a general and permanent nature of the City of Eunice and shall be construed as continuations of and as substitutes for the laws or parts of laws which are revised and consolidated therein. The Code shall be in full force and effect on and after the tenth day after promulgation of this ordinance, and all ordinances or other legislative enactments of a general and permanent nature enacted on or prior to January 1, 1986, which are not included therein, or recognized or continued in force by reference, or which may conflict with any provisions thereof, are hereby repealed, except as may be hereinafter provided. 
    Section 3. The adoption of this Code of Ordinances shall not affect the continued existence and operation, subject to the provisions hereof, of any department, agency or office heretofore legally established, any rights acquired or occurring, any taxes or other charges incurred or imposed, any penalties incurred or imposed, or any judicial procedure had or commenced prior to the adoption of this ordinance. 
    Section 4. The repeal provided in Section 2 above shall not affect any of the following types of ordinances, resolutions or other legislative enactments, to-wit: 
a.  Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money or authorizing the issuance of any bonds or any evidence or indebtedness, or any contract or obligation; 
b.  Administrative actions, such as the fixing of salaries, the establishment of agencies, etc., not inconsistent with the provisions of the Code; 
c.  Appropriating money of levying taxes, fees, special, assessments or service charges; 
d.  Pertaining to the calling of elections or promulgating the results of such elections; 
e.  Accepting, abandoning, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, paving or improving any road, public way or servitude; 
f.  Providing for local improvements or assessing taxes or charges therefor; 
g.  Dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision, or vacating same; 
h.  Establishing any special district which has not expired; 
i.  Relating to franchises, not inconsistent with the Code or granting any franchise which has not expired; 
j.  Prescribing traffic regulations at specific locations, such as through or stop streets, loading zones, speed limits, etc., not inconsistent with the Code; 
k.  Zoning or rezoning particular pieces of property. 
    Section 5. The general repeal provided for in Section 2 shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or other legislative enactment or part thereof which had heretofore been repealed. 
    Section 6. All of the rules of construction, administration provisions, severability provisions, etc., provided in Chapter 1 of the Code of Ordinances herein adopted are hereby recognized and established as being the general rules for the construction of the Code, and for its general use, interpretation and administration. 
    Section 7. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any provision of the Code of Ordinances herein adopted, or to commit any act which is declared to be a misdemeanor or unlawful, and where no specific penalty is provided therefor, a violation of any provision of said Code shall be punishable by a fine not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00) or imprisonment for a term not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both such fine and imprisonment, within the discretion of the court. Each day any violation of any provision of said Code shall continue constitutes a separate offense. 
    After the necessary publication and time lapse period having been met, this ordinance shall go into effect. 
    Thus the above and foregoing ordinance was submitted for consideration of adoption this 8th day of July, 1986. 
_____
Shirley F. Vige', Sr., Clerk _____
Curtis Joubert, Mayor  
    After a public hearing was held on the above ordinance, the title having been read and the ordinance considered, on motion by Mr. Peart, seconded by Mrs. Fontenot to adopt the ordinance, a record vote was taken and the following result was had: 
    YEAS: Peart, Dupre, Bellow, Fontenot 
    NAYS: None 
    ABSENT: Babineaux 
    WHEREUPON, the above and foregoing ordinance was duly adopted on this the 12th day of August, 1986. 
_____
Shirley F. Vige', Sr., Clerk _____
Curtis Joubert, Mayor

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1:1. - Code of ordinances; how cited. 
    The ordinances, motions and other legislative material embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances of the City of Eunice, Louisiana", and may be so cited. 
Comment- For method and procedure in adopting a code of ordinances, see LRS 33:1361. 
Sec. 1:2. - Code of ordinances not retroactive. 
    No section of this Code of Ordinances is retroactive unless it is expressly so stated. 
Sec. 1:3. - Words and phrases, how construed. 
    In the construction of this Code and of all of its provisions, the words and phrases shall be read with their context and shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language. Technical words and phrases, and such other words as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law, shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
    The word "shall" is mandatory and the word "may" is permissive. 
Sec. 1:4. - Unambiguous wording not to be disregarded. 
    When the wording of a section is clear and free of ambiguity, the letter of it shall not be disregarded under the pretext of pursuing its spirit. 
Sec. 1:5. - Clerical and typographical errors. 
    Clerical and typographical errors in the Code shall be disregarded when the meaning of the governing body is clear. 
Sec. 1:6. - Conflict in expression of figures and words. 
    Whenever there is a conflict between a number expressed both by figures and written words, the latter shall prevail unless such words obviously are contrary to the legislative intent. 
Sec. 1:7. - Singular may denote plural. 
    Words used in the singular number include the plural and the plural includes the singular. 
Sec. 1:8. - One gender may denote others. 
    Words used in one gender apply also to the other genders, except as otherwise clearly indicated by the context. 
Sec. 1:9. - Use of disjunctive. 
    Unless it is otherwise clearly indicated by the context, whenever the term "or" is used in the Code, it is used in the disjunctive and does not mean "and/or". 
Sec. 1:10. - Person, defined. 
    Unless it is otherwise clearly indicated, the word "person" includes a body of persons, whether incorporated or not. 
Sec. 1:11. - Property, defined. 
    As used in this Code, the word "property" refers to both public and private property, movable and immovable, corporeal and incorporeal property. 
Sec. 1:12. - City, defined. 
    The words "the City" or "this City" shall be construed as if the words "of Eunice" followed them and shall extend to and include any agency, board, commission, department, officer, agent, or employee of same. 
Sec. 1:13. - Classification and arrangement of chapters and sections; effect on construction. 
    The classification and organization of the chapters and sections of this Code is made for the purposes of convenience, reference and orderly arrangement, and no implication or presumption of a legislative construction shall be drawn therefrom. 
Sec. 1:14. - Headings to sections, source notes, indexes, table of contents, not part of law. 
    Headings to sections, source notes, comments, cross references, the index, and the table of contents contained herein are given for the purpose of convenient reference and do not constitute part of the law. 
Sec. 1:15. - Reference in code. 
    Unless otherwise indicated in the context, references in this Code to chapters, parts, sub-parts or sections shall mean chapters, parts, sub-parts, or sections of this Code. 
    Whenever any reference is made to any portion of this Code or to any other law or ordinance, the reference applies to all amendments thereto hereafter made. 
Sec. 1:16. - Repeal of ordinances, effect. 
    The repeal of a repealing ordinance shall not revive the first ordinance. 
    The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment of penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, or any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed under the ordinance repealed. 
Sec. 1:17. - Construction of code; continuation of existing institutions; effect on rights acquired, penalties imposed, etc. 
    This Code shall be construed as continuations of and as substitutes for the laws and ordinances or parts of laws and ordinances which are revised and consolidated herein. The adoption of this Code shall not affect the continued existence and operation, subject to the provisions hereof, of any department, agency, or office heretofore legally established or held, not any acts done, any funds established, any rights acquired or accruing, any taxes or other charges incurred or imposed, any penalties incurred or imposed or any judicial proceedings had or commenced prior to the effective date of this Code. 
Sec. 1:18. - Severability of parts of code. 
    If any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph, section or chapter of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid, or unenforceable by a judgment of any court of competent jurisdiction, such action shall not affect the other phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs, sections and chapters of this Code. If the application of the Code or any of its provisions to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the application of this Code and its provisions to other persons or circumstances shall not be affected thereby. 
Sec. 1:19. - New ordinances; amendments to code. 
(a)  All ordinances enacted into law after the effective date of this Code which amend, repeal or are of a general and permanent public nature may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system employed herein and may be printed or otherwise reproduced for inclusion herein. 
(b)  The mayor and board of aldermen of the City of Eunice shall periodically direct that supplements be prepared incorporating herein, in an appropriate place and classification, the text of all such new legislation, assigning to these ordinances an appropriate chapter and section number, if such has not been done in their enactment. Material repealed by new ordinances shall be deleted. All new material added to the Code and all material deleted shall contain a reference note indicating the source of the legislative action from which it was derived. 
(c)  Any section in this Code or in any duly authorized subsequent edition thereof, or any duly authorized supplement thereto, may be amended or repealed by reference to the appropriate section number without reference to the ordinance from which the section was derived. Such amendments may be made by using the following language, "BE IT ORDAINED by the mayor and board of aldermen of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, that Section _______ of Chapter _______ of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, is hereby amended to read as follows ..." 
    In the event a new chapter or section is to be added, the following language may be used: "BE IT ORDAINED by the mayor and board of aldermen of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, that the Code of Ordinances of the City of Eunice is hereby amended to add a new chapter (or section) to be numbered _______, which said chapter (or section) shall read as follows: ..." 
Sec. 1:20. - Incorporation of new legislation, procedure. 
(a)  In preparing supplements to the code embracing new legislation as provided for in Section 1:19, the editor, publisher or codifier shall not alter the sense, meaning or effect or any ordinance, resolution or law, but he may: 
(1)  Renumber and rearrange sections or parts of sections; 
(2)  Transfer sections or divide sections so as to give to distinct subject matters a separate section number, but without changing the meaning; 
(3)  Insert or change the wording of headnotes; 
(4)  Change reference numbers to agree with renumbered chapters or sections; 
(5)  Substitute the proper section or chapter number of the terms "this Ordinance," "the preceding section," and the like; 
(6)  Strike out figures where they are merely a repetition of written words and vice versa; 
(7)  Change capitalization for the purpose of uniformity; 
(8)  Correct manifest typographical and grammatical errors; and 
(9)  Make any other purely formal or clerical changes in keeping with the purpose of a codification of ordinances. 
(b)  The publisher, editor or codifier shall omit all titles of ordinances, all enacting, resolving and repealing clauses, all appropriation measures, all temporary ordinances, all declarations of emergency, and all validity, declaration of policy and construction clauses, except when the retention thereof is necessary to preserve the full meaning and intent of the law. Whenever any validity, declaration of policy or construction clause is omitted, proper notation of the omission may be made. 
Sec. 1:21. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any provision of the Code or to commit any act which is declared to be a crime, a misdemeanor or unlawful, and where no specific penalty is provided therefor, whoever is found to be in violation of any provision of this Code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment within the discretion of the court. 
(b)  Each day any violation of this Code shall continue constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 47-82, 4-13-82) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION, ELECTIONS AND ORGANIZATION 
SUBCHAPTER A. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2:1. - Corporate name. 
    The name of this municipality, duly incorporated under the laws of the State of Louisiana, is hereby fixed as the "City of Eunice." 
(Res. of 10-19-67; Gubernatorial Proclamation of December 6, 1967) 
Comment- In conformity with the provisions set forth in LRS 33:341, LRS 33:342, for classification of a municipality as either a "village," "town" or "city" based on population, the Resolution of 1967 certified Eunice to have a population in excess of five thousand (5,000) by taking of census. The Gubernatorial Proclamation of 1967 accordingly declared it officially a "city" instead of a "town." 
Sec. 2:2. - City to be governed by Lawrason Act. 
    The City of Eunice shall be governed by the provisions of LRS 33:321, et seq., which provisions are commonly known as the Lawrason Act. (Gubernatorial Proclamation of January 9, 1909) 
Comment- The municipality of Eunice, as indicated above, was incorporated as a town by proclamation of the governor following a referendum vote on March 20, 1908, which carried 107-4. As noted in this section, the city elected to be governed by the provisions of the Lawrason Act as cited, which act set forth a general legislative charter for Louisiana municipalities in order to provide a uniform type of government for municipalities. 
Sec. 2:3. - Corporate boundaries. 
    The boundaries and corporate limits of the City of Eunice are hereby defined and fixed as follows: 
    Commencing at a point on the south side of Highway 91, 1,384 feet west of its intersection with west side of LSU-E Drive; thence south along a line parallel to LSU-E Drive approximately one-half mile to Acadia Parish Line; thence east along Acadia Parish Line 1,384 feet; thence west to the western boundary line of Highway 755 and/or a point 40 feet west of the northeast corner of Section 2, Township 7 South, Range 1 West; thence south 0° 20' west, measured along the west right-of-way line of Louisiana Highway 755, 466.5 feet; thence west along the south line of Lot 6, Plat "B" of the Theodore Savoi Subdivision, 1,295.5 feet to the west line of the Northeast Quarter (NE/4) of the Northeast Quarter (NE/4) of Section 2, Township 7 South, Range 1 West; thence south along the quarter section line 431.4 feet; thence east parallel to the south line of said Lot 6 to the west line of said Louisiana Highway 755; thence 0° 20' west 431.25 feet to the intersection of the west right-of-way line of Louisiana Highway 755 with the north line of the Southeast Quarter (SE/4) of the Northeast Quarter (NE/4), Section 2, Township 7 South, Range 1 West; thence north 89° 28' west, measured along the north line of the south one-half (S/2) of the Northeast Quarter (NE/4) of said Section 2, 2,166.0 feet; thence due south, 1,317.6 feet; thence north 89° 36' west, 474.3 feet; Sec. 2:4. - Corporate seal. 
(a)  The official seal of the City of Eunice, State of Louisiana, be and the same is hereby adopted so that said seal shall henceforth be in the following form and description: 
Around the edge of the dye, the words, "City of Eunice, St. Landry Parish, Louisiana," and in the center an emblem representing a pelican, the state bird. 
(b)  The clerk of the City of Eunice, State of Louisiana, be and he is hereby authorized, directed and empowered to affix the newly adopted seal on all official documents of the mayor and board of aldermen effective this 11th day of June, 1968. 
(Res. of 6-11-68) 
Sec. 2:5. - Official flag. 
(a)  There is hereby provided for and established an official flag for the City of Eunice, St. Landry Parish, Louisiana. 
(b)  The official flag of the city is described as follows: The background shall be white. The borders shall be trimmed with a gold fringe. The staff end shall have attached thereto a gold rope with gold tassels at the end. In the center of the flag shall be the official seal of the City of Eunice upon blue background. The state bird, the pelican, in the center thereof. The pelican feeding her three (3) young in the nest. Their beaks shall be gold. The mother pelican shall have a red tongue and falling from her mouth will be the food in red with the young pelican's heads upward with mouth open. The young pelicans shall be in a nest colored in brown. At the top portion of the seal in white letters shall be the City of Eunice. At the bottom of the seal shall be St. Landry Parish in white letters. 
(Res. of 12-9-69) 
Sec. 2:6. - Airport operations manual adopted. 
    The City of Eunice does hereby adopt by reference the Airport Operations Manual and the authority therefor, R.S. 2:141 known as the Uniform Airport Law. 
(Ord. No. 14-80, 9-90-80) 
Editor's note- Being not specifically amendatory of the Code, the provisions of Ord. No. 14-80, adopted Sept. 9, 1980 have been codified, at the editor's discretion, as § 2:6. 
Cross reference- Airport zoning, § 18:300 et seq. 
Sec. 2:7. - Sale of abandoned property adjudicated to municipality. 
(a)  As authorized by LRS 33:4720.15, the City of Eunice through its chief executive officer may sell at public sale abandoned property as defined in LRS 33:4720.12 which has been previously adjudicated to the city. 
(b)  Prior to proceeding to the public sale of any adjudicated property the board of alderman shall hold a hearing upon giving notice to the last owner listed on the tax rolls of the St. Landry Parish Assessor to establish that the property is "abandoned property" as defined in LRS 33:4720.12. 
(c)  After the property has been declared abandoned at a public hearing with notice duly given, the city shall proceed to sell same at public sale in the manner described below. 
(d)  The intent of the City of Eunice to sell abandoned property at public sale shall be announced at three (3) consecutive regularly scheduled meetings of the board of alderman which announcement shall contain the date of the sale, the municipal address, a brief description of the property, the terms and conditions of the sale and the name of the last owner shown on the tax records of the St. Landry Parish Assessor's Office. 
(e)  The minutes of each meeting shall contain the announcement with the information set out therein. 
(f)  At least sixty (60) days prior to the sale, notice shall be given as provided in 33:4720.17. 
(g)  In addition to the notice required by LRS 33:4720.17, at least thirty (30) days prior to the scheduled date of the public sale described in subsection (h) below, the city shall take the following measures to notify owners and prospective bidders of the property: 
(1)  The date and time of said sale, as well as the municipal address or legal description of the property shall be published as a legal notice in The Eunice News. 
(2)  A sign shall be placed upon the property to be sold containing the date and time of said sale. 
(h)  The public sale of the property shall be held at a public hearing held prior to the regular scheduled meeting of the board of alderman after the notice requirements set out above have been complied with. 
(i)  The city shall have the right to set acceptable minimum bids for the property and the property shall be sold to the highest bidder at the public sale if said bid exceeds the acceptable minimum bid. 
(j)  Said post adjudication sale shall not occur until after the three-year redemptive period from the adjudication established by state law has elapsed. 
(Ord. No. 05-07(A), 5-8-07) 
Sec. 2:8. - Reimbursement of jail inmates' medical, health care and dental expenses. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Drawing account means any account under the control of the correctional facility from which an inmate may withdraw funds. 
    Book balance means what an inmate's actual balance less what is owed for medical and dental or other health care expenses. 
    Inmate means any person confined to a city jail facility including inmates sentenced to the department of public safety and corrections who are in the custody of the city. 
(b)  Authority for withdrawal from drawing account. The jailer of the Eunice city jail shall withdraw from an inmate's drawing account reimbursement for the inmate's medical and dental expenses or other health care and shall reimburse such funds to the City of Eunice. 
(c)  Precedence of withdrawals. Except as provided for in subsection (d) of this section, reimbursements for medical, dental or other health care expenses shall be made prior to any other withdrawal from an inmate's drawing account. 
(d)  Exceptions. This section shall not prohibit the withdrawal of funds for the purpose of payments under the Crime Victims Reparations Act (LRS 46:1801, et seq.), court costs as authorized by law and other withdrawals specifically authorized by the mayor in that order. 
(e)  Establishment of rules for collection and freezing assets. The Eunice City Council shall establish written rules for the collection of medical and dental expenses and for freezing assets in an inmate's drawing account and prohibiting withdrawals from such account until the expenses are paid. The drawing account may be frozen regardless of the courses of the assets contained in such account. 
(f)  Conditions. The medical and dental and other health care reimbursement shall be conditioned upon the following: 
(1)  The initial medical evaluation upon entry into the city jail shall be made at no charge to the inmate. 
(2)  Inmates shall be informed of the reimbursement requirement at the time of request for medical or dental services is made. 
(3)  No inmate shall be refused medical or dental treatment for lack of funds. 
(4)  At booking, inmate shall sign an agreement/contract to file any and all claims for payment of medical/dental expenses for reimbursement to the City of Eunice. This agreement will also include authorization for release of medical records and any and all relevant insurance information by attaching standard HIPAA form being used at the time of booking. 
(g)  Reimbursement schedule. The amount of reimbursement shall be according to the following schedule: 
(1)  Per sick call/visit for medical services ..... Actual cost 
(2)  Per sick call for dental services ..... Actual cost 
(3)  Per prescription ..... Actual cost 
(4)  Initial screening by nurse upon entry ..... Actual cost 
(5)  Sick call evaluation by nurse ..... Actual cost 
(6)  After hours sick call for nurse ..... Actual cost 
(7)  Follow up evaluation by nurse ..... Actual cost 
(8)  Jail MD evaluation ..... Actual cost 
(9)  Dental evaluation ..... Actual cost 
(10)  Psychiatric evaluation ..... Actual cost 
(11)  UMC clinic ..... Actual cost 
(12)  Health unit evaluation ..... Actual cost 
(13)  Prescription medication ..... Actual cost 
(14)  Over-the-counter medication ..... Actual cost 
(15)  Medical supplies ..... Actual cost 
(16)  Hospital service ..... Actual cost 
(17)  Ambulance service ..... Actual cost 
(h)  Liability of discharged or transferred inmates. Any inmate who is discharged or transferred to another facility shall remain liable for any reimbursement authorized herein. 
(i)  Insufficient funds. If, at any time, an inmate's drawing account book balance, if any exists, does not have sufficient funds to reimburse the costs of medical or dental services, the account shall carry a balance of not less than five dollars ($5.00) until such time as funds are deposited into the account. When funds become available, the medical, dental or other health care reimbursement shall be immediately deducted from the account. The inmate's drawing account, if any exists, shall not be reduced below five dollars ($5.00). 
(j)  Inmate's return to city jail after being discharged with negative balance. If an inmate is discharged with a negative balance in the drawing account due to unpaid medical, dental or health care reimbursement and the inmate is subsequently returned to the city jail, the unpaid balance shall immediately be collected from the new drawing account (if any) established upon entry to the city jail in accordance with the provisions outlined in this section. 
(k)  Inmates with private or public coverage. Any inmate who is covered by a private medical or health care insurer or any public medical assistance program shall file a claim for the payment or reimbursement of any medical treatment provided while he is an inmate in the City of Eunice jail. 
(l)  Assets owned by prisoners. Any asset owned by an inmate may be attached for payment of medical, dental or other health care expenses. 
(m)  Probation. The amount of money to be reimbursed to the City of Eunice for medical, dental or health care expenses may be ordered, at the discretion of the court, to be paid by defendant as a condition of probation pursuant to the conditions specified in Louisiana Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(n)  Inmates held responsible for costs. All inmates shall be held responsible for costs incurred, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Sheets. 
(2)  Pillows. 
(3)  Pillow cases. 
(4)  Soap. 
(5)  Blankets. 
(6)  Razors. 
(7)  Uniforms. 
(Ord. No. 05-07(B), 5-8-07; Ord. No. 07-09(B), §§ 1-14, 7-14-09) 
Sec. 2:9. - Fees for copies of open public records. 
(a)  A fee of not less than one dollar ($1.00) per page (one (1) side) shall be charged for photocopying public records. Such fee is to cover the cost of labor, materials, and equipment. 
(b)  For copying any public records which cannot be reproduced by the city's photocopying equipment, the requester shall be charged the actual cost to the city, including staff time, for reproducing such records. 
(Ord. No. 0318(B) , 4-10-18) 
Secs. 2:10-2:49. - Reserved.

Sec. 2:51. - Meetings of the mayor and board of aldermen. 
    The meetings of the mayor and board of aldermen shall be held on the second Tuesday of each month at 6:30 p.m. at the City Hall. 
(Ord. No. A-332, 5-9-67; Ord. No. 2-72, 3-14-72) 
Comment- Under LRS 33:405, the governing body of every Lawrason Act municipality is required to hold at least one regular meeting each month. 
Sec. 2:52. - Emergency preparedness planning committee. 
(a)  There is hereby created the Eunice Emergency Preparedness Planning Committee. 
(b)  The Eunice Emergency Preparedness Planning Committee is responsible for formulating a plan and putting it into operation during all major disasters in and around the City of Eunice by providing a command center with appropriate communications capabilities both within the city and with parish and state homeland security/emergency preparedness agencies. 
(c)  In accordance with the plan, the Eunice Emergency Preparedness Command Center will provide overall direction and control of the conduct of the response to the emergency situation, while the various agencies, i.e. police, fire, hospital, etc. will carry out their responsibilities according to the procedures in their respective implementing instructions. 
(d)  The Eunice Emergency Preparedness Planning Committee shall consist of the following persons: 
Mayor of the City of Eunice. 
Chairman, emergency preparedness committee, who shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city council. 
Chief of police or his designated representative. 
Fire chief or his designated representative. 
Hospital representative from hospital located in the city limits or within five (5) miles of the city limits. 
City public works department representative. 
Public utility franchise representative. 
Representatives of holders of public utility franchises, presently LAWCO, CLECO and Charter Communications. 
City gas department representative. 
Designated news media representative by local radio station and newspapers. 
Councilman at-large. 
Councilman, Ward One. 
Councilman, Ward Two. 
Councilman, Ward Three. 
Councilman, Ward Four. 
St. Landry Parish Councilman for districts which are adjacent to the City of Eunice, presently Wards 11, 12 and 13. 
Designated representative of Eunice Ministerial Alliance. 
Designated representative of any nursing home located in the city limits or within five (5) miles of the city limits. 
(e)  After formulation, the plan shall be submitted to the Board of Aldermen for adoption. 
(Ord. No. 10-05(B), 10-11-05) 
Secs. 2:53-2:61. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER C. - ELECTIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance of Aug. 14, 1984, enacted a new Subch. C, § 2:52, to Ch. 2. In order to provide for possible future amendments or additions to Subch. B of Ch. 2, the editor, at his discretion, has redesignated the provisions of this Aug. 14, 1984, ordinance as a new § 2:62 to Subch. C and has reserved §§ 2:52-2:61. 

Sec. 2:62. - Municipal elections generally. 
    Municipal elections in the City of Eunice shall hereafter be held on the same date as the congressional elections held for the election of members of Congress, in accordance with R.S. 18:402(B). The officers elected shall take office on the first day of January following their election and shall hold their office for four (4) years. The next municipal elections in the city after adoption of this section shall be held on the same date as the 1986 congressional elections, and the terms of office of the municipal officers currently serving as of the date of this section shall not expire on June 30, 1985, but instead are hereby extended to, and shall expire on, December 31, 1986. 
    This section is adopted pursuant to, and is intended to comply fully with, the provisions of R.S. 33:383(A) and (B), as amended by Act 829 adopted by the Louisiana Legislature in the Regular Session of 1984, effective July 13, 1984. This section supersedes any prior ordinances and governs any future elections of municipal officers in the City of Eunice. 
(Ord. of 8-14-84, § 2:52) 
Secs. 2:63-2:72. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER D. - PERSONNEL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Subchapter D, §§ 2:73-2:80, is derived from Ord. No. 32-80, adopted Nov. 10, 1981, and an ordinance adopted Jan. 14, 1986. Since these ordinances did not provide for a specific manner of inclusion of their provisions into the Code, they have been codified as Subch. D at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 2:73. - Qualifications and requirements for noncivil service employees; notification of fiscal impact to board of aldermen. 
(a)  Any person applying for a position of employment with the city, other than applicants for positions covered by civil service regulations, shall fulfill and satisfy the following qualifications prior to being so employed. The applicant for employment with the city shall: 
(1)  Reside within the boundaries of Ward 6 of St. Landry Parish, Louisiana, or within a five-mile radius of the city limits of Eunice if residing outside of said Ward 6; 
(2)  Be of legal age of majority, a registered and qualified voter of the State of Louisiana and of the United States; 
(3)  Be physically and mentally fit to perform effectively the duties of the position applied for, as certified by the physician designated by the city to examine applicants for said purpose; to wit, this examination to be performed only after applicant has accepted the city's offer of employment; 
(4)  Be in possession of a valid Louisiana driver's license if the position applied for requires the driving of a vehicle; a chauffeur's license will be required if the applicant is applying for employment that requires the operation of trucks or heavy equipment; 
(5)  Have a reputation for good moral character, and of temperate and industrious habits; and, 
(6)  Not have been convicted of a crime, other than traffic violations or misdemeanors not involving a violation of public trust or moral turpitude. 
(b)  The fee for the physical and mental examination required hereinabove will be paid for by the city; provided, however, that the applicant agrees that the cost thereof shall be withheld from the first paycheck after employment, and held in escrow until termination of the normal period of probation, after which said costs shall be refunded to the employee. If the employee is terminated or resigns prior to said period, the examination fee shall be forfeited and retained by the City of Eunice. 
(c)  The foregoing requirements and qualifications shall not apply to the city fire department and police department employees so long as they are covered by civil service regulations, and shall not apply to any other employees who are or who may later become covered by civil service regulations for employment. 
(d)  Prior to the hiring or firing of any non-civil-service employee of the city, the mayor shall first present to the board of aldermen the name of the employee to be either hired or fired, the positions involved, the rate of compensation that the employee is to be paid at the time of hire or is then being paid in the case of a proposed termination. The mayor shall also provide the board with the amount of money then available in the budget of the department in which the proposed employee is to be hired to pay that employee's salary. 
(e)  No new non-civil-service position shall be created or a person hired for such a position unless the board of aldermen have adopted a budget amendment as required by R.S. 39:1309 to provide the funds necessary to pay the salary of the new position. 
(f)  Prior to the hiring of any new employee the mayor shall present to the board of aldermen a fiscal impact statement showing what effect the proposed hiring will have on the city's budget. 
(g)  Prior to the hiring of any non-civil-service employee of the city on and after the date of adoption of this ordinance, the mayor shall certify to the board of aldermen that the person who is proposed for hire meets all of the qualifications for the position to be filled as set out in the applicable job description for employees presently in effect for the city and present to the board of aldermen proof that the proposed employee meets the requirements for non-civil-service employees set out in subsection (a) above. Such proof shall be presented in writing with copies of appropriate documentation used to verify the proposed employee's qualifications. 
(h)  No salary of a non-civil-service employee shall be increased without prior approval of the board of aldermen in a budget amendment resolution. 
(Ord. No. 32-80, 11-10-81; Ord. No. 01-95, § 1, 1-10-95) 
Sec. 2:74. - Appointment, suspension, and dismissal. 
(a)  Vacancies to be filled in the municipal service shall be publicized in order that qualified persons shall be encouraged to apply and qualify for municipal employment. 
(b)  Employees shall be appointed pursuant to R.S. 33:404(A)(3). Appointments to positions shall be made on the basis of merit and fitness. In filling vacancies, an effort should be made to promote qualified employees before seeking an outside replacement. 
(c)  All appointments to positions in the service of the municipality shall be for a probationary period of six (6) months. 
(d)  During the investigation, hearing or trial of an employee on any criminal charge, or during the course of any civil action involving an employee, when suspension would be in the best interest of the municipality, the mayor may suspend the employee without pay for the duration of the proceedings as a nondisciplinary measure. Back pay shall not ordinarily be recoverable; but where the suspension is terminated by full reinstatement of the employee, the mayor may authorize full pay and benefits for the entire or for any lesser period of the suspension. 
(e)  An unsatisfactory employee shall be notified how his work is deficient and what he must do if his work is to be satisfactory. If the employee's work continues to be below standard, the mayor shall demote or dismiss the employee pursuant to R.S. 33:404 (A)(3). 
(f)  Prior to dismissal or termination of an employee, the employee shall be notified, by the mayor or authorized department head, either verbally or in writing, of the reason or reasons for his/her dismissal or termination. The employee shall further be advised of the evidence on which the dismissal or termination is based. The employee shall also be given an opportunity to respond, either verbally or in writing, prior to dismissal or termination. 
(Ord. of 1-14-86, § 4.1) 
State Law reference- Power of mayor to appoint and remove municipal employees, LRS 33:404(A)(3). 
Sec. 2:75. - Hours of work. 
(a)  Municipal employees will normally perform their work during hours established by the mayor. 
(b)  If it shall prove necessary for employees to work beyond the hours established for the standard work day, the mayor or authorized department head may authorize overtime work. Notwithstanding Section 2:76(d), all overtime provisions will be handled in accordance with applicable federal and state statutes. 
(Ord. of 1-14-86, § 4.2) 
Sec. 2:76. - Annual leave and holidays. 
(a)  Five (5) days of annual leave shall be earned on the anniversary date of employment of each full-time, permanent, municipal employee (ten (10) working days) after two (2) years of employment and thereafter. 
(b)  Employees may not carry over or accumulate annual leave from one anniversary date of employment to another. 
(c)  Annual leave may be taken as earned by an employee with the approval of the employee's department head. However, vacation leave is permissive and may be denied by the heads of the departments or the mayor when conditions are such that the ordinary work of the town could not be performed. Annual leave cannot be taken in less than one-half-day increments. 
(d)  All employees required to work on an observed holiday shall receive compensatory time off at the rate of hour for hour. Holidays observed by the municipality shall not be counted as a vacation leave. All employees will receive full pay for such days that are designated as official holidays by the board. 
(e)  Police and fire civil service personnel shall observe the following days as regular holidays: 
(1)  New Year's Day - January 1. 
(2)  Martin Luther King, Jr. Day. 
(3)  Good Friday. 
(4)  Memorial Day - Last Monday in May. 
(5)  Independence Day - July 4. 
(6)  Labor Day - First Monday in September. 
(7)  9-11 Memorial. 
(8)  Veterans Day. 
(9)  Thanksgiving Day - Fourth Thursday in November. 
(10)  Christmas Day - December 25. 
    All employees required to work on an observed (paid) holiday shall receive either compensatory time off at the rate of one and one-half (11/2) hour for each hour worked as permissible by chief of the department, or payment for the hours worked at one and one-half (11/2) times the employee's regular rate of pay as well as payment for the employee's regularly scheduled hours of work for that holiday at a rate of one (1) times the employee's regular rate of pay. The type of compensation shall be agreed upon between the chief and the employee prior to the commencement of work. 
(Ord. of 1-14-86, § 4.3; Ord. No. 09-13, 9-10-13) 
Sec. 2:77. - Sick leave. 
(a)  Sick leave with pay is not a right which an employee may demand but a privilege granted by the municipality. 
(b)  Leave from work with pay may be charged as sick leave if the absence is due to sickness, bodily injury, quarantine, required physical or dental examinations or treatment, exposure to a contagious disease when continued work might jeopardize the health of others, illness in the employee's immediate family which requires the care of the employee, or the funeral of a member of the employee's family. All such absences, except those resulting from intemperance or immorality, shall be charged against the sick leave credit of the employee. 
(c)  Sick leave credits accumulated by each employee as of April 10, 1979, shall be retained as of the effective date of Sections 2:74-2:80. 
(d)  Sick leave will be allowed to accumulate for future use. Employees shall be paid at retirement, or his or her beneficiary shall be paid upon his or her death, for sick leave credited to his account at the rate of one-half day for each day of accumulated sick leave; provided, that maximum payment shall be based on employee's regular rate of pay at retirement and not exceed thirty (30) days. 
(e)  The mayor shall determine when a doctor's certificate is required and under what conditions certificates are required. Department heads shall be responsible for the application of this provision so that there will be no abuse of sick leave privileges. 
(f)  If and when disability of an employee is of a nature that he is entitled to payments under any workmen's compensation insurance which is in effect, he shall, at his option, be entitled to receive sick leave with pay to the extent that sick leave has accumulated; provided, that the City of Eunice is reimbursed in an amount equivalent to that received by the employee as workmen's compensation insurance while he is on sick leave with pay. 
(g)  Sick leave shall not be granted for maternity leave purposes. Maternity leave without pay may be granted at the discretion of the mayor. 
(Ord. of 1-14-86, § 4.4) 
Sec. 2:78. - Civil leave. 
    A municipal employee called for jury duty or as a witness for the federal or state governments or a subdivision thereof shall be entitled to leave with pay for such duty in addition to regular compensation. Law enforcement officers may not receive or keep any witness fees for appearing in mayor's court in connection with their official duties. 
(Ord. of 1-14-86, § 4.5) 
Sec. 2:79. - Outside employment. 
    The work of the municipality shall have precedence over the other occupational interests of employees. All outside employment for salary, wages or commission and all self-employment must be reported to and approved by the mayor and the board. Conflicting outside employment shall be grounds for dismissal. 
(Ord. of 1-14-86, § 4.6) 
Sec. 2:80. - Gifts and favors. 
    No official or employee shall accept any valuable gift, whether in the form of service, loan, thing or promise, from any person, firm or corporation which to his knowledge is interested directly or indirectly in any manner whatsoever in business dealings with the municipality; nor shall any official or employee accept any gift, favor or thing of value that may tend to influence him in the discharge of his duties or grant in the discharge of his duties any improper favor, service or thing of value. 
(Ord. of 1-14-86, § 4.7) 
Sec. 2:81. - Salary of the mayor. 
(a)  The salary of the elected Mayor of the City of Eunice shall be the sum of forty-six thousand four hundred ten dollars ($46,410.00) annually. 
(b)  This increase in salary shall take effect on January 1, 2011. 
(Ord. No. 07-09(A), 7-14-09) 
Sec. 2:82. - Salary of city marshal. 
    The compensation of the elected City Marshal of the City of Eunice be increased to the sum of thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00) annually beginning July 1, 2015. 
(Ord. No. 09-10(A), 7-14-10; Ord. No. 0416(A), 5-10-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 09-10(A), adopted July 14, 2010, did not specifically amend the Code, hence inclusion as § 2:82 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 2:83. - Deputy chief of police. 
(a)  The city creates the position of deputy chief of police in accordance with LRS 33.2481.4; provided however that not more than one (1) person shall be appointed to serve in this position and that during the fiscal year 2011, no additional funds shall be appropriated or expended to fund salaries and benefits for these positions. 
(b)  The duties and responsibilities of the deputy chief of police ("deputy chief") are established as follows: 
(1)  The primary duty and responsibility of the deputy chief of police is to assist the chief of police in the management and administration of the overall function and operations of the police department, and to perform the duties of the chief of police in the chiefs absence. The deputy chief of police assists the chief of police in the planning and development of departmental operations, participates in the personnel management function; and oversees the maintenance of departmental records and reports. As one (1) of the chief officers of the department, employees of this class perform any assigned duties with a high degree of independence, reporting directly to the chief of police who reviews the work of this class. This class ranks directly below that of chief of police. 
(2)  Additional duties and responsibilities may include, but shall not be limited to, the following: 
a.  May manage the operation of a group of divisions within the department as assigned by the chief of police may be assigned to perform the duties of the chief of police in the chiefs absence recommends management policies, goals and objectives for the department. Assists in the research and planning for department programs and activities. Keeps informed on any local conditions which may affect the work of the department. Studies new laws, regulations, ordinances, and court rulings relating to the operation of assigned services to determine if changes in policies or procedures are needed. Insures that all department personnel policies conform to EEO regulations. Evaluates manpower requirements and determines optimum officer deployment. Assist's in developing personnel recruitment and selection programs. Reviews prospective employee applications and makes recommendations for hiring. Reviews complaints against department personnel and formulates a recommendation for reply to the complaint. Provides for the accounting for money and assets of assigned police department divisions. Gathers information for and assists in preparing the departmental operating budget. Authorizes the expenditure of funds allocated for assigned services, making sure such expenditures are in accordance with the budget. Reviews purchase requisitions and authorizes expenditure of funds allocated for police department operation, making sure that such expenditures are in accordance with the budget. 
b.  Makes decisions concerning what information should be included in the records of assigned services and determines how this information should be kept. Writes reports required to document department activity. Writes letters in reply to inquiries addressed to the police department or as required to handle needs of assigned divisions. Serves as department representative to meetings of civic and professional groups to give reports, offer advice, or make recommendations. May serve as department representative to the news media, releasing information and answering questions concerning the work of the department. Answers questions for the public about the operation of the police department or any related areas of law enforcement. Supervises subordinate department employees. Holds meetings for the purpose of receiving reports and disseminating information. Discusses work performance with subordinates. Monitors the departmental promotional evaluation system. Maintains discipline by conducting corrective interviews, make recommendations for disciplinary action(s), and carry's out disciplinary action(s) as directed by the appointing authority. Manages the general care, maintenance, and use of all department equipment, vehicles and property. 
c.  Recommends the purchase of needed equipment. Manages the work of subordinate supervisors who are responsible for law enforcement functions of the department, including patrol services traffic enforcement and crash investigations, criminal investigations, special operations, community policing, the handling of juveniles, and administration of the booking function. Manages the administration and communications operations of the department by supervising subordinate officers in charge of these divisions. Performs any related duties assigned. 
d.  Performs any related duties assigned. 
(c)  The qualification requirements of the deputy chief shall include, at a minimum, those provided for in LRS 33:2541(1). 
(d)  The position of deputy chief shall be filled on a competitive basis. The deputy chief shall serve indefinitely in the classified competitive position and shall be evaluated every three (3) years by the police chief. After each evaluation, the police chief may reconfirm the deputy chief for another three (3) year period or may, at his discretion, demote the deputy chief to a position in the class he held immediately preceding his appointment as deputy chief. 
(e)  Any employee holding the position of deputy chief of police of shall not be a member of the union. 
(Ord. No. 01-11(A), 1-11-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 01-11(A), adopted Jan. 11, 2011, did not specifically amend the Code, hence inclusion as § 2:83 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 2:84-2:90. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER E. - DRUG TESTING POLICY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Being not specifically amendatory of the Code, the provisions of §§ 1-16 of Ord. No. 15-89, adopted Jan. 9, 1990, have been codified as Ch. 2, Subch. E, §§ 2:91-2:106, at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 2:91. - Purpose and general policy statement. 
    In an effort to promote and maintain a safe, healthful, productive and efficient environment and work place for all of its employees and the public which they serve, the City of Eunice (hereinafter referred to as "the city") adopts a policy against drug abuse, and places in effect a testing program for employees, as is more particularly outlined below. To accomplish this purpose, the city does hereby prohibit the possession, use, distribution or sale of illegal drugs on city premises or by any on-duty employee. Any employee reporting for work in a condition caused by off-duty use of drugs or controlled substances which detrimentally affects his or her ability to perform work shall be deemed in violation of this subchapter and subject to disciplinary action. In general, this policy is intended to eliminate any type of substance abuse which increases the potential for accidents, absenteeism, substandard work performance, poor employee morale or promotion of a negative public image. It is intended also that this procedure be in conformity with LRS 23:1601(10). 
(Ord. No. 15-89, § 1, 1-9-90) 
Sec. 2:92. - Persons to whom provisions apply. 
    The persons to whom this subchapter applies and affects are all employees of the city who are involved in employment activities which directly or indirectly affect public safety or employee safety, including, but not limited to, persons employed by the police department, fire department, water department, gas department, sewerage department, utility department and any other department or employees who operate motor vehicles or equipment in the course of their duties, with the exception of those employed seasonally (i.e. Summer Recreation Workers), for a specific limited time (i.e. Summer Food Service Program Workers, Special Project Workers, etc....) or those hired temporarily or on a part-time basis. All persons who apply for employment with the city shall be required to take and successfully pass the drug test pursuant to this subchapter. 
(Ord. No. 15-89, § 2, 1-9-90; Ord. No. 10-91, 6-11-91) 
Sec. 2:93. - Drugs included in policy and testing. 
(a)  The drugs subject to this policy and to the testing shall be those drugs included in the definition of "prohibited drugs" specified in Schedule I or Schedule II of the Controlled Substance Act, 21 USC 801.812, or any of those drugs for which the U.S. Department of Transportation allows testing of employees, as outlined in 49 Code of Federal Procedure 199.1 et seq., which drugs presently include the following: 
(1)  Amphetamines; 
(2)  Barbiturates; 
(3)  Benzodiazepines; 
(4)  Cocaine; 
(5)  Marijuana; 
(6)  Opiates; 
(7)  Phencyclidine; 
(8)  Opiates (e.g., codeine, heroin, morphine). 
(b)  In addition to the foregoing listed drugs, the city may test, and take action upon the results thereof, for any other drugs which are allowed in the future by the U.S. Department of Transportation, including alcohol, without the necessity of amending this subchapter. Employees and applicants for employment shall be given proper notice in the event drugs and/or alcohol are later added to the drugs listed above. 
(c)  Any person subject to this subchapter who is taking prescribed medicine shall notify his or her immediate supervisor of the exact type of medication prescribed and provide a written verification from the doctor prescribing same. Applicants for employment with the city are to provide the same information and verification prior to testing. If the prescribed medication is of the type that might impair the employee's ability to drive a vehicle, operate equipment or [perform] other functions which affect a person's safety, the supervisor shall order the employee to immediately discontinue such actions. 
(Ord. No. 15-89, § 3, 1-9-90; Ord. No. 05-06(A), 5-9-06) 
Sec. 2:94. - Actions in addition to testing. 
    In the implementation of this policy, and in addition to testing for drugs, the city may take the following action: 
(a)  Any and all property belonging to the city shall be subject to inspection at any time, and without prior warning, by any supervisor or other persons designated or authorized by the mayor or the board of aldermen. "City property" shall include, but not be limited to, vehicles, desks, files, cabinets, containers, boxes, footlockers, rest rooms, closets, etc. 
(b)  Lockers assigned to particular employees may be inspected in the presence of the employee. 
(c)  Any employee who has knowledge that another employee is involved in the manufacture, use or possession of any of the drugs or other substances stated in this subchapter shall have the duty to inform his or her immediate supervisor, the mayor or a member of the board of aldermen of such knowledge. 
(Ord. No. 15-89, § 4, 1-9-90) 
Sec. 2:95. - Job applicant testing. 
(a)  All persons who apply for employment with the city will be required to undergo a drug test prior to final appointment as part of the pre-employment physical. 
(b)  Positive results of an applicant's test shall be grounds for rejection unless caused by a drug for which a valid prescription was given by a doctor and which was made known to the city prior to testing. 
(c)  The cost of the test may be required to be paid by the applicant prior to testing and will be reimbursed only upon final appointment. 
(d)  Any applicant refusing to be tested shall be rejected. 
(Ord. No. 15-89, § 5, 1-9-90) 
Sec. 2:96. - Current employee testing. 
(a)  Any employee who occupies a position defined in Section 2:92 hereinabove may be required to submit to a drug test at the request of his or her immediate supervisor at random or periodically, and also when an employee is involved in an accident and when the supervisor has a reasonable suspicion that the employee is under the influence of drugs during work hours. "Reasonable suspicion" means an articulable belief based upon specific facts and reasonable inferences drawn from those facts that an employee is under the influence of drugs. Circumstances which constitute a basis for determining "reasonable suspicion" may include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  Direct observation of drug use; 
(2)  A pattern of erratic or abnormal behavior and mood changes; 
(3)  Information provided by a reliable and credible source; 
(4)  An accident; 
(5)  Presence of physical symptoms of drug use, such as slurred speech, glassy eyes and poor coordination or reflexes; 
(6)  Decreased productivity; 
(7)  Unusual absenteeism or tardiness; and 
(8)  Frequent or prolonged absence from the work area. 
(b)  The supervisor shall submit to the mayor a written report stating the facts and circumstances upon which the recommended testing is based, and the mayor or his designated representative shall make the final decision as to whether the test will be conducted. 
(Ord. No. 15-89, § 6, 1-9-90) 
Sec. 2:96.1. - Post-accident/unsafe-practice testing of employees. 
    Employees involved in on-the-job accidents, incidents, or near accidents or who engage in unsafe job-related activities which pose a danger to themselves, others, property, or any City of Eunice operation may be tested for drugs or alcohol when such circumstances involve one or more of the following: 
(a)  A serious or potentially serious accident or near accident in which: 
1.  Safety precautions, rules, procedures, and/or professional ethical guidelines were violated; 
2.  Unusual careless acts were performed; 
3.  Prescribed personal protective equipment was not worn; or 
4.  Where the employee's actions or behavior at the time of the accident or near accident would lead a prudent supervisor to suspect possible impairment. 
(b)  Any accident or loss involving city-owned property, vehicles, equipment, and/or supplies, in which such item(s) is taken out of services or cannot be located/accounted for. 
(c)  Any on-the-job injury which requires medical treatment beyond in-house first-aid. 
(d)  Any accident involving injury to, property damage/loss, or claim by a third-party is involved. 
    Employees involved in, or who observe, a job-related injury, damage, or loss are required to immediately report such incident to their supervisor. It is further required that an employee permit a medical examination and accept medical treatment for a job-related injury when it has been determined by a licensed physician or nurse, or emergency medical professional that an examination or treatment is prudent and proper, in which case the injured employee shall be accompanied to the treatment facility (as applicable) by the safety liaison or person-in-charge at the scene of the accident/injury. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of any other policy or practice to leaves of absence, any employees who tests positive for drugs or alcohol in violation of this policy, following an accident, near accident or related incident, or is found to have flagrantly disregarded or violated established safety procedures, may be disciplined, up to and including discharge, without regard to any accumulated sick or annual leave, or provision for a leave of absence without pay. 
(Ord. No. 04-01(A), 5-8-01) 
Sec. 2:97. - Consequences of positive test result. 
(a)  Applicants. Job applicants will be denied employment with the city if their test results are positive. Applicants who are rejected on the basis of a positive drug test result may not reapply for employment for a period of one year from date of notification of the results. 
(b)  Employees. If an employee's test results are positive, the employee is subject to disciplinary action by the appointing authority up to and including termination of employment. The city may require an employee testing positive to submit to a substance abuse program, psychological counseling or medical treatment, all or any of which would be at the employee's expense. The facts and circumstances of each case are to be considered, and such factors as work history, length of employment, current job performance, etc., may be considered. 
    "Appointing authority" means the municipal officer or the municipal body which has the authority to make appointments and/or employ municipal employees, such as the mayor in cases where he alone can make such appointments and such as the board of aldermen in such instances where such board makes appointments. 
(Ord. No. 15-89, § 7, 1-9-90) 
Sec. 2:98. - Gas department employee testing. 
    In addition to the testing applicable to other employees as stated in this subchapter, the employees of the gas department shall be subject to the drug testing requirements issued by the U.S. Department of Transportation, as outlined in 49 CFR Part 199, and specifically including the requirements of Section 199.11 thereof. The aforesaid provisions of the Code of Federal Regulations are adopted and incorporated herein to be applied in the same manner as if they had been stated in detail. 
(Ord. No. 15-89, § 8, 1-9-90) 
Sec. 2:99. - Refusal to submit to testing. 
    Any employee who refuses to submit to drug testing upon request, as stated hereinabove, may be subject to disciplinary action as determined by the appointing authority. The facts and circumstances of each case are to be considered in determining such action. Disciplinary action may include termination. The appointing authority may also require that an employee testing positive submit to a substance abuse program, psychological counseling, medical treatment or dismissal. 
    "Appointing authority" means the municipal officer or the municipal body which has the authority to make appointments and/or employ municipal employees, such as the mayor in cases where he alone can make such appointments and such as the board of aldermen in such instances where such board makes appointments. 
(Ord. No. 15-89, § 9, 1-9-90) 
Sec. 2:100. - Notice of testing policy. 
    The city shall provide a copy of this subchapter to all employees and job applicants. 
(Ord. No. 15-89, § 10, 1-9-90) 
Sec. 2:101. - Consent to testing. 
    Prior to a drug test being administered, the employee or job applicant will be requested to sign a consent form authorizing the test and permitting the release of the results to the employer or authorized agents, and containing an acknowledgment of notification of the testing policy. 
(Ord. No. 15-89, § 11, 1-9-90) 
Sec. 2:102. - Tampering with test procedure. 
    If an individual being tested is found to have tampered or to be tampering with the testing procedures, attempting to falsify a specimen or to invalidate the chain-of-custody, that individual is immediately disallowed from continuing testing and the individual will be treated as if a positive test result had been obtained. 
(Ord. No. 15-89, § 12, 1-9-90) 
Sec. 2:103. - Right to a hearing. 
    An employee testing positive is entitled to a predisciplinary hearing with the immediate supervisor and the mayor, but only if the employee has made a written request for such a hearing to the supervisor or to the mayor within twenty-four (24) hours of receipt by the employee of the test results. 
(Ord. No. 15-89, § 13, 1-9-90) 
Sec. 2:104. - Laboratory testing requirements. 
    All drug testing of employees and applicants shall be conducted at medical facilities or laboratories selected by the city. To be considered as a testing site, a medical facility or lab must submit in writing a description of the procedures that will be used to maintain test samples. Factors to be considered and used as a guideline by the city in selecting a testing facility include: 
(a)  Testing procedures which ensure privacy to employees and applicants consistent with the prevention of tampering; 
(b)  Methods of analysis which ensure reliable test results, including the use of gas chromatography/mass spectrometry to confirm positive test results; 
(c)  Chain-of-custody procedures which ensure proper identification, labeling and handling of test samples; and 
(d)  Retention and storage procedures which ensure reliable results on confirmatory tests of original samples. 
(Ord. No. 15-89, § 14, 1-9-90) 
Sec. 2:105. - Sample collection and testing procedure. 
    All sample collection and testing for drugs shall be performed in accordance with the following conditions: 
(a)  The collection of samples shall be performed under reasonably sanitary conditions; 
(b)  Samples shall be collected and tested with due regard to the privacy of the individual being tested, and in a manner reasonably calculated to prevent substitutions or interference with the collection or testing of reliable samples; 
(c)  Sample collection shall be documented, and the documentation procedures shall include: 
1.  Labeling of samples so as reasonably to preclude the probability of erroneous identification of test results; and 
2.  An opportunity for the individual to provide notification of any information which he considers relevant to the test, including identification of currently or recently used prescription or nonprescription drugs, or other relevant medical information; 
(d)  Sample collection, storage and transportation to the place of testing shall be performed so as reasonably to preclude the probability of sample contamination or adulteration; and 
(e)  Sample testing shall conform to scientifically accepted analytical methods and procedures. Testing shall include verification or confirmation of any positive test result by gas chromatography/mass spectroscopy, or other comparably reliable analytical method. Test results which do not exclude the possibility of passive inhalation of marijuana may not be used as a basis for disqualification under this subsection. However, test results which indicate that the concentration of total urinary cannabinoids as determined by immunoassay exceeds one hundred (100) nanograms/ml shall exclude the possibility of passive inhalation. 
(Ord. No. 15-89, § 15, 1-9-90) 
Sec. 2:106. - Confidentiality of results. 
    Except for disciplinary hearings provided for by law, such as proceedings before the Civil Service Board, claims for unemployment compensation under R.S. 23:1601(10), or others wherein the results are relevant, the results are to remain confidential to the employer, authorized agents or representatives of employer, the tested employee or applicant, or those authorized by the employee or applicant to receive the results. 
(Ord. No. 15-89, § 16, 1-9-90) 
Chapter 3 - AMUSEMENTS [1] 
Footnotes:

Chapter 4 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] 
Footnotes:
