Cross reference- Sanitary regulations pertaining to keeping of animals and livestock in the city, § 9:40; cruelty to animals prohibited, § 14:64; killing, keeping or selling wild game quadrupeds prohibited, § 14:101; trapping, hunting or shooting of birds or molesting nests within the city prohibited, § 14:102. 

SUBCHAPTER A. - HOUSEHOLD PETS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1199(B), adopted Jan. 11, 2000, amended and reenacted Subch. A, in its entirety, to read as herein set out. The history for §§ 4:1-4:5 and 4:10-4:19, which former Subch. A had been comprised of, can be found in the Code Comparative Table at the back of this Code. 

PART I. - DOGS RUNNING AT LARGE 

Sec. 4:1. - Designation of article. 
    The provisions of this subchapter may be cited as "The Animal Control Ordinance of 1999." 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:2. - Definition of terms. 
    As used in this subchapter, unless the context otherwise indicates: 
    Animal control officer shall mean the person designated by the mayor to represent and act for the City of Eunice, Louisiana, in the impoundment of dogs, controlling of dogs running at large or any other animals, and as otherwise provided and required in this subchapter. 
    Animal shelter shall mean the facility operated by the City of Eunice for the purpose of impounding and caring for animals held under the authority of this subchapter. 
    Dog shall mean any member of the canine family or species, and is intended to mean both male and female. 
    Excessive barking shall mean loud and frequent barking and howling sufficient to disturb the peace and quiet of any person who may reside within reasonable proximity of the place where a dog is kept. 
    Inhumane treatment shall mean any treatment to any animal which deprives the animal of necessary sustenance, including food, water, or protection from weather, or any treatment of any animal such as overloading, overworking, tormenting, abandoning, mutilating or other abnormal treatment as may be determined by the animal control officer. 
    Inoculation means the injection, subcutaneously or otherwise, of animal anti-rabies vaccine, as approved by the Louisiana state board of health. 
    License shall mean a certificate of ownership or tag. 
    Owner shall be intended to mean any person or persons, firm, association or corporation owning, keeping, or harboring an animal, or who acts as its custodian, or who permits an animal to remain on or about his premises. 
    Running at large shall mean off the premises of the owner and not under the control of the owner or other persons authorized by the owner to care for the animal by leash, cord, chain, or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:3. - Running at large by dogs restricted. 
(a)  Generally. No owner or keeper of any dog, licensed or unlicensed, shall permit such dog to run at large on any street, alley or any other place of the city off of the premises of the custodian of the dog except on a leash or under the command or control of a responsible person. 
(b)  On school grounds. No dog shall be allowed to run loose on school grounds at any time. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:4. - Methods of control while off the owner's premises, requirements. 
    When dogs are off the owner's premises, they must at all times be under the direct control of a responsible person, either by means of a secure leash not over six (6) feet in length or by some other equivalent means of positive physical control. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:5. - Enclosure requirements while on owner's premises; inspection. 
    Every owner of a dog shall confine it in secure confinement to prevent its running at large, and such enclosure shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. The animal control officer may examine any premises where inhumane confinement is suspected. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:6. - Confinement of unspayed females. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any unspayed female dog, while such dog is in season, to allow same to remain upon his premises, unless kept in secure confinement, or to be upon the streets or other public or private places of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:7. - Nuisance animal. 
(a)  Any animal which: 
(1)  Molests passersby or passing vehicles; 
(2)  Attacks other animals; 
(3)  Trespasses on school grounds while not under direct control of the responsible owner; 
(4)  Damages private or public property; 
(5)  Barks, whines, or howls in an excessive, continuous or untimely manner; or 
(6)  Causes unsanitary conditions or odors about the premises of the owner through urination or defecation, 
is deemed and declared a public nuisance. Upon the sworn statement of two (2) witnesses, not in the same household but living in the immediate neighborhood, or after investigation, upon the sworn statement of a law enforcement officer of the City of Eunice or the St. Landry Parish Sheriff's Department or the animal control officer or his or her designated agents and after a hearing, the owner of the animal may be penalized as provided for in Section 4:12 of this Code, upon conviction of keeping an animal declared a public nuisance by this section. 
(b)  The animal control officer or any police officer or other law enforcement officer is authorized to enforce complaints arising under this Section, including issuing citations to the owner of the nuisance animal and, after investigation or complaints, seizing the nuisance animal and impounding same at the animal control shelter until the resolution of the charge, unless ordered to release the animal by the city judge. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00; Ord. No. 06-05(B), 6-14-05) 
Sec. 4:8. - Authority of marshal to kill mad or vicious dogs at large. 
    The animal control officer or any police officer is hereby authorized to kill any mad or any vicious dog at large upon the streets or public places within the limits of the city whether such dog is muzzled or not. No officer shall be liable for damages or to prosecution by reason of killing any mad, dangerous or vicious dog. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00; Ord. No. 08-01(A), 9-11-01) 
Sec. 4:9. - Prohibition against the operation of dog hotels, farms or kennels, deemed public nuisance. 
(a)  No person shall operate or conduct dog hotels, or farms or kennels for the keeping of dogs of other persons, either for board or accommodation within the city limits, except as permitted in subsection (d). 
(b)  Running and operating of dog hotels or farms or kennels where dogs of others are kept for pay, board or accommodation, within the city limits, is hereby declared a nuisance, except as permitted in subsection (d). 
(c)  Nothing herein shall prevent a licensed veterinarian who keeps dogs for boarding and treatment to operate within the city limits. 
(d)  The business of kenneling and boarding cats and dogs is permitted within the City of Eunice, subject to the following: 
(1)  The business shall be located and operated only in zones designated "B" of the city zoning ordinance. 
(2)  Only personal pet cats and dogs shall be kenneled or boarded. 
(3)  No animal shall be kenneled or boarded for more than thirty (30) days continuously within any 12-month period. 
(4)  The animals shall be treated and housed in a humane manner and with adequate sanitary physical space for each animal. Animal waste disposal shall be in compliance with all city, parish, state and federal laws and regulations. 
(5)  The owner(s) and operator(s) shall be city licensed and they and their employees shall be properly trained in the kenneling and boarding on personal pet cats and dogs. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00; Ord. No. 06-05(A), 6-14-05; Ord. No. 10-05(A), 10-11-05; Ord. No. 12-15(A), 1-12-16) 
Sec. 4:10. - Disposition of license fees and penalties. 
    The penalties collected under the authority of this subchapter shall be deposited in a special account to be used toward the upkeep and maintenance of the facility for impounding and caring for animals. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:11. - Advisory committee for humane animal shelter. 
(a)  Appointment. The mayor of the City of Eunice, with the approval of the city council, may appoint an advisory committee to serve in an advisory capacity in the operation of a Eunice humane animal shelter. 
(b)  Composition. The committee shall be comprised of three (3) members of the humane society, one member of the city council, and the chief of police or his designated representative. The mayor or his designee may act as an ex officio member. 
(c)  Term of office; duties. The committee shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and shall advise the city on matters relevant to animal control. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:12. - Penalty for violations. 
    Any owner found violating any provision of this subchapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or both, for each such offense. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Secs. 4:13, 4:14. - Reserved. 
PART II. - LICENSE AND REGISTRATION 

Sec. 4:15. - Required. 
    All dogs kept, harbored, or maintained by their owners in the City of Eunice shall be registered if over six (6) months of age with the parish health offices as provided in Section 4:23. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:16. - Exceptions to requirement. 
    The provisions of this part shall not be intended to apply to dogs whose owners are nonresidents temporarily within the city, nor to dogs brought into the city for the purpose of participating in any dog show, nor to seeing eye dogs properly trained to assist blind persons, when such dogs are actually being used by blind persons for the purpose of aiding them in going from place to place. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:17. - Application information. 
    At the time the application is made for the license, the owner shall state, upon printed forms provided for such purpose, his name and address, and the name, breed, color and sex of each dog owned or kept by him. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:18. - Violations. 
(a)  Permitting dog or cat to wear tags of another dog or cat. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog or cat to permit said dog or cat to wear any rabies inoculation tag or license tag not issued to that particular dog or cat, and any owner violating this provision shall be punished by a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) fine. 
(b)  Removal of tags. Whoever removes from any dog or cat a collar bearing a license tax tag or a rabies inoculation tag, or alters or removes any such license tax tag or rabies inoculation tag from a dog or cat properly registered as herein provided, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and the cost of the prosecution or imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
PART III. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 4:19. - Dogs running at large to be impounded. 
    It shall be the duty of the animal control officer or his authorized representative to apprehend any dog found running at large contrary to the provisions of Section 4:2 and to impound such dog at the Eunice Humane Animal Shelter or other suitable place. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:20. - Registering impounded dogs. 
    The animal control officer, upon receiving any dog, shall make a complete registry, entering the breed, color, and sex of such dog and whether licensed; if licensed, he shall enter the name and address of the owner and the number of the license tag. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:21. - Notice to owner and redemption. 
(a)  Licensed dogs. Not later than three (3) days after the impounding of any dog, the animal control officer or his authorized representative shall notify the owner of the dog wearing a valid rabies and license tag. The owner of any dog so impounded may reclaim such dog upon payment of the sum of ten ($10.00) dollars for board daily. The owner shall also pay a thirty-five ($35.00) dollar fine for the first offense of allowing his dog to run at large; a fine of seventy ($70.00) dollars shall be charged for a second and all subsequent offenses. 
(b)  Unlicensed dogs or dogs of unknown owners. As soon as practical after the impounding of any untagged dog or dog whose owner is unknown, the animal control officer or his authorized representative shall publish in the legal journal of the City a notice describing the dog and the place of taking. The owner of any dog so impounded may reclaim such dog upon payment of the sum of ten ($10.00) dollars for board daily. The owner shall also pay a thirty-five ($35.00) dollar fine for the first offense of allowing his dog to run at large; a fine of seventy ($70.00) dollars shall be charged for a second and all subsequent offenses. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00; Ord. No. 11-12(A), 11-13-12) 
Sec. 4:22. - Impoundment period; disposition of unclaimed or unredeemed dogs. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the animal control officer to keep all dogs impounded for a period of at least seven (7) days. 
(b)  If, at the expiration of seven (7) days from the date of notice to the owner or the posting of such notice, such dog shall not have been redeemed, then it may be humanely destroyed or become available for adoption. 
(c)  Any dog so held for a period of seven (7) days and unclaimed may, after proper licensing, be adopted by any citizen for a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) plus the cost of the license. 
(d)  Any dog impounded and suffering from serious injury or disease with probability of recovery remote or having an infectious disease which would endanger the health of people or of other dogs may be humanely destroyed, after reasonable efforts to determine ownership have failed, without waiting for a lapse of seven (7) days; however, no dog under observation for a biting incident or suspected of having rabies shall be destroyed until it has been released from observation by a licensed veterinarian. 
(e)  No unclaimed impounded dog with a known record of biting shall be available for adoption. 
(f)  A dog may be humanely disposed of or made available for adoption under seventy-two (72) hours from the time of impoundment if the owner states that he does not wish to redeem the dog and subsequently releases, in writing, the dog to the custody of the animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:23. - Animals to be registered with parish health officer. 
    It shall be the duty of every person owning or having in his or her possession any cat, dog or other animal of the canine species within the corporate limits of the city over the age of two (2) months to register said animal with the parish health officer of the Parish of St. Landry or his representative. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:24. - Animal inoculations, definitions. 
(a)  As used in this part, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  The term dog and cat, shall mean dogs or cats of either sex unless otherwise specified. 
(2)  The term inoculated shall be understood to mean the administration of an anti-rabies vaccine (one which shall be approved by the parish health board) by or under the direction of a licensed veterinarian. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:25. - Animals to be inoculated for rabies. 
    Before the parish health officer shall register any such cat, dog or other animal of the canine species, he shall be presented by the owner or any person having possession of such animal, a certificate certifying to such inoculation signed by a licensed veterinarian showing that such animal has been inoculated on some date previous thereto, and recommending that said animal be isolated for ninety (90) days after inoculation which shall render said animal immune for the period of registration as herein above provided. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:26. - Health officer to furnish tags to persons registering animals. 
    The parish health officer shall furnish such person owning or having charge or possession of such animal at the time of registration with a metal tag for each animal which shall be attached to said animal's collar, and which shall be numbered and shall indicate the calendar year for which such inoculation has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:27. - Animal inoculations, registration required yearly. 
    All cats and dogs shall be registered and inoculated each year and that each certificate and tag issued by the parish health officer shall be issued from the date of registration to December 31 next following. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:28. - Keeping of cats or dogs that have not been registered, inoculated, prohibited. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person, whether as the owner of or in any other capacity, to harbor, keep or have possession of, within the corporate limits of the city, any cat, dog or other animal of the canine species over the age of two (2) months without having had said animal registered each year and inoculated with an approved and recognized anti-rabies serum as hereinabove prescribed, so that such animal may be immunized from rabies at that time, and without having first paid any necessary registration fee and for such registration and without keeping such metal tag issued him on said animal at all times where same is visible or in the owner's possession. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:29. - Impoundment of cats or dogs not registered, inoculated; redemption by owner; disposition of cats and dogs not claimed. 
    All cats, dogs or any animals of the canine species, found in the corporate limits of the city, over the age of two (2) months at any time after April 1, 1950, which have not been inoculated and registered with the parish health department, shall be seized and impounded by the parish health officer of his authorized agents and held for a period of not to exceed five (5) days, during which time the owner or keeper of such animal may have said animal inoculated and registered as heretofore provided by paying the registration and inoculation fee as herein provided, together with an impounding fee not to exceed three dollars ($3.00). Provided further that if any such animal is not claimed within five (5) days after it is arrested, seized and impounded and the requirements of this part are not complied with, it shall be the duty of the parish health officer or other official, or persons by him appointed to humanly destroy such animal, or sell said animal at public or private sale. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Secs. 4:30-4:36. - Reserved. 
Sec. 4:37. - Impoundment of cats or dogs that have bitten someone; sick cats or dogs, disposition. 
    It shall be the duty of the parish health officer or such other officials or persons appointed by him, to impound or to cause to be impounded any cat or dog or other animal, whether registered or not, that has bitten a human being within the corporate limits of the city or has been bitten by an animal suspected of having rabies, or any infection associated thereto for a period of ten (10) days or longer for observation, and if said animal so impounded shows indications of rabies it shall be the duty of the parish health officer of such other persons as may be designated by him to kill said animal and dispose of same as provided by law for the disposal of other dead animals. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:38. - Right of owner to reclaim cat or dog sold to another. 
    The owner of any cat or dog that has been impounded and sold to another person, shall be entitled to reclaim said animal within thirty (30) days after sale, provided that all fees and costs of maintenance are reimbursed to new owner. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
Sec. 4:39. - Violations, penalties. 
    Any person who shall be found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this part shall be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1199(B), 1-11-00) 
PART IV. - DANGEROUS DOGS 

Sec. 4:40. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply: 
    Animal control agency means the city animal control agency. If the city does not have an animal control agency, it means whatever entity performs animal control functions. 
    Dangerous dog means any dog that, because of its aggressive nature, training or characteristic behavior, presents a risk of serious bodily injury or death to human beings, or would constitute a danger to human life, physical well-being or property if not kept under the direct control of the owner. This definition shall not apply to dogs utilized by law enforcement officers in the performance of their duties. 
    Impounded means taken into the custody by the animal control agency or provider of animal control services to the city where the dangerous or vicious dog is found. 
    Secure enclosure means a fence, kennel, pen, or structure suitable to prevent the entry of children, and which is suitable to confine a dangerous dog in conjunction with other measures which may be taken by the owner of the dog. The enclosure shall be designed in order to prevent the animal from escaping. 
    Serious bodily injury means bodily injury which involves unconsciousness, extreme physical pain or protracted and obvious disfigurement, or protracted loss or impairment of the function of a bodily member, organ, or mental facility, or a substantial risk of death. 
(Ord. No. 12-02(A), 12-10-02) 
Sec. 4:41. - Dangerous dog committee. 
    The dangerous dog committee will be composed of three (3) persons appointed by the mayor, with the consent of board of aldermen, and shall consist of the city animal control officer, chief of police and a veterinarian. This committee is authorized to investigate any complaint regarding a dog and determine whether or not the dog is a dangerous animal. 
(Ord. No. 12-02(A), 12-10-02) 
Sec. 4:42. - Procedure for declaring a dog dangerous, vicious or fierce. 
(a)  The dangerous dog committee, on their own or on the request of any person of the full age of majority, shall notify the owner of the dog that a complaint has been filed and an investigation into whether or not the dog is a dangerous dog is being conducted. 
(b)  During the investigation, the dog shall be impounded and after the investigation, if the dog is found not to be dangerous, it shall be released to the owner without the payment of fees. However, if the dog is found to be dangerous, then the owner must pay all fees in connection with housing the dog. If the owner fails to pay the fees within ten (10) days, the dog may be humanely destroyed at the cost of the owner. 
(c)  Within five (5) days after declaring a dog dangerous, the dangerous dog committee shall notify the owner by certified mail of the dog's designation as a dangerous dog and require the owner to comply with the specific restrictions and conditions to keeping the dog as set forth in this division. The dangerous dog committee shall also notify the mayor of the City of Eunice of its decision. 
(d)  The notice shall inform the dog owner that he may request a hearing before the Eunice City Council as to the committee's decision. 
(e)  The cost for impounding a dog will be five dollars ($5.00) per day. 
(Ord. No. 12-02(A), 12-10-02) 
Sec. 4:43. - Dog that is not a dangerous dog. 
    No dog shall be declared dangerous or vicious if at the hearing authorized by this section evidence presented is sufficient to establish any of the following: 
(1)  That the dog was protecting or defending a person within the immediate vicinity of the dog from an unjustified attack or assault or any "crime of violence" as defined in LRS 14:2(13). 
(2)  That the injury or damage to a domestic animal was sustained while the dog was working as a hunting dog, herding dog, or predator control dog on the property of, or under the control of, its owner, and the damage or injury was to a species or type of domestic animal appropriate to the work of the dog. 
(Ord. No. 12-02(A), 12-10-02) 
Sec. 4:44. - Hearing regarding dangerous dogs. 
    A request for hearing must be made by the owner of the dog and must be in writing. The request for hearing must be delivered to the mayor of the City of Eunice within five (5) days of receipt of the notice that the dog has been declared dangerous. A hearing will be held before the City of Eunice Board of Aldermen at its next regular scheduled meeting or at a special meeting called for this purpose. The date, time and location will be provided to the owner by regular mail or by hand delivery. 
(Ord. No. 12-02(A), 12-10-02) 
Sec. 4:45. - Keeping of dangerous dogs. 
    The keeping of dangerous dogs is subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  Leash. No person having charge, custody, control or possession of a dangerous dog shall allow the dog to exit its secure enclosure unless such dog is securely attached to a leash strong enough to hold the dog not more than four (4) feet in length. No such person shall permit a dangerous dog to be kept on a chain, rope or other type of leash outside a secure enclosure unless a person capable of controlling the dog is in physical control of the leash. 
(2)  Muzzle. It shall be unlawful for any owner, handler, keeper, harborer or controller of a dangerous dog to allow the dog to be outside of its secure enclosure unless it is necessary for the dog to receive veterinary care or exercise. In such cases, the dog shall wear a properly fitted muzzle to prevent it from biting humans or other animals or damaging property. Such muzzle shall not interfere with the dog's breathing or vision. 
(3)  Confinement. Except when leashed and muzzled as provided in this section, a dangerous dog shall be securely confined indoors or confined in a secure enclosure that is suitable to prevent the entry of children and is designed to prevent the dog from escaping. The secure enclosure shall include shelter and protection from the elements and shall provide adequate exercise room, light and ventilation. The secure enclosure shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall meet the following requirements: 
a.  The secure enclosure must have secure sides and a secure top, or all sides must be at least six (6) feet high; 
b.  The secure enclosure must have a bottom permanently attached to the sides or the sides must be embedded not less than one (1) foot into the ground; and 
c.  The secure enclosure must be of such material and closed in such a manner that the dog cannot exit it on its own. 
(4)  Indoor confinement. No dangerous dog shall be kept on a porch, patio or in any part of a house or structure that would allow the dog to exit such building on its own volition. In addition, no such dog shall be kept in a house or structure when the windows or screen doors are the only obstacle preventing the dog from exiting the structure. 
(5)  Signs. All owners, handlers, keepers, harborers or controllers of dangerous dogs shall post signs around the secure enclosure no more than thirty (30) feet apart and at each normal point of ingress and egress. The signs shall bear the words, "Beware of Dog" or "Dangerous Dog" in letters at least three and one-half (31/2) inches high and shall be so placed as to be readily visible to any person approaching the secure enclosure. 
(6)  Liability insurance, surety bond. The owner, handler, keeper, harborer or controller of a dangerous dog shall present to the city animal control officer and the mayor of the City of Eunice proof that he has procured liability insurance or a surety bond in the amount of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) covering any damage or injury that may be caused by such dangerous dog. The policy or bond shall contain a provision requiring that the City of Eunice be notified by the agent issuing the policy or bond at least ten (10) days prior to the cancellation of this insurance policy or bond or as soon thereafter as the issuing agent receives notice that the policy of insurance or bond will be cancelled; however, not later than the date of cancellation, in the event that the insurance policy or bond is cancelled, terminates or expires. The liability insurance or surety bond shall be obtained prior to the insuring of a permit to keep a dangerous dog. The dog owner shall sign a statement attesting that he shall maintain and not voluntarily cancel the liability insurance policy or bond during the twelve-month period for which a permit is sought, unless he ceases to own or keep the dog prior to the expiration date of the permit period. In the event that the owner advises that he cannot obtain insurance or a bond, he shall be ordered to surrender the dog to the city animal control officer for humane destruction. 
(7)  Notification of escape. The owner, handler, keeper, harborer or controller of a dangerous dog shall notify the city animal control officer and the chief of police of the City of Eunice immediately if such dog escapes from its secure enclosure or restrain and is at large. Such immediate notification shall also be required if the dog bites or attacks a person or domestic animal. In the event that the dangerous dog escapes, the owner, handler, keeper, harborer, controller or person that was supposed to be in charge or control of the dog will be personally liable for any damages that may result from the escape, as well as the cost of the capture of the dangerous dog. 
(8)  Failure to comply. It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for any owner, handler, keeper, harborer, controller or person that is supposed to be in charge or control of a dangerous dog registered with the City of Eunice to fail to comply with the requirements and conditions set forth in this division. Any dog found to be in violation of this division shall be subject to immediate humane destruction. In addition, failure to comply the requirements and conditions of this division shall result in the revocation of the dog permit for the keeping of such animal. 
(Ord. No. 12-02(A), 12-10-02) 
Sec. 4:46. - Ownership and change of ownership. 
(a)  The owner, handler, keeper, harborer or controller of a dog determined to be a vicious dog may be prohibited from owning, possession, controlling, or having custody of any dog for a period of up to three (3) years, when it is found, after proceedings conducted pursuant to this section, that ownership or possession of dog by that person would create a significant threat to the health, safety, or welfare of the public. 
(b)  Any owner of a dangerous dog who sells or otherwise transfers ownership, custody or residence of the dog shall, within five (5) days after such change of ownership or residence, provide written notification to the city animal control officer, the mayor of the City of Eunice and the chief of police of the City of Eunice the name, address and telephone number of the new owner. It also shall be the responsibility of the person transferring ownership or custody of the dog to provide written notification of the dog's classification as dangerous to the person receiving the dog. The previous owner shall furnish a copy of such notification to the city animal control officer and the mayor and chief of police of the City of Eunice along with written acknowledgment by the new owner of his receipt of such notification. The city animal control officer or his designee shall notify the City of Eunice of any changes of ownership, custody or residence of the dog within three (3) days after receiving the required information from the previous dog owner. 
(c)  Any person receiving a dog classified as dangerous must obtain the required permit, tag and secure enclosure prior to acquisition of the dog. The new owner, handler, keeper, harborer or controller shall comply fully with the provisions of this division pertaining to obtaining liability insurance or surety bond, payment of fees, and maintenance, control and ownership of a dangerous dog. 
(Ord. No. 12-02(A), 12-10-02) 
Sec. 4:47. - Penalty. 
    Any person who is an owner, handler, keeper, harborer or controller of a dangerous dog and who has been found to be in violation of any of the provisions of this division shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not more than six (6) months, or both. 
(Ord. No. 12-02(A), 12-10-02) 
Secs. 4:48, 4:49. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER B. - LIVESTOCK 
PART I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4:50. - Livestock running at large prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for horses, mules, cattle, sheep, goats and hogs, to roam at large within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice. 
(Ord. No. A-97, § 1, 9-12-50) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. A-97, adopted Sept. 12, 1950, supersedes the following ordinances: Ord. No. 116, adopted Aug. 15, 1919; Ord. No. 158, adopted Oct. 15, 1925; and Ord. No. A-8, adopted July 3, 1928. 
Cross reference- Similar provision, § 9:40. 
Sec. 4:51. - Mayor to appoint officer to impound livestock found at large. 
    The mayor shall appoint a special officer, whose duties shall be to impound any horses, mules, cattle, sheep, goats or hogs found roaming within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice. 
(Ord. No. A-97, § 2, 9-12-50) 
Sec. 4:52. - Penalty for allowing livestock to run at large. 
    For each head of horses, mules, cattle, sheep, goats or hogs, found roaming at large within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, the owner of such animals shall be fined in a sum of three dollars ($3.00) per head for such animals; the fine so assessed to be levied in addition to that for the keeping and feeding of such animals. 
(Ord. No. A-97, § 3, 9-12-50) 
Sec. 4:53. - Fees for impounding livestock running at large. 
    There shall be levied and collected the sum of one dollar ($1.00) per head for each head of horses, mules, cattle, sheep, goats or hogs to be used to defray the cost of keeping and feeding of such impounded animals. Such sum shall be levied for each day that said animals are impounded. 
(Ord. No. A-97, § 4, 9-12-50) 
Sec. 4:54. - Disposition of livestock found at large not claimed by owner; rights of owner. 
    After any animal or animals have been impounded as provided for herein for a period of three (3) full days and the owner has not come forth, claimed the animals and paid the penalties and the costs provided for herein, the pound keeper or special officer appointed by the mayor shall give notice in one issue of the Official Journal of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, that he will within five (5) days dispose of the animal or animals so impounded at public auction to the highest bidder. The owner of the animal or animals may, up to the date of the sale, pay all of the fines, assessments, cost of keep of the animals, and publication, and redeem the animals so impounded. 
(Ord. No. A-97, § 5, 9-12-50) 
Secs. 4:55-4:74. - Reserved. 
PART II. - HOGS 

Sec. 4:75. - Keeping hogs in city prohibited; violations, penalties. 
    It shall be unlawful for hogs to be kept within the city limits of Eunice, Louisiana. 
    Anyone violating this Part shall upon conviction be fined in a sum not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00) or be imprisoned for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days, or both fine and imprisonment at the discretion of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. A-38, §§ 1, 2, 6-4-35) 
Cross reference- For related provisions, see Section 9:40, this Code. 
Secs. 4:76-4:89. - Reserved. 
PART III. - STALLIONS, JACKASSES 

Sec. 4:90 - Keeping horses, mules, goats, sheep or any livestock, including, but not limited to, a cow kept for milling purposes; enclosed areas required, proximity to occupied buildings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any horses, mules, goats, llamas, sheep or any livestock, including, but not limited to, a cow kept for milling purposes, within the city limits without having first obtained a special exception permit from the City of Eunice. After hearing of the application for a special exception permit from the City Council of the City of Eunice, if approved, the special permit shall be subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  The horses, mules, goats, sheep or any approved livestock, must be kept in an enclosed area designated by the permit, which such area shall not be located less than three hundred (300) feet from the nearest neighboring residence, commercial building, park, recreation center or other area of public or private use and at least one hundred fifty (150) feet from the closest private property line. 
(2)  The horses, mules, goats, sheep or an approved livestock shall be housed with an adequate enclosed shelter (not sheet metal or other nontraditional material) located with the permitted area. 
(3)  The special permit must include an approved cleaning and maintenance plan consisted with Section 9:40 as well as sanitary on and off-site drainage plans. 
(4)  The permitted area shall be subject to inspection as set forth in Section 9:40. 
(5)  A special permit may be subject to immediate revocation and removal of the animal(s) for noncompliance, or for any willful or negligent act prohibited or listed in criminal code Section 14:64, whether or not such willful or negligent act is civil or criminal in nature. 
(6)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein, a waiver of the conditions in subsection (1) may be allowed if the adjacent landowners whose homes are less than three hundred (300) feet from the livestock areas and/or whose property lines are less than one hundred fifty (150) feet from the livestock areas consent in writing to same, the chief sanitation officer for public health approves the sanitation and health conditions and no landowners within one (1) mile makes a valid objection during the permit application hearing before the Eunice City Council. This application shall be at no expense. 
(7)  The above requirements shall apply only to tracts of land and/or to persons owning land that do not exceed one hundred (100) acres. 
(Ord. No. A-38, §§ 1, 2, 6-4-35; Ord. No. 05-14(A), 6-10-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 05-14(A), adopted June 10, 2014, amended the catchline of § 4:90 to read as herein set out. Said catchline formerly read "Keeping stallions, jackasses in city prohibited; violations, penalties." 
Cross reference- For related provisions, see Section 9:40, this Code. 
Secs. 4:91-4:99. - Reserved. 
PART IV. - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 

Sec. 4:100. - Staking livestock near sidewalks, streets restricted; violations, penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to tie to a stake, any horses, mules, cattle, sheep, goats, etc., on any vacant lot in the City of Eunice, Louisiana in a manner which shall enable such animal or animals to roam within a distance of less than ten (10) feet from any sidewalk or street of the City. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person or person to tie to a stake, any horse, mule, cattle, sheep, goat, etc. on any vacant lot, street, alley, sidewalk or public park in the City of Eunice, Louisiana, between the hours or period from sunset to sunrise. 
(c)  Whoever shall violate either provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction be fined not in excess of two hundred dollars ($200.00) or imprisoned for a term not in excess of thirty (30) days, or both, at the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. A-22, §§ 1-3, 9-2-30) 
Chapter 5 - BUILDING AND CONSTRUCTION REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire code, § 7:1; minimum housing code, § 11:1. 

SUBCHAPTER A. - BASIC BUILDING REGULATIONS 
PART I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5:1. - State uniform construction code. 
    Definitions: 
    City of Eunice Building Official shall mean that employee or individual appointed by the board of aldermen/council to serve as the building official for the City of Eunice and to serve as building codes enforcement officer for the City of Eunice. 
    Safety Compliance Officer Inspector shall mean city building inspector, building inspector, electrical inspector, plumbing inspector, air conditioning inspector, heating inspector, mechanical-refrigeration inspector or ventilation inspector. 
    Sec. 5:1.1. Adoption of state uniform construction code. Pursuant to LRS 40:1730.21 et seq., the following codes are hereby adopted as the regulations governing the construction of buildings and other structures in the City of Eunice. Unless specified, all standards contained in a referenced code are adopted and included for purposes of this ordinance. Unless referenced by name or letter designation, no appendix or appendices to a code is adopted. 
(a)  The International Building Code, 2006 Edition, as published by the International Code Council, not including Chapter 1, Administration; Chapter 11, Accessibility; Chapter 27, Electrical; and Chapter 29, Plumbing Systems; including any applicable standards referenced therein, but not including any appendices thereto; and 
(b)  The International Existing Building Code, 2006 Edition, as published by the International Code Council, including any applicable standards referenced therein, but not including any appendices thereto and not including Chapter 1, Administration; 
(c)  International Residential Code, 2006 Edition, as published by the International Code Council, including Appendix J, Existing Buildings and Structures, but not including Parts I, Administrative; V, Mechanical; VII, Plumbing; and VIII, Electrical. For the purposes of this part, IRC R301.2.1.1 (Design Criteria) therein shall be amended as follows and shall only apply to the International Residential Code, 2006 Edition: 
(1)  Amendment of R301.2.1.1 (Design Criteria). 
(2)  Item 6 of Guide to Concrete Masonry Residential Construction in High Winds Areas, as published by the American Concrete Institute, shall be added; 
(3)  Item 7, Optional Code plus Fortified for Safer Living, as published by Institute for Business and Home Safety, shall be added; and 
(4)  Item 8, Optional Code plus Blueprint for Safety, as published by Federal Alliance for Safe Homes, shall be added. 
(d)  International Mechanical Code, 2006 Edition, as published by the International Code Council; 
(e)  Louisiana State Plumbing Code (Part XIV (Plumbing) of the State Sanitary Code; 
(f)  International Fuel Gas Code, 2006 Edition, as published by the International Code Council; and 
(g)  National Electrical Code, 2005 Edition, as published by the National Fire Protection Association. 
    Sec. 5:1.2. Permits. It shall be unlawful to construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, demolish, or change the occupancy of any building or structure, or to erect, install, enlarge, alter, repair, remove, convert or replace any electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system, or any natural gas generator, the installation of which is regulated by the technical codes adopted in Section 5:1.1, or to cause any such work to be done, without obtaining a properly issued permit from the City of Eunice Building Official for said work. 
    Sec. 5:1.3. Applications for permit. The permit mandated under section 5:1.1 shall only be issued after the owner or his designee has submitted an application for a construction permit to the City of Eunice Building Official and that official has approved the application for permit. The application shall, at a minimum, include the following information: 
(a)  Name, address, and daytime telephone number of owner; 
(b)  Name, address, and daytime telephone number of any and all contractors; 
(c)  Location of the construction; 
(d)  Description of the construction, including but not limited to square footage, type of construction, intended occupancy, and whether any work will involve following types: 
(1)  Electrical; 
(2)  Concrete or masonry; 
(3)  Plumbing; 
(4)  Structural; and 
(5)  Natural gas, liquefied gas, or other gas fuel. 
(e)  Anticipated completion of construction; and 
(f)  Certification, under penalty of perjury, that the construction will be done in compliance with the applicable codes and standards. 
    Sec. 5:1.4. Certification of compliance. It shall be unlawful for any structure or other construction which is required to be permitted under section 5:1.1 to be occupied, used, or otherwise put in service before the owner or his designee has filed a certificate of completion and compliance on the form provided by the City of Eunice Building Official. The certificate of completion and compliance shall include the following information: 
(a)  Name, address, and daytime telephone number of owner; 
(b)  Name, address, and daytime telephone number of any and all contractors; 
(c)  Location of the construction; 
(d)  Description of the construction, including but not limited to square footage, type of construction, and intended occupancy; 
(e)  Date of construction; and 
(f)  Certification, under penalty of perjury, that the construction was done in compliance with the applicable codes and standards. 
    Sec. 5:1.5. Enforcement of construction code. The Building Official of the City of Eunice may, through the city attorney, seek to enjoin further construction or work which is required to be permitted under this chapter and which construction or work does not have a validly issued permit. Further, the building official may seek to enjoin the occupancy or use of any building or structure which has, without compliance with this chapter, been, in whole or in part, constructed, enlarged, altered, repaired, moved, demolished, or the occupancy changed or for which the electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system has been erected, installed, enlarged, altered, repaired, removed, converted or replaced in any fashion. 
    Sec. 5:1.6. Appointment of city inspector, certification and enforcement authority. 
(a)  The city building inspector shall be the chief building inspector and enforcement official of the City of Eunice. 
(b)  The building official and inspector shall enforce only the international codes and regulations specifically adopted in this chapter, as amended and required under the provisions of LRS 40:1730.2.1. 
(c)  The city inspector and any officials/inspectors shall become certified in accordance with the requirements for certification and education of code enforcement officers, code enforcement inspectors and building officials as required by the Louisiana State Uniform Construction Code Council in accordance with law. 
    Sec. 5:1.7. Penalties. Any person, partnership, or corporation who violates any of the provisions of this chapter or aids or abets in the violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punishable by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), nor less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. 
    Sec. 5:1.8. Authorization for cooperative agreements and engagement of services from certified third party providers. 
(a)  The Mayor of the City of Eunice is hereby authorized to negotiate, establish and execute cooperative agreements with other governmental entities of the State of Louisiana, parishes or municipalities and/or engage certified third party providers to provide services, including but not limited to the review of plans, inspection of premises, enforcement, training or other services as may be deemed necessary or appropriate in his/her sole discretion and with the approval of the city attorney. 
(b)  The Mayor of the City of Eunice is hereby further authorized and empowered to negotiate, fix or accept fees and charges with or established by the State of Louisiana or other parish or municipality and/or to negotiate fees or charges with certified third party providers in his/her sole discretion. 
    Sec. 5:1.9. Imposition of fees and charges. 
(a)  No permit(s) required by the Uniform Code shall be issued until the fee(s) and/or charge(s) for plan review have been paid; plans and specifications have been approved and stamped; and any charge(s) or fee(s) due to other governmental entities or certified third party providers have been paid and evidence thereof has been provided to the office of the inspector. 
(b)  The schedule of charges and fees of governmental entities, including but not limited to the state fire marshal's office, which are included in a cooperative/intergovernmental agreement as authorized herein, the schedule of charges and fees included in the contract(s) with certified third party provider(s) plus all fees and charges for permit(s), inspection(s) and license(s) as may be required under the provisions of this chapter or any other chapter of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Eunice relative to buildings and/or construction are hereby imposed and shall be the minimum amount to be charged plus any additional amounts for cost(s) or charge(s) as may be established and/or required under the authorization of the state uniform code and the authority promulgated hereunder, specifically including the charge(s) required under any other provision, article, section, subsection or clause of this Code which establishes or fixes said charges or fees shall remain in effect and enforceable. 
(Ord. No. 7-74, 4-9-74, §§ 1, 4; Ord. No. 28-80, 9-8-81; Ord. No. 12-06(C), 12-20-06; Ord. No. 04-12(B), 4-10-12; Ord. No. 12-12(B), 12-11-12) 
Comment- Ordinance No. 7-74 superseded a number of earlier ordinances:

Sec. 5:2. - Building code-Definitions; application for permit; fees; requirements for builders of movable buildings.

(1)  Definitions: 
a.  Owner shall mean the person upon whose property any building or structure is erected. 
b.  Builder shall mean the person, firm or corporation erecting the building or under whose supervision the building is erected. 
(2)  Application. The owner shall make application to the building official for a permit to commence work on any building or structure and shall attach to such application a copy of the contract between the builder and owner. In the absence of written contract, the owner shall make a statement of the agreed price of construction. If the owner is also builder, he shall set forth in the application the cost of building complete.

(4)  Fees for buildings to be located outside of city. Moveable builders shall deposit with the building official, when permit is applied for, a permit fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) for those structures to be ultimately located outside of Eunice. 
(5)  Construction requirements for moveable structures. Buildings and structures constructed by moveable home builders shall be constructed so as to conform to the building code required of the city and parish of its ultimate destination. 
(6)  Expiration of demolition permits. All demolition permits shall be issued for a period of no more than sixty (60) days and shall be invalid after that time. If the demolition of the building has not been accomplished within the time of the demolition permit, then an additional permit must be obtained pursuant to the provisions set out above. The granting of an additional permit shall be in the discretion of the city building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 7-74, § 3, 4-9-74; Ord. No. 3-79, §§ 2, 3, 2-27-79; Ord. of 10-31-81; Ord. No. 08-03(C), 8-12-03; Ord. No. 06-04(B), 6-8-04; Ord. No. 09-12(A), 9-11-12) 
Sec. 5:3. - Same-violations, penalties. 
    Section 9.1 (Penalties) of said code shall be changed and/or amended to read as follows: 
    A person who shall violate a provision of this Code or fail to comply therewith or with any of the requirements thereof, or who shall erect, construct, alter or repair, or has erected, constructed, altered or repaired a building or structure, in violation of a detailed statement or plan submitted and approved thereunder, or a permit or certificate issued thereunder, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00), nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), or by imprisonment not exceeding thirty (30) days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 7-74, § 2, 4-9-74) 
Editor's note- The maximum fine in the above section was increased to two hundred dollars ($200.00) to make it consistent with the penalty provision in the ordinance adopting this Code.

(c)  Violation; penalty.

Each day's violation shall constitute a separate violation and be subject to separate penalties. 
(2)  In addition to the aforesaid penalty the City of Eunice may enjoin any action or work determined to be in violation of this Ordinance by a suit for injunction in the Eunice City Court or any other court of competent jurisdiction, and recover costs of said injunction in addition to the penalties.

Sec. 5:5. - Safety inspection. 
    Before any public utilities can be connected to any building in the city, commercial or residential, or before anyone will be allowed to occupy any such building, the safety compliance officer shall conduct a safety inspection to make certain that the building in question is safe for habitation and shall so certify same. A fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be charged for each inspection. Each inspection shall include, but not be limited to the following: 
(a)  Check that the building is structurally sound. 
(b)  Check that there are no visible frayed, or undersized wires and that all visible wiring covers and plates are properly attached. 
(c)  Check that there is no visible loosed or damaged plumbing and that all piping is properly attached under the buildings. 
(d)  Check that visible gas lines are properly piped and connected and that the gas water heaters are properly vented. 
(e)  This mandatory inspection shall not constitute a warranty of any kind or nature by the city to any occupant or owner of said buildings. 
(Ord. No. 0299(B), 3-9-99; Ord. No. 04-11(A), 4-12-11)

Each day's violation shall constitute a separate violation and be subject to separate penalties. 
(2)  In addition to the aforesaid penalty, the City of Eunice may enjoin any action or work determined to be in violation of this section by a suit for injunction in the Eunice City Court or any other court of competent jurisdiction, and recover costs of said injunction in addition to the penalties. 
(Ord. No. 11-07(A), 11-13-07; Ord. No. 12-12(A), 12-11-12; Ord. No. 03-13(A), 2-13-13) 
Secs. 5:7-5:39. - Reserved. 
PART II. - FLOODPRONE AREAS 

Sec. 5:40. - City to participate in national flood insurance program. 
    The board of aldermen hereby: 
(1)  Assures the Federal Insurance Administration that it will enact as necessary, and maintain in force for those areas having flood or mudslide hazards, adequate land use and control measures with effective enforcement provisions consistent with the criteria set forth in Section 1910 of the National Flood Insurance Program Regulations; and 
(2)  Vests the building inspector of the City of Eunice with the responsibility, authority, and means to: 
a.  Delineate or assist the administrator, at his request, in delineating the limits of the areas having special flood (and/or mudslide) hazards on available local maps of sufficient scale to identify the location of building sites. 
b.  Provide such information as the administrator may request concerning present uses and occupancy of the floodplain. 
c.  Cooperate with federal, state, and local agencies and private firms which undertake to study, survey, map, and identify floodplain or mudslide areas, and cooperate with neighboring communities with respect to management of adjoining flood plain and/or mudslide areas in order to prevent aggravation of existing hazards. 
d.  Submit on the anniversary date of the community's initial eligibility an annual report to the administrator on the progress made during the past year within the community in the development and implementation of floodplain (and/or mudslide area) management measures. 
(3)  Appoints the building inspector of the City of Eunice to maintain for public inspection and to furnish upon request a record of elevations (in relation to mean sea level) of the lowest floor (including basement) of all new or substantially improved structures located in the special flood hazard areas. If the lowest floor is below grade on one or more sides, the elevation of the floor immediately above must also be recorded. 
(4)  Agrees to take such other official action as may be reasonably necessary to carry out the objectives of the program. 
(Res. No. 5-1, 5-13-75) 
Editor's note- The Preamble to the foregoing resolution reads as follows: 
"WHEREAS, certain areas of the City of Eunice, Louisiana are subject to periodic flooding from streams causing serious damages to properties within these areas; and 
"WHEREAS, relief is available in the form of Federally subsidized flood insurance as authorized by the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968; and 
"WHEREAS, it is the intent of this board of aldermen to require the recognition and evaluation of flood and/or mudslide hazards in all official actions relating to land use in the floodplain areas having special flood hazards; and 
"WHEREAS, this body has the legal authority to adopt land use and control measures to reduce future flood losses pursuant to Louisiana Revised Statutes 33:4721. 
"NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED ... 
Sec. 5:41. - General regulations for new construction or substantial improvements. 
    The building inspector shall review all building permit applications for new construction or substantial improvements to determine whether proposed building sites will be reasonably safe from flooding. If a proposed building site is in a location that has a flood hazard, any proposed new construction or substantial improvement (including prefabricated and manufactured homes) must: 
(1)  Be designed (or modified) and anchored to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure; 
(2)  Use construction materials and utility equipment that are resistant to flood damage; and 
(3)  Use construction methods and practices that will minimize flood damage. 
(Res. No. 5-1, ¶ 1, 5-13-75; Ord. No. 2-87, 2-10-87) 
Comment- See § 5:50 et seq. for additional requirements. 
Sec. 5:42. - Special requirements-For subdivisions. 
    The planning commission of the City of Eunice shall review subdivision proposals and other proposed new developments to assure that: 
(1)  All such proposals are consistent with the need to minimize flood damage; 
(2)  All public utilities and facilities, such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems are located, elevated and constructed to minimize or eliminate flood damage; and 
(3)  Adequate drainage is provided so as to reduce exposure to flood hazards. 
(Res. No. 5-1, ¶ 2, 5-13-75; Ord. No. 2-87, 2-10-87) 
Sec. 5:43. - Same-For water supply and sewage systems. 
    The city engineer shall require new or replacement water supply systems and/or sanitary sewage systems to be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the systems into floodwaters, and require on-site waste disposal systems to be located so as to avoid impairment of them or contamination from them during flooding. 
(Res. No. 5-1, ¶ 3, 5-13-75; Ord. No. 2-87, 2-10-87) 
Sec. 5:44. - Minimum finish floor elevation. 
(a)  Guide map or plat. There shall be attached to this section a map or plat, or maps or plats, containing limits of flood-prone areas or elevations which will serve as a guide or method for determination elevations of buildings or structures to be erected in the flood-prone area or areas of the city. 
(b)  Method of determining elevation. The builder shall be responsible for establishing the minimum finish floor elevation of such buildings or structures as follows: 
(1)  The relative average national ground elevation at the nearest point of the outside limits of said flood-prone area to the proposed building shall be determined. 
(2)  The average natural ground elevation shall be transferred to the proposed building site. 
(3)  The finished floor elevation of the building shall be constructed a minimum of twelve (12) inches above the transferred average natural ground elevation. 
(c)  Certificates. The builder or contractor must issue a certificate in duplicate, the original of which will be filed with the city building inspector, and the other with the owner or the individual corporation or partnership for whom the structure is being constructed. The certificate shall contain the description of property upon which the building is to be erected, and shall further recite that the structure is to be located in the flood-prone area of the city, and shall also certify that the finish floor elevations are in compliance with the provisions of this section, which governs construction in flood-prone areas in the City of Eunice. The owner shall also execute the certificate confirming the elevation established by the builder, and release the city if elevations are not found to be in compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(d)  Penalty for violation of these provisions. The builder who erects a building not in conformity with the provisions of this section shall be fined in a sum of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) or not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or be incarcerated in the city jail for not more than thirty (30) days, either or both, at the discretion of the city judge. 
(Ord. No. 4-79, §§ 1-4, 2-22-79) 
Editor's note- Section 5:44 is derived from Ord. No. 4-79, §§ 1-4, adopted Feb. 22, 1979. This ordinance, nonamendatory of the Code, has been codified herein at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 5:45-5:49. - Reserved. 
PART III. - FLOOD DAMAGE PREVENTION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 07-10(A), adopted July 16, 2010, amended part III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, part III, §§ 5:50-5:71 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 2-87, adopted February 10, 1987, and Ord. No. 498(B), adopted May 12, 1998. 

Sec. 5:50. - Statutory authorization. 
    The legislature of the State of Louisiana has in statute LRS 38:84 delegated the responsibility of local governmental units to adopt regulations designed to minimize flood losses. Therefore, the Eunice City Council of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, does ordain as follows. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. I(A), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:51. - Findings of fact. 
(a)  The flood hazard areas of Eunice are subject to periodic inundation, which results in loss of life and property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, and extraordinary public expenditures for flood protection and relief, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(b)  These flood losses are created by the cumulative effect of obstructions in floodplains which cause an increase in flood heights and velocities, and by the occupancy of flood hazard areas by uses vulnerable to floods and hazardous to other lands because they are inadequately elevated, flood proofed or otherwise protected from flood damage. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. I(B), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:52. - Statement of purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this ordinance to promote the public health, safety and general welfare and to minimize public and private losses due to flood conditions in specific areas by provisions designed to: 
(1)  Protect human life and health; 
(2)  Minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control projects; 
(3)  Minimize the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with flooding and generally undertaken at the expense of the general public; 
(4)  Minimize prolonged business interruptions; 
(5)  Minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water and gas mains, electric, telephone and sewer lines, streets and bridges located in floodplains; 
(6)  Help maintain a stable tax base by providing for the sound use and development of flood-prone areas in such a manner as to minimize future flood blight areas; and 
(7)  Insure that potential buyers are notified that property is in a flood area. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. I(C), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:53. - Methods of reducing flood losses. 
    In order to accomplish its purposes, this ordinance uses the following methods: 
(1)  Restrict or prohibit uses that are dangerous to health, safety or property in times of flood, or cause excessive increases in flood heights or velocities; 
(2)  Require that uses vulnerable to floods, including facilities which serve such uses, be protected against flood damage at the time of initial construction; 
(3)  Control the alteration of natural floodplains, stream channels, and natural protective barriers, which are involved in the accommodation of flood waters; 
(4)  Control filling, grading, dredging and other development which may increase flood damage; 
(5)  Prevent or regulate the construction of flood barriers which will unnaturally divert flood waters or which may increase flood hazards to other lands. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. I(D), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:54. - Definitions. 
    Unless specifically defined below, words or phrases used in this part shall be interpreted to give them the meaning they have in common usage and to give this part its most reasonable application. 
    Alluvial fan flooding means flooding occurring on the surface of an alluvial fan or similar landform which originates at the apex and is characterized by high-velocity flows; active processes of erosion, sediment transport, and deposition; and unpredictable flow paths. 
    Apex means a point on an alluvial fan or similar landform below which the flow path of the major stream that formed the fan becomes unpredictable and alluvial fan flooding can occur. 
    Appurtenant structure means a structure which is on the same parcel of property as the principal structure to be insured and the use of which is incidental to the use of the principal structure 
    Area of future conditions flood hazard means the land area that would be inundated by the one (1) per cent-annual chance (100 year) flood based on future conditions hydrology. 
    Area of shallow flooding means a designated AO, AH, AR/AO, AR/AH, or VO zone on a community's Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM) with a one (1) per cent or greater annual chance of flooding to an average depth of one (1) to three (3) feet where a clearly defined channel does not exist, where the path of flooding is unpredictable and where velocity flow may be evident. Such flooding is characterized by ponding or sheet flow. 
    Area of special flood hazard is the land in the floodplain within a community subject to a one (1) per cent or greater chance of flooding in any given year. The area may be designated as zone A on the Flood Hazard Boundary Map (FHBM). After detailed rate making has been completed in preparation for publication of the FIRM, zone A usually is refined into zones A, AO, AH, A1-30, AE, A99, AR, AR/A1-30, AR/AE, AR/AO, AR/AH, AR/A, VO, V1-30, VE or V. 
    Base flood means the flood having a one (1) per cent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. 
    Base flood elevation [means] the elevation shown on the Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM) and found in the accompanying Flood Insurance Study (FIS) for zones A, AE, AH, A1-A30, AR, V1-V30, or VE that indicates the water surface elevation resulting from the flood that has a one (1) per cent chance of equaling or exceeding that level in any given year. Also called the "Base flood." 
    Basement means any area of the building having its floor sub-grade (below ground level) on all sides. 
    Breakaway wall means a wall that is not part of the structural support of the building and is intended through its design and construction to collapse under specific lateral loading forces, without causing damage to the elevated portion of the building or supporting foundation system. 
    Critical feature means an integral and readily identifiable part of a flood protection system, without which the flood protection provided by the entire system would be compromised. 
    Development means any man-made change to improved and unimproved real estate, including but not limited to buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavation or drilling operations or storage of equipment or materials. 
    Elevated building means, for insurance purposes, a non-basement building, which has its lowest elevated floor, raised above ground level by foundation walls, shear walls, posts, piers, pilings, or columns. 
    Existing construction means for the purposes of determining rates, structures for which the "start of construction" commenced before the effective date of the FIRM or before January 1, 1975, for FIRMs effective before that date. "Existing construction" may also be referred to as "existing structures." 
    Existing manufactured home park or subdivision means a manufactured home park or subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including, at a minimum, the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads) is completed before the effective date of the floodplain management regulations adopted by a community. 
    Expansion to an existing manufactured home park or subdivision means the preparation of additional sites by the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads). 
    Flood or flooding means a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from: 
(1)  The overflow of inland or tidal waters. 
(2)  The unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. 
    Flood elevation study means an examination, evaluation and determination of flood hazards and, if appropriate, corresponding water surface elevations, or an examination, evaluation and determination of mudslide (i.e., mudflow) and/or flood-related erosion hazards. 
    Flood insurance rate map (FIRM) means an official map of a community, on which the Federal Emergency Management Agency has delineated both the special flood hazard areas and the risk premium zones applicable to the community. 
    Flood insurance study (FIS). See "Flood elevation study." 
    Floodplain or flood-prone area means any land area susceptible to being inundated by water from any source (see definition of flooding). 
    Floodplain management means the operation of an overall program of corrective and preventive measures for reducing flood damage, including but not limited to emergency preparedness plans, flood control works and floodplain management regulations. 
    Floodplain management regulations means zoning ordinances, subdivision regulations, building codes, health regulations, special purpose ordinances (such as a floodplain ordinance, grading ordinance and erosion control ordinance) and other applications of police power. The term describes such state or local regulations, in any combination thereof, which provide standards for the purpose of flood damage prevention and reduction. 
    Flood protection system means those physical structural works for which funds have been authorized, appropriated, and expended and which have been constructed specifically to modify flooding in order to reduce the extent of the area within a community subject to a "special flood hazard" and the extent of the depths of associated flooding. Such a system typically includes hurricane tidal barriers, dams, reservoirs, levees or dikes. These specialized flood modifying works are those constructed in conformance with sound engineering standards. 
    Flood proofing means any combination of structural and non-structural additions, changes, or adjustments to structures which reduce or eliminate flood damage to real estate or improved real property, water and sanitary facilities, structures and their contents. 
    Floodway. See "Regulatory floodway." 
    Functionally dependent use means a use, which cannot perform its intended purpose unless it is located or carried out in close proximity to water. The term includes only docking facilities, port facilities that are necessary for the loading and unloading of cargo or passengers, and ship building and ship repair facilities, but does not include long-term storage or related manufacturing facilities. 
    Highest adjacent grade means the highest natural elevation of the ground surface prior to construction next to the proposed walls of a structure. 
    Historic structure means any structure that is: 
(1)  Listed individually in the National Register of Historic Places (a listing maintained by the Department of Interior) or preliminarily determined by the Secretary of the Interior as meeting the requirements for individual listing on the National Register; 
(2)  Certified or preliminarily determined by the Secretary of the Interior as contributing to the historical significance of a registered historic district or a district preliminarily determined by the Secretary to qualify as a registered historic district; 
(3)  Individually listed on a state inventory of historic places in states with historic preservation programs which have been approved by the Secretary of the Interior; or 
(4)  Individually listed on a local inventory or historic places in communities with historic preservation programs that have been certified either: 
a.  By an approved state program as determined by the Secretary of the Interior; or 
b.  Directly by the Secretary of the Interior in states without approved programs. 
    Levee means a man-made structure, usually an earthen embankment, designed and constructed in accordance with sound engineering practices to contain, control, or divert the flow of water so as to provide protection from temporary flooding. 
    Levee system means a flood protection system which consists of a levee, or levees, and associated structures, such as closure and drainage devices, which are constructed and operated in accordance with sound engineering practices. 
    Lowest floor means the lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area (including basement). An unfinished or flood resistant enclosure, usable solely for parking or vehicles, building access or storage in an area other than a basement area is not considered a building's lowest floor; provided that such enclosure is not built so as to render the structure in violation of the applicable non-elevation design requirement of Section 60.3 of the National Flood Insurance Program regulations. 
    Manufactured home means a structure transportable in one (1) or more sections, which is built on a permanent chassis and is designed for use with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities. The term "manufactured home" does not include a "recreational vehicle". 
    Manufactured home park or subdivision means a parcel (or contiguous parcels) of land divided into two (2) or more manufactured home lots for rent or sale. 
    Mean sea level means, for purposes of the National Flood Insurance Program, the North American Vertical Datum (NAVD) of 1988 or other datum, to which base flood elevations shown on a community's Flood Insurance Rate Map are referenced. 
    New construction means, for the purpose of determining insurance rates, structures for which the "start of construction" commenced on or after the effective date of an initial FIRM or after December 31, 1974, whichever is later, and includes any subsequent improvements to such structures. For floodplain management purposes, "new construction" means structures for which the "start of construction" commenced on or after the effective date of a floodplain management regulation adopted by a community and includes any subsequent improvements to such structures. 
    New manufactured home park or subdivision means a manufactured home park or subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including at a minimum, the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads) is completed on or after the effective date of floodplain management regulations adopted by a community. 
    Recreational vehicle means a vehicle which is (i) built on a single chassis; (ii) four hundred (400) square feet or less when measured at the largest horizontal projections; (iii) designed to be self-propelled or permanently towable by a light duty truck; and (iv) designed primarily not for use as a permanent dwelling but as temporary living quarters for recreational, camping, travel, or seasonal use. 
    Regulatory floodway means the channel of a river or other watercourse and the adjacent land areas that must be reserved in order to discharge the base flood without cumulatively increasing the water surface elevation more than a designated height. 
    Riverine means relating to, formed by, or resembling a river (including tributaries), stream, brook, etc. 
    Special flood hazard area. See "Area of special flood hazard." 
    Start of construction (for other than new construction or substantial improvements under the Coastal Barrier Resources Act (Pub. L. 97-348)), includes substantial improvement and means the date the building permit was issued, provided the actual start of construction, repair, reconstruction, rehabilitation, addition placement, or other improvement was within one hundred eighty (180) days of the permit date. The actual start means either the first placement of permanent construction of a structure on a site, such as the pouring of slab or footings, the installation of piles, the construction of columns, or any work beyond the stage of excavation; or the placement of a manufactured home on a foundation. Permanent construction does not include land preparation, such as clearing, grading and filling; nor does it include the installation of streets and/or walkways; nor does it include excavation for basement, footings, piers or foundations or the erection of temporary forms; nor does it include the installation on the property of accessory buildings, such as garages or sheds not occupied as dwelling units or not part of the main structure. For a substantial improvement, the actual start of construction means the first alteration of any wall, ceiling, floor, or other structural part of a building, whether or not that alteration affects the external dimensions of the building. 
    Structure means, for floodplain management purposes, a walled and roofed building, including a gas or liquid storage tank, that is principally above ground, as well as a manufactured home. 
    Substantial damage means damage of any origin sustained by a structure whereby the cost of restoring the structure to its before damaged condition would equal or exceed fifty (50) per cent of the market value of the structure before the damage occurred.
