    Substantial improvement means any reconstruction, rehabilitation, addition, or other improvement of a structure, the cost of which equals or exceeds fifty (50) per cent of the market value of the structure before "start of construction" of the improvement. This term includes structures which have incurred "substantial damage", regardless of the actual repair work performed. The term does not, however, include either: (1) Any project for improvement of a structure to correct existing violations of state or local health, sanitary, or safety code specifications which have been identified by the local code enforcement official and which are the minimum necessary to assure safe living conditions or (2) Any alteration of a "historic structure", provided that the alteration will not preclude the structure's continued designation as a "historic structure." 
    Variance means a grant of relief by a community from the terms of a floodplain management regulation. (For full requirements see Section 60.6 of the National Flood Insurance Program regulations.) 
    Violation means the failure of a structure or other development to be fully compliant with the community's floodplain management regulations. A structure or other development without the elevation certificate, other certifications, or other evidence of compliance required in Section 60.3(b)(5), (c)(4), (c)(10), (d)(3), (e)(2), (e)(4), or (e)(5) is presumed to be in violation until such time as that documentation is provided. 
    Water surface elevation means the height, in relation to the North American Vertical Datum (NAVD) of 1988 (or other datum, where specified), of floods of various magnitudes and frequencies in the floodplains of coastal or riverine areas. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 2, 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:55. - Lands to which this part applies. 
    This part shall apply to all areas of special flood hazard with the jurisdiction of the City of Eunice, Louisiana; 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 3(A), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:56. - Basis for establishing the areas of special flood hazard. 
    The areas of special flood hazard identified by the Federal Emergency Management Agency in the current scientific and engineering report entitled, "The Flood Insurance Study (FIS) for St. Landry Parish, Louisiana," dated August 5, 2010, with accompanying Flood Insurance Rate Maps (FIRM) dated August 5, 2010, and any revisions thereto are hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this ordinance; along with the scientific and engineering report entitled, "The Flood Insurance study (FIS) for Acadia Parish, Louisiana and Incorporated Area dated November 26, 2010 with accompanying Flood Insurance Rate Maps (FIRM) dated November 26, 2010, and any revisions thereto are hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this part. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 3(B), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:57. - Establishment of development permit. 
    A floodplain development permit shall be required to ensure conformance with the provisions of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 3(C), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:58. - Compliance. 
    No structure or land shall hereafter be located, altered, or have its use changed without full compliance with the terms of this part and other applicable regulations. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 3(D), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:59. - Abrogation and greater restrictions. 
    This part is not intended to repeal, abrogate, or impair any existing easements, covenants, or deed restrictions. However, where this ordinance and another ordinance, easement, covenant, or deed restriction conflict or overlap, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 3(E), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:60. - Interpretation. 
    In the interpretation and application of this part, all provisions shall be: 
(1)  Considered as minimum requirements; 
(2)  Liberally construed in favor of the governing body; and 
(3)  Deemed neither to limit nor repeal any other powers granted under state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 3(F), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:61. - Warning and disclaimer or liability. 
    The degree of flood protection required by this part is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on scientific and engineering considerations. On rare occasions greater floods can and will occur and flood heights may be increased by man-made or natural causes. This part does not imply that land outside the areas of special flood hazards or uses permitted within such areas will be free from flooding or flood damages. This part shall not create liability on the part of the community or any official or employee thereof for any flood damages that result from reliance on this part or any administrative decision lawfully made hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 3(G), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:62. - Designation of the floodplain administrator. 
    The building inspector is hereby appointed the floodplain administrator to administer and implement the provisions of this part and other appropriate sections of 44 CFR (Emergency Management and Assistance - National Flood Insurance Program Regulations) pertaining to floodplain management. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 4(A), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:63. - Duties and responsibilities of the floodplain administrator. 
    Duties and responsibilities of the floodplain administrator shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Maintain and hold open for public inspection all records pertaining to the provisions of this part. 
(2)  Review permit application to determine whether to ensure that the proposed building site project, including the placement of manufactured homes, will be reasonably safe from flooding. 
(3)  Review, approve or deny all applications for development permits required by adoption of this part. 
(4)  Review permits for proposed development to assure that all necessary permits have been obtained from those federal, state or local governmental agencies (including Section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972, 33 U.S.C. 1334) from which prior approval is required. 
(5)  Where interpretation is needed as to the exact location of the boundaries of the areas of special flood hazards (for example, where there appears to be a conflict between a mapped boundary and actual field conditions) the floodplain administrator shall make the necessary interpretation. 
(6)  Notify, in riverine situations, adjacent communities and the state coordinating agency which is the department of transportation and development, prior to any alteration or relocation of a watercourse, and submit evidence of such notification to the Federal Emergency Management Agency. 
(7)  Assure that the flood carrying capacity within the altered or relocated portion of any watercourse is maintained. 
(8)  When base flood elevation data has not been provided in accordance with section 5:56, the floodplain administrator shall obtain, review and reasonably utilize any base flood elevation data and floodway data available from a federal, state or other source, in order to administer the provisions of sections 5:66-5:72. 
(9)  When a regulatory floodway has not been designated, the floodplain administrator must require that no new construction, substantial improvements, or other development (including fill) shall be permitted within zones A1-30 and AE on the community's FIRM, unless it is demonstrated that the cumulative effect of the proposed development, when combined with all other existing and anticipated development, will not increase the water surface elevation of the base flood more than one (1) foot at any point within the community. 
(10)  Under the provisions of 44 CFR Chapter 1, Section 65.12, of the National Flood Insurance Program regulations, a community may approve certain development in zones A1-30, AE, AH, on the community's FIRM which increases the water surface elevation of the base flood by more than one (1) foot, provided that the community first completes all of the provisions required by Section 65.12. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 4(B), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:64. - Permit procedures. 
(a)  Application for a floodplain development permit shall be presented to the floodplain administrator on forms furnished by him/her and may include, but not be limited to, plans in duplicate drawn to scale showing the location, dimensions, and elevation of proposed landscape alterations, existing and proposed structures, including the placement of manufactured homes, and the location of the foregoing in relation to areas of special flood hazard. Additionally, the following information is required: 
(1)  Elevation (in relation to mean sea level), of the lowest floor (including basement) of all new and substantially improved structures; 
(2)  Elevation in relation to mean sea level to which any nonresidential structure shall be flood proofed; 
(3)  A certificate from a registered professional engineer or architect that the nonresidential flood proofed structure shall meet the flood proofing criteria of section 5:67(2); 
(4)  Description of the extent to which any watercourse or natural drainage will be altered or relocated as a result of proposed development; 
(5)  Maintain a record of all such information in accordance with subsection 5:63(1); 
(b)  Approval or denial of a floodplain development permit by the floodplain administrator shall be based on all of the provisions of this part and the following relevant factors: 
(1)  The danger to life and property due to flooding or erosion damage; 
(2)  The susceptibility of the proposed facility and its contents to flood damage and the effect of such damage on the individual owner; 
(3)  The danger that materials may be swept onto other lands to the injury of others; 
(4)  The compatibility of the proposed use with existing and anticipated development; 
(5)  The safety of access to the property in times of flood for ordinary and emergency vehicles; 
(6)  The costs of providing governmental services during and after flood conditions including maintenance and repair of streets and bridges, and public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems; 
(7)  The expected heights, velocity, duration, rate of rise and sediment transport of the floodwaters and the effects of wave action, if applicable, expected at the site; 
(8)  The necessity to the facility of a waterfront location, where applicable; 
(9)  The availability of alternative locations, not subject to flooding or erosion damage, for the proposed use. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 4(C), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:65. - Variance procedures. 
(a)  The appeal board, as established by the community, shall hear and render judgment on requests for variances from the requirements of this part. 
(b)  The appeal board shall hear and render judgment on an appeal only when it is alleged there is an error in any requirement, decision, or determination made by the floodplain administrator in the enforcement or administration of this part. 
(c)  Any person or persons aggrieved by the decision of the appeal board may appeal such decision in the courts of competent jurisdiction. 
(d)  The floodplain administrator shall maintain a record of all actions involving an appeal and shall report variances to the Federal Emergency Management Agency upon request. 
(e)  Variances may be issued for the reconstruction, rehabilitation or restoration of structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places or the State Inventory of Historic Places, without regard to the procedures set forth in the remainder of this part. 
(f)  Variances may be issued for new construction and substantial improvements to be erected on a lot of one-half (1/2) acre or less in size contiguous to and surrounded by lots with existing structures constructed below the base flood level, providing the relevant factors in subsection 5:64(b) of this part have been fully considered. As the lot size increases beyond the (1/2) acre, the technical justification required for issuing the variance increases. 
(g)  Upon consideration of the factors noted above and the intent of this part, the appeal board may attach such conditions to the granting of variances as it deems necessary to further the purpose and objectives of this part (section 5:52). 
(h)  Variances shall not be issued within any designated floodway if any increase in flood levels during the base flood discharge would result. 
(i)  Variances may be issued for the repair or rehabilitation of historic structures upon a determination that the proposed repair or rehabilitation will not preclude the structure's continued designation as a historic structure and the variance is the minimum necessary to preserve the historic character and design of the structure. 
(j)  Prerequisites for granting variances: 
(1)  Variances shall only be issued upon a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary, considering the flood hazard, to afford relief. 
(2)  Variances shall only be issued upon: 
a.  Showing a good and sufficient cause; 
b.  A determination that failure to grant the variance would result in exceptional hardship to the applicant; and 
c.  A determination that the granting of a variance will not result in increased flood heights, additional threats to public safety, extraordinary public expense, create nuisances, cause fraud on or victimization of the public, or conflict with existing local laws or ordinances. 
(3)  Any application to which a variance is granted shall be given written notice that the structure will be permitted to be built with the lowest floor elevation below the base flood elevation, and that the cost of flood insurance will be commensurate with the increased risk resulting from the reduced lowest floor elevation. 
(k)  Variances may be issued by a community for new construction and substantial improvements and for other development necessary for the conduct of a functionally dependent use provided that: 
(1)  The criteria outlined in subsections (a)-(i) are met; and 
(2)  The structure or other development is protected by methods that minimize flood damages during the base flood and create no additional threats to public safety. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 4(D), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:66. - General standards. 
    In all areas of special flood hazards the following provisions are required for all new construction and substantial improvements: 
(1)  All new construction or substantial improvements shall be designed (or modified) and adequately anchored to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure resulting from hydrodynamic and hydrostatic loads, including the effects of buoyancy; 
(2)  All new construction or substantial improvements shall be constructed by methods and practices that minimize flood damage; 
(3)  All new construction or substantial improvements shall be constructed with materials resistant to flood damage; 
(4)  All new construction or substantial improvements shall be constructed with electrical, heating, ventilation, plumbing, and air conditioning equipment and other service facilities that are designed and/or located so as to prevent water from entering or accumulating within the components during conditions of flooding; 
(5)  All new and replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of flood waters into the system; 
(6)  New and replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of flood waters into the system and discharge from the systems into flood waters; and 
(7)  On-site waste disposal systems shall be located to avoid impairment to them or contamination from them during flooding. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 5(A), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:67. - Specific standards. 
    In all areas of special flood hazards where base flood elevation data has been provided as set forth in (i) section 5:56, (ii) section 5:63(8), or (iii) section 5:68(c), the following provisions are required: 
(1)  Residential construction. New construction and substantial improvement of any residential structure shall have the lowest floor (including basement), elevated to or above the base flood elevation. A registered professional engineer, architect, or land surveyor shall submit a certification to the floodplain administrator that the standard of this subsection as proposed in section 5:64(a)(1), is satisfied. 
(2)  Nonresidential construction. New construction and substantial improvements of any commercial, industrial or other nonresidential structure shall either have the lowest floor (including basement) elevated to or above the base flood level or together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, be designed so that below the base flood level the structure is watertight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water and with structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and effects of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall develop and/or review structural design, specifications, and plans for the construction, and shall certify that the design and methods of construction are in accordance with accepted standards of practice as outlined in this subsection. A record of such certification which includes the specific elevation (in relation to mean sea level) to which such structures are flood proofed shall be maintained by the floodplain administrator. 
(3)  Enclosures. New construction and substantial improvements, with fully enclosed areas below the lowest floor that are usable solely for parking of vehicles, building access or storage in an area other than a basement and which are subject to flooding shall be designed to automatically equalize hydrostatic flood forces on exterior walls by allowing for the entry and exit of floodwaters. Designs for meeting this requirement must either be certified by a registered professional engineer or architect or meet or exceed the following minimum criteria: 
(a)  A minimum of two (2) openings on separate walls having a total net area of not less than one (1) square inch for every square foot of enclosed area subject to flooding shall be provided. 
(b)  The bottom of all openings shall be no higher than one (1) foot above grade. 
(c)  Openings may be equipped with screens, louvers, valves, or other coverings or devices provided that they permit the automatic entry and exit of floodwaters. 
(4)  Manufactured homes. 
a.  Require that all manufactured homes to be placed within zone A on a community's FHBM or FIRM shall be installed using methods and practices which minimize flood damage. For the purposes of this requirement, manufactured homes must be elevated and anchored to resist flotation, collapse, or lateral movement. Methods of anchoring may include, but are not limited to, use of over-the-top or frame ties to ground anchors. This requirement is in addition to applicable state and local anchoring requirements for resisting wind forces. 
b.  Require that manufactured homes that are placed or substantially improved within zones A1-30, AH, and AE on the community's FIRM on sites (i) outside of a manufactured home park or subdivision, (ii) in a new manufactured home park or subdivision, (iii) in an expansion to an existing manufactured home park or subdivision, or (iv) in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision on which a manufactured home has incurred "substantial damage" as a result of a flood, be elevated on a permanent foundation such that the bottom of the longitudinal structural I beam of the manufactured home is elevated to or above the base flood elevation and be securely anchored to an adequately anchored foundation system to resist flotation, collapse, and lateral movement. 
c.  Require that manufactured homes be placed or substantially improved on sites in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision with zones A1-30, AH and AE on the community's FIRM that are not subject to the provisions of subsection (4) of this section be elevated so that either: 
1.  The bottom of the longitudinal structural I beam of the manufactured home is at or above the base flood elevation; or 
2.  The manufactured home chassis is supported by reinforced piers or other foundation elements of at least equivalent strength that are no less than thirty-six (36) inches in height above grade and be securely anchored to an adequately anchored foundation system to resist flotation, collapse, and lateral movement. 
(5)  Recreational vehicles. Require that recreational vehicles placed on sites within zones A1-30, AH, and AE on the community's FIRM either (i) be on the site for fewer than one hundred eighty (180) consecutive days, or (ii) be fully licensed and ready for highway use, or (iii) meet the permit requirements of subsection 5:64(a), and the elevation and anchoring requirements for "manufactured homes" in subsection (4) of this section. A recreational vehicle is ready for highway use if it is on its wheels or jacking system, is attached to the site only by quick disconnect type utilities and security devices, and has no permanently attached additions. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 5(B), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:68. - Standards for subdivision proposals. 
(a)  All subdivision proposals including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall be consistent with sections 5:51, 5:52 and 5:53 of this part. 
(b)  All proposals for the development of subdivisions including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall meet floodplain development permit requirements of section 5:57; section 5:64; and the provisions of section 5:66-5:72 of this part. 
(c)  Base flood elevation data shall be generated for subdivision proposals and other proposed development including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions which is greater than fifty (50) lots or five (5) acres, whichever is lesser, if not otherwise provided pursuant to 5:56 or section 5:63(8) of this part. 
(d)  All subdivision proposals including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall have adequate drainage provided to reduce exposure to flood hazards. 
(e)  All subdivision proposals including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall have public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems located and constructed to minimize or eliminate flood damage. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 5(C), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:69. - Standards for areas of shallow flooding (AO/AH zones). 
    Located within the areas of special flood hazard established in section 5:56, are areas designated as shallow flooding. These areas have special flood hazards associated with flood depths of one (1) to three (3) feet where a clearly defined channel does not exist, where the path of flooding is unpredictable, and where velocity flow may be evident. Such flooding is characterized by ponding or sheet flow; therefore, the following provisions apply: 
(1)  All new construction and substantial improvements of residential structures have the lowest floor (including basement) elevated to or above the base flood elevation or the highest adjacent grade at least as high as the depth number specified in feet on the community's FIRM (at least two (2) feet if no depth number is specified). 
(2)  All new construction and substantial improvements of non-residential structures; 
(a)  have the lowest floor (including basement) elevated to or above the base flood elevation or the highest adjacent grade at least as high as the depth number specified in feet on the community's FIRM (at least two (2) feet if no depth number is specified), or 
(b)  together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities be designed so that below the base specified flood depth in an AO zone, or below the base flood elevation in an AH zone, level the structure is watertight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water and with structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads of effects of buoyancy. 
(3)  A registered professional engineer or architect shall submit a certification to the floodplain administrator that the standards of this section, as proposed in section 5:64 are satisfied. 
(4)  Require within zones AH or AO adequate drainage paths around structures on slopes, to guide flood waters around and away from proposed structures. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 5(D), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:70. - Floodways. 
    Located within areas of special flood hazard established in section 5:56, are areas designated as floodways. Since the floodway is an extremely hazardous area due to the velocity of flood waters which carry debris, potential projectiles and erosion potential, the following provisions shall apply: 
(1)  Encroachments are prohibited, including fill, new construction, substantial improvements and other development within the adopted regulatory floodway unless it has been demonstrated through hydrologic and hydraulic analyses performed in accordance with standard engineering practice that the proposed encroachment would not result in any increase in flood levels within the community during the occurrence of the base flood discharge. 
(2)  If subsection (1) above is satisfied, all new construction and substantial improvements shall comply with all applicable flood hazard reduction provisions of 5:66-5:72. 
(3)  Under the provisions of 44 CFR Chapter 1, Section 65.12, of the National Flood Insurance Program Regulation, a community may permit encroachments within the adopted regulatory floodway that would result in an increase in base flood elevations, provided that the community first completes all of the provisions required by Section 65.12. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 5(E), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:71. - Severability. 
    If any section, clause, sentence, or phrase of this part is held to be invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, then said holding shall in no way affect the validity of the remaining portions of this part. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 5(F), 10-12-10) 
Sec. 5:72. - Penalties for noncompliance. 
    No structure or land shall hereafter be constructed, located, extended, converted, or altered without full compliance with the terms of this part and other applicable regulations. Violation of the provisions of this part by failure to comply with any of its requirements (including violations of conditions and safeguards established in connection with conditions) shall constitute a misdemeanor. Any person who violates this part or fails to comply with any of its requirements shall upon conviction thereof be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not more than six (6) months, or both, for each violation. Each day the violation continues shall be deemed a new violation. In addition, the violator shall pay all costs and expenses involved in the case. Nothing herein contained shall prevent the City of Eunice from taking such other lawful action as is necessary to prevent or remedy any violation. 
(Ord. No. 07-10(A), 7-16-10; Ord. No. 10-10(C), Art. 5(B), 10-12-10) 
Secs. 5:73-5:99. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER B. - ELECTRICAL REGULATIONS 

Sec. 5:100. - Minimum electrical regulations established; objectives, exceptions. 
(a)  The object of this subchapter is to reduce the personal hazard and the fire hazard from electrical causes. To accomplish this, the requirements set forth herein are intended to provide a minimum standard for electrical installation in the City of Eunice. 
(b)  The provisions of this subchapter shall not apply to installations in railway cars, automotive equipment, electrical railway companies, to installations used by electrical public utility, telephone, telegraph companies, radio transmission stations or in distribution of electricity or for the operation of signals or the transmission of intelligence, in the exercise of their function as such agencies and located outdoors and in buildings used exclusively for that purpose; provided, however, that these regulations, except as to permits, shall apply to all such wiring and equipment installed in or on the consumer's premises. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 1, 7-14-70) 
Comment- This ordinance supersedes Ord. No. A-139, adopted March 8, 1955; Ord. No. A-113, adopted April 8, 1952 and Ord. No. A-92, adopted July 11, 1950. 
Sec. 5:101. - Applications for inspections and permits; form of application; exception; inspections; certificates of inspection; furnishing power before approval of electrical inspector prohibited; termination of electrical service in hazardous situations; installation of permanent meters. 
(a)  Before proceeding with the installation, alteration of or the addition to any electrical wiring equipment within or on any building, structure or premises, publicly or privately owned in the City of Eunice, the electrician, electrical sign manufacturer or specialty electrician in charge of such proposed work shall first file with the electrical inspector an application requesting inspection and secure a permit therefor; except as provided for in Section 5:100 and except that no permit shall be specified in the following four (4) paragraphs: 
(1)  The replacement of lamps or the connection of portable electrical equipment to suitable permanently installed receptacles. 
(2)  The installation, alteration or repair of electrical equipment for the operation of signals or for the transmission of intelligence by wire by a communication agency. 
(3)  The installation, alteration or repair of electrical equipment installed by or for an electrical supply agency for the use of such agency in the generation, transmission or distribution of electricity. 
(4)  Specialty electricians who maintain and make minor repairs to elevators, escalators, X-ray equipment or other items that require special factory training. 
(b)  Application for such inspection and permit describing the work to be done shall be made in writing to the city by the electrician or specialty electrician giving the exact street number of the premises on which work is to be done, date inspection is desired, name of the owner or occupant, name of the electrician doing work and class of wiring. 
(c)  On all applications where plans and specifications require installation above the minimum standards as set forth in this subchapter, the plans and specifications for such work shall be accompanied with applications for inspection. No deviation may be made from installation described in such plans and specifications without the written approval of the owner or architect. 
(d)  All applications for inspection shall be accompanied by the inspection fees as follows: 
(1)  Charge, per circuit ..... $4.00 
(2)  Meter base charge, each ..... 5.00 
(3)  Service change-over charge, each ..... 5.00 
(4)  Temporary service pole for construction charge, each ..... 5.00 
(5)  Service pole for mobile home service charge, each ..... 7.00 
For each reinspection additional fee must be charged. 
(e)  Master electricians shall at all times keep the electrical inspector notified of the progress of their work and shall request inspections as the work progresses. Upon receipt of an application requesting inspection, the electrical inspector shall inspect or cause to be inspected said work within forty-eight (48) hours after receiving application, Sundays and holidays not included in this time. After inspecting the electrical wiring covered by any application, the electrical inspector shall leave a tag, which tag shall state that the work has been inspected and approved or that it is not approved and must be held open for correction, and if the wiring is to be held open for inspection no person shall lath, seal or in any manner conceal any wiring until they are informed that such wiring has been approved by the electrical inspector. 
(f)  Master electricians shall have all electrical work installed by them inspected before such work is covered or concealed. All cabinet and panel board covers or trims shall be left off for final inspection, any fitting or cover that conceals any wiring which may hinder the proper inspection of electrical work shall be removed by the master electrician at the request of the electrical inspector. 
    Master electricians making extensions or additions to existing electrical systems shall before proceeding with such work ascertain from the electrical inspector whether any of the old work must be changed or must be brought up to the requirements of this subchapter. 
(g)  Upon completion and receipt of final inspection papers covering electrical work the electrical inspector shall make final inspection, and if such work is found to comply with this subchapter, a certificate of inspection shall be issued, stating that the work has been done according to the provisions of this subchapter and the rules governing the respective class to which it belongs. 
(h)  This certificate shall not relieve the master electrician of his responsibility for any defective work that may have been concealed or escaped the inspector. 
(i)  It shall be unlawful for any public service, person, firm or corporation operating in the City of Eunice to furnish current to any new building, tent, structure or outdoor wiring of any kind, nature or description without first obtaining a clearance from the electrical inspector, stating that such wiring is approved and a permit has been issued for the use of current. Whenever any service is discontinued to any building structure for any cause whatever (excepting nonpayment of bill), a clearance will be necessary before each building or structure can be reconnected. Any time a building is vacated, the electrical inspector must make certain that there has not been any unauthorized additions made to wiring of such building that might create a fire hazard or that the wiring has not become in such a condition as to be hazardous. 
(j)  Whenever any electrical conductor or electrical material in or on any building, or any electrical conductor on any pole line, or any conductor underground becomes or is in a condition that is dangerous to life or property, the electrical inspector is hereby empowered to condemn, disconnect and cause the owner of such conductor or material to immediately correct same or have it removed. 
(k)  Immediately upon completion of each and every job, the master electrician shall request a final inspection of his work. No permanent meter installation will be authorized until such final inspection has been made. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 16, 7-14-70; Ord. No. 27-80, 9-8-81; Ord. No. 02-11(B), 2-8-11) 
Sec. 5:102. - Installation of electrical work without permit prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, whether acting as principal, servant, agent or employee, to do or cause or permit to be done any electrical work for which a permit is required within the city without securing such permit from the electrical inspector of the city authorizing him to do so. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 17, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:103. - Issuance of electrical permits, restrictions; exceptions for homeowners; working permits for nonlicensed contractors; applications for permits, issuance. 
(a)  No permit shall be issued to any person, firm or corporation to do or cause to be done any construction or work regulated by this subchapter except to a person, firm or corporation holding a valid, unexpired and unrevoked certificate of competency, except as herein excepted. 
(b)  Any permit required by this subchapter may be issued to any person to do any construction or work regulated by this subchapter in a single-family dwelling used exclusively for living purpose, including the usual accessory buildings and quarters in connection with such buildings, in the event that any such person is the bona fide owner of any such dwelling and accessory building and quarters, and the same are occupied by said owner; provided, that said owner shall personally purchase all material and shall personally perform all labor in connection therewith; and provided, that said owner can answer questions and draw such sketches as required by the electrical inspector to show that he has sufficient knowledge and skill to install the electrical work in a safe manner and according to the rules and regulations of this subchapter. 
(c)  Any electrical contractor not licensed in the City of Eunice must hold a state contractor's license and shall obtain a working permit of $100.00 for each job in the city. 
(d)  Any person legally entitled to apply for and receive a permit shall make such application at the office of the electrical inspector on forms provided for that purpose. He shall give a description of the character of the work proposed, including lot number, block number, name of addition or subdivision, street and house number of the premises where work is to be done, name of owner, kind of building, number of stories, and list of electrical fixtures, etc., to be installed, and shall have plans and specifications of the work to be done, where required by the electrical inspector. 
(e)  If the electrical inspector determines that the plans, specifications, drawings, description or information furnished by the applicant are in compliance with this subchapter and the rules and regulations of the State of Louisiana pertaining to electrician's work applicable in the city, he shall issue the permit applied for upon receipt of payment of the required fee as hereinafter fixed. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 18, 7-14-70; Ord. No. 28-80, 9-8-81) 
Sec. 5:104. - Appointment of electrical inspector, compensation. 
(a)  An electrical inspector shall be appointed by the mayor by and with the approval of the board of aldermen of the city. 
(b)  The salary to be paid to the electrical inspector shall be determined by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 2, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:105. - Duties of the electrical inspector; limitations on inspectors, interference with inspector prohibited; installations to be in accordance with requirements of National Electrical Code. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to enforce the provisions of this subchapter. He shall make inspections of electrical installations as provided for in this subchapter. 
(b)  He shall maintain public office hours, receive applications for permits, review plans, and specifications for work to be performed. He shall grant permission for permits to be issued to qualified persons. He shall keep complete records of all permits issued, inspections and re-inspections, defects found and corrections ordered, notices issued, and work performed and maintain an official register of persons, firms or corporations qualified in accordance with the provisions of this subchapter and lawfully licensed to engage in the business of electrical work in the City of Eunice, Louisiana. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the electrical inspector or for any of his assistants to engage in the business of the sale, installation, or maintenance of electrical equipment, directly, but they may have a financial interest in a concern engaged in such business in the City of Eunice while holding such office. 
(d)  The electrical inspector shall have the right during reasonable hours to enter any building or premises in the discharge of his official duties or for the purpose of making any inspections, re-inspections, or test of the electrical equipment contained therein or its installation. When any electrical equipment is found to be dangerous to persons or to property, because it is defective or defectively installed, the person, firm or corporation responsible for the electrical equipment shall be notified in writing and shall make any changes or repairs required in the judgment of the electrical inspector, to place such equipment in safe condition, and if such work is not completed within fifteen (15) days, or any longer period that may be specified by the electrical inspector in said notice, the electrical inspector shall have authority to disconnect or order the discontinuance of electrical service to said electrical equipment. In cases of emergency where necessary for safety of persons, or of property, or where electrical equipment may interfere with the work of the fire department, the electrical inspector shall have the authority to immediately disconnect or to cause the disconnection of any electrical equipment. 
(e)  He may remove or compel the removal of any conductors which are enclosed in conduit or otherwise inaccessible for complete inspection. When said conductors or appliances are not in accordance with requirements of this subchapter, or found to be unsafe to life or property, he shall have the right to condemn such conductors or appliances as hereinafter provided. 
(f)  If, in the judgment of the inspector, work is being done in a manner prohibited by this subchapter which will foreseeably endanger public citizenry or public property or the property of other owners, then he shall have the power to compel the suspension of any electrical work being performed by issuing a cease and desist citation which, if not complied with, shall be heard by the Eunice City Court on an instanta basis within seventy-two hours of the issuance of the citation. Any work performed after notice of the citation is served upon a contractor and prior to a hearing before the Eunice City Court shall be a violation of this subchapter. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to hinder or interfere with the electrical inspector in the discharge of his duties under this subchapter. 
(h)  Prior to issuance of an electrical permit, the electrical inspector shall require from the applicant a copy of proposed wiring diagram including a riser diagram and electrical service requirements for all commercial and industrial structures. Residential structures less than forty thousand dollars ($40,000.00) evaluation are exempt from this requirement. The electrical inspector shall review such plans to determine that they meet the National Electrical Code, 1965 Edition, together with its requirements, amendments and additions. He shall retain on file for a period of five (5) years a copy of all approved diagrams. Corrections of diagrams from architects, electrical engineers, electrical contractors, or agents of the owner by a signed addendum will be accepted. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 2, 7-14-70; Ord. No. 09-04(B), 9-14-04) 
Secs. 5:106-5:149. - Reserved. 
Sec. 5:150. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 03-11(A), adopted Mar. 9, 2011, repealed § 5:150, in its entirety. Former § 5:150 pertained to city electrical board established; membership and appointment. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 5:151. - Duties of electrical board. 
(a)  The electrical board shall have and is hereby given full power and authority to prepare and promulgate such rules as may be deemed necessary to carry out the provisions herein, provided the same are not inconsistent with the provisions of this subchapter. The board shall establish standards and procedures for the examinations and qualifications for licensing of electricians, specialty electricians and electrical sign manufacturers. It shall also issue or cause to be issued an appropriate certificate to each person, firm or corporation who meets the qualifications and successfully passes the examination given by the board. The board shall act in an advisory capacity pertaining to all work within the jurisdiction of this subchapter. 
(b)  The board shall review any interpretation or ruling relative to this subchapter by the electrical inspector when requested to do so by any person, firm or corporation or the electrical inspection department. Any decisions or rulings rendered by the electrical board shall be final and conclusive unless within thirty (30) days from the date thereof, the aggrieved party shall seek relief therefrom any court of competent jurisdiction as provided by the laws of the State of Louisiana. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 5, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:152. - Authority of electrical board. 
    The board shall, subject to approval of board of aldermen, have the power to revoke or suspend a license or certificate of any electrician, and for firms or corporations to whom said certificates or licenses are issued, including electrical sign manufacturers, who are found guilty of a violation as set forth in this subchapter. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 6, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:153. - Hearings required before electrical certificates can be suspended or revoked. 
(a)  Before a certificate may be revoked or suspended, the licensee shall have notice in writing, enumerating the charge against him and be entitled to a hearing by the electrical board not sooner than five (5) days from receipt of notice. The licensee shall be given an opportunity to present testimony, oral or written and shall have the right of cross examination. All testimony shall be given under oath. The electrical board shall have the power to administer oaths, issue subpoenas and compel the attendance of witnesses. The decision of the electrical board shall be based upon the evidence produced at the hearing and made part of the record thereof. 
(b)  The board may suspend or revoke any certificate of registration for refusal to comply with the recommendations of the Electrical Inspector and violations of this subchapter. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 7, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:154. - Authority of board to grant variations and modifications to electrical code. 
(a)  The board may vary the application of any provision of the National Electrical Code together with its amendments, modifications and additions. In any particular case, when in its opinion, the enforcement thereof would be manifestly unjust, and would be contrary to the spirit and purpose of this subchapter or public interest or when in its opinion, the interpretation or decision of the electrical inspector should be modified, reversed or disallowed. 
(b)  A decision of the electrical board to vary the application of any provision of the electrical code or to modify, reverse or disallow an interpretation or order of the electrical inspector shall specify in writing, in what manner such variations, modifications or decisions are made, the conditions upon which it is made and the reasons therefor. 
(c)  The electrical board shall in every case render an opinion and/or decision without unreasonable or unnecessary delay. 
(d)  Varying the applications of any provisions of the electrical code, or in modifying, reversing or disallowing the interpretation or order of the electrical inspector or director, shall require affirmative votes of the majority present, but not less than three (3) affirmative votes shall be required. No board member shall act in a decision in which he has a personal or direct interest. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 8, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:155. - Qualifications of members of the electrical board; election of chairman, vice-chairman, secretary. 
(a)  It shall be a requirement that each member of the electrical board be a registered voter of the City of Eunice. The appointments shall be for terms as follows: Of the members first appointed, two (2) shall be appointed for a term of one year; two (2) shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years; and one shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years; and thereafter they shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years. Vacancies shall be filled for an unexpired term in the manner in which the original appointments are required to be made. 
(b)  The board will elect a chairman and vice-chairman and secretary from its membership to serve for a period of twelve (12) consecutive months and who will be eligible for re-election upon expiration of their terms as chairman, vice-chairman or secretary. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 9, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:156. - Regular meetings of electrical board. 
    The electrical board shall hold its regular meetings on the second Monday prior to regularly scheduled council meetings of January, April, July and October of each year for the purpose of performing its duties. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 10, 7-14-70; Ord. of 5-13-82) 
Sec. 5:157. - Special meetings of electrical board. 
    The mayor or his authorized representative may call a special meeting of the electrical board. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 11, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:158. - Quorum of the electrical board. 
    Three (3) members of the board shall constitute a quorum. Any board member who has a direct or indirect personal interest in a consideration, examination or applicant for a certificate of competency, etc., shall recluse himself as a board member for said consideration. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 12, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:159. - Procedure for the examination of applicants for electrical certificates of competency; examination fees; grading examinations. 
(a)  At a regularly scheduled meeting of the board, any person, firm or corporation desiring a certificate of competency in the classification requested, shall make application in writing to the electrical board to wit: Individual applicants shall file a personal resume giving information as to work experience, education, current financial statement, bank reference and two (2) personal references from local residents, firms or corporations. A firm or corporation making application shall furnish a financial statement, bank reference, two (2) references from prominent firms or corporations doing business in Eunice, Louisiana. After filing the required documents with the board, the board will determine the eligibility of the applicant to be examined at the time of application. 
(b)  If the applicant is ruled eligible, the board will give a written examination to the applicant no sooner than three (3) days nor less than ten (10) days from date of the application (weekends and legal holidays excluded). 
(c)  Grading of the applicant's examination shall take place within seventy-two (72) hours after examination is completed and then forwarded to the chairman of the board. 
(d)  The grade given to the examination shall not be available to any board member, official of the City of Eunice, citizen, firm or corporation until the board has convened an official meeting at which time the grading of the examination shall be checked and verified by the board members in closed session. 
(e)  If the applicant has successfully passed the examination, the board shall issue a certificate of competency authorizing the applicant to do business in the City of Eunice in the classification of work allowed by the certificate. 
(f)  If the applicant has failed to pass the examination the board shall so notify applicant and show him evidence of failure. 
(g)  The applicant then may refile for examination to be taken no sooner than ten (10) days nor less than thirty (30) days from date of filing. The same procedure for examination previously prescribed shall be followed. 
(h)  If applicant fails to pass the second examination, he shall forfeit the examination fee and not be eligible for re-examination for a period not less than six (6) months from date of the last examination. 
(i)  Examination fees of ten dollars ($10.00) shall accompany the application and shall be in the form of a certified check or money order made payable to the electrical board, City of Eunice, Louisiana. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 12A, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:160. - Application fees; renewal of certificates; date due; qualifications required of applicants to take competency examination. 
(a)  The following fees shall be charged each applicant for examination or registration, or both and shall be paid at the time the application is filed: 
Electrical Contractor ..... $25.00 
Electrician ..... $25.00 
(b)  All certificates of competency shall expire on December 31st of each year and must be renewed on or before February 1st of the following year. Renewal fees are charged as follows: 
Electrical Contractor ..... $25.00 
Electrician ..... $25.00 
(c)  The registration fees shall be due January 1st and become delinquent February 1st of the same year. Delinquent applications shall carry a twenty-five (25) per cent penalty in fees. Where the applicant for renewal has not performed electrical work during the previous twelve (12) months, he shall be re-examined. Exception: Where an applicant has maintained a license in good standing and has paid the required fees when due and where extenuating circumstances required said applicant to accept a hiatus for twelve (12) consecutive months, the applicant may be granted at the discretion of the board, a renewal certificate without being re-examined. 
(d)  If the board shall find, upon due investigation that the applicant for electrician's certificate of competency is at least twenty-one (21) years of age and has had at least four (4) years practical experience as a journeyman electrician, or is a graduate of any technical school of recognized standing and, in addition thereto, has had practical experience as a journeyman electrician and that he is of good moral character, he shall be given the examination. The examination shall be given under the direction of the board and the examination shall be graded by the board. The applicant shall satisfy the board that he is a master of his trade or calling. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 13, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:161. - Liability of members of the electrical board. 
(a)  No member of the electrical board charged with the duties of the board in connection and in conjunction with the enforcement of the Electrical Code together with its amendments, modifications and additions, shall thereby render himself liable, personally, and any such member is hereby relieved from all personal liability for any damage that may occur to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties. Any suit brought against any such member because of the Code shall be defended by the office of the city attorney until the final termination of the proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 14, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:162. - General requirements of those engaged in electrical work; certificates required; reciprocal certificates; renewal of certificates; revocation of certificates; registration; bonds; liability insurance; occupational licenses; established place of business required; rough-in inspections; final inspections; re-inspections. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to carry on or engage in the business of electrical work or to labor at the trade of installing electrical wiring, devices, appliances, signs, or equipment in the City of Eunice, Louisiana, unless such person has successfully passed an examination conducted by the electrical board, and has had issued to him an electrical contractor or electrician certificate of competency by the electrical board, in the manner and in accordance with the provisions of this subchapter, except as otherwise provided for in this subchapter. All persons, firms or corporations which have been licensed and qualified to perform electrical work in the City of Eunice, Louisiana, for the immediate past three-year period as of the date of the passing of Ordinance No. 9-70 shall be issued certificates of competency on their application to the electrical board without the necessity of taking an examination and upon payment of the fees provided for. 
(b)  Reciprocal certificate: The electrical board, may in lieu of the examination called for in this subchapter accept of the applicant's competency, any record from any city having like qualifications or license from the State Board of Electrical Examiners, and such applicant who applies for examination and registration may be registered without examination by the electrical board. 
(c)  Renewal of certificates: Each certificate of competency shall be issued for one year, from January 1st to December 31st and shall remain in force and effect for that period, unless sooner revoked. Each such certificate may be renewed from year to year, upon payment of fee required, without further examination, unless such certificate has been cancelled or revoked. Each such renewal shall be made within thirty (30) days from the date of expiration of the certificate, and any certificate which is not renewed shall become null and void. 
(d)  Revocation of certificate: The electrical board may cancel or revoke any certificate of competency issued by them, if the person to whom the certificate was granted later shows incompetency or lack of knowledge in matters relevant to the certificate; if the certificate was obtained by fraud, the board may require such person to appear before it for examination or re-examination. 
(e)  Registration: Before any person, firm or corporation shall carry on or engage in the business of electrical work or labor at the trade of installing electrical wiring and devices, appliances, signs, or equipment in the City of Eunice, Louisiana, he shall first register his name and address with the electrical inspector, together with information as may be required, except as otherwise provided for in this subchapter. 
(f)  Contractor's bond: Every person, firm or corporation must, before engaging in the electrical contracting business, deposit with the City Clerk of the City of Eunice, an electrical contractor's bond in the principal sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) executed by two (2) or more solvent sureties or a solvent surety company authorized to do business in the State of Louisiana, conditioned that the principal therein shall faithfully comply with the terms of this subchapter and shall indemnify and hold harmless the said City of Eunice, Louisiana, and all of its officials, employees or agents against all cost, expense, damage and injury sustained by the negligence of such principal, his agents, servants, and employees, or his failure to comply with the terms of this subchapter in doing work made the subject matter hereof, and otherwise to be in the form and executed as required by the City of Eunice. The bond shall be renewed annually on the first day of January of each year as a prerequisite to the issuance of an electrical contractor's certificate of competency for the year. 
(g)  Public liability insurance: Each and every licensed electrical contractor shall carry public liability insurance with an insurance agency authorized to do business in the State of Louisiana in the amount of at least fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). 
(h)  License required: Before any person, firm or corporation shall carry on or engage in the business of installing electrical wiring, devices, appliances, signs or equipment in the City of Eunice, Louisiana, he or it shall first procure a contractor's license from the city clerk of the City, and pay the annual license fee imposed on such business, as per the occupational license law. No such license shall be transferable. 
(i)  Every applicant for an electrical contractor's license shall furnish proof that he is the lawful possessor of a valid certificate of competency. If the applicant be a partnership, firm or corporation, some bona fide member or authorized agent thereof shall be the possessor of a valid certificate of competency who shall at all times be in actual charge of the electricians performing the work. When any person is designated as agent for the applicant, one copy of said written designation shall be filed with the City Clerk of the City of Eunice, Louisiana. 
(j)  Expiration of license: All contractors licenses shall expire on the 31st day of December of each year unless sooner revoked. 
(k)  License not transferable: No person holding a contractor's license issued by the City of Eunice, Louisiana, shall lend such license to any other person or allow any other person to do any electrical work under any permit taken out in his name, except certified electricians in his employ. A violation of this Paragraph shall be grounds for the revocation of such person's license, in addition to other penalties provided for by this subchapter. 
(l)  Must have an established place of business: Every licensed electrical contractor must have and maintain an established place of business in the City of Eunice. He must and shall have someone in attendance to receive complaints or notices from the electrical inspector or the electrical board. His place of business must be where he can be reached by patrons. 
(m)  Must hold a certificate to advertise as such: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation not in legal possession of a valid certificate of competency issued by the electrical board of Eunice, Louisiana, to engage in, carry on or represent himself, itself, or themselves, as engaging in, or carrying on the business of and electrical contractor in the City of Eunice, Louisiana or to use the words electrical contractor in any advertising, or to display or expose a sign having imprint for the purpose of implying the advertiser to be so engaged. 
(n)  Approval of roughing-in: When the rough-in electrical work has been completed on any premises and the electrical inspector notified, he shall cause an inspection to be made of the work. If the said electrical work has been installed in accordance with the provisions of this subchapter and meets the requirements of the Code, the electrical inspector shall sign the inspection card, noting thereon the date of approval. More than one rough-in inspection may be made without additional charge when the type of progress of construction requires such inspection. 
(o)  Final inspection: Upon the completion of all electrical work in any building or on any premises and the notification to the electrical inspector has been made, the electrical inspector shall cause an inspection of the work to be made. If such work is found to be correctly installed, replaced or repaired, and in accordance with the requirements of this subchapter, the inspector shall sign the inspection approval card, noting thereon the date of approval. 
(p)  Notice of defects: If after any inspection (rough-in or final) and before issuance of approval card, the electrical work is found to be faulty, incorrectly or defectively installed, the electrical inspector shall notify the person authorized by the permit to do the work on the change to be made in order that the work will conform to the requirements of this subchapter. 
(q)  Re-inspection and fee: For each and every reinspection made necessary by faulty, incorrectly or defectively installed electrical work, a re-inspection fee as set out in this subchapter shall be paid by the person authorized by the permit to do the work. 
(r)  Limits to correct defects: The person authorized by the permit to do the work, shall, within forty-eight (48) working hours from the time of notification, make or commence to make the changes ordered, and shall proceed with the work until the changes are completed. Upon completion thereof and payment of the re-inspection fee, the electrical inspector shall then cause a re-inspection to be made and if the work is found to comply with the code, he shall sign the inspection card noting thereon the date of approval of the work. 
(s)  Continued notices of defects and re-inspection. If the electrical inspector should upon re-inspection find the work incorrectly installed, he shall collect an additional re-inspection fee. If the required changes are not made within a reasonable time, the electrical inspector shall refuse to issue to such person any additional permits until the faulty work has been corrected and approved. 
(t)  Electrical work shall be approved. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to knowingly allow or permit the use of electrical power in new, existing, altered or repaired installations until such electrical work has been inspected, tested and approved by the electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 9-70, § 15, 7-14-70) 
Secs. 5:163-5:198. - Reserved. 
Sec. 5:199. - Violations, penalties. 
    Whoever violates the provisions of this subchapter or any section thereof shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in Section 1:21 of this Code. 
SUBCHAPTER C. - PLUMBING AND GAS FITTING 
PART I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5:200. - Adoption of plumbing code, object and scope of code. 
    This subchapter shall apply to and include all plumbing work, installation or equipment installed, constructed or altered in or about a building or structure of any kind, class or character, or used, or to be used for any purpose whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. 10-70, § 1; 7-14-70) 
Comment- Ordinance No. 10-70 supersedes Ord. No. A-262, adopted March 12, 1963; Ord. No. A-53, adopted February 7, 1939; Ord. No. A-44, adopted March 2, 1937; and Ord. No. A-42, adopted February 6, 1936. 
Cross reference- Adoption of state sanitary code, § 10:1. 
Sec. 5:201. - Adoption of standard plumbing code; enforcement of plumbing code; decisions, variations, modifications. 
(a)  The City of Eunice adopts by reference the rules and regulations as set forth in the Standard Plumbing Code, 1975 edition, as amended, together with basic principles and accompanying this act, and said rules and regulations are hereby incorporated by reference in this subchapter as fully as if set out in full herein. These rules and regulations are to be considered an integral part of the Eunice Plumbing Code and are hereby legalized as such; and shall be taken by all the courts of the State of Louisiana and by all public officials to have the same force and effect as if included in this subchapter. 
(b)  The plumbing board may vary the application of any provision of the Standard Plumbing Code, together with its amendments, modifications and additions, in any particular case, when in its opinion, the enforcement thereof would do manifest injustice and would be contrary to the spirit and purpose of this subchapter or the public interest or when in its opinion the interpretation or decision of the plumbing inspector should be modified, reversed or disallowed. 
(c)  A decision of the plumbing board to vary the application or any provision of the Standard Plumbing Code or to modify, reverse or disallow an interpretation or order of the plumbing inspector shall specify in writing, in what manner such changes are made, the condition upon which it is made and the reasons therefor. 
(d)  It is hereby declared to be the intention of the board of aldermen that the amendments to the city plumbing code herein adopted shall be deemed to be incorporated in said code so that a reference to the plumbing code of the City of Eunice shall be understood and intended to include such amendments. 
(e)  The plumbing board shall in every case render an opinion and/or decision without unreasonable or unnecessary delay. 
(f)  Varying, modifying, revising or disallowing the interpretation or order of the plumbing inspector shall require the affirmative votes of the majority present, but not less than three (3) affirmative votes shall be required. No board member shall act in a decision in which he has a personal or direct interest. 
(Ord. No. 10-70, § 8, 7-14-70; Ord. No. 6-72, 5-2-72; Ord. No. 28-80, 9-8-81) 
Comment- Ordinance No. 10-70 originally provided for the enforcement of only the state sanitary code regulations. Ordinance No. 6-72 replaced the state code with the National Standard Plumbing Code. The requirements of the state code are still applicable in the city as per Section 10:1 of this codification. 
Sec. 5:202. - Office of plumbing inspector; qualifications and appointment. 
(a)  A plumbing inspector shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the approval of the board of aldermen. 
(b)  The salary to be paid to the plumbing inspector shall be determined by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 10-70, § 2, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:203. - Duties of the plumbing inspector; applications for permits, inspections. 
(a)  The plumbing inspector shall have the duty: 
(1)  To issue all permits for plumbing work. 
(2)  To inspect and pass upon all plumbing and inspect any plumbing of any character already in use or being constructed which he may have reason to believe is out of repair or imperfect. 
(3)  To maintain public office hours, receive applications for permits, review plans and specifications for work to be performed, keep records of all permits issued and work performed, maintain an official register of persons, firms or corporations qualified and licensed to engage in the business of plumbing work in the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the plumbing inspector to engage in the business of the sale, installation or maintenance of plumbing equipment directly, but he may have a financial interest in a concern engaged in such business. 
(c)  The plumbing inspector shall have the right to enter any building or premises in the discharge of his duties. 
(d)  When any plumbing is found to be defective or defectively installed, the party responsible shall be notified in writing and shall make any changes or repairs required or needed to place such in safe and working condition, and if such work is not completed within fifteen (15) days, or any longer period granted in said notice, the plumbing inspector shall have authority to stop the further construction or use of such plumbing until it has been properly constructed or repaired. 
(e)  All applications for plumbing inspection shall be accompanied by the inspection fees as follows: 
(1)  First fixture ..... $5.00 
(2)  Each additional fixture up to ten (10) ..... $ 1.00 
(3)  Inspection of hot water tanks ..... 20.00 
(4)  Gas inspection (in city) ..... 15.00 
(5)  Gas inspection (out of city) ..... 25.00 
For each reinspection additional fee must be charged. 
(f)  If in the judgment of the inspector work being done in a manner prohibited by this subchapter will foreseeably endanger public citizenry or public property or the property of other owners, then he shall have the power to compel the suspension of any plumbing work being performed by issuing a cease and desist citation which, if not complied with, shall immediately be heard by the Eunice City Court on an instanta basis within seventy-two hours of the issuance of the citation. Any work performed after notice of the citation is served upon a contractor and prior to a hearing before the Eunice City Court shall be a violation of this subchapter. 
(g)  Prior to the issuance of a permit, an application for a permit shall be made on the form prescribed, stating the location of the property, the name of the licensed plumber to be employed, with a full and clear description of the work proposed, signed by the owner, that the work will conform with the rules and ordinances regulating sewer connections and plumbing. Each application shall be accompanied by a diagram and specifications made in duplicate on the form, showing and describing the location of the building and of the rooms containing the work, the connections with the sewer, with every pipe, fixture and connection neatly drawn in. If one vertical section cannot be made to show the work fully, other drawings are to be added. In showing extensions, the old work is to be shown in red ink and all new in black ink. 
(h)  No permits are required for minor work such as repair of leaks, traps, drains, or faucets or opening up waste or supply pipes or replacing broken fixtures. 
(Ord. No. 10-70, § 3, 7-14-70; Ord. No. 09-04(B), 9-14-04; Ord. No. 02-11(C), 2-8-11) 
Sec. 5:204. - Plumbing board organization, qualifications. 
(a)  There is hereby created the plumbing board of the City of Eunice, which shall consist of five (5) members. The members shall be appointed by the mayor by and with the advice and consent of the board of aldermen and shall serve for terms as prescribed and provided for herein and shall serve as a body to administer the provisions of this subchapter. 
(b)  The members of the board shall include: 
One plumber, licensed to do business in Eunice, Louisiana. 
One electrician, licensed to do business in Eunice, Louisiana. 
One Alderman of the City of Eunice, Louisiana. 
One plumbing inspector of the City of Eunice, Louisiana. 
One general contractor (resident), or realtor doing business in Eunice, Louisiana. 
(Ord. No. 10-70, § 4, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:205. - Duties of the plumbing board. 
(a)  The plumbing board shall have and is hereby given full power and authority to prepare and promulgate such rules as may be deemed necessary to carry out the provisions herein, provided the same are not inconsistent with the provisions of this subchapter. The board shall establish standards and procedures for the examination and qualifications for licensing of plumbers and shall issue or cause to be issued, an appropriate certificate to each person, firm or corporation who meets the qualifications and passes the examination given by the board. The board shall act in an advisory capacity pertaining to all work with and in the jurisdiction of this subchapter. 
(b)  The board shall review any interpretation or ruling relative to this subchapter by the plumbing inspector when requested to do so by any such person, firm or corporation or the plumbing inspection department. 
(c)  Any decisions or rulings rendered by the plumbing board shall be final and conclusive unless within thirty (30) days from the date thereof, the aggrieved party shall seek relief therefrom in any court of competent jurisdiction as provided by the laws of the State of Louisiana. 
(Ord. No. 10-70, § 5, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:206. - Authority of the plumbing board to revoke, suspend plumbing licenses. 
    The board shall, subject to approval of the board of aldermen, have the power to revoke or suspend a license or certificate of any plumber or firms or corporations to whom said certificates or licenses are issued who are found guilty of a violation as set forth in this subchapter. 
(Ord. No. 10-70, § 6, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:207. - Revocation, suspension of plumbing licenses, procedure. 
(a)  Before a certificate may be revoked or suspended, the licensee shall have notice, in writing, enumerating the charges and be entitled to a hearing by the plumbing board, not sooner than five (5) days from receipt of notice. The licensee shall be given an opportunity to present testimony, oral or written, and shall have the right to cross-examination. All testimony shall be given under oath. The board shall have the power to administer oaths, issue subpoenas and compel the attendance of witnesses. The decisions of the plumbing board shall be based upon the evidence produced at the hearing and made part of the record thereof. 
(b)  The board may suspend or revoke any certificate of registration for refusal to comply with the recommendations of the plumbing inspector and violations of this subchapter. 
(c)  No certificate shall be revoked until a public hearing has been held by the board at which hearing the registrant may appear in person or be represented by counsel. 
(Ord. No. 10-70, § 7, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:208. - Qualifications of the plumbing board. 
(a)  It shall be a requirement that each member of the plumbing board be a registered voter of the City of Eunice. The appointments shall be for terms as follows: Of the members first appointed, two (2) shall be appointed for a term of one year; two (2) shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years and one shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years. Thereafter, they shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years. Vacancies shall be filled for an unexpired term in the manner in which the original appointments are required to be made. 
(b)  The board will elect a chairman and vice-chairman and secretary from its membership to serve for a period of twelve (12) consecutive months and who will be eligible for re-election upon expiration of a term. 
(c)  The board shall keep a record of all proceedings and the secretary shall file the same with all proper city and state agencies as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 10-70, § 9, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:209. - Regular meetings of the plumbing board. 
    The plumbing board shall hold its regular meetings on the second Monday prior to regularly scheduled council meetings of January, April, July and October of each year for the purpose of performing its duties. 
(Ord. No. 10-70, § 10, 7-14-70; Ord. of 5-13-82) 
Sec. 5:210. - Special meetings of the plumbing board. 
    The mayor or his authorized representative may call a special meeting of the plumbing board. 
(Ord. No. 10-70, § 11, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:211. - Quorum of the plumbing board. 
    Three (3) members of the plumbing board shall constitute a quorum. Any board member who has a direct or indirect personal interest in a consideration, examination or application for a certificate shall recuse himself as a board member for said consideration. 
(Ord. No. 10-70, § 12, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:212. - Procedure for the examination of applicants and the granting of certificate of competency as a plumbing contractor. 
(a)  At a regularly scheduled meeting of the board, any person, firm or corporation desiring a certificate of competency shall make application in writing to the board, to wit: 
(1)  An individual applicant shall file a personal resume giving information as to work experience, education, current financial statement, bank reference and two (2) personal references from local residents, firms or corporations. 
(2)  A firm or corporation making application shall furnish a financial statement, bank reference, two (2) personal references from local residents, firms or corporations doing business in Eunice, Louisiana. 
(3)  All Applicants shall furnish the board with evidence that he or one of the members of the firm or corporation holds a certificate issued by the state board of examiners of journeyman plumbers. 
(b)  After filing the required documents with the board, the board will determine the eligibility of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 10-70, § 12A, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:213. - Permit fees for plumbers and plumbing contractors; renewal fees; date due; delinquency. 
(a)  The following fees shall be charged each applicant for registration and shall be paid at the time the application is filed: 
    Plumbers ..... $50.00 
    Plumbing contractors ..... 50.00 
(b)  All certificates of competency shall expire on December thirty-first of each year and must be renewed on or before February first of the following year. Renewal fees are charged as follows: 
    Plumbers ..... $25.00 
    Plumbing contractors ..... 25.00 
(c)  The registration fees shall be due January first and become delinquent February first of the same year. Delinquent applications shall carry a twenty-five (25) per cent penalty in fees. 
(Ord. No. 10-70, § 13, 7-14-70) 
Sec. 5:214. - Personal liability of members of the plumbing board.
