The restrictions of the zoning ordinance of the city shall not be deemed to be modified by any provisions of this code; and such restrictions shall be controlling except insofar as this code imposes greater restrictions by reason of the type of construction used, in which case the provisions of this code shall control. 
(Ord. No. 6-86, §§ 1-3, 7-8-86) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 6-86, §§ 1-3, adopted July 8, 1986, being not specifically amendatory of the Code, has been codified herein as a new § 7:101 at the discretion of the editor. Chapter 3, §§ 301-1-305 and §§ 602-606.3, of the Southern Building Code and the fire district map referred to above as being attached to said Ord. No. 6-86 have not been included herein, but can be found on file in the city clerk's office and available for public inspection. 
Comment- Ordinance No. 3-88, adopted May 24, 1988, amended Ord. No. 6-86, set out above as § 7:101, by adding to Section 304 of the Southern Building Code, adopted by reference in § 7:101 above, the following exception to the restrictions in the fire district of the city: 
"11. Temporary buildings and/or seasonal stands used for commercial purposes, for a period of one hundred fifty (150) days, said structures to be located no less than twenty-five (25) feet from the nearest permanent structure." 
Sec. 7:102. - Fire chief responsible for investigations of fires. 
    The Chief of the Eunice Fire Department shall be responsible for the investigation of the cause, origin and circumstances of any fire inside the city when there is a loss of life or injury to persons by which property has been destroyed or damaged. 
(1)  If there is an injury to a firefighter or a fatality of a firefighter or civilian, the state fire marshal shall also be called to investigate with the city fire department. 
(2)  The Chief of the Eunice Fire Department or the authorized representative shall be qualified to investigate the cause and origin of fires and this qualification shall consist of certification as fire officer 1 or fire investigator. 
(3)  Any fire that is or could possibly be due to an intentional or malicious act shall be treated as a crime scene and the department has the authority contained in LRS 40:1563.1 to further investigate the circumstances and determine the person or persons responsible. 
(Ord. No. 0416(B), 5-10-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0416(B), adopted May 10, 2016, did not expressly amend the Code and has been included as herein set out at the editor's discretion. 
Chapter 8 - FRANCHISES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to grant franchises, LRS 33:4401. 

SUBCHAPTER A. - CABLE TELEVISION 
PART I. - EUNICE/CABLE TV OF ACADIANA[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 12-89, adopted Dec. 12, 1989, being not specifically amendatory of the Code, has been treated as superseding provisions formerly codified as §§ 8:1-8:5, which sections set out an earlier franchise agreement between the city and Cable TV of Acadiana, Inc., enacted and amended by, respectively, Ord. No. 1-75, §§ 1-4, adopted March 11, 1975, and a motion of April 8, 1975. 

Sec. 8:1. - Short title. 
    This ordinance shall be known as the "Eunice/Cable TV of Acadiana, Inc. Cable Television Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § I, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:2. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this part, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words in the plural include the singular and words in the singular include the plural. The word "shall" is mandatory and "may" is permissive. Words not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning. Whenever the masculine gender is used it includes the feminine gender. 
    Cable antenna service means the lowest priced service which shall be offered at a reduced rate from full basic service and shall include the retransmission of local television broadcast signals and the access channel. 
    Cable service or CATV service means the one-way transmission to subscribers of video programming or other programming service, and subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection of such video programming or other programming service. 
    Cable system or CATV system means a facility, consisting of a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception and control equipment, that is designed to provide cable service which includes video programming and which is provided to multiple subscribers within a community, but such terms do not include: 
(1)  A facility that serves only to retransmit the television signals of one or more television broadcast stations; 
(2)  A facility that serves only subscribers in one or more multiple-unit dwellings under common ownership, control or management unless such facility or facilities use any public right-of-way; 
(3)  A facility of a common carrier which is subject, in whole or in part, to the provisions of Title II of the Communications Act of 1934, as amended; except that such facility shall be considered a cable system (other than for purposes of Section 621(c) of the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984) to the extent such facility is used in the transmission of video programming directly to subscribers; or 
(4)  Any facilities of any electric utility used solely for operating its electric utility systems. 
    City means the City of Eunice, as represented by the elected officials thereof, or the area within the territorial limits of the city now or hereafter annexed. 
    Class IV channel means a signaling path provided by a cable communications system to transmit signals of any type from a subscriber to another point in the cable communications system. 
    FCC means the Federal Communications Commission and any legally appointed or elected successor. 
    Franchisee or company means Cable TV of Acadiana, Inc., or its lawful successor, transferee or assignee. 
    Full basic service means that package of services which includes cable antenna service and any additional programming services offered by the franchisee in one or more tiers or levels of service; provided, that it shall not include services offered on a per-program or per-channel basis. 
    Gross revenues means all revenue received by the franchisee from subscribers within the city and that portion of advertising revenue received by the franchisee, including, but not limited to, the CVN channel and all other similar channels, and allocated to the city based on a percentage of the number of subscribers in the city as compared to total subscribers served by the cable system; provided, however, that this shall not include any taxes on services furnished by the franchisee herein imposed directly upon any subscriber or user by the local or other governmental unit and collected by the franchisee on behalf of said governmental unit. The advertising revenue referred to herein shall include such revenues earned by franchisee, whether paid directly to franchisee or to its parent company, a company controlling, controlled by or under common control with the franchisee and/or any affiliate. 
    Installation means the connection of the system from feeder cable to a subscriber's terminal. 
    Monitoring means observing a communications signal, or the absence of a signal, where the observer is neither the subscriber nor the franchisee, whether the signal is observed by visual or electronic means, for any purpose whatsoever. Monitoring shall not include system wide, nonindividually addressed sweeps of the system for purposes of verifying system integrity, controlling return path transmission or billing for pay services. 
    Person means an individual, partnership, association, organization, corporation or any lawful successor, transferee or assignee of said individual, partnership, association, organization or corporation. 
    Property of franchisee means all property owned by a franchisee in the operation of a CATV system or service located in the city under the authority of a franchise granted pursuant to this part. 
    Rates means those charges assessed by the franchisee to the subscribers or users of the cable television system. Rates refer not only to charges assessed but also to charges if set at zero. 
    State means the State of Louisiana. 
    Street or road or right-of-way means the surface of and the space above and below any publicly owned or maintained property or right-of-way, including, but not limited to, any street, road, highway, freeway, land, path, alley, court, sidewalk, parkway or drive, now or hereafter existing as such within the city. 
    Subscriber means any person or entity lawfully receiving any portion of the cable television service of the franchisee pursuant to this part. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § II, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:3. - Grant of franchise. 
(a)  The city council of the city hereby grants to Cable TV of Acadiana, Inc., the nonexclusive right and franchise (the "franchise") to construct, operate and maintain a cable television system in the city for the purpose of receiving, amplifying, originating and distributing television and radio signals for the use of the citizens and residents of the city. 
(b)  The franchisee shall be authorized to construct or have constructed, operate and maintain a CATV system and to engage in the business of providing a CATV service in the city, and for that purpose to erect, install, construct, repair, replace, reconstruct and maintain such property as may be necessary and appurtenant to the CATV system, provided, however, that before such property may be placed within any street or road, the proper permission and authority to do so must be obtained by the franchisee from any and all other agencies of competent jurisdiction, and to use, operate and provide similar facilities or properties rented or leased from other persons. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to engage in the construction, operation or maintenance of a CATV system or provide a CATV service in the city unless such person or the person for whom such action is being taken shall have first obtained and shall currently hold a valid franchise. 
(d)  It is unlawful for any telephone, telegraph, or power company or any other public utility company or person to lease or otherwise make available to any other person any poles, lines, facilities, equipment, or other property for use in connection with the operation of a CATV system or service unless such other person holds a valid franchise. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § III, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:4. - Acceptance; effective date. 
(a)  Within sixty (60) days after the effective date of the ordinance from which this Part I is derived, the franchisee shall file with the city clerk an acceptance acknowledged before a notary public. Such acceptance shall acknowledge that the franchisee agrees to be bound by and to comply with the provisions of such ordinance and shall be in a form acceptable to the city. 
(b)  Concurrently with the filing of the written acceptance, the franchisee shall file with the city clerk the proof of insurance as specified in Section 8:17 hereof. 
(c)  The franchise granted pursuant to the ordinance from which this part is derived shall take effect and be in full force from and after final passage by the city council, subject to the approval by the city of the acceptance and evidence of the insurance as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § IV, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:5. - Term of franchise; renewal. 
    The duration of this franchise granted shall be ten (10) years from the effective date. This franchise shall be renewable for additional terms of ten (10) years each, upon terms satisfactory to both the city and the franchisee. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § V, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:6. - Transfer of cable television system. 
    Neither this franchise nor any cable system servicing the city shall be transferred or assigned without the prior written consent of the city council, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § VI, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:7. - Franchise fees. 
    The franchisee shall pay to the city for the privilege of constructing, operating and maintaining the CATV system, and for the privilege of providing the CATV service, and for the cost of the city regulating and supporting the system, a sum of five (5) percent of its gross revenues, as defined herein. Payment shall be made annually by the first day of March for the preceding calendar year. Acceptance of any payment shall not be construed as an accord by the city that the sum is correct, nor a release of any possible claim for additional funds, subject to an annual audit to be conducted at city's option. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § VII, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:8. - Rates and charges. 
(a)  The rates of the franchisee shall not be regulated by the city, except as may be allowed by the applicable state and federal law or by regulations of the FCC, or any other rules issued by all regulatory agencies now or hereafter in existence. 
(b)  Except as and to the extent elsewhere provided herein, the franchisee shall not, as to rates, charges, services, facilities, rules, regulations or in other respects, make or grant any preferences or advantages to any person connected to its system, nor subject any such person to any prejudice or disadvantage; provided, that nothing herein contained shall be deemed to prevent the establishment of a graduated scale of charges and classified rate schedules to which any customer coming within such classifications would be entitled, including, but not limited to, the classification of courtesy accounts provided at no charge. 
(c)  Before putting any rate changes into effect, the franchisee shall be required to notify all customers at least thirty (30) days and the city at least forty-five (45) days before such rate changes are to become effective. 
(d)  The franchisee shall provide, upon written request from the city and at no charge, one outlet (standard drop) of full basic cable service to the City Hall, fire and police stations, libraries, and all public and parochial schools and colleges located within the franchise area. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § VIII, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:9. - Limitations of franchise. 
    In addition to the limitations otherwise herein, the franchisee is subject to the following limitations: 
(a)  The franchisee shall at all times during the life of any franchise hereunder be subject to all lawful exercise of the police power by the city and other duly authorized regulatory state and federal bodies and shall comply with any and all ordinances which the city has adopted or shall adopt applying to the public generally, and shall be subject to all present and future laws of the State of Louisiana and the United States. 
(b)  Time shall be of the essence in this franchise. The franchisee shall not be relieved of its obligations to promptly comply with provisions of this franchise by the failure of the city to enforce prompt compliance. Failure of the city to enforce any breach by the franchisee shall not constitute a waiver of those violations by the city. 
(c)  The franchise granted hereunder shall not relieve the franchisee of any obligation under any pole or conduit use agreements from others maintaining poles or conduits in the streets of the city whenever the franchisee finds it necessary to make use of said poles or conduits. 
(d)  Nothing in this franchise shall in any way or to any extent be construed to waive, modify or abridge the city's right of eminent domain in respect to the franchisee. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § IX, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:10. - Initial service area; annexation. 
(a)  The franchisee shall make service available to all potential subscribers who reside within the city limits within one year of the obtaining of all pole attachment agreements and permits by the franchisee. 
(b)  The franchisee shall extend service to areas annexed into the city within one year of annexation and the obtaining of all pole attachment agreements and permits by the franchisee; provided, that such areas shall have a minimum density of thirty (30) homes per mile of cable plant required to serve such homes, as measured from the nearest terminal point of franchisee's activated cable plant. In the event that an annexed area does not meet the minimum density standard set forth in this paragraph at the time of annexation, service shall be provided to such annexed area within one year of the time the minimum density standard is met and the obtaining of all pole attachment agreements and permits by the franchisee. 
(c)  The franchisee shall diligently and without delay pursue the acquisition of pole attachment agreements and permits, as time is of the essence, and franchisee shall proceed with all due diligence to acquire said pole attachment agreements and permits. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § X, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:11. - Conditions on use of streets and roads. 
(a)  The poles used for the distribution system shall be, to the extent possible, those erected and maintained by either the power company or the telephone company, or both, whenever agreement can be reached with the owners of such poles. 
(b)  The installation of lines and facilities, including service drops to subscribers, shall be made underground in areas where the telephone and power lines are underground. Any existing aboveground facilities shall be placed underground when required by the city and when both telephone and power lines are also placed underground. 
(c)  The franchisee shall, at its expense, protect, support, temporarily disconnect or relocate in the same street or other public place any property of the franchisee when required by the city by reason of traffic conditions, public safety, street closing or abandonment, highway or street construction, change or establishment of street grade, installation of sewer drains, water pipes, power lines, signal lines, or any other types of structures or improvements, and the city shall not be liable for any disturbance of the franchisee's installations resulting therefrom. The franchisee may do such tree trimming or other maintenance as shall be necessary to maintain its lines and cables and other property in good working order after first obtaining the required and proper permission to do so from the property owners being affected and any and all other agencies of competent jurisdiction. 
(d)  Whenever the franchisee takes up or disturbs any pavement, sidewalk or other improvement of any street or road, the same shall be restored to reasonably as good condition as before entry, all in accordance with standards, regulations and policies of the city. Any opening or obstruction in the streets shall be guarded and protected at all times by the placement of adequate barriers, fences or boardings, the bounds of which shall be clearly designated by warning lights of approved type. 
(e)  In the event of the failure by the franchisee to complete any work required by this section or any work required by city ordinance within the time established and to the satisfaction of the city, the city may cause such work to be done and the franchisee shall reimburse the city the costs thereof within thirty (30) days after receipt of any itemized list of such costs. 
(f)  Any poles, cables, electronic equipment or other appurtenances of the franchisee to be installed in, under, over, along, across or upon a street shall be located so as to cause minimum interference with the rights of other users of the streets or of owners of property which adjoins any of the streets. 
(g)  The franchisee shall, upon reasonable notice from any person holding a building moving permit issued by the city, temporarily alter its facilities to permit the moving of such building. The actual cost of such altering shall be borne by the person requesting the altering and the franchisee shall have the right to request payment in advance. For this provision of the franchise, "reasonable notice" shall be construed to mean at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to move. 
(h)  In the event the continued use of a street is denied for any reason, the franchisee will make every effort to provide service over alternate routes. 
(i)  If at any time in case of fire or disaster in the city it shall become necessary in the judgment of the mayor or his designee to cut or move any of the wires, cables, amplifiers, appliances or appurtenances thereto of the franchisee, such cutting or moving may be done and any repairs rendered necessary thereby shall be made by the franchisee at its sole expense. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § XI, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:12. - System capacity. 
(a)  Within sixty (60) days of the effective date of this franchise, the franchisee shall proceed with all due diligence to construct and/or upgrade and rebuild its cable system to sixty-channel capacity, and shall activate the sixty-channel capacity system throughout all areas of the city that are physically being served by the franchisee within one year of the franchisee having acquired all pole attachment agreements and permits. 
(b)  Upon activation of the sixty-channel capacity system, the franchisee shall make one channel in the cable antenna service available to the city for governmental and educational access use, at no cost to the city, such access channel to be available to the city throughout the term of this franchise and extended terms. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § XII, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:13. - Construction and operational standards. 
(a)  Franchisee shall construct, install, operate and maintain its system in a manner consistent with all laws, ordinances, governmental requirements and FCC technical standards, and in accordance with the highest industry standards in order to assure subscriber receipt of the best and most desirable form of service. 
(b)  All installation and maintenance of electronic equipment shall be of a permanent nature, durable, and installed in accordance with the applicable sections of the current edition of the National Electric Safety Code and all state and local codes where applicable. 
(c)  The franchisee shall put, keep and maintain all parts of the system in good condition throughout the entire franchise period. 
(d)  The franchisee shall render efficient service, make repairs promptly, and interrupt service only for good cause and for the shortest time possible. Such interruptions, insofar as possible, shall be preceded by notice and shall occur during periods of minimum system use. 
(e)  The franchisee shall not allow its operations to interfere with television reception of persons not served by franchisee, nor shall the system interfere with, obstruct or hinder in any manner the operation of the various utilities servicing the residents within the confines of the city. 
(f)  The following requirements are to be met by the franchisee to ensure a process for locating, reporting and repairing damages to a cable system: 
(1)  Franchisee shall furnish to all franchised cable television operators the names and current phone numbers of persons responsible for receiving damage reports. These persons shall be in a position to dispatch information to field personnel expeditiously. 
(2)  Franchisee shall join the "One-Call Concepts" locating organization, or any successor or replacement organization, upon acceptance of this franchise and shall follow all rules and regulations established by that organization. 
(3)  Franchisee shall handle all locate requests promptly in accordance with the "One-Call Concepts" procedure; or such procedures as may be established by any successor or replacement organization. 
(4)  Franchisee shall handle all make-ready requests and perform any required joint utility ride-outs promptly to ensure a smooth working relationship for all parties involved. 
(5)  Franchisee has the option to either perform its own locating services or contract out these services. If the franchisee chooses to perform these services in-house and its efforts prove to be unsatisfactory to the city, franchisee shall seek the services of a professional locating contractor. After being notified in writing by the city that an unsatisfactory situation still exists, the franchisee shall rectify any problems within ten (10) days or be considered in violation of this franchise. 
(6)  Franchisee shall use commercial-grade locating equipment. The franchisee further shall provide qualified personnel to ensure continuity and accuracy for all locating assignments. 
(7)  Franchisee shall inspect its cable system for radiation and signal leakage at the time cable system locates are performed to ensure that another franchised cable television operator does not incur liability for pre-existing radiation and signal leakage. Franchisee shall keep its system free from spurious radiation. 
(8)  Franchisee's system shall be capable of twenty-four (24) hours per day of continuous operation. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § XIII, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:14. - Complaint procedures. 
(a)  The franchisee shall maintain a local business office inside the city for subscribers to conduct business during regular business hours, so that complaints regarding cable service may be promptly reported to the company. Whenever feasible, the franchisee shall make reasonable effort to remedy complaints within one business day of their receipt. In the event of a total interruption of service to a subscriber, the affected subscriber shall, upon timely request, be entitled to receive a credit for the time of service interruption, starting from the time of notification to the franchisee concerning the service interruption until service is restored; provided, however, no credit shall be given for service interruptions of less than twenty-four (24) continuous hours. Should a subscriber have an unresolved complaint regarding cable service, the subscriber shall be entitled to file his complaint with the city clerk. The franchisee shall notify each subscriber at the time of initial subscription to the service of the procedures for reporting and resolving service complaints. 
(b)  When there have been multiple similar service complaints, or where there exists other evidence which, in the judgment of the city, casts doubt on the reliability or quality of cable service, the city shall have the right and authority to require the franchisee to test, analyze and report on the performance of the system. Any such requirement shall be made by written notice to the franchisee. Franchisee shall fully cooperate with the city in performing such testing and shall prepare results and a report within sixty (60) days after receipt of the notice. 
(c)  The city's rights under this section shall be limited to requiring tests, analyses and reports covering specified subjects and characteristics based on said complaints or other evidence when and under such circumstances as the city has reasonable grounds to believe that the complaints or other evidence requires that tests be performed to protect the public against substandard cable service. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § XIV, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:15. - Rights of individuals. 
(a)  Franchisee shall not deny service, deny access or otherwise discriminate against subscribers, channel users, or other users, or any citizen on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, sex or sexual orientation. Franchisee shall comply at all times with all other present and future applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations, and all executive and administrative orders relating to nondiscrimination which are incorporated and made part of this franchise by reference. 
(b)  No signals of Class IV cable communications channel shall be transmitted from a subscriber terminal for purposes of monitoring individual viewing patterns or practices without the express written permission of the subscriber. No person shall be required to grant such permission. The franchisee, however, shall be entitled to: 
(1)  Conduct system wide or individually addressed "sweeps" for the purpose of verifying system integrity, provided such sweeps do not monitor or reveal what subscribers are viewing; and 
(2)  Conduct individually addressed sweeps for the purpose of controlling return-path transmission or billing for pay services. 
(c)  Pursuant to the requirements of the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, the franchisee shall be required to notify subscribers annually as to their rights to subscriber privacy under the Act. The franchisee shall be prohibited from disclosure of any personally identifiable information except as provided for under the Act. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § XV, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:16. - Access equipment. 
(a)  To assist the city in the production of programming for the access channel, the franchisee shall, upon activation of the sixty-channel cable system and obtaining a total of seven hundred fifty (750) subscribers and receipt of a written request of the city describing its specific equipment needs, purchase and provide to the city programming production equipment, which total cost shall not exceed twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), which shall, upon delivery, become the property of the city. At the aforesaid time, should franchisee be the only franchisee contracted with the city (but only after the sixty-day period for acceptance stated in Section 8:4(a)), franchisee agrees to provide thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00) of equipment instead of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00). If another franchisee is later accepted by the city during the term of this franchise, the city agrees to rebate to franchisee the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
(b)  Upon completion and activation of the sixty-channel capacity system, franchisee shall install and activate a direct line from the City Hall which would provide use of that line of delivery of programming for the government access channel. Upon completion and activation of the sixty-channel capacity system and upon request of the city, the franchisee shall install and activate a direct line from the Cajun Cultural Arts Center, also for delivery of programming for the government access channel. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § XVI, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:17. - Liability and indemnification. 
(a)  Prior to the effective date of this franchise and at all times during the term of the franchise, franchisee shall obtain and maintain, pay all premiums for and file with the city executed duplicate copies and receipts evidencing the payment of premiums for, the following: 
(1)  A general comprehensive public liability policy indemnifying, defending and saving harmless the city, its elected officials, agents, and employees from any and all claims by any person whatsoever on account of injury to or death of a person or persons occasioned by the operations of franchisee under this franchise, with a minimum liability of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per personal injury or death of any one person with one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for personal injury or death of any two (2) or more persons in any one occurrence. 
(2)  Property damage insurance indemnifying, defending and saving harmless the city, its elected officials, agents and employees from and against all claims by any person whatsoever for property damage occasioned by the operation of franchisee under this franchise, with a minimum liability of two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for property damage to any one person and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for property damage to two (2) or more persons in any one occurrence. 
(b)  Such insurance as provided for in this section shall be kept in full force and effect by franchisee during the existence of and until after the removal of all poles, wires, cables, underground conduits, manholes, and other conductors and fixtures installed by or at the direction of franchisee incident to the maintenance and operation of the cable system. 
(c)  All of the foregoing insurance contracts shall be in form satisfactory to the city and shall be issued and maintained by companies authorized to do business in the State of Louisiana, and shall require thirty (30) days' written notice of any cancellation of both the city and franchisee herein, and copies of said policies shall be filed with the city. 
(d)  In lieu of filing copies of said policies and evidence of premium payments, franchisee may submit a certificate of insurance evidencing the required coverages and providing thirty (30) days' prior written notice to the city of any material changes in or cancellations of the coverages evidenced herein. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § XVII, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:18. - Unauthorized connections or modifications. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to make any connection, extension or division, whether physically, acoustically, inductively, electronically or otherwise, with or to any segment of a franchised cable system for any purpose whatsoever without the express consent of the franchisee. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to willfully interfere, tamper, remove, obstruct or damage any part, segment or content of a franchised cable television system network for any purpose whatsoever. 
(c)  Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § XVIII, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:19. - Forfeiture or revocation. 
(a)  Grounds for revocation. The city reserves the right to revoke this franchise and rescind all rights and privileges granted herewith in the following circumstances, each of which shall represent a default and breach under this franchise: 
(1)  If the franchisee shall materially default in the performance of any of the substantial obligations under this franchise. 
(2)  If the franchisee shall fail to provide or maintain in full force and effect the liability and indemnification coverage as required herein. 
(3)  The franchisee becomes insolvent, unable or unwilling to pay its debts, or is adjudged bankrupt. 
(4)  The franchisee fails to restore service after ten (10) consecutive days of interrupted system wide service, except when approval of such interruption is obtained from the city. 
(5)  Material misrepresentation in franchisee's audited financial statement. 
(b)  Request for termination. The city shall make written demand that the franchisee comply with any such requirement, limitation, term, condition, rule or regulation or correct any action deemed cause for revocation. If franchisee does not commence within thirty (30) days following such written demand and continuously pursue to remedy the action or inaction, the city shall place its request for termination of the franchise upon a regular city council meeting agenda. The city shall cause to be served upon the franchisee at least ten (10) days prior to the date of such city council meeting a written notice of this intent to request such termination and the time and the place of the meeting, notice of which shall be published by the city clerk in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. 
(c)  Determination by council. The city council shall hear any persons interested therein, and shall determine in its discretion whether or not any failure or refusal by the company was with just cause. 
(d)  Failure with just cause. If such failure or refusal by the franchisee was with just cause, the city council shall direct the franchisee to comply within such time and manner and upon such terms and conditions as are reasonable. 
(e)  Termination of franchise. If the city council shall determine such failure or refusal by the franchisee was without just cause, the city council shall then grant a period of not more than ninety (90) days for franchisee to commence and continue to pursue all necessary remedies. Upon the expiration of ninety (90) days, city council may, at a regular or special city council meeting, by resolution, declare that the franchise is terminated. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § XIX, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:20. - Miscellaneous provisions. 
(a)  Compliance with rules and regulations. The franchisee agrees to comply fully with all local ordinances, state and federal laws, and with all rules issued by all regulatory agencies having authority over cable television matters, now or hereafter in existence. 
(b)  Validity. If any section, sentence, clause or phrase of the ordinance from which this part is derived is held invalid or unconstitutional, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not affect the validity of the remainder of such ordinance, and any portions in conflict are hereby repealed. 
(c)  Captions. The captions to sections are inserted solely for information and shall not affect the meaning or interpretation of such ordinance. 
(d)  Delivery of notices. All notices hereunder shall be made in writing and shall be delivered by U. S. Mail or by hand, unless otherwise provided herein; if to the city, to Post Office Box 1106, Eunice, Louisiana 70535, and if to Cable TV of Acadiana, Inc., Post Office Box 1047, Eunice, Louisiana 70535. 
(e)  Effect. This part shall be in effect from and after its adoption by the city council. 
(f)  Interpretation. This franchise shall be interpreted in accordance with the laws of the State of Louisiana. 
(Ord. No. 12-89, § XX, 12-12-89) 
PART II. - EUNICE/TRI-PARISH CABLE-VISION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 13-89, §§ I-XX, adopted Dec. 12, 1989, was not enacted as a specific amendment or addition to the Code, but is included herein as Part II of Subchapter A, §§ 8:21-8:40, at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 8:21. - Short title. 
    This ordinance shall be known as the "Eunice/Tri-Parish Cable-Vision, Inc., Cable Television Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § I, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:22. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this part, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words in the plural include the singular and words in the singular include the plural. The word "shall" is mandatory and "may" is permissive. Words not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning. Whenever the masculine gender is used it includes the feminine gender. 
    Cable antenna service means the lowest priced service which shall be offered at a reduced rate from full basic service and shall include the retransmission of local television broadcast signals and the access channel. 
    Cable service or CATV service means the one-way transmission to subscribers of video programming or other programming service, and subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection of such video programming or other programming service. 
    Cable system or CATV system means a facility, consisting of a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception and control equipment, that is designed to provide cable service which includes video programming and which is provided to multiple subscribers within a community, but such terms do not include: 
(1)  A facility that serves only to retransmit the television signals of one or more television broadcast stations; 
(2)  A facility that serves only subscribers in one or more multiple-unit dwellings under common ownership, control or management unless such facility or facilities use any public right-of-way; 
(3)  A facility of a common carrier which is subject, in whole or in part, to the provisions of Title II of the Communications Act of 1934, as amended; except that such facility shall be considered a cable system (other than for purposes of Section 621(c) of the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984) to the extent such facility is used in the transmission of video programming directly to subscribers; or 
(4)  Any facilities of any electric utility used solely for operating its electric utility systems. 
    City means the City of Eunice, as represented by the elected officials thereof, or the area within the territorial limits of the city now or hereafter annexed. 
    Class IV channel means a signaling path provided by a cable communications system to transmit signals of any type from a subscriber to another point in the cable communications system. 
    FCC means the Federal Communications Commission and any legally appointed or elected successor. 
    Franchisee or company means Tri-Parish Cable-Vision, Inc., or its lawful successor, transferee or assignee. 
    Full basic service means that package of services which includes cable antenna service and any additional programming services offered by the franchisee in one or more tiers or levels of service; provided, that it shall not include services offered on a per-program or per-channel basis. 
    Gross revenues means all revenue received by the franchisee from subscribers within the city and that portion of advertising revenue received by the franchisee, including, but not limited to, the CVN channel and all other similar channels, and allocated to the city based on a percentage of the number of subscribers in the city as compared to total subscribers served by the cable system; provided, however, that this shall not include any taxes on services furnished by the franchisee herein imposed directly upon any subscriber or user by the local or other governmental unit and collected by the franchisee on behalf of said governmental unit. The advertising revenue referred to herein shall include such revenues earned by franchisee, whether paid directly to franchisee or to its parent company, a company controlling, controlled by or under common control with the franchisee and/or any affiliate. 
    Installation means the connection of the system from feeder cable to a subscriber's terminal. 
    Monitoring means observing a communications signal, or the absence of a signal, where the observer is neither the subscriber nor the franchisee, whether the signal is observed by visual or electronic means, for any purpose whatsoever. Monitoring shall not include system wide, nonindividually addressed sweeps of the system for purposes of verifying system integrity, controlling return path transmission or billing for pay services. 
    Person means an individual, partnership, association, organization, corporation or any lawful successor, transferee or assignee of said individual, partnership, association, organization or corporation. 
    Property of franchisee means all property owned by a franchisee in the operation of a CATV system or service located in the city under the authority of a franchise granted pursuant to this part. 
    Rates means those charges assessed by the franchisee to the subscribers or users of the cable television system. Rates refer not only to charges assessed but also to charges if set at zero. 
    State means the State of Louisiana. 
    Street or road or right-of-way means the surface of and the space above and below any publicly owned or maintained property or right-of-way, including, but not limited to, any street, road, highway, freeway, land, path, alley, court, sidewalk, parkway or drive, now or hereafter existing as such within the city. 
    Subscriber means any person or entity lawfully receiving any portion of the cable television service of the franchisee pursuant to this part. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § II, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:23. - Grant of franchise. 
(a)  The city council of the city hereby grants to Tri-Parish Cable-Vision, Inc., the nonexclusive right and franchise (the "franchise") to construct, operate and maintain a cable television system in the city for the purpose of receiving, amplifying, originating and distributing television and radio signals for the use of the citizens and residents of the city. 
(b)  The franchisee shall be authorized to construct or have constructed, operate and maintain a CATV system and to engage in the business of providing a CATV service in the city, and for that purpose to erect, install, construct, repair, replace, reconstruct and maintain such property as may be necessary and appurtenant to the CATV system, provided, however, that before such property may be placed within any street or road, the proper permission and authority to do so must be obtained by the franchisee from any and all other agencies of competent jurisdiction, and to use, operate and provide similar facilities or properties rented or leased from other persons. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to engage in the construction, operation or maintenance of a CATV system or provide a CATV service in the city unless such person or the person for whom such action is being taken shall have first obtained and shall currently hold a valid franchise. 
(d)  It is unlawful for any telephone, telegraph, or power company or any other public utility company or person to lease or otherwise make available to any other person any poles, lines, facilities, equipment, or other property for use in connection with the operation of a CATV system or service unless such other person holds a valid franchise. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § III, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:24. - Acceptance; effective date. 
(a)  Within sixty (60) days after the effective date of the ordinance from which this Part II is derived, the franchisee shall file with the city clerk an acceptance acknowledged before a notary public. Such acceptance shall acknowledge that the franchisee agrees to be bound by and to comply with the provisions of such ordinance and shall be in a form acceptable to the city. 
(b)  Concurrently with the filing of the written acceptance, the franchisee shall file with the city clerk the proof of insurance as specified in Section 8:37 hereof. 
(c)  The franchise granted pursuant to the ordinance from which this part is derived shall take effect and be in full force from and after final passage by the city council, subject to the approval by the city of the acceptance and evidence of the insurance as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § IV, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:25. - Term of franchise; renewal. 
    The duration of this franchise granted shall be ten (10) years from the effective date. This franchise shall be renewable for additional terms of ten (10) years each, upon terms satisfactory to both the city and the franchisee. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § V, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:26. - Transfer of cable television system. 
    Neither this franchise nor any cable system servicing the city shall be transferred or assigned without the prior written consent of the city council, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § VI, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:27. - Franchise fees. 
    The franchisee shall pay to the city for the privilege of constructing, operating and maintaining the CATV system, and for the privilege of providing the CATV service, and for the cost of the city regulating and supporting the system, a sum of five (5) percent of its gross revenues, as defined herein. Payment shall be made annually by the first day of March for the preceding calendar year. Acceptance of any payment shall not be construed as an accord by the city that the sum is correct, nor a release of any possible claim for additional funds, subject to an annual audit to be conducted at city's option. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § VII, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:28. - Rates and charges. 
(a)  The rates of the franchisee shall not be regulated by the city, except as may be allowed by the applicable state and federal law or by regulations of the FCC, or any other rules issued by all regulatory agencies now or hereafter in existence. 
(b)  Except as and to the extent elsewhere provided herein, the franchisee shall not, as to rates, charges, services, facilities, rules, regulations or in other respects, make or grant any preferences or advantages to any person connected to its system, nor subject any such person to any prejudice or disadvantage; provided, that nothing herein contained shall be deemed to prevent the establishment of a graduated scale of charges and classified rate schedules to which any customer coming within such classifications would be entitled, including, but not limited to, the classification of courtesy accounts provided at no charge. 
(c)  Before putting any rate changes into effect, the franchisee shall be required to notify all customers at least thirty (30) days and the city at least forty-five (45) days before such rate changes are to become effective. 
(d)  The franchisee shall provide, upon written request from the city and at no charge, one outlet (standard drop) of full basic cable service to the City Hall, fire and police stations, libraries, and all public and parochial schools and colleges located within the franchise area. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § VIII, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:29. - Limitations of franchise. 
    In addition to the limitations otherwise herein, the franchisee is subject to the following limitations: 
(a)  The franchisee shall at all times during the life of any franchise hereunder be subject to all lawful exercise of the police power by the city and other duly authorized regulatory state and federal bodies and shall comply with any and all ordinances which the city has adopted or shall adopt applying to the public generally, and shall be subject to all present and future laws of the State of Louisiana and the United States. 
(b)  Time shall be of the essence in this franchise. The franchisee shall not be relieved of its obligations to promptly comply with provisions of this franchise by the failure of the city to enforce prompt compliance. Failure of the city to enforce any breach by the franchisee shall not constitute a waiver of those violations by the city. 
(c)  The franchise granted hereunder shall not relieve the franchisee of any obligation under any pole or conduit use agreements from others maintaining poles or conduits in the streets of the city whenever the franchisee finds it necessary to make use of said poles or conduits. 
(d)  Nothing in this franchise shall in any way or to any extent be construed to waive, modify or abridge the city's right of eminent domain in respect to the franchisee. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § IX, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:30. - Initial service area; annexation. 
(a)  The franchisee shall make service available to at least fifty (50) percent of all potential subscribers who reside within the city limits within one year of the obtaining of all pole attachment agreements and permits by the franchisee, and shall make service available to the remaining fifty (50) percent of all potential subscribers residing within the City of Eunice within two (2) years after the obtaining of all pole attachment agreements and permits by the franchisee. 
(b)  The franchisee shall extend service to areas annexed into the city within one year of annexation and the obtaining of all pole attachment agreements and permits by the franchisee; provided, that such areas shall have a minimum density of thirty (30) homes per mile of cable plant required to serve such homes, as measured from the nearest terminal point of franchisee's activated cable plant. In the event that an annexed area does not meet the minimum density standard set forth in this paragraph at the time of annexation, service shall be provided to such annexed area within one year of the time the minimum density standard is met and the obtaining of all pole attachment agreements and permits by the franchisee. 
(c)  The franchisee shall diligently and without delay pursue the acquisition of pole attachment agreements and permits, as time is of the essence, and franchisee shall proceed with all due diligence to acquire said pole attachment agreements and permits. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § X, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:31. - Conditions on use of streets and roads. 
(a)  The poles used for the distribution system shall be, to the extent possible, those erected and maintained by either the power company or the telephone company, or both, whenever agreement can be reached with the owners of such poles. 
(b)  The installation of lines and facilities, including service drops to subscribers, shall be made underground in areas where the telephone and power lines are underground. Any existing aboveground facilities shall be placed underground when required by the city and when both telephone and power lines are also placed underground. 
(c)  The franchisee shall, at its expense, protect, support, temporarily disconnect or relocate in the same street or other public place any property of the franchisee when required by the city by reason of traffic conditions, public safety, street closing or abandonment, highway or street construction, change or establishment of street grade, installation of sewer drains, water pipes, power lines, signal lines, or any other types of structures or improvements, and the city shall not be liable for any disturbance of the franchisee's installations resulting therefrom. The franchisee may do such tree trimming or other maintenance as shall be necessary to maintain its lines and cables and other property in good working order after first obtaining the required and proper permission to do so from the property owners being affected and any and all other agencies of competent jurisdiction. 
(d)  Whenever the franchisee takes up or disturbs any pavement, sidewalk or other improvement of any street or road, the same shall be restored to reasonably as good condition as before entry, all in accordance with standards, regulations and policies of the city. Any opening or obstruction in the streets shall be guarded and protected at all times by the placement of adequate barriers, fences or boardings, the bounds of which shall be clearly designated by warning lights of approved type. 
(e)  In the event of the failure by the franchisee to complete any work required by this section or any work required by city ordinance within the time established and to the satisfaction of the city, the city may cause such work to be done and the franchisee shall reimburse the city the costs thereof within thirty (30) days after receipt of any itemized list of such costs. 
(f)  Any poles, cables, electronic equipment or other appurtenances of the franchisee to be installed in, under, over, along, across or upon a street shall be located so as to cause minimum interference with the rights of other users of the streets or of owners of property which adjoins any of the streets. 
(g)  The franchisee shall, upon reasonable notice from any person holding a building moving permit issued by the city, temporarily alter its facilities to permit the moving of such building. The actual cost of such altering shall be borne by the person requesting the altering and the franchisee shall have the right to request payment in advance. For this provision of the franchise, "reasonable notice" shall be construed to mean at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to move. 
(h)  In the event the continued use of a street is denied for any reason, the franchisee will make every effort to provide service over alternate routes. 
(i)  If at any time in case of fire or disaster in the city it shall become necessary in the judgment of the mayor or his designee to cut or move any of the wires, cables, amplifiers, appliances or appurtenances thereto of the franchisee, such cutting or moving may be done and any repairs rendered necessary thereby shall be made by the franchisee at its sole expense. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § XI, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:32. - System capacity. 
(a)  Within sixty (60) days of the effective date of this franchise, the franchisee shall proceed with all due diligence to construct and/or upgrade and rebuild its cable system to sixty-channel capacity, and shall activate the sixty-channel capacity system throughout all areas of the city that are physically being served by the franchisee within one year of the franchisee having acquired all pole attachment agreements and permits. 
(b)  Upon activation of the sixty-channel capacity system, the franchisee shall make one channel in the cable antenna service available to the city for governmental and educational access use, at no cost to the city, such access channel to be available to the city throughout the term of this franchise and extended terms. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § XII, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:33. - Construction and operational standards. 
(a)  Franchisee shall construct, install, operate and maintain its system in a manner consistent with all laws, ordinances, governmental requirements and FCC technical standards, and in accordance with the highest industry standards in order to assure subscriber receipt of the best and most desirable form of service. 
(b)  All installation and maintenance of electronic equipment shall be of a permanent nature, durable, and installed in accordance with the applicable sections of the current edition of the National Electric Safety Code and all state and local codes where applicable. 
(c)  The franchisee shall put, keep and maintain all parts of the system in good condition throughout the entire franchise period. 
(d)  The franchisee shall render efficient service, make repairs promptly, and interrupt service only for good cause and for the shortest time possible. Such interruptions, insofar as possible, shall be preceded by notice and shall occur during periods of minimum system use. 
(e)  The franchisee shall not allow its operations to interfere with television reception of persons not served by franchisee, nor shall the system interfere with, obstruct or hinder in any manner the operation of the various utilities servicing the residents within the confines of the city. 
(f)  The following requirements are to be met by the franchisee to ensure a process for locating, reporting and repairing damages to a cable system: 
(1)  Franchisee shall furnish to all franchised cable television operators the names and current phone numbers of persons responsible for receiving damage reports. These persons shall be in a position to dispatch information to field personnel expeditiously. 
(2)  Franchisee shall join the "One-Call Concepts" locating organization, or any successor or replacement organization, upon acceptance of this franchise and shall follow all rules and regulations established by that organization. 
(3)  Franchisee shall handle all locate requests promptly in accordance with the "One-Call Concepts" procedure; or such procedures as may be established by any successor or replacement organization. 
(4)  Franchisee shall handle all make-ready requests and perform any required joint utility ride-outs promptly to ensure a smooth working relationship for all parties involved. 
(5)  Franchisee has the option to either perform its own locating services or contract out these services. If the franchisee chooses to perform these services in-house and its efforts prove to be unsatisfactory to the city, franchisee shall seek the services of a professional locating contractor. After being notified in writing by the city that an unsatisfactory situation still exists, the franchisee shall rectify any problems within ten (10) days or be considered in violation of this franchise. 
(6)  Franchisee shall use commercial-grade locating equipment. The franchisee further shall provide qualified personnel to ensure continuity and accuracy for all locating assignments. 
(7)  Franchisee shall inspect its cable system for radiation and signal leakage at the time cable system locates are performed to ensure that another franchised cable television operator does not incur liability for pre-existing radiation and signal leakage. Franchisee shall keep its system free from spurious radiation. 
(8)  Franchisee's system shall be capable of twenty-four (24) hours per day of continuous operation. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § XIII, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:34. - Complaint procedures. 
(a)  The franchisee shall maintain a local business office inside the city for subscribers to conduct business during regular business hours, so that complaints regarding cable service may be promptly reported to the company. Whenever feasible, the franchisee shall make reasonable effort to remedy complaints within one business day of their receipt. In the event of a total interruption of service to a subscriber, the affected subscriber shall, upon timely request, be entitled to receive a credit for the time of service interruption, starting from the time of notification to the franchisee concerning the service interruption until service is restored; provided, however, no credit shall be given for service interruptions of less than twenty-four (24) continuous hours. Should a subscriber have an unresolved complaint regarding cable service, the subscriber shall be entitled to file his complaint with the city clerk. The franchisee shall notify each subscriber at the time of initial subscription to the service of the procedures for reporting and resolving service complaints. 
(b)  When there have been multiple similar service complaints, or where there exists other evidence which, in the judgment of the city, casts doubt on the reliability or quality of cable service, the city shall have the right and authority to require the franchisee to test, analyze and report on the performance of the system. Any such requirement shall be made by written notice to the franchisee. Franchisee shall fully cooperate with the city in performing such testing and shall prepare results and a report within sixty (60) days after receipt of the notice. 
(c)  The city's rights under this section shall be limited to requiring tests, analyses and reports covering specified subjects and characteristics based on said complaints or other evidence when and under such circumstances as the city has reasonable grounds to believe that the complaints or other evidence requires that tests be performed to protect the public against substandard cable service. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § XIV, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:35. - Rights of individuals. 
(a)  Franchisee shall not deny service, deny access or otherwise discriminate against subscribers, channel users, or other users, or any citizen on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, sex or sexual orientation. Franchisee shall comply at all times with all other present and future applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations, and all executive and administrative orders relating to nondiscrimination which are incorporated and made part of this franchise by reference. 
(b)  No signals of Class IV cable communications channel shall be transmitted from a subscriber terminal for purposes of monitoring individual viewing patterns or practices without the express written permission of the subscriber. No person shall be required to grant such permission. The franchisee, however, shall be entitled to: 
(1)  Conduct system wide or individually addressed "sweeps" for the purpose of verifying system integrity, provided such sweeps do not monitor or reveal what subscribers are viewing; and 
(2)  Conduct individually addressed sweeps for the purpose of controlling return-path transmission or billing for pay services. 
(c)  Pursuant to the requirements of the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, the franchisee shall be required to notify subscribers annually as to their rights to subscriber privacy under the Act. The franchisee shall be prohibited from disclosure of any personally identifiable information except as provided for under the Act. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § XV, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:36. - Access equipment. 
(a)  To assist the city in the production of programming for the access channel, the franchisee shall, after one year of the obtaining of all pole attachment agreements and permits by the franchisee, and receipt of a written request of the city describing its specific equipment needs, purchase and provide to the city programming production equipment, which total cost shall not exceed fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00), which shall, upon delivery, become the property of the city. At the aforesaid time, should franchisee be the only franchisee contracted with the city (but only after the sixty-day period for acceptance stated in Section 8:24(a)), franchisee agrees to provide thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00) of equipment instead of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00). If another franchisee is later accepted by the city during the term of this franchise, the city agrees to rebate to franchisee the sum of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00). 
(b)  Upon completion and activation of the sixty-channel capacity system, franchisee shall install and activate a direct line from the City Hall which would provide use of that line of delivery of programming for the government access channel. Upon completion and activation of the sixty-channel capacity system and upon request of the city, the franchisee shall install and activate a direct line from the Cajun Cultural Arts Center, also for delivery of programming for the government access channel. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § XVI, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:37. - Liability and indemnification. 
(a)  Prior to the effective date of this franchise and at all times during the term of the franchise, franchisee shall obtain and maintain, pay all premiums for and file with the city executed duplicate copies and receipts evidencing the payment of premiums for, the following: 
(1)  A general comprehensive public liability policy indemnifying, defending and saving harmless the city, its elected officials, agents, and employees from any and all claims by any person whatsoever on account of injury to or death of a person or persons occasioned by the operations of franchisee under this franchise, with a minimum liability of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per personal injury or death of any one person with one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for personal injury or death of any two (2) or more persons in any one occurrence. 
(2)  Property damage insurance indemnifying, defending and saving harmless the city, its elected officials, agents and employees from and against all claims by any person whatsoever for property damage occasioned by the operation of franchisee under this franchise, with a minimum liability of two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for property damage to any one person and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for property damage to two (2) or more persons in any one occurrence. 
(b)  Such insurance as provided for in this section shall be kept in full force and effect by franchisee during the existence of and until after the removal of all poles, wires, cables, underground conduits, manholes, and other conductors and fixtures installed by or at the direction of franchisee incident to the maintenance and operation of the cable system. 
(c)  All of the foregoing insurance contracts shall be in form satisfactory to the city and shall be issued and maintained by companies authorized to do business in the State of Louisiana, and shall require thirty (30) days' written notice of any cancellation of both the city and franchisee herein, and copies of said policies shall be filed with the city. 
(d)  In lieu of filing copies of said policies and evidence of premium payments, franchisee may submit a certificate of insurance evidencing the required coverages and providing thirty (30) days' prior written notice to the city of any material changes in or cancellations of the coverages evidenced herein. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § XVII, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:38. - Unauthorized connections or modifications. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to make any connection, extension or division, whether physically, acoustically, inductively, electronically or otherwise, with or to any segment of a franchised cable system for any purpose whatsoever without the express consent of the franchisee. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to willfully interfere, tamper, remove, obstruct or damage any part, segment or content of a franchised cable television system network for any purpose whatsoever. 
(c)  Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § XVIII, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:39. - Forfeiture or revocation. 
(a)  Grounds for revocation. The city reserves the right to revoke this franchise and rescind all rights and privileges granted herewith in the following circumstances, each of which shall represent a default and breach under this franchise: 
(1)  If the franchisee shall materially default in the performance of any of the substantial obligations under this franchise. 
(2)  If the franchisee shall fail to provide or maintain in full force and effect the liability and indemnification coverage as required herein. 
(3)  The franchisee becomes insolvent, unable or unwilling to pay its debts, or is adjudged bankrupt. 
(4)  The franchisee fails to restore service after ten (10) consecutive days of interrupted systemwide service, except when approval of such interruption is obtained from the city. 
(5)  Material misrepresentation in franchisee's audited financial statement. 
(b)  Request for termination. The city shall make written demand that the franchisee comply with any such requirement, limitation, term, condition, rule or regulation or correct any action deemed cause for revocation. If franchisee does not commence within thirty (30) days following such written demand and continuously pursue to remedy the action or inaction, the city shall place its request for termination of the franchise upon a regular city council meeting agenda. The city shall cause to be served upon the franchisee at least ten (10) days prior to the date of such city council meeting a written notice of this intent to request such termination and the time and the place of the meeting, notice of which shall be published by the city clerk in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. 
(c)  Determination by council. The city council shall hear any persons interested therein, and shall determine in its discretion whether or not any failure or refusal by the company was with just cause. 
(d)  Failure with just cause. If such failure or refusal by the franchisee was with just cause, the city council shall direct the franchisee to comply within such time and manner and upon such terms and conditions as are reasonable. 
(e)  Termination of franchise. If the city council shall determine such failure or refusal by the franchisee was without just cause, the city council shall then grant a period of not more than ninety (90) days for franchisee to commence and continue to pursue all necessary remedies. Upon the expiration of ninety (90) days, city council may, at a regular or special city council meeting, by resolution, declare that the franchise is terminated. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § XIX, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 8:40. - Miscellaneous provisions. 
(a)  Compliance with rules and regulations. The franchisee agrees to comply fully with all local ordinances, state and federal laws, and with all rules issued by all regulatory agencies having authority over cable television matters, now or hereafter in existence. 
(b)  Validity. If any section, sentence, clause or phrase of the ordinance from which this part is derived is held invalid or unconstitutional, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not affect the validity of the remainder of such ordinance, and any portions in conflict are hereby repealed. 
(c)  Captions. The captions to sections are inserted solely for information and shall not affect the meaning or interpretation of such ordinance. 
(d)  Delivery of notices. All notices hereunder shall be made in writing and shall be delivered by U. S. Mail or by hand, unless otherwise provided herein; if to the city, to Post Office Box 1106, Eunice, Louisiana 70535, and if Tri-Parish Cable-Vision, Inc., Post Office Box 689, Eunice, Louisiana 70535. 
(e)  Effect. This part shall be in effect from and after its adoption by the city council. 
(f)  Interpretation. This franchise shall be interpreted in accordance with the laws of the State of Louisiana. 
(Ord. No. 13-89, § XX, 12-12-89) 
PART III. - RENAISSANCE MEDIA LLC 

Sec. 8:41. - Definitions. 
    Unless the particular provision or the context requires, the definitions and provisions contained in this section shall govern the construction, meaning and application and the words and phrases used herein. The definition of each word or phrase shall constitute, to the extent applicable, the definition of each word or phrase which is derivative from it or from which it is a derivative as the case may be. 
(a)  City means City of Eunice acting through its city council. It also means, where appropriate the geographical area over which the city has jurisdiction. 
(b)  City council means the city council of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, and the city's lawful successors, if any. 
(c)  Franchising authority means the City of Eunice, Louisiana, acting through its city council. 
(d)  Grantee means Renaissance Media LLC, a corporation organized and existing under the laws of the State of Louisiana and lawful successors, if any, as approved by the city. 
(e)  Franchise area sometimes referred to as "the city" means the entire area, with no exceptions whatsoever, within the geographical limits of the City of Eunice, as it now exists or may be expanded during the term of any franchise granted hereunder. 
(f)  Cable Act or Federal Law mean collectively the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, as amended; the Cable Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, as amended; and the Telecommunications Act of 1996, as amended. 
(g)  Franchise means this agreement, as well as all referenced specifications and exhibits thereto, as adopted by ordinance and as amended or renewed by ordinance, and as accepted by grantee. 
(h)  Gross revenues means receipts derived directly or indirectly by grantee, arising from or attributable to the operation of the cable system in the franchise area, including but not limited to the following: 
1.  All amounts received from subscribers to entertainment and nonentertainment services, except for those services offered where a competitive provider is operating without a franchise and/or not being assessed fees, unless the city is prevented from so assessing said fees due to state or federal law, with no deductions whatsoever, except those provided for specifically herein; 
2.  Receipts from all charges for the sale of commercial time and for the insertion of commercial advertisements on the system. 
3.  Receipts from all charges for the lease or other use of cable channels, studios and equipment; 
4.  Receipts for all charges for the rental or use of equipment and services necessary for the utilization of the system, and from the provision of subscriber and other services; 
5.  Receipts paid to the grantee, directly or indirectly, from the sale, exchange, cablecast, broadcast, or other use of any programming developed for use on access channels; 
6.  Receipts from the sale or lease of time or channel capacity on any institutional network, to nongovernmental entities owned or operated by grantee in connection with the system; 
"Gross revenue" shall not include refunds issued to subscribers in the normal course of business, late fees, NSF check charges, collection fees, and administrative fees, and local, state or federal sales, franchise fees or entertainment taxes, if any, collected by grantee for payment to the franchising authority. 
"Administrative fees" as defined in the preceding paragraph shall be limited to those fees charged to a customer for changes to the customer's account where said changes can be implemented through a paperwork only action and/or where those changes can be implemented with an entry into the company's billing system, but where "new services to the customer" are not being activated for said customer; however, the entry could cause a change of service for the customer where an individual representing the company does not have to physically visit the resident of said customer. The term administrative fees shall not include any regular recurring charges to a customer's account. 
(i)  Public right-of-way means the surface of, and the space above and below, any public street, highway, freeway, bridge, land path, alley, court, boulevard, sidewalk, parkway, way, lane, public way, drive, circle, or other public right-of-way, including, but not limited to public utility easements, dedicated utility strips, of rights-of-way dedicated for compatible uses and any temporary or permanent fixtures or improvements located thereon now or hereafter held by the franchising authority in the franchise area which shall entitle the franchising authority and the grantee to the use thereof for the purpose of installing, operating, repairing, and maintaining the system within the guidelines set by the franchising authority. 
"Public right-of-way" shall also mean any easement now or hereafter held by the franchising authority within the franchise area for the purpose of public travel, or for utility or public service use or dedicated for compatible uses, and shall include other easements or rights-of-way as shall within their proper use and meaning entitle the franchising authority and the grantee to the use thereof within the guidelines set by the franchising authority for the purpose of installing and operating the grantee's system over poles, wires, cables, conductors, ducts, conduits, vaults, manholes, amplifiers, appliances, attachments, and other property as may be ordinarily necessary and pertinent to the system. 
(j)  System or cable system means a facility, consisting of a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception, and control equipment that is designed to provide cable service which includes video programming and which is provided to multiple subscribers within a community, but such term does not include (A) a facility that serves only to retransmit the television signals of one or more television broadcast stations; (B) a facility that serves subscribers without using any public right-of-way; (C) a facility of a common carrier which is subject, in whole or in part, to the provisions of Title II of the Cable Act, except that such facility shall be considered a cable system (other than for purposes of Section 621(c) [of the Cable Act]) to the extent such facility is used in the transmission of video programming directly to subscribers, unless the extent of such use is solely to provide interactive on-demand services; (D) an open video system that complies with Section 653 of the Cable Act; or (E) any facilities of any electric utility used solely for operating its electric utility systems. 
(k)  Cable channel or channel means a 6 Megahertz (MHz) frequency band of the electromagnetic frequency spectrum which is used in the cable system and which is capable of delivering a television channel (as defined by the FCC). It shall also mean appropriate, channel capacity for transmission of HDTV signals. 
(l)  Cable service means (i) the one-way transmission to subscribers of video programming or other programming service, and (ii) subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection or use of such video programming or any other communications service. 
(m)  Control or controlling interest means actual working control in whatever manner exercised.
