f.  Being within six (6) feet of any vehicle registered to a known unlawful drug user, possessor, or seller, or a person for whom there is an outstanding warrant for a crime involving drug-related activity. 
g.  Repeatedly beckoning to, stopping, or attempting to stop passersby or engaging passersby in conversation. 
h.  Repeatedly stopping or attempting to stop motor vehicle operators by hailing, waving of arms, or any other bodily gesture. 
i.  Circling an area in a motor vehicle and repeatedly beckoning to, contacting, or attempting to stop pedestrians. 
(4)  The subject of any court order, which directs the person to stay out of any specified area as a condition of release from custody, a condition of probation, parole, or other supervision or any court order, in a criminal or civil case involving illegal drug activity. 
(5)  Evicted as the result of his illegal drug activity and ordered to stay out of a specified area affected by drug-related activity. 
(6)  Taking flight upon the appearance of a police officer. 
(7)  Trying to conceal himself or any object within his possession that reasonably could be involved in an unlawful drug-related activity. 
(Ord. No. 09-06(A), 9-12-06; Ord. No. 0915(B), 10-13-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0915(B), adopted Oct. 13, 2015, amended the penalty provision of § 14:85 to increase the maximum jail term from 60 days to six months. 
Secs. 14:86-14:99. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER B. - OTHER CRIMES 

Sec. 14:100. - Wearing of masks on streets and public places restricted; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to wear upon the public streets or in public places within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice a hood or mask, or anything in the nature of either, or any facial disguise of any kind or description calculated to conceal or hide the identity of the person, or to prevent his being readily recognized. 
(b)  This section shall not apply: 
(1)  To activities of children twelve (12) years of age or younger on Halloween, to persons participating in any public parade or exhibition of an educational, religious, or historical character given by any school, church, or public governing authority, or to persons in any private residence, club, or lodge room; or, 
(2)  To persons participating in masquerade balls or entertainments, to persons participating in carnival parades or exhibitions during the period of Mardi Gras festivities, to persons participating in the parades or exhibitions of minstrel troupes, circuses, or other dramatic or amusement shows, or to promiscuous masking on Mardi Gras. 
    All persons having charge or control of any of the festivities set forth in Paragraph (2) of this section shall, in order to bring the persons participating therein within the exceptions contained in Paragraph (2), make written application for and shall obtain in advance of the festivities from the mayor a written permit to conduct the festivities. 
(c)  Whoever violates this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. A-230, §§ 1-3, Rev., 2-14-61) 
Sec. 14:101. - Killing, keeping, selling wild game quadrupeds prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to kill, wound, trap, hold in possession, (whether dead or alive), receive, offer for sale, sell, offer to purchase, purchase, transport, carry or cause to be transported or carried by any means whatever, at any time and in any manner, any wild game quadrupeds, or to disturb or destroy any nest or egg or young of such wild game quadruped. 
(b)  Wild game quadrupeds include the following: wild deer, bears, squirrels, chipmunks, wild rabbits, and wild herds of all species. 
(c)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. A-275, §§ 1-3, 10-8-63) 
Sec. 14:102. - Trapping, hunting or shooting of birds prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  The entire area embraced within the corporate limits of the municipality of Eunice is hereby designated as a Bird Sanctuary. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to trap, hunt, shoot or attempt to shoot or molest in any manner any bird or wild fowl or to rob bird nests or wild fowl nests. Provided, however, if starlings or similar birds are found to be congregating in such numbers in a particular locality that they constitute a nuisance or menace to health or property in the opinion of the proper health authorities of the municipality of Eunice, then in such event said health authorities shall meet with representatives of the Audubon Society, Bird Club, Garden Club or Humane Society, or as many of said clubs as are found to exist in the municipality of Eunice, after having given at least three (3) days actual notice of the time and place of said meeting to the representatives of said clubs. 
(c)  If as a result of said meeting no satisfactory alternative is found to abate such nuisance, then said birds may be destroyed in such numbers and in such manner as is deemed advisable by said health authorities under the supervision of the chief of police of the municipality of Eunice. 
(d)  Anyone violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. A-330, §§ 1-3, 3-23-67) 
Sec. 14:103. - Regulations established governing trick-or-treat on Halloween night. 
(a)  The event, program, occurrence or festival of "Trick or Treat" may be conducted within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice only one night each year, that of Halloween night. 
(b)  No one over the age of 12 years may participate in the event, program, occurrence or festival of "Trick or Treat", except during the hours of 6:00 to 8:00 o'clock p.m. 
(c)  Anyone violating or assisting or participating in the violation of this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 16-69, §§ 1-3, 10-14-69) 
Sec. 14:104. - Regulations established governing the conduct of criminal investigations, private detectives. 
(a)  Only public officers, city, parish, state and federal may conduct criminal investigations, or serve in the capacity as private detective within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice, without a permit. 
(b)  Anyone except public law enforcement officials wishing to conduct private criminal investigations, or act in the capacity of a private detective, may not, without first obtaining a permit, to so act. 
(c)  Anyone wishing to act as a private detective, or investigator, shall apply to the mayor, who, with the concurrence of the chief of police will direct the city clerk to issue a permit. No such permit shall issue, except upon the joint concurrence of the mayor and the chief of police. 
    (d) Anyone violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 13-73, §§ 1-4, 8-14-73) 
Sec. 14:105. - Curfew for minors established. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any unemancipated minor under the age of seventeen (17) years to travel, loiter, wander, stroll or play in or upon or traverse any public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, places of amusements and entertainment, places and buildings, vacant lots or other unsupervised places in the city between the hours of 10:00 p.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday night and 5:00 a.m. of the following day, or 12:00 midnight on any Friday or Saturday night and 5:00 a.m. of the following day, all official time of the city, unless the minor is accompanied by his parents, tutor or other responsible adult or unless the minor is upon an emergency errand or has in his possession the written permission of his parent, tutor or other adult having custody of such minor to be upon or in such places between such hours of such date, unless an event officially sanctioned by the mayor and chief of police happens to be scheduled on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday nights, on which occasions the curfew hour would extend to 12:00 midnight. 
(b)  Any minor violating any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed a neglected child, as such term is defined in Louisiana Revised Statutes, Title 13, sections 1569 and 1570, as now enacted or hereafter amended or reenacted, and such minor and his parents, tutor or other adult having the care and custody of such minor shall be dealt with under proper procedure in any juvenile court having jurisdiction of such child. 
(c)  If any minor is found guilty of violating this section, as provided in paragraph (a) hereinabove, in addition to the provisions contained in paragraph (b) hereinabove, either parent, or both, of the minor violating this section, or the custodial parent, tutor or any other person having the care and custody of said minor, shall be subject to a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or imprisoned for a period of not more than thirty (30) days, either or both, at the discretion of the city judge, provided that such parent or other person having the care and custody of the minor, shall have received two (2) warnings or notices from the police department or the city court of the minor's previous violation or violations of curfew prior to the penalty being assessed, and provided further that such violation occur within any consecutive twenty-four (24) month period. A fine or penalty in conformity herewith may be assessed upon to the maximum limits set forth herein for each separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 22-74, §§ 1, 2, 10-8-74; Ord. No. 4-91, 3-12-91; Ord. No. 04-94, 7-12-94) 
Sec. 14:106. - Possessing or consuming beverages from open glass containers on public property prohibited; violations, penalties. 
(a)  It shall be illegal and unlawful for any person to possess or consume from an open glass container, bottle or otherwise, containing a beverage, spirituous or nonspirituous, alcoholic or nonalcoholic, upon the public streets or public properties belonging to the city, both within and without its corporate limits, particularly but not limited to city parks, city lakes, tennis courts, baseball fields, basketball courts, softball fields, airports, and city hall. 
(b)  Anyone violating the provisions of this section shall be fined in a sum of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or imprisoned for a period of thirty (30) days, either or both at the discretion of the city judge. 
(Ord. No. 11-78, § 1, 6-13-78) 
Sec. 14:107. - Water skiing/jet skis in City Park Lake prohibited; violations, penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to ski and/or operate a jet ski or ride upon any other similar personal watercraft device on City Park Lake at any time. 
(b)  Anyone who violates the provisions of this section shall be fined in a sum of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or imprisoned for a period of thirty (30) days or more, either or both at the discretion of the city judge. 
(Ord. No. 16-78, 6-22-78; Ord. No. 05-04(B), 5-11-04) 
Sec. 14:108. - Sale, exhibition or distribution of material harmful to minors. 
(a)  In order to maintain a safe, healthy and stable environment for the citizens of Eunice, and in particular to prohibit the sale, exhibition or distribution of material harmful to minors, the board of alderman for the city of Eunice does hereby adopt, for the purpose of application and enforcement of this section, the provisions of R.S. 14:91.11, and in particular, the following provisions are incorporated herein. 
(b)  Terms defined: 
(1)  The "unlawful sale, exhibition, rental, leasing or distribution of material harmful to minors" is the intentional sale, allocation, distribution, advertisement, dissemination, exhibition or display of material harmful to minors, to any unmarried person under the age of seventeen (17) years, or the possession of material harmful to minors with the intent to sell, allocate, advertise, disseminate, exhibit, or display such material to any unmarried person under the age of seventeen (17) years, at a newsstand or any other commercial establishment which is open to persons under the age of seventeen (17) years. 
(2)  "Material harmful to minors" is defined as any paper, magazine, book, newspaper, periodical, pamphlet, composition, publication, photograph, drawing, picture, poster, motion picture film, video tape, figure, phonograph record, album, cassette, compact disc, wire or tape recording, or other similar tangible work or thing which exploits, is devoted to or principally consists of descriptions or depictions of illicit sex or sexual immorality or commercial gain, and when the trier of fact determines that the average person applying contemporary community standards would find that the work or thing is presented in a manner to provoke or arouse lust, passion or perversion or exploits sex. 
(3)  For the purpose of this section, "descriptions or depictions of illicit sex or sexual immorality" includes the depiction, display, description, exhibition or representation of: 
a.  Ultimate sexual acts, normal or perverted, actual, simulated or animated, whether between human beings, animals, or an animal and a human being, 
b.  Masturbation, excretory functions or exhibition, actual simulated, or animated, of the genitals, pubic hair, anus, vulva or female breast nipples; 
c.  Sadomasochistic abuse, meaning actual, simulated, or animated flagellation or torture by or upon a person who is nude or clad in undergarments or in a costume which reveals the pubic hair, anus, vulva, genitals, or female breast nipples, or the condition of being fettered, bound or otherwise physically restrained, on the part of one so clothed. 
d.  Actual, simulated or animated, touching, caressing, or fondling of, or other similar physical contact with, a pubic area, anus, female breast nipple, covered or exposed, whether alone or between human, animals or a human and an animal, of the same or opposite sex, in an act of apparent sexual stimulation or gratification; or 
e.  Actual, simulated or animated, stimulation of the human genital organs by an device whether or not the device is designed, manufactured, and marketed for such purpose. 
(c)  Prohibition; lack of knowledge of age not considered defense; "exhibit or display" defined. It shall be unlawful to invite or permit any unmarried person under the age of seventeen (17) years of age to be in any commercial establishment that exhibits or displays any item, material, work or thing of any kind that is described in subsection (a) of this section. 
    Lack of knowledge of age or marital status shall not constitute a defense, unless the defendant shows that he had reasonable cause to believe that the minor involved was either married or seventeen (17) years of age or more and that the minor exhibited to the defendant a draft card, driver's license, birth certificate or other official or apparently official document purporting to establish that such a minor was either married or seventeen (17) years of age or more. 
    For the purpose of subsection (a) and this subsection, "exhibition or display" means the exhibition or display of material harmful to minors as defined in subsection (a) so that, as displayed, depictions and representations of illicit sex or sexual immorality are visible to minors, or that an unmarried person under the age of seventeen (17) years is permitted to see or examine the contents of the material harmful to minors. 
(d)  Scope. This section does not pre-empt, nor shall anything in this section be construed to pre-empt, the regulation of obscenity by municipalities, parishes and consolidated city-parish governments; however, in order to promote uniform obscenity legislation throughout the state, the regulation of obscenity by municipalities, parishes and consolidated city-parish governments shall not exceed the scope of the regulatory prohibitions contained in the provisions of this section. 
(e)  Penalty. Whoever is found guilty of violating the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) or imprisoned for not more than one year, or both. 
(Ord. No. 5-96, § 1, 4-9-96) 
Sec. 14:109. - Wearing of pants below the waist in public. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person on public property, including streets and sidewalks, to wear pants below the waist which expose any part of the buttocks, public hair, or undergarments of that person. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, regardless of age, to wear pants in a manner that does not prevent the pants from falling more than three (3) inches below the hips (crest of the ileum) causing exposure of any part of the person's buttocks, pubic hair, or the person's undergarments. 
(c)  Fines and civil penalties, community service and counseling: 
(1)  If a juvenile is determined to be in violation of this ordinance, a citation shall be issued to the parent or legal guardian who has care and control of the minor and he or she shall be subject to, in the discretion of a judge, a warning to the parent and juvenile or a civil penalty of not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) on the first offense and not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) on each subsequent offense. In addition to the civil penalty, the court may order the juvenile and/or the parent or legal guardian to participate in up to forty (40) hours of court approved community service activities, or a combination of up to forty (40) hours of court appointed community service and attendance by both a parent or legal custodian and the minor, at a court approved family counseling program. 
(2)  If an adult is determine to be in violation of this section, a citation shall be issued to the person and the person shall be subject to a civil penalty of not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) on the first offense and not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each subsequent offense. In addition to the civil penalty, the court may order such person to participate in up to forty (40) hours of court approved community service activities, or a combination of up to forty (40) hours of court approved community service and attendance at a court approved counseling program. 
(3)  Violators of any provision of this section shall be issued a citation and subject to the civil penalties described above. To this end, a violation of this section shall not be deemed a criminal offense, and thus, violators shall not be subject to arrest, imprisonment or other criminal penalty for violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 10-07(B), 10-9-07) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-07(B), adopted Oct. 9, 2007, did not specifically amend the Code, hence inclusion as § 14;109 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Chapter 15 - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 
SUBCHAPTER A. - BICYCLES 
PART I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 15:1-15:24. - Reserved. 
PART II. - BICYCLE CONTROL PROGRAM[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 19-78, adopted July 11, 1978, being not specifically amendatory of the Code, has been codified as superseding former Subch. A, § 15:1, which pertained to the registration of bicycles and was derived from Ord. No. A-249, §§ 1-3, adopted Sept. 11, 1962. 

Sec. 15:25. - Title. 
    This part shall be known and identified as the bicycle control program. 
(Ord. No. 19-78, § 1, 7-11-78) 
Sec. 15:26. - Supervision and conduct of program. 
    The bicycle control program of the City of Eunice shall be supervised and conducted by the police department of the city, whose duty it shall be to perform those functions necessary for the proper conduct of the program, and to provide all the forms and collect all license fees, which program shall be conducted annually. 
(Ord. No. 19-78, § 1, 7-11-78) 
Sec. 15:27. - License. 
    The license for the first year shall be the sum of three dollars ($3.00) and annually thereafter the license shall be one dollar ($1.00). The sum collected by the police department shall be [transferred] by the chief of police to the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 19-78, § 1, 7-11-78) 
Sec. 15:28. - Proper forms and license certificates. 
    Proper forms and license certificates shall be signed by the police, shall bear the date, phone number, owner, and owner of license [sic], sex, age, weight, and address of licensee, and if a minor, address of parent, make of vehicle, wheel size, serial number, model, model number, color, trim color, and other identification required by the police department, registered by name of officer and shall bear the signature of the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 19-78, § 1, 7-11-78) 
Sec. 15:29. - Registration required. 
(a)  It is hereby made the duty of the owner of every bicycle, before operating or permitting the operation of the same upon any public way within the city, to register said vehicle with the police department on a form provided for such purpose. 
(b)  Registration may be accomplished by filing the registration record or form, duly filled out, in the office of the chief of police by the bicycle owner or mailing said form, duly filled out, to Records and Communications Division, Police Headquarters, Eunice, Louisiana. 
(Ord. No. 19-78, § 1, 7-11-78) 
Sec. 15:30. - Registration record. 
    The registration record shall be in size and style as prescribed by the chief of police and shall contain the date of registration; the make, serial number, model, and description of the bicycle registered; the name and residence address of the owner; the signature of the owner, the owner's age, and if such owner is under twenty-one (21) years of age, the name and address of his or her parent or guardian; the name and address of the person from whom purchased; the date of purchase; and such additional information as the chief of police may require. 
(Ord. No. 19-78, § 1, 7-11-78) 
Sec. 15:31. - Registration after sale or transfer of ownership. 
    Upon the sale or transfer of any bicycle registered hereunder, it shall be the duty of he purchaser, within (10) days of the date of such sale or transfer, to register such bicycle in his name in the manner provided for in the case of an original registrant. 
(Ord. No. 19-78, § 1, 7-11-78) 
Sec. 15:32. - Procedures upon recovery of bicycles. 
(a)  Duties of office-When reported stolen. When a bicycle is recovered, the officer making the recovery shall contact the proper section of the police department to determine if the bicycle has been registered or reported stolen; if the bicycle has been reported stolen, the recovering officer will: 
(1)  Obtain the RD number of the general case report on which the bicycle was reported stolen and the information necessary to contact the owner. He will then request the owner to pick up the bicycle at the station. If the owner is unwilling to pick up the bicycle, or does not pick up the bicycle, or cannot be contacted within a reasonable time, the officer should forward the bicycle to the evidence and recovered property section. In any event, a bicycle should not be held in the recovering unit for more than three (3) days. 
(2)  Inventory the bicycle. 
(3)  Prepare a supplementary report to indicate that the bicycle has been recovered. 
(b)  Same-When registered but not reported stolen. If the bicycle has been registered, but not reported stolen, the officer will: 
(1)  Obtain the information necessary to contact the owner and have him pick up the bicycle at the station. If the owner is unwilling to pick up the bicycle, or cannot be contacted, or does not pick up the bicycle within a reasonable time, the officer should forward the bicycle to the evidence and recovered property station. 
(2)  Prepare a lost and found case report. 
(3)  Inventory the bicycle. 
(c)  Same-When no record available. If no record of the bicycle is available, the officer will: 
(1)  Prepare a lost and found case report. 
(2)  Inventory the bicycle. 
(3)  Forward the bicycle to the evidence and recovered property section. 
(d)  Search of files. When the bicycle unit personnel are contacted by the recovering officer a search of the files will be made to determine if the bicycle is registered and/or reported stolen or lost. If registered only, the recovering officer will be given the name, address and telephone number of the owner. If reported stolen or lost, the recovering officer will be given the RD number, the type of crime (if one was committed when the bicycle was taken), the date of the theft or loss, and the name, address and telephone number of the owner or complainant. 
(e)  General case reports. A general case report will be made out when a complainant reports a theft of a bicycle (an exception to this rule occurs when a bicycle is taken from inside the complainant's dwelling place, garage or shed; a burglary case report will be made out.) 
(f)  Description on inventory form. A bicycle shall be identified and described on the inventory form as follows: 
(1)  Name or make. 
(2)  Model, name or number. 
(3)  Type of bicycle: 
a.  Boys or girls. 
b.  Racer, heavy-duty, delivery, standard. 
(4)  Colors. 
(5)  Serial number and its location. 
a.  Usually on the left side of the frame at bottom rear where wheel and axle meet frame; or 
b.  Under the pedal housing; or 
c.  On the upright bar below the seat. 
(6)  If a complete bicycle is not recovered, show "bicycle parts only" and list parts. 
(7)  If bicycle is not operable, so note. 
(g)  Disposition if needed for investigation or evidence. If a bicycle is needed for investigation or evidence, indicate this fact on the inventory to avoid having the bicycle disposed of automatically (at public auction approximately forty-five (45) days after the date of recovery). No tracers for disposition will be sent from the evidence and recovered property section unless the inventory is marked "Hold for Investigation or Evidence." Since the great majority of bicycles are not needed as evidence, and the forty-five (45) days are sufficient for the investigation conducted for bicycles, a great deal of proper work will be eliminated by automatic disposition. 
    If an owner is located after the bicycle has been sent to the evidence and recovered property section, notify the evidence and recovered property section. Record on the yellow copy of the inventory the date and name of the evidence and recovered property officer notified. 
(Ord. No. 19-78, § 1, 7-11-78) 
Sec. 15:33. - Penalty for violation. 
    Anyone violating the provisions of this part shall be fined and or imprisoned as provided for under the criminal laws of the State of Louisiana and the City of Eunice. 
(Ord. No. 19-78, § 1, 7-11-78) 
Cross reference- General penalty, § 1:21. 
Secs. 15:34-15:49. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER B. - EUNICE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMITTEE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0417(B) , Subch. B(a)-(g), adopted May 9, 2017, amended Subchapter B in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Subchapter B, § 15:50, pertained to industrial development, and derived from Ord. No. A-236, §§ 1-9, 8-8-61. 

Sec. 15:50. - Established. 
    This is hereby established and created an economic development committee for the City of Eunice, Louisiana. The name of said committee shall be "Eunice Economic Development." 
(Ord. No. 0417(B) , Subch. B, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15:51. - Purpose and authority. 
    The committee shall advise and make recommendations to the mayor and the board of aldermen/alderwomen on matters related to economic development, which include but are not limited to business assistance programs, economic development incentives, business climate, business attraction and retention, marketing opportunities, investment incentives and other issues that may promote economic development. 
    In addition, the committee may be responsible for managing one (1) or more economic development programs and budgets to the extent authorized by the mayor and a board of aldermen/alderwomen vote in a public meeting. Final authorization for any budgeted expenditure or contractual agreement resides with the mayor and the board of aldermen/alderwomen. 
(Ord. No. 0417(B) , Subch. B(a), 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15:52. - Goals and priorities. 
    In doing its work, the committee will ensure that policies and strategies it develops will follow economic development goals: diversifying the local tax base, creating local jobs, providing citizens and visitors with local services and improving the overall quality of life in the city. Galvanizing and strengthening local businesses will be a priority, followed by attracting complementary businesses that will enhance the commercial center and maintain the rural character of the town. 
(Ord. No. 0417(B) , Subch. B(b), 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15:53. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    Committee members shall: 
(1)  Work in a coordinated fashion, respect all points of view and, in carrying out its duties and tasks, shall adhere to the values and mission of the city. 
(2)  Review and understand the city's current economic development challenges and incentives. 
(3)  Interface with businesses seeking economic development assistance including requests for local tax increment financing (TIF) assistance. 
(4)  Provide recommendations and guidance to the mayor and the board of aldermen/alderwomen regarding use of TIF revenues. Prepare the annual TIF budget. 
(5)  Have responsibility for the structure of any city revolving loan fund and/or grant fund for economic development/business assistance purposes. 
(6)  Advise on tools that could be used to encourage economic development and community investment opportunities. 
(7)  Serve as ambassadors of city and promote the city to their contacts. 
(8)  Provide business leads and contacts to the city where appropriate. 
(9)  Be respectful of all other committee members and work positively toward accomplishing committee objectives. 
(Ord. No. 0417(B) , Subch. B(c), 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15:54. - Membership. 
    The committee shall consist of eight (8) members recommended by the mayor and appointed by the board of aldermen/alderwomen. The mayor shall be an ex-officio member of the committee. The committee shall represent a diverse cross section of the city's economic base and shall include, but are not limited to representatives of the following: 
 Industrial business. 
 Retail business. 
 Technology business. 
 Downtown business owner. 
 Banking or finance professional. 
 Farming/agricultural. 
 LSU Eunice representative. 
 Attorney/law professional. 
 Real estate. 
 Chamber of commerce member. 
(Ord. No. 0417(B) , Subch. B(d), 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15:55. - Officers and roles. 
    Members will meet at the first opportunity after their appointments to elect a chair, a vice chair and a secretary to serve for one (1) year unless otherwise provided. The committee may develop additional roles as circumstances direct and select members to be responsible for leading those areas of the committee's work. 
    The chair shall preside at all committee meetings and shall have authority to rule on questions of evidence and procedure, to maintain order and determine the course of proceedings, and to take such other action as may be necessary and not inconsistent with these bylaws or other law to enable the committee to perform its duties and conduct its affairs. The chair also shall set the agenda for each meeting and provide the agenda to the city clerk for posting as required. The vice chair shall assume the responsibilities of chair in the chair's absence. 
    The secretary shall maintain a permanent record of all committee meetings and all correspondence of the committee, which shall be a public record except as otherwise provided by law. The secretary shall be responsible for providing the city clerk a copy of all meeting minutes. 
(Ord. No. 0417(B) , Subch. B(e), 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15:56. - Appointments, terms and termination. 
(a)  Committee members shall be appointed by the board of aldermen/alderwomen in a public meeting. 
(b)  Committee members are appointed for a period of four (4) years with the term expiring at the same time as the term served by the board of aldermen/alderwomen and mayor. 
(c)  Committee members may be removed by a majority vote of the committee and confirmed by a majority vote of the board of aldermen/alderwomen. 
(Ord. No. 0417(B) , Subch. B(f), 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15:57. - Meetings and procedures. 
(a)  The committee shall hold an organizational meeting at the first opportunity following annual appointments to orient members, elect officers and establish an annual work plan and meeting schedule. 
(b)  The committee shall meet at least four (4) times per year. The committee shall schedule meetings as it deems necessary, providing public notice to the city clerk for posting. 
(c)  Attendance shall be considered a quorum when fifty (50) per cent of voting members are present. 
(d)  The chair shall not cast a vote unless it is a tiebreaker vote. 
(e)  Votes shall pass by a simple majority. 
(f)  Members must recuse themselves from participating in any discussions or votes on any matter where that member has a conflict of interest regarding that matter. 
(g)  Members are expected to attend three-quarters (3/4) of the meetings held with no more than four (4) consecutive "unexcused" absences. An excused absence may be requested of the chair in advance of scheduled meetings. 
(h)  Following attempts to resolve issues within the committee, the committee will vote on removal of any member(s) violating any of the duties, responsibilities, attendance or procedures outlined in this subchapter. Upon an affirmative committee vote, the chair will make recommendation to the board of aldermen/alderwomen for confirmation of removal. 
(i)  The committee may adopt bylaws or other rules of procedure to manage its affairs beyond provisions of this subchapter provided they do not conflict with this subchapter. 
(Ord. No. 0417(B) , Subch. B(g), 5-9-17) 
Secs. 15:58-15:74. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER C. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 15:75. - Fishing by means of a net. 
(a)  Prohibition. It shall be unlawful and illegal for anyone to fish in the city lake by the use or employment of any type of net or webbing. 
(b)  Penalty. Anyone violating the provisions of this section shall be fined a sum of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) at the discretion of the city judge. 
(Ord. No. 18-80, §§ 1, 2, 11-11-80) 
Editor's note- Being not specifically amendatory of the Code, the provisions of §§ 1 and 2 of Ord. No. 18-80, adopted Nov. 11, 1980, have been codified, at the editor's discretion, as § 15:75 to a new Subch. C. 
Sec. 15:76. - Charitable games of chance. 
    There is hereby adopted, in toto, all of the provisions and regulations of LRS, Chapter 33, Part v-A, and particularly those contained in LSA-R.S. 4861.1 through 4861.20, thereby permitting charitable games of chance, as defined therein, to be conducted within the limits of the City of Eunice, provided the same shall be in strict conformity with, and be subject to, all of the aforesaid provisions and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 9-87, 4-27-87) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 9-87, adopted April 27, 1987, enacted the provisions codified as § 15:76 above. Since said ordinance did not specifically amend the Code, its inclusion herein and its manner of codification has been at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 15:77. - Endangered wildflower habitat. 
(a)  Designated. The ten-acre tract of land located on the corner of Magnolia Avenue and North Martin Luther King, Jr. Drive in the City of Eunice, being that certain ten-acre tract of land leased by the city from Missouri Pacific Railroad Company by lease agreement dated August 26, 1988, is hereby designated as an endangered wildflower habitat, in conjunction with the Cajun Prairie Restoration Project sponsored by the City of Eunice. 
(b)  Trespass. Any person, animal or vehicle entering upon the aforesaid property or removing or damaging any of the wildflowers thereon without specific authority and permission from the city or its official representative shall be guilty of trespassing upon municipal property and subject to all of the penalties which may be imposed for such violations, as provided for in the trespass ordinance. 
    Additional penalties. It is further provided that in addition to the trespass violation, anyone found guilty of damaging the wildflowers or any portion of the habitat shall pay a fine of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), or [be] sentenced to not more ten (10) days in jail, or both. 
(Ord. No. 2-89, §§ 1, 2, 2-14-89) 
Editor's note- Being not specifically amendatory of the Code, the provisions of Ord. No. 2-89, adopted Feb. 14, 1989, have been codified as § 15:77 at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 15:78-15:100. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER D. - SKATES, SKATEBOARDS AND ROLLERBLADES 

Sec. 15:101. - Prohibited in designated areas. 
    No person shall ride and/or make other use of skates, skateboards or roller blades or any apparatus similar to a skate, skateboard or roller blades, on or in the following designated areas within the City of Eunice: 
(1)  The area commencing at the intersection of North 4th Street and Magnolia Avenue, thence proceeding South on 4th Street, across Laurel Avenue, down to the intersection of Ash Street and 4th Street, thence proceeding East on Ash Street to its intersection with C.C. Duson Drive, thence proceeding North on C.C. Duson Drive, across Laurel Avenue, to the intersection of Magnolia Avenue and C.C. Drive, thence proceeding West on Magnolia Avenue to its intersection with N. 4th Street, thence South on 4th Street down to the point of beginning. This prohibition against skates, skateboards and roller blades shall apply to any and all areas encompassed between the lines designated hereinabove. 
(2)  Any privately owned or publicly owned walkway or parking area, or parking lot, or other hard-surfaced area, upon which the owner or occupant of the premises, or the City of Eunice, has posted signs stating "NO SKATES, SKATEBOARDS OR ROLLER BLADES ALLOWED ON THESE PREMISES" on the prohibited site, clearly visible to persons entering or going upon the site. 
(Ord. No. 5-97(C), § 2, 6-26-97) 
Sec. 15:102. - Rules and regulations. 
    In all other areas within the City of Eunice, the following rules and regulations shall apply: No person shall ride or use skates, skateboards or roller blades in a reckless manner on any public sidewalk. No person shall ride skates, skateboards or roller blades on a sidewalk without exercising due care for the safety of other persons using the sidewalk. Under all circumstances, the rider shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians using the sidewalk, and due and proper care shall at all times be exercised by the rider for the pedestrians. When approaching a pedestrian on the sidewalk, the speed of the skates, skateboards or roller blades shall be reduced to a speed which is no greater than necessary to continue the operation of the skates, skateboards or roller blades without the rider dismounting, and shall not be increased until the pedestrian has been passed. 
(Ord. No. 5-97(C), § 3, 6-26-97) 
Sec. 15:103. - Violation penalties. 
    Any person violating any provision of this subchapter shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00), nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each offense. Any offense committed by the same person after being warned that he or she is committing an offense shall constitute a separate offense, subject to a separate fine for each. The police are further authorized to confiscate the skates, skateboards and roller blades involved in the offense and retain same at the police station or other convenient location until the fine or fines are paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 5-97(C), § 4, 6-26-97) 
Secs. 15:104-15:110. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER E. - GARAGE SALES 

Sec. 15:111. - Definitions. 
    [The following definitions shall apply to this subchapter:] 
(1)  Garage sale shall mean and include all sales entitled "Garage Sale," "Lawn Sale," "Attic Sale," "Flea Market Sale" or any similar casual sale of tangible personal property which is advertised by any means whereby the public at large is or can be made aware of said sale. 
(2)  Goods is meant to include any goods, warehouse merchandise or other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated hereunder. 
(3)  Person shall mean and include all individuals, partnerships, voluntary associations and corporations. 
(Ord. No. 698(A), § (A), 7-14-98) 
Sec. 15:112. - Permits and fees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a garage sale in the City of Eunice without first filing with the clerk the information hereinafter specified and obtaining from such clerk a license to do so, to be known as a "Garage Sale License." The fee for such license shall be five dollars ($5.00). 
(Ord. No. 698(A), § (B), 7-14-98) 
Sec. 15:113. - Licensing. 
    Such license shall be issued to any one person only twice within a twelve-month period and no such license shall be issued for more than three (3) consecutive calendar days. Each license issued under this subchapter must be prominently displayed on the premises upon which the garage sale is conducted throughout the entire period of the licensed sale. 
(Ord. No. 698(A), § (C), 7-14-98) 
Sec. 15:114. - Information to be filed. 
    The information to be filed with the clerk, pursuant to this subchapter, shall be as follows: 
(1)  Name of owner or the person, firm, group, corporation, association or organization conducting said sale. 
(2)  Name of owner of the property on which said sale is to be conducted, consent of owner if applicant is other than the owner. 
(3)  Location at which said sale is to be conducted. 
(4)  Number of days of sale. 
(5)  Date, nature of any past sale. 
(6)  Relationship or connection applicant may have had with any other person, firm, group, organization, association or corporation conducting said sale and the date or dates of such sale. 
(7)  Whether or not applicant has been issued any other vendor's license by any local, state or federal agency. 
(8)  Sworn statement of affirmation by the person signing that the information therein given is full and true and known to him to be so. 
(Ord. No. 698(A), § (D), 7-14-98) 
Sec. 15:115. - Person and sale excepted. 
    The provisions of this subchapter, shall not apply to or affect the following persons or sales: 
(1)  Persons selling goods pursuant to a process of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(2)  Persons acting in accordance with their power and duties as public officials. 
(3)  Any person selling or advertising for sale an item or items of personal property which are specifically named or described in the advertisement and which separate items do not exceed five (5) in number. 
Sec. 15:116. - Penalty. 
    Any person, association or corporation conducting any such sale without being properly licensed therefor or who shall violate any of the other terms and regulations of this subchapter shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or be imprisoned for a period not to exceed ten (10) days for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 698(A), § (F), 7-14-98) 
Secs. 15:117-15:120. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER F. - TREES AND SHRUBBERY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-07(A), adopted Oct. 9, 2007, did not specifically amend the Code, hence inclusion as Subch. F, § 15;121 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 15:121. - Preservation and protection. 
(a)  The purpose of this subchapter is to define, regulate and control the planting, pruning, trimming, replanting, removal, disposal of, care and preservation of trees and shrubs on the streets and public grounds within the city; to regulate the preservation and replacement of trees, the removal of dead trees, to define certain works and positions, to license persons servicing trees, and to provide and establish procedures and practices for fulfilling these purposes. 
(b)  Definitions: 
    Public street trees. Public street trees are herein defined as trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues or ways within the city. 
    Public park trees. Public park trees are herein defined as trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation in public parks having individual names and all areas owned by the city to which the public has free access as a park. 
    Arborist. Any person servicing trees in any manner other than one working on his own property. 
    Person. An individual, firm, association, partnership or corporation. 
    Tree service. Work performed on shade or ornamental trees specifically excluding shrubbery and including tree removals, planting, trimming, spraying, controlling and fertilizing. 
(c)  Public street and park tree care. The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to insure safety when servicing city utilities or to preserve the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. The city may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines or other public improvements or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. 
(d)  Tree topping. It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm, or city department to top any street tree, park tree or other tree on public property. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three (3) inches in diameter within the three's [trees] crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical are exempted from this subchapter. 
(e)  Pruning, corner clearance. Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from a street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of ten (10) feet above the surface of the street or right-of-way. Said owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light or interferes with visibility of any street control device or sign. 
(f)  Dead or diseased tree removal. The city shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the city, when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city. The city street commissioner shall notify in writing the owners of such trees. Such removal shall be done by said owners at their own expense within sixty (60) days after date of service of notice and in the event of failure of owners to comply with such provisions, the city shall have the authority to remove such trees and charge the cost of removal to the owner. 
(g)  Arborist's permit. It shall be unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of trimming, planting, pruning, treating or removing street or park trees within the City of Eunice without first applying for and procuring a permit. The permit fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per permit or two-hundred dollars ($200.00) for a one (1) year permit, annually, in advance, provided, however, that no permit fee shall be required of any public service company, city department or city employee doing such work n the pursuit of their public service endeavors. Before any such permit shall be issued, each applicant shall first file written evidence of possession of liability insurance in the minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for property damage. The said application shall also include a photostatic copy of the person's license issued by the Louisiana Horticulture Commission. 
(h)  License not transferable. It shall be unlawful to transfer any arborist license to any other person or for any arborist to knowingly allow any other person to use said license. 
(i)  Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this subchapter or who shall fail to comply with any of the requirements hereof shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction in a court of proper jurisdiction shall be punishable by fine not to exceed the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) on the first offense, and upon conviction of the second offense shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) and for each offense thereafter, the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 10-07(A), 10-9-07; Ord. No. 12-12(C), 12-11-12) 
Chapter 16 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Related motor vehicle regulations, Ch. 14; prohibiting obstruction of public thoroughfares; §§ 14:50, 14:51; prohibiting driving while intoxicated, § 14:61; prohibiting reckless operation of a vehicle, § 14:62; prohibiting hit and run driving, § 14:63; zoning regulations pertaining to off-street parking, loading and unloading, § 18:151 et seq.; inclusion of provisions prohibiting obstruction of public thoroughfares, §§ 23:1, 23:2. 

SUBCHAPTER A. - TRAFFIC REGULATIONS IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16:1. - Adoption of Louisiana Highway Regulatory Act. 
    Pursuant to the authority conferred by LRS 32:42, the provisions of LRS Title 32, Chapter 1, commonly referred to as the "Louisiana Highway Regulatory Act," as it may be amended from time to time, and all regulations of the State Department of Highways and the Director of Public Safety adopted pursuant thereto which govern the operation of motor vehicles, traffic, and streets are hereby adopted and made applicable to the operation of motor vehicles, traffic, and streets within the City of Eunice, except as such are in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this subchapter and except such as by their nature are inapplicable. 
Editor's note- Over the years, the city has adopted numerous ordinances dealing with motor vehicles and traffic. Many of these were determined to be archaic, contradictory and in conflict with related state laws. This subchapter, therefore, represents a complete revision of the city's traffic laws in an effort to up-date them and bring them into conformance with state statutes and authorities. 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to adopt the Louisiana Highway Act by reference, LRS 32:41; provisions of this Act, 32:1 et seq. 
Sec. 16:2. - Duty of operators to comply with highway regulatory act; requirements for vehicles; penalty for violations. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of persons owning, operating or having in charge or under their control or custody any vehicle including a bicycle or motorcycle, upon the streets, highways and roads within the City of Eunice, and all pedestrians, to observe and conform to the provisions, rules, and regulations of the Highway Regulatory Act as supplemented by the provisions of this subchapter and any other ordinance of this city providing with respect thereto and they are subject to the penalties provided in section 1:21 of this Code, if they do not observe and comply with such rules and regulations. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle on any public way in this city which does not fully comply with all the requirements of the Louisiana Highway Regulatory Act pertaining to lights, brakes, other equipment, safety devices, inspection, construction or maintenance. 
Editor's note- The general provisions contained in the above section render a number of earlier ordinances dealing with traffic obsolete. These include Ord. No. 77, June 14, 1913; Ord. No. 149, Sept. 2, 1924; Ord. No. 157, Sept. 1, 1925 and Ord. No. A-12, Nov. 8, 1929. 
State Law reference- Similar state law requirements, LRS 32:51, 32:52 and 32:53. 
Sec. 16:3. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this subchapter, the words and phrases used in the Louisiana Highway Regulatory Act shall have the meaning ascribed to them in R.S. 32:1, with the exception that: 
(1)  Where the words "department" or "department of highways" are used, they shall be deemed to include the mayor and board of aldermen of the City of Eunice, unless the meaning clearly indicates otherwise. 
(2)  Where the words "department of public safety" are used, they shall be deemed to include the mayor and board of aldermen and the police department of the City of Eunice, unless the meaning clearly indicates otherwise. 
Sec. 16:4. - Mayor and board of aldermen to inspect streets and set maximum tonnage allowed thereon; penalties. 
(a)  The mayor and board of aldermen shall inspect all streets, lanes and public ways of the city and shall prescribe the necessary regulations and the maximum vehicular tonnage permitted to travel thereon. 
(b)  The mayor shall be responsible for seeing that clear and understandable signs are erected at the entrance or entrances to said streets, lanes and public ways designating the prescribed regulations and maximum tonnage of any vehicle traveling thereon. 
(c)  Any person traveling upon any street, lane or public way in violation of such prescribed regulations and maximum tonnage shall be condemned to pay all damages to said streets, lanes and public ways caused by him and also be subject to the penalties provided for in section 1:21 of this Code. 
Comment- Over the years, the city has established numerous limited-application traffic regulations governing specific streets and/or locations and dealing with such matters as load limits, speed limits, parking regulations, yield intersections, etc. For example, Ord. No. A-132 of March 16, 1954 established truck routes on certain streets; Ord. No. 20-70 of Oct. 13, 1970 prohibited trucks weighing in excess of five (5) tons from using Prairie Avenue; and Ord. No. A-256 of Jan. 8, 1963 prohibited trucks over three-fourths ton from using a portion of Fuselier Street. 
Because of the general authorizations contained in this chapter providing for the establishment of special traffic regulations and the enforcement of same after signs giving notice of the regulations are erected, the specific requirements of these special limited-application ordinances were not included in this codification. This omission does not reflect the intent of the mayor and board of aldermen to repeal these ordinances, but rather to obviate the necessity for making frequent amendments to this publication for matters that do not affect the entire municipality. 
Cross reference- For additional provisions of this Code pertaining to streets, see Ch. 23. 
Sec. 16:5. - Truck routes. 
(a)  Designation generally. Only those streets situated within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice which are designated as state or federal highways shall be used by trucks in excess of three (3) tons and truck-trailers commonly known and identified as "eighteen-wheelers," except as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  Prohibition; exceptions. It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or to permit the driving of a vehicle commonly known or identified as an "eighteen-wheeler", or a truck in excess of three (3) tons, on any streets situated within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice, except on those streets designated as state or federal highways; save and except that it shall be lawful for any such vehicle to drive on any street within the City of Eunice solely for the purpose of pickup and delivery connected directly with a commercial business, or going directly to and/or returning from one's usual place of business, in which event such vehicles shall travel the shortest or nearest route deviating from the aforesaid state or federal highway, and save and except that it shall be lawful to drive the tractor portion only (meaning that the trailer has been completely disconnected) on any street solely for the purpose of going directly to or returning from the driver's place of business or from the aforesaid state or federal highways. Any other use of the public streets of Eunice by such vehicles is strictly prohibited by this section. 
(c)  Penalty for violation. Any person convicted of any violation of any provision of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 5-86, §§ 1, 2, 4, 6-10-86; Ord. No. 1000(B), 11-14-00) 
Editor's note- Sections 1, 2 and 4 of Ord. No. 5-86, adopted June 10, 1986, were not enacted as a specific amendment or addition to the Code, and hence are included herein as § 16:5 at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Parking of eighteen-wheelers regulated, § 16:75. 
Secs. 16:6-16:14. - Reserved. 
Sec. 16:15. - Maximum speed limits established; violations, penalties. 
(a)  The maximum speed limit on all streets, avenues and thoroughfares within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice shall be and is hereby established as twenty-five (25) miles per hour, save and except those streets, avenues and thoroughfares herein listed below: 
(1)  North Eighth Street being from North City Limits to West Laurel Avenue is thirty-five (35) miles per hour, all school zones are fifteen (15) miles per hour, with the exception of North 8th Street school zone, which will be twenty-five (25) miles per hour and all other streets, avenues and thoroughfares posted at a lower limit; and 
(2)  Speed limits on all state maintained highways through the City of Eunice shall be set, posted or at least approved by the appropriate state highway authority; and 
(3)  Changes to subsection (a) above can only be made by the recommendation of the City Council and investigation by the Chief of Police, due to accidents and traffic situations, and then only after a public hearing and final Council approval. 
(b)  Reserved. 
Editor's note- The provisions of former paragraph (b), setting out a 25-mile-per-hour maximum speed limit on all streets, avenues and thoroughfares in the city, have been deleted as being superseded by Ord. No. 65-83, adopted June 14, 1983, which amended paragraph (a) to read as set out above. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to operate a vehicle upon the public streets above identified in excess of the maximum speed limits thereon specified. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful to operate motor vehicles upon the public alleys within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice at a rate of speed greater than ten (10) miles per hour. 
(e)  All vehicles traveling upon the public alleys within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice shall come to a stop before entering the public streets. 
(f)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. A-183, §§ 1-4, 12-10-57; Ord. No. A-356, §§ 1-3, 8-13-68; Ord. of 8-11-81; Ord. No. 65-83, 6-14-83; Ord. No. 11-90, § 1, 11-13-90; Ord. No. 03-12(A), § (A), 3-13-12) 
Comment- Ordinance No. A-183 provided for the general speed limits on streets and Ord. No. A-356 added the limitations on alleys. These ordinances superseded several earlier speed ordinances including Ord. No. A-91 of June 13, 1950; Ord. No. A-179 of Nov. 12, 1957; and Ord. No. A-274 of Oct. 8, 1963. 
In using the provisions of this section, the user's attention should be directed to the ordinances establishing limited-application speed zones listed following § 16:16. These ordinances are on file for public inspection in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 16:16. - Authority of mayor and board of aldermen to designate special speed zones. 
    Whenever the mayor and board of aldermen shall determine, upon the basis of an engineering or traffic investigation, that any maximum speed limit set forth in section 16:15 above is greater or less than is reasonable or safe under the conditions found to exist upon any street or public way within the corporate limits, or any part thereof, it may declare a maximum speed limit thereat which it deems reasonable and safe, which, when appropriate signs giving notice thereof are erected, shall be effective at all times or at such times as may be determined by the mayor and board of aldermen and indicated on the posted signs; provided, however, that the maximum speed limit on any state-maintained highway within the city shall be set or at least approved by the appropriate state highway authority. 
Comment- See the note following § 16:4. Ordinances establishing limited-application speed zones are listed below:

In using the provisions of this section, the user's attention is directed to the provisions establishing specific maximum speed limit zones in § 16:15(a) above. 
Sec. 16:17. - Additional speed limitations. 
    In addition to the specific speed limitations herein provided or authorized, no person shall drive a vehicle on any street or public way within this city at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions and potential hazards then existing, having due regard for the traffic on, and the surface and width of the street or public way on which he is traveling, and the conditions of the weather. 
Sec. 16:18. - Street closings, posted signage-School zones. 
    This section is enacted for the safety of the children who are arriving at school in the morning prior to beginning school at 8:00 a.m. and who are leaving school at dismissal at 3:00 p.m. 
(a)  The closure of through traffic on Mathilda Street, which is a one-way street for eastbound traffic during school days at its intersection with Tisington Street, is enacted for the safety of the children who are arriving at the school and leaving the school at times of dismissal. 
(1)  Between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. and 4:00 p.m. on all days which East Elementary School is in session with students present, the intersection of Mathilda Street and Tisington Street shall be closed to through traffic. 
    The street commissioner and/or city police chief shall direct the placing of proper signs designating the hours for closing the intersection to through traffic. 
(b)  Signs. 
(1)  A "NO LEFT TURN between the hours of 2:50 PM and 3:30 PM" sign shall be placed at the eastbound lane of Maple Avenue at its intersection with South Martin Luther King Drive, prohibiting left turn from eastbound Maple Avenue onto South Martin Luther King Drive between these hours. 
(2)  A "BUSES ONLY" sign shall be placed at the above location, allowing the left-hand turn from eastbound Maple Avenue onto South Martin Luther King Drive by school buses only. 
    The purpose of these designations is to provide for a smooth flow of traffic at Central Middle School for the picking up of students after school. The street supervisor shall direct the placing of proper street signs at the proper places as above described. 
(c)  Fairground Avenue, between Ninth and Tenth Streets. 
(1)  A traffic sign designating "Closed to All Traffic Except School Bus 2:45 PM-3:45 PM" [shall] be placed as follows: 
a.  On South Tenth Street at its intersection with Fairground Avenue; 
b.  On South Ninth Street at its intersection with Fairground Avenue. 
(2)  The street supervisor shall direct the placing of proper street signs at the proper places as above described. 
(Ord. No. 02-08(B), 2-12-08; Ord. No. 11-13(A), §§ 1-3, 12-10-13; Ord. No. 0917(A) , §§ 1, 2, 1-10-17) 
Editor's note- With the codification of Ord. No. 11-13(A), adopted Dec. 10, 2013, at the editor's discretion, the catchline of § 16:18 was revised to read as herein set out. Said catchline formerly read "Street closings-School zones." 
Sec. 16:19. - Four-way stop signs. 
    That the stop signs are to be placed as follows: 
(1)  On North 2nd Street at its intersection with Camellia Avenue. 
    That the street supervisor shall direct the placing of proper street signs at the proper places as above described. 
(Ord. No. 03-08(A), §§ 1, 2, 3-11-08)

Sec. 16:30. - Authority of mayor and board of aldermen to install traffic-control signals. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen may provide for the procuring, erection and maintenance of traffic-control signals exhibiting the words "Go," "Caution" or "Stop" or exhibiting different-colored lights successfully one at a time, or with arrows, or directing pedestrians to "Walk," "Don't Walk" or "Wait," or exhibiting flashing red, yellow or amber lights, and it shall be unlawful to fail to comply with any such signals in the manner provided by LRS 32:232, 32:233, and 32:234; provided, however, that vehicles may turn right on a red or "Stop" signal, after coming to a complete stop and yielding the right-of-way to conflicting vehicles or pedestrian, unless there is in place at the location a sign or marking prohibiting such turns. 
Comment- See the note following § 16:4. Limited-application ordinances authorizing the erection of traffic-control devices at specific locations include the following:

Sec. 16:31. - Traffic-control devices on state highways, limitations. 
    No local municipal or parish authority shall place or maintain any traffic-control device upon any state-maintained highway without having first obtained the written approval of the state highway department. 
(LRS 32:235C) 
Comment- The above section and several other sections in this subchapter were derived from the Louisiana Highway Regulatory Act and not from local ordinances. They are, however, self-operative and add to the matters of law herein presented, and were, therefore, included herein for the convenience of the user. For source, see note at the end of each section. 
Sec. 16:32. - Specifications for traffic-control devices. 
    Local municipal and parish authorities in their respective jurisdiction shall place and maintain such traffic-control devices upon highways under their jurisdiction as they may deem necessary to indicate and to carry out the provisions of this chapter, regulations of the department and director of public safety adopted pursuant hereto, and local traffic ordinances adopted pursuant to the authority granted by R.S. 32:41 and 32:42. All such traffic-control devices hereafter erected shall conform to the department's manual or specifications. If any such device hereafter erected by a political subdivision of this state fails to conform to the manual or specifications, payment of any funds allocated to said political subdivision of this state shall be withheld by the department of highways until such time as the standards established by the department are complied with. 
(LRS 32:235B) 
Comment- See note following § 16:31.

    The mayor and board of aldermen may from time to time designate intersections or other places at which vehicles on a certain street or streets shall be required to stop and yield the right-of-way or yield the right-of-way without being required to stop to other vehicles or pedestrians. Suitable signs, signals or markings shall be erected giving notice of said designation and it shall be unlawful to fail to comply with any such sign, signal or marking. 
Comment- See the note following § 16:4. Ordinances establishing stop and yield intersections include the following:

Sec. 16:41. - Stop and yield signs, requirements. 
(a)  Preferential right-of-way at an intersection may be indicated by stop signs or yield signs. 
(b)  Except when directed to proceed by a police officer or traffic-control signal, every driver and operator of a vehicle approaching a stop intersection indicated by a stop sign shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway before entering the intersection. After having stopped, the driver shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles which have entered the intersection from another highway or which are approaching so closely on said highway as to constitute an immediate hazard. 
(c)  The driver or operator of a vehicle approaching a yield sign shall slow down to a speed reasonable for the existing conditions, or shall stop if necessary, before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection, or in the event there is no crosswalk, at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway. Having slowed or stopped in this manner, the driver shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian legally crossing the roadway on which he is driving, and to any vehicle in the intersection or approaching on another highway so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard. (LRS 32:123) 
Sec. 16:42. - Cutting corners to avoid traffic signals or signs prohibited. 
    No person operating a motor vehicle of any nature in the city shall drive through filling stations at intersections of streets or cut corners at intersections of streets for the purpose of evading the stop or wait required by electronic traffic lights, traffic signals or signs of any kind used at street intersections in the city. 
Sec. 16:43. - Stop required before exiting alleys. 
    All vehicles traveling upon the public alleys within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice shall come to a stop before entering the public streets. 
(Ord. No. A-91, 6-13-50; Ord. No. A-356, § 2, 8-13-68)

    The mayor and board of aldermen may from time to time designate specified streets or portions of streets for one-way traffic only. Appropriate signs shall be erected giving notice of such designation, and vehicles operated thereon shall be driven only in the direction designated, and a vehicle shall be driven as nearly as practicable, entirely within a single lane of traffic and shall not be moved from such lane of traffic until the driver has first ascertained that such movement can be made with safety.

Secs. 16:51-16:59. - Reserved. 
Sec. 16:60. - Following distances required of vehicles. 
(a)  The driver of a motor vehicle shall not follow another vehicle more closely than is reasonable and prudent, having due regard for the speed of such vehicle and the traffic upon and the condition of the highway. 
(b)  Motor vehicles being driven upon any roadway inside of the business or residential areas of Eunice, whether or not towing other vehicles, shall be so operated as to allow sufficient space between each such vehicles or combinations of vehicles so as to enable any other vehicle to enter and occupy such space without danger. This provision shall not apply to a funeral procession. 
(c)  Whoever commits the crime of following another vehicle too closely shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 5-70, §§ 1, 2, 3-10-70) 
Sec. 16:61. - Requirements governing passing on right. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle may overtake and pass upon the right of another vehicle only under the following conditions: 
(1)  When the vehicle overtaken is making or about to make a left turn; 
(2)  Upon a one-way street, or upon a highway on which traffic is restricted to one direction of movement, where the highway is free from obstructions and of sufficient width for two (2) or more lines of moving vehicles; 
(3)  Upon multiple-lane highways. 
(b)  The driver of a vehicle may overtake and pass another vehicle upon the right only under conditions permitting such movement in safety. In no event shall such movement be made by driving off the pavement or main traveled portion of the highway. 
(c)  Whoever commits the crime of passing on the right when it is not permitted shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 3-70, §§ 1, 2, 2-17-70) 
Sec. 16:62. - Walking on streets restricted. 
(a)  Between the curbs or between the ditches on either side of the street, it shall be unlawful for anyone to walk in or upon the streets within the City of Eunice, except for the purpose of crossing the street; and where there are no sidewalks, it shall be legal to walk on the left side thereof facing the oncoming traffic and in single file. 
(b)  Under no conditions shall two (2) or more persons walk abreast upon the public streets of the city. 
(c)  Anyone violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 17-69, §§ 1, 2, 10-14-69) 
Sec. 16:63. - Operation of vehicles with lugs on city streets restricted. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to operate upon the paved or hard-surfaced streets of the City of Eunice vehicles with lugs, tracks or other like contrivances. 
(b)  Anyone violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. A-88, §§ 1, 2, 12-6-49) 
Comment- See § 23:3 for inclusion of the above section. 
Secs. 16:64-16:69. - Reserved. 
Sec. 16:70. - Stopping, standing or parking-generally. 
    No person shall stop, park or leave standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended, upon the paved or main traveled part of any street or public way when it is practicable to stop, park or so leave such vehicle off such part of said street or public way, but in every event, an unobstructed width of the street or public way opposite a standing vehicle shall be left for the free passage of other vehicles and a clear view of such stopped vehicles shall be available from a distance of fifty (50) feet in each direction upon such street or public way. 
Sec. 16:71. - Stopping, standing or parking-prohibited in specific places. 
(a)  No person shall stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or traffic-control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk; 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway; 
(3)  Within an intersection; 
(4)  Within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant; 
(5)  On a crosswalk; 
(6)  Within twenty (20) feet of a crosswalk at an intersection; 
(7)  Within twenty (20) feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon stop sign or traffic-control signal located at the side of a roadway; 
(8)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb, or within twenty (20) feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone; 
(9)  Within fifty (50) feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing; 
(10)  Within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station, and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within seventy-five (75) feet of said entrance, when properly posted; 
(11)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic; 
(12)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street; 
(13)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within a highway tunnel; 
(14)  At any place where official signs prohibit such; 
(15)  Any place where parking will obscure or obstruct visibility of any traffic-control device. 
(b)  No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any such prohibited area or away from curb such a distance as is unlawful. (LRS 32:143) 
Comment- See note following § 16:31. 
Sec. 16:72. - Mayor and board of aldermen authorized to provide additional parking regulations. 
    In addition to the general parking restrictions provided above and provided by the Highway Regulatory Act in LRS 32:143 et seq., which are hereby adopted by reference, the mayor and board of aldermen may from time to time prohibit parking at specified places and/or times; or regulate the length of time a vehicle may remain parked; or regulate, limit or restrict the manner of parking; and it shall be the duty of the city to install and maintain appropriate signs, signals or markings giving notice of such regulations or restrictions. It shall be unlawful to fail to comply with the directions of any such sign or marking. 
Comment- See the note following § 16:4. Limited-application ordinances establishing parking regulations may be found in the following:
