Sec. 16:73. - Parking regulations, exceptions for disabled vehicles. 
    The provisions of this subchapter shall not apply to the driver of any vehicle that is disabled, so as to make it impossible to avoid stopping and leaving the vehicle thus parked. However, the driver shall remove the vehicle as soon as possible and not later than thirty-six (36) hours, and until it is removed, it is his responsibility to protect traffic on such street or road. 
Sec. 16:74. - Officers authorized to remove illegally parked vehicles. 
    Any police officer who finds a vehicle illegally parked on a street, lane or alley which obstructs traffic or creates a hazard is hereby authorized to move it, have it moved, or to require the person in charge of such vehicle to move it. 
Comment- See subchapter B of this chapter for regulations governing removal of abandoned automobiles. 
Sec. 16:75. - Parking of eighteen-wheelers regulated. 
(a)  Prohibition and exception. It shall be unlawful to park vehicles commonly known or identified as "eighteen-wheelers," whether it be the tractor portion, trailer portion, or both, on any streets or other public place situated within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice, or on any property not designated as a commercial or business parking area, save and except that the driver of such a vehicle shall be permitted to park the tractor portion only at his official residence, provided it is situated completely upon the property occupied by his residence. 
(b)  Penalty for violation. Any person convicted of any violation of any provision of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 5-86, §§ 3, 4, 6-10-86) 
Editor's note- Being not specifically amendatory of the Code, the provisions of §§ 3 and 4 of Ord. No. 5-86, adopted June 10, 1986, have been codified herein as a new § 16:75 at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference- Truck routes, § 16:5. 
Secs. 16:76-16:79. - Reserved. 
Sec. 16:80. - Designation of congested areas. 
    The following named and described areas, streets or portions of streets and such other areas, street or portions of streets as may hereafter be included in this section by amendment hereto, lying within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice, shall constitute congested areas and the same is hereby declared to be: 
(1)  Second street, west side, from north side of public alley between Ash and Park avenues, from alley to off-street parking lot of Dr. Fink Building. 
(2)  Walnut Avenue, from its intersection with west side of First Street to its intersection with east side of Third Street, both sides. 
(3)  Park Avenue, north side only, from a point one hundred four (104) feet east of the west side of Second Street, west to east side of Third Street. 
(4)  Vine Avenue, south side only, from its intersection with east side of Second Street to its intersection with west side of public alley. 
(Ord. No. A-85, § 2, 8-2-49; Ord. No. A-268, 6-21-63; Ord. No. A-208, 8-11-64) 
Comment- The various amending ordinances revised the boundaries of the congested areas. 
The preamble to Ord. No. A-85 set out the purpose of the regulations established therein as follows: 
"WHEREAS, the volume of traffic on the streets in certain sections of the Town of Eunice, Louisiana, has the effect of congesting the streets and impeding the movement of traffic, and 
"WHEREAS, the numerous operators of motor vehicles park on the streets of Eunice in the congested areas for unreasonably long periods of time, too near to other parked vehicles so parked on the most congested parts of the Town's busiest streets, and 
"WHEREAS, such practices retard orderly and even shopping intervals, impede traffic and constitute a danger to persons and property of motorists and pedestrians, and 
"WHEREAS, the mayor and board of aldermen of the Town of Eunice, Louisiana, are agreed that the best method by which these conditions may be remedied is by the designation of individual parking spaces in the area so congested, by restricting parking in said areas to reasonable intervals of time and by the compelling of operators of vehicles who use the parking space so designated to pay a portion of the cost of establishing and maintaining the same, and 
"WHEREAS, attempts to regulate traffic and parking in the congested areas have proved not as successful as desirable for the reason that adequate policing of this problem by the Police Department alone requires a larger number of officers for such work than can be spared from other necessary functions of the Police Department: 
"NOW THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED..." 
Sec. 16:81. - Congested area regulations-definitions. 
(a)  Where employed in these congested area regulations, the following words shall be defined as follows: 
(1)  Vehicle shall mean any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported upon the streets. 
(2)  Operator shall mean and include every individual who shall operate a vehicle as owner, agent, employee, permittee or licensee of the owner or is in physical control of a vehicle. 
(3)  Park or parking shall mean the standing of a vehicle whether occupied or not upon a street for a period of time in excess of two (2) minutes. 
(4)  Parking meter shall mean any mechanical device not inconsistent with these regulations erected for the regulation of parking by the authority of this City. Each parking meter installed shall indicate by proper legend, the legal parking time established by the City and when operated shall at all times indicate the balance of legal parking time and at the expiration of such period shall indicate illegal or overtime parking. 
(5)  Individual parking space shall mean any space within a parking meter zone, adjacent to a parking meter and which is duly designated for the parking of a single vehicle by lines painted or otherwise durably marked on the curb or on the surface of the street adjacent to or adjoining the parking meters. 
(Ord. No. A-85, § 1, 8-2-49) 
Sec. 16:82. - Town marshal, police department directed to designate parking spaces. 
    The town marshal and/or the department of police is hereby directed and authorized to mark off individual parking spaces in the congested area designated and described in section 16:80 above, said parking spaces to be designated by lines painted or durably marked on the curbing or surface of the street. At each space so marked off it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in such a way that said vehicle shall not be entirely within the limits of the space so designated. 
(Ord. A-85, 8-2-49, § 3) 
Sec. 16:83. - Installation of parking meters. 
    The city, through its authorized agents or contractor, shall cause to be installed parking meters upon the curb or sidewalk immediately adjacent to the parking spaces provided in section 16:82, above, designated "Congested Area", said installation to be placed not more than two (2) feet from the curb nor more than four (4) feet from the front line of the parking space as indicated; and the town marshal shall be responsible for the regulation, control, operation, maintenance and use of such parking meters. Each meter shall be so installed as to properly display a signal indicating legal parking upon the deposit of the appropriate coin or coins, lawful money of the United States of America, only, for the period of time prescribed in these regulations and each meter shall be so arranged that upon the expiration of the lawful time limit, it will indicate by a proper visible signal that the lawful parking period has expired and in such cases the right of such vehicle to occupy such space shall cease and the operator, owner, possessor or manager thereof shall be subject to the penalties hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. A-85, § 4, 8-2-49) 
Sec. 16:84. - Operation of parking meters. 
    When any vehicle shall be parked in any parking space alongside or next to which a parking meter is located, the operator of such vehicle shall upon entering said individual parking space, immediately deposit or cause to be deposited in said meter such proper coin as is required for such parking meter and as is designated by directions on the meter, and failure to deposit such proper coin shall constitute a violation of these regulations. Upon the deposit of such coin, the parking space may be lawfully occupied by such vehicle during the period of time which has been prescribed for the part of the street on which said parking space is located. If said vehicle shall remain parked in any such individual parking space beyond the parking time limit set for such space and if the meter shall indicate such illegal parking, in that event such vehicle shall be considered as parked overtime and beyond the period of legal parking time, and such parking shall be deemed a violation of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. A-85, § 5, 8-2-49) 
Sec. 16:85. - Parking time limits. 
    Parking or standing a vehicle in a designated individual parking space shall be lawful for twelve (12) minutes for each one cent coin deposited, or sixty (60) minutes for each five-cent coin deposited. 
    Parking meters shall be operated in the congested area provided for herein, every day between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., except Sundays and holidays; provided, however, that within the meaning of these regulations, the term "holiday" shall include the following days only: on the first day of January, fourth day of July, first Monday in September, Thanksgiving Day, and the twenty-fifth day of December, in each year. 
(Ord. No. A-85, § 6, 8-2-49) 
Sec. 16:86. - Additional parking time limits; violations, penalties. 
(a)  During all times between the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Sundays and holidays excluded, it shall be unlawful to park vehicles opposite parking meters or opposite parking meter poles, when said meters are not in operation, for a longer period than two (2) hours' time. 
(b)  Any vehicle parked in excess of two (2) hours and/or in violation of this section shall be towed to the police station and the owner and/or operator shall be liable for towing charges to be assessed as a part of cost. 
(c)  Anyone violating the provisions of this section shall be fined a sum not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than five dollars ($5.00), at the discretion of the city judge. 
(Ord. No. A-292, §§ 1-3, 7-27-65) 
Sec. 16:87. - Prohibited acts, parking violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person: 
(1)  To cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or operated by any such persons, to be parked overtime or beyond the period of legal parking time established for any individual parking space as herein described or to deposit in any parking meter any coin for the purpose of parking beyond the maximum legal parking time for the particular individual parking space. 
(2)  To permit any vehicle to remain or to be placed in any individual parking space adjacent to any parking meter which said meter is displaying a signal indicating that the vehicle occupying such parking space has already been parked beyond the period prescribed for such individual parking space. 
(3)  To park any vehicle across any line or marking of an individual parking space or in such position that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the area designated by such lines or marks. 
(4)  To deface, injure, tamper with, open or willfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter installed under these congested area provisions. 
(5)  To deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter any slugs, device or substance or other substitute for lawful coins. 
(6)  During all times between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., Sundays and holidays excluded, it shall be unlawful to park vehicles for a period longer than two (2) hours' time in parking spaces located on 2nd Street south of its intersection with Peach Avenue and north of its intersection of Park Avenue and in parking spaces on Walnut Street east of its intersection with Third Street and west of its intersection with CC Duson also known as First Street. 
(Ord. No. A-85, § 7, 8-2-49; Ord. No. 1000(A), 11-14-00; Ord. No. 0101(A), 2-13-01) 
Sec. 16:88. - Enforcement of parking regulations. 
    It shall be the duty of the town marshal and/or department of police to enforce these provisions pertaining to congested area parking. 
(Ord. No. A-85, § 8, 8-2-49) 
Sec. 16:89. - Collection of parking meter deposits. 
    It shall be the duty of the town marshal to designate some member or members of the police department to make regular collections of the moneys deposited in said meters and it shall be the duty of such persons so designated to remove from the parking meters the sealed containers therein containing the coins so deposited in said meters and to deliver such sealed containers with the seals unbroken, to the city clerk of the City of Eunice, to break the seals and count the funds contained therein and to deposit such funds with the fiscal agent bank of the city. 
(Ord. No. A-85, § 9, 8-2-49) 
Sec. 16:90. - Violations, penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate or fail to comply with any of the provisions of this subchapter, where no penalty is otherwise provided for, or who shall counsel, aid or abet any such violation or failure to comply shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1:21 of this Code. 
Secs. 16:91-16:99. - Reserved. 
Sec. 16:100. - Traffic laws apply to persons riding bicycles and motorcycles and motor-driven cycles. 
    Every person riding a bicycle, motorcycle or motor-driven cycle upon any street or road in this city shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by this subchapter and shall also be bound by those special requirements provided for in the Louisiana Highway Regulatory Act except as to those provisions which by their very nature can have no application. 
Cross reference- Bicycles, § 15:1 et seq. 
Sec. 16:101. - Operation of bicycles, motorcycles by more than one person prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for more than one person to ride or occupy at any given time a bicycle or motorcycle upon the streets or thoroughfares of the City of Eunice. 
(b)  It shall not be unlawful for more than one person to ride or occupy, or double, upon a bicycle or motorcycle upon the streets or thoroughfares of the City of Eunice, provided said vehicle, bicycle or motorcycle is specially equipped with seats or side cars for that purpose, but the installation of no such seating equipment may be placed in front of the operator or driver of the vehicle. 
(c)  Any person, firm or corporation who violates the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. A-74, §§ 1-3, 11-4-47) 
Cross reference- Bicycles, § 15:1 et seq. 
Sec. 16:102. - Special requirements for operators of motorcycles, motor-driven cycles. 
(a)  No person shall operate or ride upon any motorcycle or any motor-driven cycle unless said person is equipped with and is wearing on the head a safety helmet of the type and design manufactured for use by operators of such vehicles, which shall be secured properly with a chin strap while the vehicle is in motion, and each of said cycles shall be equipped with a rearview mirror. 
(b)  A person operating a motorcycle shall ride only upon the permanent and regular seat attached thereto. Such operator shall not carry any other person nor shall any other person ride on a motorcycle unless such motorcycle is designed to carry more than one person, in which event a passenger may ride upon the permanent and regular seat if designed for two (2) persons, or upon another seat firmly attached to the rear or side of the motorcycle, and in all such cases the vehicle shall be equipped with a foot rest for the passenger. 
(c)  Anyone violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. A-361, §§ 1-3, 10-8-68) 
Secs. 16:103-16:199. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER B. - ABANDONED VEHICLES[2] 

Footnotes:

 Depositing junk, wrecked or abandoned motor vehicles, § 9:41. 

Sec. 16:200. - Abandoning vehicles prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to leave an abandoned vehicle, as herein defined, upon the public property or upon private property, without the consent of the owner or the person in control of the property. 
(Ord. No. A-306, § 2, 1-13-66; Ord. of 9-8-81; Ord. No. 1-91, 2-13-91) 
State Law reference- See LRS 32:471 et seq.; for additional state authority on abandoned vehicles. 
Sec. 16:201. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this section, an "abandoned vehicle" shall mean: 
(1)  A motor vehicle that is inoperable and is left unattended on public property for more than five (5) days, or a motor vehicle that has remained illegally on public property for a period of more than five (5) days, or a motor vehicle that has remained on private property without the consent of the owner or person in control of the property for more than five (5) days. 
(Ord. No. A-306, § 1, 1-13-66; Ord. of 9-8-81; Ord. of 1-91, 2-13-91) 
Sec. 16:202. - Police department, street department authorized to remove abandoned vehicles. 
    The police department or the street department shall have the right to remove any abandoned vehicle from the public streets of Eunice, or from private property located in the city and to store same with any yard, firm or corporation engaged in such business or engaged in the car business or the wrecking business at a reasonable rental, at the expense of the owner. 
(Ord. No. A-306, § 3, 1-13-66; Ord. of 9-8-81)

Sec. 16:203. - Violations, penalties. 
    Anyone violating the provisions of this subchapter shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. A-306, § 4, 1-13-66) 
Note- See the editor's note to the title of this subchapter. 
Sec. 16:204. - Sale of abandoned vehicles. 
    The police department or the street department of the city is hereby authorized and empowered to sell any abandoned vehicle which has been removed and/or stored pursuant to the provisions of this subchapter, as amended, following the procedure outlined by the Louisiana Legislature in LRS 32:476. All costs of the sale, in addition to the costs of removal and storage, are to be reimbursed the city out of the proceeds of the sale. 
(Ord. of 9-8-81) 
Secs. 16:205-16:220. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER C. - FIRE LANES 

Sec. 16:221. - Establishment. 
    The governing body of the City of Eunice does hereby authorize the establishment and maintenance of fire lanes on both public and private property, within the city limits, such fire lanes to be designated and their locations and markings and signings to be within the sole discretion and authority of the chief of the fire department, after due consultation with the city police chief, the city building inspector and the state fire marshal. The fire chief shall henceforth have the power and authority to have fire lanes placed upon both public and private property, and shall the power of requiring owners and/or lessees of private property to establish said fire lanes and maintain same in accordance with legal specifications. This authority is not extended to supersede state law, but it is intended to be in addition thereto and to complement same. 
(Ord. No. 3-92, § 1, 1-14-92) 
Sec. 16:222. - Penalties for violating establishment and maintenance of fire lanes. 
    If any property owner or lessee refuses or fails to establish and maintain fire lanes, as directed by the city fire chief or the state fire marshal, the chief shall have the authority to enforce this subchapter by obtaining a court order from the city court, directing the owner to comply under penalty of contempt of court, the fine for each violation shall be not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or thirty (30) days confinement in the city jail, or both, at the discretion of the city judge. The city fire chief shall have the authority to issue citations and to order the arrest of violators. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate violation and the penalty may be assessed for each day the violation continues. The city fire chief may also order the work done for the establishment and/or maintenance of fire lanes on private property and the cost thereof shall be paid by the property owner or lessee in addition to the fine stated hereinabove. If a civil action becomes necessary to enforce collection of these costs, the property owner and/or lessee shall pay reasonable attorney's fees and court costs in addition to the actual costs. 
(Ord. No. 3-92, § 2, 1-14-92) 
Sec. 16:223. - Parking of nonauthorized vehicles in fire lanes and obstruction thereof prohibited. 
    It shall henceforth be illegal and in violation of this subchapter for any vehicle, cart, bicycle, motorcycle or objects or physical items of any nature to be parked, placed or left, at any time, on any fire lanes established and marked as such, within the city. The only exceptions to this no-parking [regulation] are vehicles and equipment being used by the fire departments, police departments, or life-saving personnel, and then only when it is deemed essential to do so because of a threat to the safety of lives or property. Any private vehicle or other object shall have a special permit prominently displayed on the body thereof, if designated as an official vehicle by the fire chief. It shall also be illegal and a violation of this subchapter to obstruct a fire lane, or access to a fire lane, by placing or leaving any physical object in a position that would reasonably be expected to so obstruct. 
(Ord. No. 3-92, § 3, 1-14-92) 
Sec. 16:224. - Penalties for violations. 
    Anyone found guilty of violating the provisions of section 16:223 hereinabove shall be fined no less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), plus court costs, or thirty (30) days confinement in the city jail, or both. In addition, if the vehicle or other object violating this subchapter was towed away or stored at the direction of the city police, the owner and/or operator thereof shall be assessed the cost of the towing and storage, in addition to the penalties stated hereinabove. Each separate day that a violation occurred shall be considered a separate violation, and a separate penalty may be applied for each day the violation continues or occurs. The owner of the vehicle or object in violation of this subchapter shall be presumed to be the person responsible, unless the vehicle or object was proven to be stolen. The operation thereof shall under any circumstances be penalized if found guilty. Both parties may be found guilty for the same violation, at the discretion of the city judge. 
(Ord. No. 3-92, § 4, 1-14-92) 
Sec. 16:225. - Authority of city police to enforce ordinance. 
    The city police shall have the power and authority to enforce the provisions of this subchapter by issuing citations to the operator and/or owner, or both, of the vehicle or other object allegedly violating same, by arresting the operator and/or owner and charging them with the violation thereof, and by ordering the vehicle or other object towed away and stored at any time. If a vehicle is towed away and stored, the owner and/or operator shall be responsible for the payment of costs thereof, as also provided hereinabove. The city police shall henceforth have full authority and power to enter upon public or private property to enforce the provisions of this subchapter, and any person preventing or obstructing them in any manner from entering or going upon public or private property, whether they be the owners or lessees thereof, shall be deemed in violation of this subchapter, and subject to the same penalties stated above, if found guilty by the proper court. If any person removes or damages signs or otherwise defaces signs or paintings in designated fire lanes or no-parking in fire lanes, such person shall also be deemed guilty of violating this subchapter and subject to the same penalties stated hereinabove. 
(Ord. No. 3-92, § 5, 1-14-92) 
Secs. 16:226-16:240. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER D. - RESTRICTED HANDICAPPED PARKING AREAS 

Sec. 16:241. - Applicability of ADA guidelines to public facilities and publicly used facilities. 
    The standards contained in the Americans with Disabilities (Civil Rights) Act Accessibility Guidelines for Buildings and Facilities, hereinafter referred to as "ADA Guidelines" are hereby adopted and shall be complied with at all public facilities and privately owned commercial facilities offering goals, services, lodging or other accommodations to the general public, except where otherwise provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 1, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:242. - Definitions. 
    As used in this subchapter: 
    Improved area includes parking lots, curbings, sidewalks, streets, harbors, parks, beaches, public telephones, recreational areas, drinking fountains, camping grounds and restrooms. 
    Mobility impaired person includes any person who is impaired because of any of the following conditions: 
(1)  Cannot walk two hundred (200) feet without stopping to rest. 
(2)  Cannot walk without the assistance of another person, walker, cane, crutches, braces, prosthetic device, or wheelchair. 
(3)  Is restricted by a lung disease to such an extent that the person's forced (respiratory) expiratory volume for one second, when measured by spirometry, is less than one liter, the arterial oxygen tension is less than sixty (60) mm/hg on room at rest. 
(4)  Uses portable oxygen. 
(5)  Has a cardiac condition to the extent that the person's functional limitations are classified in severity as class III or class IV according to standards act by the American Hearing Association. 
(6)  Has a diagnosed disease or disorder, including a severe arthritic, neurological, or orthopedic impairment, which creates severe mobility limitation. 
    Public facility means any building, structure, parking spaces, parking lots and other similar areas belonging to privately owned or publicly owned parking areas, or improved area to which the general public customarily has access or utilizes, and utilized for purposes of education, employment, transportation, or recreation; or, for the purchase, rental, or acquisition of goods and services, or housing other than a privately owned one-or two-family dwelling. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, §§ 1, 6, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:243. - ADA guidelines and exceptions thereto; universally accessible parking area design and scope. 
    The following standards shall apply to all existing public facilities: Restricted handicapped parking areas, access curbs, cuts and ramps, and accessible loading zones shall be provided by all business and parking lot owners, licenses, lessees and operators according to the following: 
(1)  Generally. The provisions of ADA Guidelines 4.1.2(1) and (5); however, the exception to 5(B) which refers to the Appendix A4.6.3 shall be the standard for restricted handicapped parking area design. 
(2)  Specifications of A4.6.3. Further, ADA Guidelines 4.3, 4.6, 4.7, and 4.8 shall apply as to parking areas; however, the specifications stated in Appendix A4.6.3 shall be the standard for restricted handicapped parking area design. 
(3)  Location: 
a.  Accessible parking spaces and passenger loading zones that serve a particular building shall be located within one hundred (100) feet of an accessible facility entrance if site conditions permit. Otherwise, they shall be located closest to the nearest accessible entrance on an accessible route not to exceed one hundred fifty (150) feet. 
b.  In separate parking structures or lots that do not serve a particular building, parking spaces for disabled people shall be located on the shortest possible accessible circulation route to an accessible pedestrian entrance of the parking facility. 
c.  The location of accessible parking spaces shall not compel disabled people to walk or maneuver behind other parked vehicles to reach the accessible route. If the accessible route must cross a traffic lane, it shall be demarcated and identified as stated herein with regard to aisles. 
d.  If a facility does not have accessible parking within one hundred fifty (150) feet of its accessible entrance, a passenger loading zone complying with ADA Guidelines 4.6.6 shall be provided at the shortest possible distance along the accessible route to the facility. 
(4)  Parking at accessible housing. Parking spaces at accessible housing shall be provided in accordance with the following: 
a.  Where parking is provided for all residents, on accessible parking space shall be provided for each accessible dwelling unit; and 
b.  Where parking is provided for only a portion of the residents, an accessible parking space shall be provided on request of the occupant of an accessible dwelling unit: 
c.  Where parking is provided for visitors, two (2) percent of the space, or at least one, shall be accessible. 
(5)  Parking spaces. All restricted handicapped parking areas shall comply with ADA Guidelines Appendix A4.6.3 "Universal Parking Space Design," and shall comply with the criteria indicated in Figure 1 and Figure 1 legend. 
(6)  Access aisles and routes. 
a.  Parking access aisles shall be part of an accessible route to the building or facility entrance and shall comply with ADA Guidelines 4.3. 
b.  If ramps or curb cuts are used to provide access to a building or an accessible route, they shall be aligned with access aisles. Curb ramps and cuts shall be located so that they will not be obstructed by parked vehicles or lifts. 
c.  Two (2) accessible parking spaces may share a common access aisle, but if the aisle is part of a single accessible space, it shall be on the right/passenger of the space. 
d.  Parked vehicle overhangs shall not reduce the clear width of an accessible circulation route. 
(7)  Demarcation. 
a.  Restricted handicapped parking spaces and access aisles shall be prominently outlined on four (4) sides with eight-inch-wide stripes of a blue color which contracts with the surrounding regular parking spaces. 
b.  The access aisle shall be included within the outlined area required above and shall be striped in the same blue color with diagonal stripes not less than four (4) inches wide. 
c.  If the accessible route must cross a traffic lane, it shall be demarcated and identified and striped in the same size stripes and blue color as the access aisle. 
d.  It shall be the responsibility of the owner, licenser, and/or operator of any public facilities, parking areas or other business subject to this section to paint the areas designated in the property size and color and erect the signage. 
(8)  Signage. In addition to ADA Guidelines 4.6.4., the following criteria shall apply. 
a.  Accessible parking spaces and loading zones shall be designated as reserved for persons with disabilities by an upright sign on a stationary post or object mounted at average windshield height and centered in front of the parked vehicle. 
b.  Enforcement of a voluntary compliance with proper use of accessible parking restrictions are enhanced by including a notice on the sign which states violation penalties. Therefore, signs stating notice of penalties are required as follows: 
FINES UP TO $500.00 
PLUS TOWING 
PLATE/CARD AND I.D. 
REQUIRED 
Also, in parking areas where shopping carts are used, the following words shall be included: 
NO CARTS 
(9)  Maintenance. It shall be the responsibility of the owners, licensees, and/or operators of public facilities, parking areas and/or businesses to see that the striping of the areas designated are maintained for visibility and that signs are replaced when necessary. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 2, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:244. - Penalties for violation by licensees, owners or operators. 
    Any owners, licensees, and/or operators of any businesses, parking area and/or public facilities who shall violate any of the provisions of this subchapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), or imprisonment not to exceed thirty (30) days of both. Each day's violation of the provisions hereof shall be deemed a separate offense, and subject to a separate penalty. Also, each location not in compliance shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 3, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:245. - Existing business/construction. 
    The owners, licensees, and/or operators of any business who has completed construction of any applicable facilities prior to March 1, 1992 does not have to comply until March 1, 1993 with the restricted handicapped parking space design requirements referred to in this section if all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  Alternative restricted handicapped parking spaces which allow equally appropriate and safe access to said business by all persons with mobility impairments have been provided, and 
(2)  Compliance with the handicapped parking space design requirements referred to in this section either: 
a.  Would not be "readily achievable"; or 
b.  Would create and "undue burden" as defined by the Americans with Disabilities (Civil Rights) Act (ADA) of 1990 (Public Law 101-336). 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 4, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:246. - Authority to grant exceptions to standards and specifications; grounds. 
    In cases of undue burden or lack of ready achievability, the city building inspector may, with the concurrence of the city council, grant exceptions from the literal requirements of the standards and specifications required by this subchapter or permit the use of other methods or materials, but only when it is clearly evident that equivalent facilitation and protection are thereby secured. Unless a written exception is granted by the city building inspector, any unauthorized deviation from the standards shall be rectified by full compliance within fifteen (15) days after discovery of the deviation and delivery of a copy of the order requiring remedying of the deviation to the occupant or any person in charge of the premises personally or by registered or certified mail. If no person is found on the premises the order may be served by affixing a copy thereof in a conspicuous place on the door at the entrance of the premises. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 5, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16-247. - Restricted handicapped parking areas for persons with mobility impairments. 
    A restricted handicapped parking area for the mobility impaired consists of the parking space, access aisle and adjacent route, ramp and curb cut. No person shall park or place any object in a restricted handicapped parking area set aside and identified for use only by persons with mobility impairments unless the motor vehicle is actually transporting a person eligible for the mobility impaired placard or license plate, bearing the international wheelchair symbol and the vehicle has displayed therein a mobility impaired parking placard as provided in LA Revised Statutes, Title 47, Chapter 463.4 B(1) or 463.4(2) or license plate bearing the international wheelchair symbol issued pursuant to LA Revised Statutes, Title 37, Chapter 463.4(1), other special mobility impaired license plate or placard statute, or any subsequent replacement statutes dealing with parking for mobility impaired persons or as set forth by United States Public Law 100-641. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 5A, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:248. - Wrongful use of or blocking restricted handicapped parking area, access aisle, route, ramp or curb cuts. 
    Any person who either: 
(1)  Parks in such a restricted area without either a handicapped license plate or placard and actually transporting the person eligible for the license plate or placard; or, 
(2)  Effectively prevents the use of such a restricted area access aisle, route, ramp or curb cut in any manner, 
shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or shall be imprisoned for no more than ten (10) days, or both. On the second and subsequent offense, the person shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than thirty (30) days, or both; except that if a nonmotorized object such as a shopping cart, bicycle, large box or other item is used to violate this provision, then the stated penalties are optional and shall not apply to the owner of the object unless the owner is responsible for the object being placed in violation hereof. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 7, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:249. - Violations occurring during inclement weather or at night. 
(a)  Whenever any violation of any of the provisions of this subchapter occurs during any of the following conditions which may exist at any time during the violation, then the applicable penalties shall be doubled: 
(1)  During any form and degree or level of precipitation, such as and including, but not limited to, rain, sleet, hail or snow; or 
(2)  Any time between sunset and sunrise and at any other time when, due to insufficient light or unfavorable atmospheric conditions, persons and vehicles on the highway are not clearly discernible at a distance of five hundred (500) feet ahead. 
(b)  Whenever any violation of any of the provisions of this subchapter occurs during any of the following conditions which may exist at any time during the violation, such conditions shall be aggravating circumstances which are to be considered in the imposition of sentence: When the surrounding air temperature is either: 
(1)  Above ninety (90) degrees Fahrenheit; or 
(2)  Below thirty-two (32) degrees Fahrenheit. 
    Proof of the surrounding air temperature may be made by any reliable or verifiable evidence and source such as and including, but not limited to, a report of the temperature made by any National Weather Service agency for the area. 
    Further, the existence of frozen water (ice) outdoors within the city will create a rebuttable presumption that the surrounding air temperature is below thirty-two (32) degrees Fahrenheit. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 8, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:250. - Persons wrongfully obtaining mobility impaired parking plate or card. 
    Any person who is not a mobility impaired person as prescribed by LRS 47:463.4(E)(1), any other mobility impaired parking statute, or any subsequent replacement statutes and who represents himself/herself as having the qualifications to obtain such special license plate, parking card, or mobility impaired identification card shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), or shall be imprisoned for not more than ten (10) days, or both. On the second and subsequent offenses, the person shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or shall be imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days or both. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 9, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:251. - Physician or other person who wrongfully issues mobility impaired certification. 
    Any physician or other person who improperly certifies that a person is mobility impaired in order to allow a person to obtain the special license plate, parking card, or mobility impaired identification card discussed in this subchapter and authorized by LRS 47:464.4(E)(1) or any replacement statute shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), or shall be imprisoned for not more than ten (10) days, or both. On the second and subsequent offenses, the physician or staff shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or shall be imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 10, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:252. - Failure to transport a mobility impaired person. 
    Any person who utilizes a parking card or a vehicle bearing a special license plate to obtain handicapped parking privileges and has not transported a mobility impaired person as defined in this subchapter or in LRS 47:463.4(E)(1) in that vehicle prior to parking the vehicle, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or shall be imprisoned for not more than ten (10) days, or both. On the second and subsequent offense, shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or shall be imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 11, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:253. - Allowing abuse of privileges by mobility impaired persons. 
    Any mobility impaired person who permits his/her parking card or specially licensed vehicle to be used to illegally access handicapped parking privileges by an individual not entitled to use such special handicapped parking privileges may be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or shall be imprisoned for not more than ten (10) days for the first offense, or both. On the second and subsequent offenses, the individual shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), or shall be imprisoned not more than twenty (20) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 12, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:254. - Towing illegally parked vehicles. 
    Any vehicles illegally parked in a restricted handicapped parking area may be towed away from such zones and placed in storage. The costs of towing, storage and redemption of such towed vehicles shall be paid by the owner of such vehicle in addition to any fines designated herein. The city police are authorized and empowered to order the towing done by a commercial towing service to enforce this subchapter in addition to other remedies. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 13, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:255. - Mobility impaired I.D. card required for Louisiana residents. 
    Not later than January 1, 1995, any mobility impaired person who is a Louisiana resident and has a special license plate or parking card shall also have a pictured identification card issued by a state level issuing authority in his/her possession when using handicapped parking areas. Without such identification, such persons may be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or shall be imprisoned for not more than ten (10) days, or both when found guilty of violating this provision. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 14, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:256. - Law enforcement authority to enter onto private property. 
    All law enforcement officers of the city are hereby vested with full authority to direct, control, or regulate traffic or parking are authorized to enter upon private property within their territorial jurisdiction to enforce the provisions of this subchapter, and are empowered to issue citation and/or arrest the operator and/or owner of the vehicle or other object used in the violation, or any other persons violating this subchapter. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 15, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:257. - Rebuttable presumption of operation. 
    When an officer issues a citation for an alleged violation of the laws of governing restricted handicapped parking area, there shall be a rebuttable presumption that the person/owner in whose name the vehicle is registered was the operator of the vehicle when the alleged violation was committed. As such, the owner is responsible for the violation and subject to the applicable penalties unless such person/owner can provide adequate proof of the actual operator's possession and use of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation and the current street address of the operator. These provisions shall apply to vehicles owned by business entities. Further, the owners, managers, officers and any employees having authority and control regarding the use of any business vehicle at the time of the violation are also subject to the fines, restrictions and provisions stated herein regarding registered owners. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 16, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:258. - Reciprocity of out-of-state licenses and placards. 
    Every mobility impaired person operating or otherwise being transported by a vehicle displaying the international symbol of the handicapped or the word "handicapped" on a valid special license plate, disabled veteran license plate, or other handicapped parking permit prominently displayed shall be entitled to invoke all handicapped parking privileges provided in this subchapter without regard to the location of the issuing authority, or the residence or domicile of the person invoking the handicapped parking privileges. "Issuing authority," as defined in this section, shall mean only the Louisiana Office of Motor Vehicles of the Department of Public Safety and Corrections or comparable state level government issuing authorities in or outside the State of Louisiana. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 17, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 16:259. - Theft or criminal damage to handicapped sign, post, or object. 
    Any person who commits theft (as defined in LRS 14:67) or commits an act of criminal damage to property (as defined in LRS 14:56) regarding a sign, post or any object designating a restricted handicapped parking area, as defined in this subchapter, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned for thirty (30) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 4-92, § 18, 1-23-92) 
Chapter 17 - PARKS, RECREATION AND LIBRARIES 
SUBCHAPTER A. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17:1. - Creation of recreation commission; membership; organization; powers and duties; reports. 
(a)  There is hereby established and created a recreation commission for the City of Eunice, Louisiana. 
(b)  The name of the commission shall be "The Recreation Commission of the City of Eunice". 
(c)  The commission shall consist of no more than thirteen (13) members who shall serve without pay, and who shall be appointed by the board of aldermen of the City of Eunice. 
(d)  The term of office of the members of the recreation commission shall be for a term of four (4) years, or until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(e)  Immediately after their appointment, the recreation commission shall meet and organize and shall elect one of their members president and such other officers as may be necessary. At the organizational meeting, the recreation commission shall adopt by-laws, rules and regulations for the proper conduct of the recreation commission. 
(f)  The function and duties of the recreation commission shall be to plan for the provision, conduct and supervision of public playgrounds, recreation centers, and other recreation facilities and activities for the populace of the City of Eunice. 
(g)  Pursuant to the general powers hereinabove enumerated, the recreation commission shall pass upon and recommend to the board of aldermen of the City of Eunice any and all personnel to be hired by the City of Eunice, as well as the duties of any such employees and the salaries of any such employee. 
(h)  Not later than June 1 of each year, the recreation commission shall submit a budget to the board of aldermen of the City of Eunice for its approval. 
(i)  Not later than the first Tuesday of each month, the recreation commission shall make a full and complete monthly report to the mayor and board of aldermen, as to finances, personnel, compensation of personnel and progress of programs, as well as any and all matters of public interest in connection with the powers hereinabove set forth. 
(j)  No later than June 1 of each year, the said recreation commission shall submit an annual report of those subjects enumerated in paragraph (i) hereof. 
(k)  In addition to those reports hereinabove provided for, the recreation commission shall also make other reports, from time to time, as requested by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(l)  The recreation commission shall have the power to solicit money or goods, or receive gifts of money or goods, or donations, to be applied, in both principal and income, for either temporary or permanent use, for playgrounds or other recreational purposes in the City of Eunice, all of which money and goods received by it shall be turned over to the board of aldermen of the City of Eunice for disposition. 
(Ord. No. A-235, §§ 1-12, 7-11-61; Ord. No. 0900(B), 10-10-00) 
Editor's note- The above ordinance superseded Ord. No. A-133 of May 11, 1954. 
Sec. 17:2. - Use of ponds at the "nature trail." 
(a)  In order to [protect] the safety and welfare of its citizens, and simultaneously protect the environment, the board of aldermen deem it necessary to prohibit anyone from swimming, wading, using boats or jet skis, or similar apparatus, in the pond or ponds located or to be located on the "Nature Trail" park constructed by the City of Eunice on Maple Avenue. 
(b)  The city police, the city building inspector and the director of the street department are hereby authorized to make an arrest and detain suspects for violation of this section. 
(c)  Violations of this section shall subject the violator or violators to the provisions and penalties imposed by Section 1:21 of the City of Eunice Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 11-97(A), §§ 1-3, 12-9-97) 
Sec. 17:3. - Recreation director. 
    The city shall employ a recreation director who shall be hired by the mayor with the approval of the board of aldermen. The approval of the board of aldermen shall not be necessary to terminate the recreation director. The recreation director shall be responsible for organizing and supervising all recreational activity sponsored by the City of Eunice and the supervising of the maintenance of all recreational facilities owned or leased by the City of Eunice. 
    The individual appointed to the position of recreation director shall be selected only after the position has been advertised for and interviews conducted. The salary for the position shall be included as part of the overall recreation director budget. 
    In addition to the duties provided in Section 17:1, the recreation commission shall meet quarterly to review and monitor the recreation department and the job performance of the city recreation director and make appropriate recommendations to the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 03-02(B), 4-9-02) 
Secs. 17:4-17:49. - Reserved. 
Sec. 17:50. - Remaining on park property after certain hours prohibited. 
(a)  All city parks in the City of Eunice, excluding ballparks, tennis courts and basketball court pavilions, shall be opened to the public from sunrise until sunset and the Eunice Community Nature Trail and Walking Park shall be open to the public from 4:00 a.m. to sunset. 
(b)  No person shall enter the city's parks properties, excluding ballparks, tennis courts and basketball court pavilions, or remain thereon between sunset and sunrise, and between 4:00 a.m. and sunset at the Eunice Community Nature Trail and Walking Park, except by special written permission from the mayor. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. A-82, §§ 1-3, 9-15-48; Ord. No. 02-15(A), 3-10-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 02-15(A), adopted March 10, 2015, amended the catchline of § 17:50 to read as herein set out. Said catchline formerly read "Remaining in park property after certain hours prohibited." 
Sec. 17:51. - Remaining on city lake property after hours prohibited. 
(a)  The city lake operated by the City of Eunice shall be open to the public from sunrise to sunset. No person shall enter the city lake property or remain thereon between the hours of sunrise and sunset except by special written permission from the mayor. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 0499(F), 5-11-99; Ord. No. 02-15(B), 3-10-15) 
Secs. 17:52-17:99. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER B. - LIBRARIES 

Sec. 17:100. - Creation of Opelousas-Eunice Public Library. 
    The City of Eunice avails itself of the provisions of L.R.S. 33:1321 et seq. by the entering into of an agreement with the municipality of Opelousas, for the promotion, maintenance, support and operation of a public library known as the Opelousas-Eunice Public Library. 
(Ord. No. A-331, § 1, 4-11-67) 
Editor's note- Pursuant to the below cited authority, the city, by resolution of Nov. 12, 1974, also agreed to participate with the Parishes of Acadia, Evangeline, Iberia, Lafayette, Lafourche, St. Martin, St. Mary, Terrebonne and Vermillion and the City of Opelousas in a cooperative project to improve the library service in south central Louisiana, said cooperative system being designated the Bayouland Library System. The resolution sets forth the method of organization and operation of the system between the several participants. 
State Law reference- Authority of local governing bodies to create cooperative facilities and systems for greater economy and efficiency, L.R.S. 33:1321 et seq. 
Sec. 17:101. - Creation of Opelousas-Eunice Board of Commissioners, powers and duties. 
    For the purpose of administering any agreement made hereunder, and the operating, maintaining and supporting of the library, the mayor and board of aldermen of the municipality of Eunice, by this subchapter, agrees with the mayor and board of aldermen of the municipality of Opelousas, to create a joint commission to be known as the Opelousas-Eunice Public Library board of commissioners, who shall be clothed with all the powers and duties authorized or conferred by law and by this subchapter. 
(Ord. No. A-331, § 2, 4-11-67) 
Sec. 17:102. - Mayors of Opelousas and Eunice to be ex-officio members of library board. 
    The mayors of the respective municipalities of Eunice and Opelousas shall be ex-officio members of the Opelousas-Eunice Public Library Board of Commissioners. 
(Ord. No. A-331, § 3, 4-11-67) 
Sec. 17:103. - Appointment of members to library board. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen of the City of Opelousas shall appoint three (3) members, and the mayor and board of aldermen of the City of Eunice shall appoint two (2) members of the Opelousas-Eunice Public Library Board of Commissioners, which commissioners shall serve without pay. 
(Ord. No. A-331, § 4, 4-11-67) 
Sec. 17:104. - Terms of office of library board members. 
    The first commissioners appointed shall, at their first meeting, draw lots to determine the term of each. The terms of all succeeding commissioners appointed by the respective municipalities, by their respective governing authorities, shall be five (5) years. 
(Ord. No. A-331, § 5, 4-11-67) 
Sec. 17:105. - Financing of Opelousas-Eunice Public Library. 
    The operation of the Opelousas-Eunice Public Library shall be financed by: The municipality of Opelousas shall appropriate, dedicate and budget from its monies available for such purpose, sixty (60) percent of the total cost for the operation of said Opelousas-Eunice Public Library, and the municipality of Eunice shall appropriate, dedicate and budget, from its monies available such purpose, forty (40) percent of the total cost of the operation of said library. 
(Ord. No. A-331, § 6, 4-11-67) 
Sec. 17:106. - Powers and duties of library board; officers. 
    The Opelousas-Eunice Public Library Board of Commissioners shall have authority to establish rules and regulations for its own government and for the administration of this subchapter and any agreement pursuant to same, and the operation of the Opelousas-Eunice Public Library, not inconsistent with law or with the provisions of this subchapter; to elect a President, Vice-President, Secretary and Treasurer; to elect and employ a librarian, and, upon the recommendation and approval of the latter, to employ assistant librarians and other employees and fix their salaries and compensation, provided that no person shall be employed as head librarian, who has not been certified by the State Board of Library Examiners, as provided by the State Board of Library Examiners, as provided by R.S. 25:222. The office of Secretary and Treasurer may be held by one person, who may be the head librarian. In any case, the Secretary-Treasurer, or Treasurer of said Board, shall furnish bond with good and solvent surety in favor of the Opelousas-Eunice Public Library Board of Commissioners, for such amount as said board may determine and conditioned as required by law. 
(Ord. No. A-331, § 7, 4-11-67) 
Comment- LRS 25:222, cited above, specifies that all persons wishing to practice the profession of librarian, in order to obtain requisite certificates or permits for same, must apply to and be approved by a State Board of Library Examiners, according to the state board's established rules and regulations. 
Sec. 17:107. - Reserved. 
Sec. 17:108. - Acquisition of immovable property. 
    Should immovable property be acquired by either the municipality of Opelousas or the municipality of Eunice, the immovable property shall remain that of the municipality so acquiring same. 
(Ord. No. A-331, § 8, 4-11-67) 
Sec. 17:109. - Eunice Branch Manager salary. 
    The salary of the manager of the Eunice Branch of the Opelousas-Eunice Public Library shall be paid by the City of Eunice as a Eunice city employee with all rights attendant to that status. The City of Eunice shall receive credit for such salary in computing its proportionate share of the Opelousas-Eunice Public Library budget as specified in Section 17:105 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 08-13, 9-10-13) 
Chapter 18 - PLANNING AND ZONING 
SUBCHAPTER A. - MUNICIPAL PLANNING COMMISSION 

Sec. 18:1. - Municipal planning commission created. 
    There is hereby created a municipal planning commission which shall consist of five (5) members, all to be appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the board of aldermen who may remove any member of the commission, after public hearing for inefficiency, neglect of duty or malfeasance. 
(Ord. No. A-293, § 1, 8-10-65) 
Comment- See LRS 33:101 et seq. for authority of municipalities to create planning commission. Also, see LRS 33:4726, which provides that before a municipality can adopt any zoning restrictions, it must create a planning and zoning commission to develop and recommend restrictions. 
Sec. 18:2. - Municipal planning commission; terms of office of members; vacancies. 
    All members of the commission shall serve without compensation and shall hold no other public office. The members of the commission first appointed shall hold office for terms of one, two, three, four and five years, respectively; their successors shall be appointed for a term of five (5) years from and after the expiration of the term of their predecessors in office. If a vacancy occurs otherwise than by an expiration of term, it shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. A-293, § 2, 8-10-65) 
Sec. 18:3. - Municipal planning commission; chairman and officers; meetings; rules. 
    The commission shall elect a chairman from its members and operate and fill such other of its offices as it may determine. The term of chairman shall be one year, with eligibility for re-election. The commission shall hold at least one regular meeting each month. It shall adopt rules for transaction of business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which record shall be a public record. 
(Ord. No. A-293, § 3, 8-10-65) 
Sec. 18:4. - Municipal planning commission; employees and expenses. 
    The commission may appoint such employees as it may deem necessary for its work and may also contract with planning experts, engineers, architects and other consultants for such services as it may require. The expenditures of the commission, exclusive of those made from funds received by gift, shall be within the amounts appropriated for that purpose by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. A-293, § 4, 8-10-65) 
Sec. 18:5. - Municipal planning commission, powers and duties. 
    The commission shall exercise all of the powers and duties conferred by R.S. 33:101 through R.S. 33:119, inclusive. 
(Ord. No. A-293, § 5, 8-10-65) 
Sec. 18:6. - Municipal planning commission to serve as municipal zoning commission. 
    The commission herein established shall serve as a municipal zoning commission, and when acting as such, it shall hold separate meetings with separate minutes and records. When acting as the municipal zoning commission, it shall exercise all of the powers and duties conferred by R.S. 33:4721 through R.S. 33:4729. 
(Ord. No. A-293, § 6, 8-10-65) 
Comment- LRS 33:4721 through 4732, referred to above, provides the general authority and procedure for implementing the authority granted to municipalities with regard to zoning regulations. See Section 17, Art. 6, La. Const. (1974) for current constitutional authority for local governmental bodies to enact zoning and land use controls. 
Secs. 18:7-18:39. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER B. - REGIONAL PLANNING COMMISSION 
PART I. - ST. LANDRY REGIONAL PLANNING COMMISSION 

Sec. 18:40. - St. Landry Parish regional planning commission established. 
    There is hereby created the St. Landry Parish regional planning commission under the authority granted in Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1950, Title 33, Part IV, Subpart C, Sections 131-140 inclusive. 
(Ord. No. 21-69, § 1, 12-9-69) 
Comment- LRS 33:131, cited above, provides the basic statutory authority for the creation of regional planning areas. LRS 33:132, et seq. provides for the creation of regional planning commissions, the organization of such commissions, their general powers and duties, etc. 
Ordinance No. 21-69 superseded Ordinance No. A-279 of August 11, 1964. 
Sec. 18:41. - St. Landry regional planning commission, planning area. 
(a)  The St. Landry Parish planning region is hereby established as consisting of the unincorporated area within St. Landry Parish, and also the area lying within the municipalities of St. Landry Parish and other parishes and parts thereof adjacent to St. Landry Parish which choose to adopt the necessary ordinance to become an official part of the planning region. 
(b)  Establishment of such a planning region is authorized under Section 132 of Revised Statutes of 1950, Title 33, Part IV, Subpart C. The described area is declared to be an urban and urbanizing area with a population of more than fifty thousand (50,000) persons, and such area has been classified by the department of housing and urban development as an urban and urbanizing area for comprehensive planning purposes. 
(Ord. No. 21-69, § 2, 12-9-69) 
Sec. 18:42. - St. Landry regional planning commission, appointment of members. 
(a)  The planning commission membership shall be open ended with the total membership at any one time influenced by the number of municipalities, parishes, and/or parts thereof participating in the planning program; however, the membership of the planning commission shall consist of not less than nine (9) members. 
(b)  The members shall serve without compensation and they may hold other appointive or elected public office, provided same is not prohibited by law. 
(c)  Appointments to the commission will be made by the presidents of any parish police jury participating in the regional planning program and by the mayors of municipalities participating in the program. Appointments to the commission will be based upon the following: the president of the St. Landry Parish police jury shall appoint a total of nine (9) members with two (2) members being appointed for each of wards one and six, and one member for each of the remaining wards. The mayor of each municipality adopting this ordinance will be entitled to appoint one member for each ten thousand (10,000) or fraction thereof of population in the municipality. The presidents of police juries of adjacent parishes adopting this ordinance will be entitled to appoint a member for each ward included in this commission. 
(d)  Of the members first appointed by the president of the St. Landry Parish police jury, one member shall hold office for a term of one year, one for a term of two (2) years, one for a term of three (3) years, one for a term of four (4) years, one for a term of five (5) years, one for a term of six (6) years, one for a term of seven (7) years, one for a term of eight (8) years, and one for a term of nine (9) years. 
(e)  Members appointed to the planning commission who hold other public offices, appointed or elected, shall serve terms co-extensive with their terms of other public office. All other appointments to the commission shall be for terms of five (5) years. The successors of the members first appointed shall be appointed for a term of five (5) years from and after the expiration of the terms of their predecessors in office. 
(f)  If a vacancy occurs otherwise than by expiration of a term, it shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired term. Such appointments shall be made by the original appointing authority. 
(Ord. No. 21-69, § 3, 12-9-69) 
Sec. 18:43. - St. Landry regional planning commission, powers and duties. 
    The powers and duties of the regional planning commission shall be as provided by law, particularly Revised Statutes of 1950, Title 33, Part IV, Subpart C. 
(Ord. No. 21-69, § 4, 12-9-69) 
Sec. 18:44. - St. Landry regional planning commission, municipal participation. 
(a)  Any municipality, parish, or parts thereof, within or adjacent to St. Landry Parish may elect to participate in the regional planning program by adopting an ordinance making such municipality, parish, or part thereof, a part of the planning region and agreeing to provide its share of the cost of preparing detailed comprehensive plans for the land within the municipality. 
(b)  A municipality electing to participate in the regional planning program will make arrangements with the regional planning commission for the preparation of the municipality's entire comprehensive plan or a portion of such comprehensive plan and to harmonize such plans with the overall plans for the parish as a whole. The regional planning commission may cooperate with and provide such planning assistance and technical services as necessary to prepare such comprehensive plans for the municipalities. 
(c)  The legislative body of any municipality may, by ordinance, designate the St. Landry Parish regional planning commission as its municipal planning commission. Upon such designation, the regional planning commission shall have all the powers and functions relating to making, adopting, amending, and adding to the comprehensive plan of the municipality as granted by Louisiana Revised Statutes 33:101 through 33:119 inclusive. Any municipality taking this action shall pay to the designated commission that portion of the expenses of the regional planning commission which is properly chargeable to the planning service rendered to the municipality. 
(d)  Plans prepared for a municipality by the regional planning commission at the request of a municipality, which has not designated the regional planning commission as the official municipal planning commission do not have any legal status unless and until such plans are adopted by the municipal planning commission after public hearing, as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 21-69, § 5, 12-9-69) 
Secs. 18:45-18:74. - Reserved. 
PART II. - ACADIANA REGIONAL PLANNING COMMISSION 

Sec. 18:75. - Creation of Acadiana regional planning area. 
(a)  Pursuant to the provision of LRS 33:131, there is to be created a regional planning area, which may include, but not limited to, the area shown on the map attached to Ordinance No. 13-75 and made a part of this section. The minimum number of parishes to comprise the Acadiana regional planning area shall be two (2) in number. 
(b)  As soon as two (2) or more of the contiguous parishes included in the Acadiana regional planning area, as per the map (identified as Acadiana regional planning area) have adopted this or an identical ordinance, then the existence of the Acadiana regional planning area shall be created, effective immediately upon adoption by the first two (2) parishes, within Acadiana regional planning area, as per LRS 33:131. 
(Ord. No. 13-75, §§ 1, 2, 7-8-75) 
Comment- For explanation of LRS 33:131 et seq., cited in the above Section, see note following Section 18:40, this Code. LRS 33:1321, et seq., cited below, authorizes two (2) or more municipalities, or two (2) or more parishes, or any combination thereof, to join together to cooperatively render governmental functions or services. 
Sec. 18:76. - Creation of Acadiana planning and development district. 
    For the purpose of exercising the powers and duties set forth in LRS 33:131 through 140, inclusive, and LRS 31:1321 through 1332, inclusive, there is to be hereby created the Acadiana planning and development district. As soon as two (2) or more of the contiguous parishes included in the Acadiana regional planning area, as per the map (identified as Acadiana regional planning area) have adopted this or an identical ordinance, then the existence of the Acadiana planning and development district shall be created, effective immediately upon adoption by the first two (2) parishes, within the Acadiana regional planning area, as per LRS 33:131. 
(Ord. No. 13-75, § 3, 7-8-75) 
Sec. 18:77. - Evangeline economic development district board designated as Acadiana planning and development district governing body. 
    In accordance with Section 132(C) of LRS 33:131 through 140, the governing body of this Acadiana planning and development district hereby designated to be the board of directors of the Evangeline economic development district, an economic development district duly authorized by the governor of the State of Louisiana, and duly designated by the United States department of commerce, economic development administration. It is expressly understood that the privilege to act or vote on matters coming before the Acadiana planning and development district shall be limited to the Evangeline economic development district board members who represent parishes and municipalities that have adopted this identical ordinance, and EEDD members-at-large who reside in parishes and municipalities that have adopted this identical ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 13-75, § 4, 7-8-75) 
Sec. 18:78. - Effectiveness of part; filing of materials. 
    This Part shall be effective in and for the Acadiana regional planning area described above upon the adoption of this and one more identical ordinance by one more governing authority of an adjacent parish within the Acadiana regional planning area. As and when this ordinance becomes effective, it shall be filed, together with its accompanying map and copies of the other identical ordinances adopted by governing authorities, in the official offices of the member units of government as per LRS 33:131. 
(Ord. No. 13-75, § 5, 7-8-75) 
Sec. 18:79. - Expansion of district; filing names of participating member units. 
(a)  The Acadiana planning and development district may be expanded to include additional parishes and incorporated areas, by passage of this identical ordinance. 
(b)  A true and correct list of all governing bodies passing this identical ordinance shall be filed with the official office of each such governing body. 
(Ord. No. 13-75, §§ 6, 7, 7-8-75) 
Secs. 18:80-18:99. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER C. - ZONING REGULATIONS, IN GENERAL 
PART I. - ESTABLISHMENT OF DISTRICTS; PROVISION FOR OFFICIAL MAP 

Sec. 18:100. - Establishment of districts; provision for official map. 
    All the area within the corporate limits of Eunice, Louisiana is hereby divided into districts, as shown on the official zoning map which, together with all explanatory matter thereon, is hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this subchapter. These districts are as follows: 
R-1 Residence B-2 Highway Business R-2 Residence B-3 Central Business B-1 Local Business M-1 Industrial  
(Ord. No. 6-71, § 1.01, 6-29-71) 
Comment- The basis for enactment of these zoning regulations is set forth in the preamble to Ordinance No. 6-71, which reads as follows: 
"WHEREAS, Revised Statutes of 1950, Title 33:4732, empower Louisiana municipalities to enact a zoning ordinance and to provide for its administration, enforcement, and amendment, and 
"WHEREAS, the Eunice mayor and board of aldermen deem it necessary for the purpose of promoting the health, safety, morals, or general welfare of the city to enact such an ordinance, and 
"WHEREAS, the Eunice planning commission has divided the city into districts and has prepared regulations pertaining to such districts in accordance with a comprehensive plan and designed to lessen congestion in the public streets, secure safety from fire, panic, and other dangers, to provide adequate light and air, to prevent the over-crowding of land, to avoid undue concentration of population, and to facilitate the adequate provision of transportation, water, sewerage, schools, parks, and other public requirements, and 
"WHEREAS, they have been made with reasonable consideration, among other things, as to the character of each district and its peculiar suitability for particular uses, and with a view to conserving the value of buildings and encouraging the most appropriate use of land throughout the city, and 
"WHEREAS, the Eunice planning commission has made a preliminary report and held public hearings thereon, and submitted its final report to the mayor and board of aldermen, and 
"WHEREAS, all requirements of Title 33:4721-4732 of Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1950, with regard to preparation of the report of the planning commission and the subsequent action of the mayor and board of aldermen, have been met; 
"NOW THEREFORE BE IT ORDAINED BY THE MAYOR AND BOARD OF ALDERMEN OF THE CITY OF EUNICE, LOUISIANA THAT THE FOLLOWING ZONING REGULATIONS ARE ADOPTED ...." 
Sec. 18:101. - Identification of zoning map. 
    The official zoning map shall be identified by the signature of the mayor, attested to by the city clerk, and bearing the following words: "This is to certify that this is the official zoning map referred to in Article 1, Section 1.01 of Ordinance No. 6-71 of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, adopted on June 29, 1971. (Section 18:100, this Code). 
(Ord. No. 6-71, § 1.02, 6-29-71) 
Sec. 18:102. - Changes in the zoning map. 
    Changes made in the district boundaries or other matter portrayed on the official zoning map in accordance with the provision of this subchapter shall be made on the official zoning map promptly after the amendment has been approved by the legislative body of the municipality. It will be the duty of the city clerk to file with the building inspector a copy of the ordinance amending the official zoning map within five (5) days after such an amending ordinance is adopted by the mayor and board of aldermen. It will be the duty of the building inspector to record the district boundary change on the official zoning map, together with the number of the amending ordinance and the date of its passage, within five (5) days after the amending ordinance has been transmitted to the building inspector by the city clerk. No amendment involving changes in the district boundaries or involving a change in the zoning classification of the land within the city shall become effective until after such an entry has been made on said map. Regardless of the existence of maps purported to be copies of the official zoning map, the final authority as to the current zoning status of lands, buildings, and other structures shall be the official zoning map which shall be located in the office of the building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 6-71, § 1.03, 6-29-71) 
Sec. 18:103. - Changes in the zoning text. 
    When an ordinance is adopted which amends the text of this subchapter, it will be the duty of the city clerk to prepare an addendum to the text of this subchapter, and to transmit a suitable number of copies of such an addendum to the building inspector for the purpose of distribution to interested parties. It will be the duty of the building inspector to make an entry in the copies of the zoning text reserved for distribution to the general public calling attention to the particular section which has been amended. 
(Ord. No. 6-71, § 1.04, 6-29-71) 
Sec. 18:104. - Rules for interpretation of district boundaries. 
(a)  Where uncertainty exists as to the boundaries shown on the official zoning map, the following rules shall apply: 
(1)  Boundaries indicated as approximately following the center lines of streets, highways, or alleys, shall be construed to follow such lines. 
(2)  Boundaries indicated as approximately following platted lot lines, shall be construed as following such lot lines. 
(3)  Boundaries indicated as approximately follow-city limits, shall be construed as following city limits. 
(4)  Boundaries indicated as following railroad lines, shall be construed to be midway between the main tracks. 
(5)  Boundaries indicated as following shore lines, shall be construed to follow such shore line and in the event of change of the shore line, shall be construed as moving with the actual shore line. 
(6)  Boundaries indicated as parallel to or extensions of features indicated in subsections (1)-(5) above shall be so construed. Distances not specifically indicated on the official zoning map, shall be determined by the scale of the map. 
(7)  Where the street or property layout existing on the ground is at variance with that shown on the official zoning map, or in other circumstances not covered by subsections (1)-(6) above, the board of adjustment shall interpret the district boundaries. 
(Ord. No. 6-71, § 1.05, 6-29-71) 
Sec. 18:105. - Division of lot by district boundary. 
    Where a district boundary divides a lot existing as of June 29, 1971, and the major portion of said lot is in the less restrictive district, the regulations relative to that district may extend as well to such portion of said lot as is not more than twenty (20) feet within the more restrictive district. 
(Ord. No. 6-71, § 1.06, 6-29-71) 
Secs. 18:106-18:120. - Reserved. 
PART II. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 18:121. - Zoning affects every structure and use. 
    No structure or land shall hereafter be used and no structure or part thereof shall be erected, reconstructed, converted, moved, or structurally altered unless in conformity with the regulations as set forth in this subchapter. However, buildings which are legally nonconforming with respect to yard areas or height may be structurally altered or enlarged providing the portion of the building which is altered or the portion of the building which is added is in conformity with the provisions of this subchapter. 
(Ord. No. 6-71, § 2.01, 6-29-71) 
Sec. 18:122. - Only one principal building on any lot.
