(3)  In the areas lying within the limits of the transition zones beyond the perimeter of the horizontal zone, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than seventy-five (75) feet of vertical height above the ground except when such tree or structure, because of terrain, land contour or topographic features would extend above the height limit prescribed for such transition zones. 
Nothing contained in any of the foregoing exceptions shall be construed as permitting or intending to permit any construction, alteration or growth of any structure or tree in excess of any of the height limits established by this subchapter except as set forth in Section 18:303. 
(b)  Existing uses: No permit shall be granted that would allow the establishment or creation of an airport hazard or permit a nonconforming use, structure, or tree to be made or become higher, or become a greater hazard to air navigation, than it was on June 18, 1965 or any amendments thereto or than it is when the application for a permit is made. Except as indicated, all applications for such a permit shall be granted. 
(c)  Nonconforming uses abandoned or destroyed: Whenever the administrative agency determines that a nonconforming structure or tree has been abandoned or more than eighty (80) percent torn down, physically deteriorated, or decayed, no permit shall be granted that would allow such structure or tree to exceed the applicable height limit or otherwise deviate from the zoning regulations. 
(d)  Variances: Any person desiring to erect or increase the height of any structure, or permit the growth of any tree, or use his property not in accordance with the regulations prescribed in this subchapter, may apply to the board of appeals for a variance from such regulations. Such variances shall be allowed where it is duly found that a literal application or enforcement of the regulations would result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship and the relief granted would not be contrary to the public interest but will do substantial justice and be in accordance with the spirit of this subchapter. 
(e)  Hazard marking and lighting: Any permit or variance granted may, if such action is deemed advisable to effectuate the purpose of this subchapter and be reasonable in the circumstances, be so conditioned as to require the owner of the structure or tree in question to permit the administrative agency at the expense of the City of Eunice, to install, operate, and maintain thereon such markers and lights as may be necessary to indicate to flyers the presence of an airport hazard. 
(Ord. No. A-291, § 7, 6-18-65) 
Comment- See Section 5:1, this Code, for general building regulations. See also Section 18:253, above, for building permits. 
Sec. 18:307. - Administration of airport zoning regulations. 
    The city engineer is hereby delegated the duty of administering and enforcing the zoning regulations herein adopted and is likewise entrusted with the administrative duty of hearing and deciding all permits under LSA-R.S. 2:385 (A). 
(Ord. No. A-291, § 8, 6-18-65) 
Sec. 18:308. - Enforcement of airport zoning regulations. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineer to administer and enforce the regulations prescribed herein. Applications for permits and variances shall be made to the city clerk upon a form furnished by him. Applications required by this subchapter to be submitted to the city engineer shall be promptly considered and granted or denied by him. Applications for action by the board of appeals shall be forthwith transmitted by the city clerk to the chairman of the board of appeals. 
(Ord. No. A-291, § 9) 
Sec. 18:309. - Airport zoning regulations, board of appeals. 
(a)  There is hereby created a board of appeals to have and exercise the following powers: (1) to hear and decide appeals from any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the administrative agency in the enforcement of this subchapter; (2) to hear and decide special exceptions to the terms of this subchapter upon which such board of appeals under such regulations may be required to pass; (3) to hear and decide specific variances. 
(b)  The board of appeals shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the board of aldermen of the City of Eunice and each shall serve for a term of three (3) years except as hereinafter provided and until his successor is duly appointed and qualified. Of the members first appointed one shall be appointed for a term of one year, two (2) for a term of two (2) years and two (2) for a term of three (3) years. Members shall be removable by the appointing authority for cause, upon written charges, after a public hearing. 
(c)  The board of appeals shall adopt rules for its governance and procedure in accordance with the provisions of this subchapter. Meetings of the board of appeals shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such other times as the board of appeals may determine. The chairman, or in his absence the acting chairman, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. All hearings of the board of appeals shall be public. The board of appeals shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member upon each question, or, if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall immediately be filed in the office of the city clerk and shall be on public record. 
(d)  The board of appeals shall make written findings of fact and conclusions of law giving the facts upon which it acted and its legal conclusions from such facts in reversing, affirming, or modifying any order, requirement, decision, or determination which comes before it under the provisions of this subchapter. 
(e)  The concurring vote of a majority of the members of the board of appeals shall be sufficient to reverse any order, requirement, decision, or determination of the administrative agency or to decide in favor of the applicant on any matter upon which it is required to pass under this subchapter, or to effect any variation in this subchapter. 
(Ord. No. A-291, § 10, 6-18-65) 
Sec. 18:310. - Procedure for appeals. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved, or any taxpayer affected, by any decision of the administrative agency made in the administration of this subchapter, if of the opinion that a decision of the administrative agency is an improper application of these regulations, may appeal to the board of appeals. 
(b)  All appeals hereunder must be taken within a reasonable time as provided by the rules of the board of appeals, by filing with the city clerk a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The city clerk shall forthwith transmit to the board of appeals all the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 
(c)  An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the administrative agency certifies to the board of appeals, after the notice of appeal has been filed with it, that by reason of the facts stated in the certificate a stay would, in its opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property. In such case, proceedings shall not be stayed except by order of the board of appeals on notice to the agency from which the appeal is taken and on due cause shown. 
(d)  The board of appeals shall fix a reasonable time for hearing appeals, give public notice and due notice to the parties in interest, and decide the same within a reasonable time. Upon the hearing any party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney. 
(e)  The board of appeals may, in conformity with the provisions of this subchapter, reverse or affirm, in whole or in part, or modify the order, requirement, decision or determination appealed from and may make such order, requirement, decision, or determination, as may be appropriate under the circumstances. 
(Ord. No. A-291, § 11, 6-18-65) 
Sec. 18:311. - Judicial review. 
    Any person aggrieved, or any taxpayer affected by any decision of the board of appeals, may present to the district court of the parish a verified petition as provided in LSA-R.S. 2:387 (A). 
(Ord. No. A-291, § 12, 6-18-65) 
Sec. 18:312. - Violations, penalties. 
    Each violation of this subchapter or of any regulation, order, or ruling promulgated hereunder shall constitute a misdemeanor and be punishable as provided by Section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. A-291, § 13, 6-18-65) 
Sec. 18:313. - Conflicting regulations. 
    Where there exists a conflict between any of the regulations or limitations prescribed in this subchapter and any other regulations applicable to the same area, whether the conflict be with respect to the height of structures or trees, the use of land, or any other matter, the more stringent limitation or requirement shall govern and prevail. 
(Ord. No. A-291, § 14, 6-18-65) 
Sec. 18:314. - Short title. 
    This subchapter shall be known and may be cited as "Eunice Municipal Airport Zoning Ordinance". 
(Ord. No. A-291, § 1, 6-18-65) 
Chapter 19 - RAILROADS AND COMMON CARRIERS 
SUBCHAPTER A. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19:1. - Public carrier vehicles; findings and declaration of policy. 
    The legislature of Louisiana, in the exercise of its police power, hereby finds and declares that the operation of public carrier vehicles (as herein defined) within this state is a business affected with the public interest; that there has been within this state a marked increase in the number of such vehicles, and use thereof, with a consequent increase in hazards to the general public; that such vehicles in particular, are not adequately protected against risks resulting from the operation of such vehicles; that uniform remedial legislation is required to correct and eliminate the conditions adversely affecting the public interest, to insure as far as practicable that the public will receive the benefits of more responsible operation of such vehicles; that the health, safety, morals and welfare of the public make it imperative that effective, uniform, reasonable and just supervision, regulation and control be exercised over the operation of such vehicles to ensure their responsibility in order that the paramount interest of the public be protected and conserved, that irresponsible operation of such vehicles detrimental to the public interest be prevented, and that this remedial legislation should be construed liberally and enforced strictly in favor of the public; and that penalties for violations should be prescribed. 
(LRS 45:200.1) 
Comment- As indicated by the source note, the provisions contained in the above section, and the sections that follow in this subchapter were derived from the Louisiana Revised Statutes and not from a local ordinance. Because the provisions are self-operative, and add to the matter of law herein presented, they were included in this Code for the convenience of the user. 
Sec. 19:2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, when used in Section 19:1 through 19:15 have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except when a different meaning is expressly stated or clearly indicated by the context. 
(1)  Certificate means a formal printed or written certificate of public necessity and convenience issued to an owner of a public carrier vehicle by municipal or parochial authority, evidencing consent of such authority to operation of such vehicle. 
(2)  Public carrier vehicle means and includes any motor vehicle, having a normal seating capacity of less than ten (10) passengers, used for the transportation of passengers for hire over any streets by a route or to a destination controlled by the passenger. Nothing herein contained shall be construed to include carriers by motor vehicle subject to the jurisdiction of the Louisiana Public Commission under LRS 45:161 et seq., or engaged solely in interstate commerce. 
(3)  Person means and includes any individual, corporation, association, and their lessees, assigns, trustees or receivers. 
(4)  Street means and includes any street, avenue, road, park, parkway, highway or other public place in the state of Louisiana, including all municipalities and parishes thereof. 
(LRS 45:200.2) 
Sec. 19:3. - Necessity of municipal or parochial consent for operation of public carrier vehicles. 
    No public carrier vehicle shall be operated upon any street in any municipality or parish until the owner thereof shall have applied for, and shall have received from the municipality or parish, a certificate issued by the duly designated authority thereof. 
(LRS 45:200.3) 
Sec. 19:4. - Insurance required of public carrier vehicles. 
    No such certificate shall be issued until the owner of the public carrier vehicle shall first have filed with the duly designated authority of the municipality or parish in which such operation is permitted, a policy of liability insurance issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in this state. Said insurance policy shall provide for payment of a sum not less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) to satisfy all claims for damages by reason of bodily injury, to or death of, any one person resulting from any one accident, and subject to said limit for one person, for payment of a sum not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) to satisfy all claims for damages by reason of bodily injury to, or death of, two (2) or more persons, resulting from any one accident, and for payment of a sum not less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) to satisfy all claims for damage to property resulting from any one accident, by reason of the ownership, operation, maintenance or use of such vehicle upon any street. 
(LRS 45:200.4) 
Sec. 19:5. - Blanket insurance policies authorized. 
    If such owner operates more than one public carrier vehicle, he may file with the duly designated authority of the municipality or parish, in lieu of the policy required by Section 19:4, a policy or policies of liability insurance issued by a company or companies authorized to do business in this state, insuring payment of claims for each public carrier vehicle operated by such owner in the amounts provided in Section 19:4. 
(LRS 45:200.5) 
Sec. 19:6. - Self-insurance authorized. 
    In lieu of the insurance coverage required under Section 19:4, or permitted under Section 19:5, the owner of one or more public carrier vehicles may act as self-insurer, provided that he shall have filed, and shall refile annually with the duly designated authority of the municipality or parish, a financial statement certified by a certified public accountant showing an unencumbered net worth of such owner in excess of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) in current assets within the state of Louisiana; and shall also have filed with such authority a policy or policies of liability insurance issued by one or more underwriters or insurance companies amenable to suit in Louisiana, insuring payment of claims for each public carrier vehicle operated by such owner, in the amounts fixed in Section 19:4, in excess of a maximum of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) for personal injury to, or death of, any one person, a maximum of thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00) for personal injury to, or death of, any one person, a maximum of thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00) for personal injury to, or death of, two (2) or more persons, resulting from any one accident. The certificate or certificates of such owner shall be effective, and operation thereunder shall be permitted, only so long as the insurance shall remain in force as herein provided. 
(LRS 45:200.6) 
Sec. 19:7. - Effectiveness of certificate of public carrier vehicle. 
    The certificate for any public carrier vehicle or vehicles of an owner thereof shall be effective, and operation shall be permitted thereunder, only so long as the insurance required under Section 19:4, or permitted under Section 19:5, as to such vehicle or vehicles shall remain in force as therein provided, or the statement of financial responsibility required under Section 19:6 shall be filed currently each year and the insurance required under said section shall remain in force with regard thereto. 
(LRS 45:200.7) 
Sec. 19:8. - Appointment of secretary of state as agent to receive service of process. 
(a)  The acceptance by an owner of a public carrier vehicle or vehicles, of a certificate issued by the duly designated authority of a municipality or parish, shall be deemed appointment, by such owner, of the secretary of state of Louisiana, to be his true and lawful attorney for service of process, upon whom may be served all lawful process, whether issued out of a court or by other lawful authority, in any action or proceeding involving such owner by reason of ownership, operation, maintenance or use of such vehicle or vehicles upon any street; and acceptance of such certificate shall constitute agreement by such owner that any such process against him so served shall be of the same legal force and validity as if served on him personally. 
(b)  When any process of pleadings are served upon the secretary of state, it shall be by duplicate copies, one of which shall be filed in the office of the secretary of state and the other immediately forwarded by the secretary of state by registered mail to the address shown on such certificate of such owner against whom the process and pleadings are directed. The secretary of state shall note on the copy retained the date, the manner and other particulars of service, and disposition of the forwarded copy. 
(c)  To facilitate service of process on such owners, the duly designated authority of each municipality and parish shall make and deliver in January of each year to the secretary of state, printed or typed certified lists giving in alphabetical order, the full names and addresses of all owners of public carrier vehicles holding valid certificates issued by said authority. 
(LRS 45:200.8) 
Sec. 19:9. - Certificate of compliance; contents; filing and posting. 
    Upon filing by the owner of a public carrier vehicle or vehicles, of the required financial statement or insurance policy, the duly designated authority of the municipality or parish shall issue a certificate for each such vehicle. This certificate shall show that the owner of such vehicle has complied with the requirements of this section, and shall recite the full name of the owner of the vehicle and of the insurer together with the number and date of expiration of the policy, a description of the vehicle insured thereunder, and the number thereof. The original certificate shall be posted conspicuously within the vehicle. The issuing officer shall retain and preserve a duplicate of the certificate. 
(LRS 45:200.9) 
Sec. 19:10. - Operation in more than one municipality or parish; filing of insurance policy; statement and copies of certificate. 
    When a public carrier vehicle operates in more than one municipality or parish, the insurance policy required by Section 19:4, or permitted under Section 19:5 and Section 19:6, together with the statement of financial responsibility required under Section 19:6, shall be filed with duly designated authority of the municipality or parish in which the owner has his principal place of business, who shall issue copies of the certificate, which shall be filed by the owner with the duly designated authority of every other municipality or parish in which said vehicle is operated. 
(LRS 45:200.10) 
Sec. 19:11. - Other automobile laws applicable. 
    Nothing in Sections 19:1-19:15 shall exempt any person owning or operating any public carrier vehicle from complying with all applicable laws and municipal and parochial ordinances relating to the ownership, registration and operation of automobiles in this state. 
(LRS 45:200.11) 
Sec. 19:12. - Name of owner and number of certificate to be painted on vehicle. 
    The full name of the owner of each public carrier vehicle operated as a taxi-cab, and the number of the vehicle's certificate, shall be painted conspicuously on each side of the vehicle in letters and figures at least two (2) inches high. 
(LRS 45:200.12) 
Sec. 19:13. - Effect on certificates previously issued; new certificates required. 
    Certificates of public necessity and convenience heretofore issued by municipalities or parishes and now validly outstanding are hereby recognized as valid hereunder for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days from the effective date of Sections 19:1-19:15, and each such certificate shall become null and void and deemed revoked at the end of said period. 
(LRS 45:200.13) 
Sec. 19:14. - Enforcement by civil remedy. 
    The provisions of Sections 19:1-19:15 may be enforced by appropriate civil remedy in any court of competent jurisdiction by governmental authority or by any person having an interest affected, directly or indirectly, by any violation thereof. 
(LRS 45:200.14) 
Sec. 19:15. - Violations, penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall operate a public carrier vehicle upon any street without complying with, or in violation of, any provision of Sections 19:1-19:15 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or imprisoned for not less than sixty (60) days nor more than one year, or both. 
(b)  Conviction hereunder shall, if so ordered, carry with it cancellation of the certificate or certificates involved, permanently or for a fixed period, as the court shall direct. No such certificate shall be re-issued in favor of the person in whose name it stood when cancelled permanently, as herein provided, except by authority of a judge of the court which ordered its cancellation. 
(c)  Violation by a partnership, corporation or association shall be presumptive evidence of such violation by all partners, officers and directors thereof, and any such partner, officer or director who knowingly, or without exercise of due and reasonable care and inquiry, consented to, permitted or approved, directly or indirectly, such violation, in whole or in part, shall be subject to the penalties hereinabove provided. 
(LRS 45:200.15) 
Sec. 19:16. - Construction. 
    The Legislature hereby declares that Sections 19:1 through 19:15 are remedial in nature and shall be construed liberally in favor of the public in general, and the users of public carrier vehicles in particular, and to exact strict compliance by the owners and operators of public carrier vehicles with the requirements of Sections 19:1-19:14. 
(LRS 45:200.16) 
Secs. 19:17-19:49. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER B. - CITY TAXI-CAB REGULATIONS 

Sec. 19:50. - Permits required for operation of motor vehicles for hire. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate in the corporate limits of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, a motor vehicle for hire without first obtaining a driver's permit from the town marshal, chief of police, of the City of Eunice, for the operation of said motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. A-261, § 1, 3-19-63) 
Comment- Ordinance No. A-261 superseded Ordinance No. A-258 of January 8, 1963 and part of Ordinance No. A-247 of July 10, 1962. 
Sec. 19:51. - Applicants for permits to operate motor vehicles for hire to be fingerprinted and photographed. 
    Every person wishing to engage in the operation of a motor vehicle for hire within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice, shall make application for said permit for the operation of said motor vehicle to the town marshal, chief of police, of the City of Eunice, and shall be fingerprinted and photographed. 
(Ord. No. A-261, § 2, 3-19-63) 
Sec. 19:52. - Permits to be issued in name of applicant. 
    The permit shall be issued in the name of the applicant and shall entitle only the person thereon shown to operate a motor vehicle for hire. 
(Ord. No. A-261, § 3, 3-19-63) 
Sec. 19:53. - Reasons for denial of driver's permit. 
(a)  A driver's permit shall not be issued to any person who within one year prior to his application shall have been: 
(1)  Convicted of a felony under the laws of the State of Louisiana, or of any other state, and whose citizenship has not been restored. 
(2)  Convicted of being the keeper of a house of ill fame; or who was directly or indirectly connected therewith or interested therein; or who was convicted of pandering or of any other crime opposed to decency and morality. 
(3)  Convicted of drunken driving or who was convicted more than once of reckless driving and/or speeding. 
(Ord. No. A-261, § 4, 3-19-63) 
Comment- The source ordinance superseded Ordinance No. A-258 of January 8, 1963 with respect to reasons for denial. 
Sec. 19:54. - Insurance requirements, taxi-cab drivers. 
(a)  No one shall operate upon the public streets of the City of Eunice, a motor vehicle or taxi-cab for hire, which vehicle has not been licensed or unless such unit is insured by a company authorized to do business in the State of Louisiana under a policy of liability insurance or bond. Said insurance shall be for such minimum amounts as provided in Sections 19:4 and 19:5, this Code, or in lieu thereof, self-insurance as provided in Section 19:6. 
(b)  The applicant for license or permit shall file with the city clerk a certificate or other satisfactory evidence of the insurance or self-insurance as required above. 
(Ord. No. 247, §§ 2, 3, Rev., 9-10-72) 
Comment- Ordinance No. 247 provided for lower minimum amounts of insurance and was accordingly revised to conform to current state law requiring higher limits as set forth in Sections 19:4, 19:5 and 19:6, above. 
The source ordinance superseded Ordinance No. A-65 of April 2, 1946. 
Sec. 19:55. - Revocation of taxi-cab driver's permit. 
(a)  A driver's permit when issued shall, at the discretion of the mayor, be revoked for a period of not less than sixty (60) days, nor more than one year, upon the occurrence of any of the following: 
(1)  Upon conviction of a felony under the laws of the State of Louisiana or any other state. 
(2)  Upon conviction as being the keeper of a house of ill fame; or of any other crime opposed to decency and morality. 
(3)  Upon conviction of drunken driving or of hit and run driving. 
(4)  Upon conviction within a three-year period of the following: 
a.  Three (3) offenses of speeding 
b.  Three (3) offenses of reckless driving 
c.  Four (4) offenses of stop sign violation 
d.  Four (4) offenses of traffic light violation 
(Ord. No. 261, § 5, 3-19-63) 
Sec. 19:56. - Physical qualifications of applicants; brake inspection of vehicle required. 
(a)  The city clerk shall not issue an operating permit to anyone until the applicant shall have furnished a medical certification from a reputable physician reflecting the physical fitness of the applicant and that he has proper eyesight and hearing, which medical certification shall accompany the application for permit. 
(b)  In addition, no one shall operate a public vehicle or taxi-cab carrying passengers for hire unless the vehicle be equipped with adequate, proper and efficient brakes, and the carrier or operator shall furnish to the city marshal a certification from a reputable mechanic that the brakes on the vehicle are in good condition. The city marshal shall issue to such carrier a brake inspection tag bearing date of issue. Each such certificate and inspection tag shall be void ninety (90) days after issue. 
(Ord. No. A-65, 5-4-68) 
Sec. 19:57. - Violations, penalties. 
    In addition to the penalties provided in Section 19:55, anyone violating any of the provisions of this subchapter shall be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. A-261, § 6, Rev., 3-19-63) 
Secs. 19:58-19:99. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER C. - TRAINS 

Sec. 19:100. - Speed limit for trains established. 
    It shall be unlawful for any train to operate within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, at a speed in excess of twenty-five (25) miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. A-277, § 1, 4-14-64) 
Comment- The source ordinance superseded Ordinance No. 8 of June 18, 1895; Ordinance No. 50 of December 7, 1909 and Ordinance No. 62 of March 5, 1912. 
Sec. 19:101. - Blocking of intersections by trains restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any train to block any of the street crossings within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, for a period in excess of five (5) minutes. 
(Ord. No. A-277, § 2, 4-14-64) 
Sec. 19:102. - Violations, penalties. 
    Any individual found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this subchapter shall be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. A-277, § 3, 4-14-64) 
Chapter 20 - RETIREMENT AND PENSION PLANS 
SUBCHAPTER A. - MUNICIPAL EMPLOYEES RETIREMENT SYSTEM 
PART I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20:1. - Declaration of intention to have municipal employees enrolled in Municipal Employees Retirement System. 
    It is hereby declared the policy and purpose of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, to extend the provisions of Act No. 356, Regular Session, Louisiana Legislature of 1954, providing retirement to eligible officers and employees of the City of Eunice, Louisiana. In pursuance of said policy, and for said purpose, the officers and employees of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, shall take such action as may be required by applicable state laws or regulations. The coverage of eligible officers and employees shall be retroactive to January 1, 1955. 
(Ord. No. 3-71, § 1, 2-9-71) 
Comment- Act 356 of 1954, cited in the above section, has been codified in the Revised Statutes as LRS 33:7151 et seq. Generally, these laws provide for the creation of the Municipal Employees Retirement System, membership therein, creditable service, benefits and administration of the program. 
Ordinance No. 3-71 superseded Ord. No. A-305 of January 13, 1966, and Ord. of December 11, 1956. 
The city also passed a resolution on February 9, 1971, providing for back payment into the system for the retroactive period, as follows: 
"WHEREAS, the great majority of the officers and employees of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, have indicated their desire to take part in the Retirement Plan under the Municipal Employees Retirement System of Louisiana. 
"AND WHEREAS, by Ordinance No. 3-71, adopted the 9th day of February, 1971, the City of Eunice, Louisiana did formally adopt the said Retirement Plan, retroactive to January 1, 1955. 
"AND WHEREAS, in order to institute said plan, it is necessary to pay into said Retirement Plan the sum of approximately forty thousand dollars ($40,000.00) for back service time for officers and employees of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, which said back service time shall be retroactive to January 1, 1955. 
"AND WHEREAS, the City of Eunice, Louisiana, has verbally agreed heretofore to pay the said amount necessary to that back service time for officers and employees of the City of Eunice will be retroactive to January 1, 1955, the amount necessary to be paid so as to acquire said back service time to be paid in five (5) annual installments into the Retirement Plan. 
"NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED by the mayor and board of aldermen of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, that the City of Eunice does hereby bind and obligate itself to pay into the retirement plan under the Municipal Employees Retirement System of Louisiana such sum as is necessary to pay for back service time of officers and employees of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, retroactive to January 1, 1955, said amount being estimated roughly as being in the approximate amount of forty thousand dollars ($40,000.00), or such other sum as shall be determined by the board of trustees of the Municipal Employees Retirement System of Louisiana as being necessary to pay for back service time, the initial installment to be made with submission of this resolution, together with ordinance and contract documents, to the board of trustees of the Municipal Employees Retirement System of Louisiana; provided, however, that in the event any officer or employee is retired prior to the payment in full of the amount necessary to pay for said back service time for him, the City of Eunice will at said time, pay to the Municipal Employees Retirement System the amount necessary to pay for the back service time of such retired officer or employee." 
Sec. 20:2. - Mayor authorized to enter into agreement with MERS board. 
    The mayor of the City of Eunice is hereby authorized and directed to execute an agreement with the board of trustees of the Municipal Employees' Retirement System to secure coverage of eligible officers and employees as provided in Section 20:1 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 3-71, § 2, 2-9-71) 
Sec. 20:3. - Employees contributions; withholdings from wages. 
    Withholdings from salaries or wages of officers and employees for the purposes provided in Section 20:1 hereof are hereby authorized to be made in the amount and at such times as may be required by the board of trustees in accordance with Act No. 356 of 1954, and shall be paid over to the board of trustees in such amounts and at such times as are designated by State laws and regulations of said agency. 
(Ord. No. 3-71, § 3, 2-9-71) 
Comment- For amount of withholdings, see LRS 33:7392. 
Sec. 20:4. - Employer contributions; administrative expenses. 
    Employer contributions and assessment for administrative expenses shall be paid from amounts appropriated for such purposes to the board of trustees in accordance with applicable state laws and regulations of said board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 3-71, § 4, 2-9-71) 
Comment- See LRS 33:7401 for the amounts the MERS board can assess member municipalities for operating expenses. 
Sec. 20:5. - City clerk to maintain records. 
    The city clerk shall maintain such records and submit such reports as may be required by applicable State laws or regulations of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 3-71, § 5, 2-9-71) 
Comment- See LRS 33:7393 for specific record keeping and reporting requirements of the city clerk with respect to the MERS program. 
Secs. 20:6-20:19. - Reserved. 
PART II. - SUPPLEMENTAL BENEFITS AND CANCELLATION OF SOCIAL SECURITY 

Sec. 20:20. - Social security coverage cancelled. 
    The City of Eunice, Louisiana, avails itself of the provisions of Section G of the contract and agreement by and between the board of trustees of the public employees board of Louisiana and the Town of Eunice, now City of Eunice, dated August 20, 1956; and directs the mayor of the City of Eunice to notify the public employees board of its election to cancel and terminate the agreement effective June 30, 1976. 
(Ord. No. 11-74, § 1, 6-11-74) 
Comment- Ordinance No. 11-74 superseded an Ordinance of July 6, 1956. 
The basis for withdrawal from the social security system is set forth in the preamble to Ordinance No. 11-74, which reads as follows: 
"WHEREAS, the City of Eunice, pursuant to an ordinance enacted by said municipality, July 6, 1956, the City of Eunice and Public Employee Board entered into an agreement dated August 20, 1956, effective August 1, 1956, as relates to social security coverage; and 
"WHEREAS, Section G of that contract provided: 
The POLITICAL SUBDIVISION, upon giving at least two (2) years' advance notice in writing to the STATE AGENCY, may terminate this agreement, effective at the end of a calendar quarter specified in the notice, provided, however, that the agreement may be terminated only if it has been in effect not less than five (5) years prior to receipt of such notice; and 
"WHEREAS, the agreement has been in effect for more than five (5) years; and 
"WHEREAS, the municipality has studied another plan, which is more advantageous to the employees of the City of Eunice, Louisiana. 
"NOW THEREFORE BE IT ORDAINED ...." 
Sec. 20:21. - Supplemental retirement benefits authorized. 
    The mayor, Wilson J. Moosa, be and he is hereby authorized to enter into an agreement with the Municipal Employees Retirement System of Louisiana to extend the benefits of the Supplemental Retirement Plan to the employees of the City of Eunice effective July 1, 1976. 
(Res. of 2-10-76) 
Secs. 20:22-20:49. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER B. - DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN 

Sec. 20:50. - Deferred compensation for city employees authorized. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen hereby expresses their authorization and approval for the City of Eunice to enter into a plan of deferred compensation with city employees and officials. 
(Res. of 12-11-73, § 1) 
Comment- The above cited 1973 Resolution was enacted in accordance with LRS 42:1301, et seq., which provides the method of implementation of deferred compensation plans. 
The source resolution superseded a Resolution of October 9, 1973. 
Sec. 20:51. - Purchase of retirement annuity contracts. 
    In order to accumulate the appropriate funds to pay participating members benefits in accordance with the deferred compensation plan, the mayor and board of aldermen hereby authorize and approve the purchase by the City of Eunice retirement annuity contracts in such amounts as may be appropriate to provide plan benefits. 
(Res. of 12-11-73, § 2) 
Sec. 20:52. - Premiums for annuity contracts not to be considered as income to employees; contracts to be held as unrestricted assets. 
    It is the intention of the mayor and board of aldermen that the premiums paid by the city for such annuity contracts will not currently be considered as income paid to the members concerned. Thus, the City of Eunice will own and have all rights under the said annuity contracts and such contracts will not be held in any way as collateral security for fulfilling of the obligations of the City of Eunice but shall be held as a general and unrestricted asset. 
(Res. of 12-11-73, § 3) 
Sec. 20:53. - Mayor authorized to act on contracts; rules and procedures. 
    The board of aldermen hereby authorize the mayor of Eunice to act on their behalf in respect to these annuity contracts and to formulate rules and procedures for the purchase and administration of the same. 
(Res. of 12-11-73, § 4) 
Sec. 20:54. - Reduction in employee wages. 
    The city treasurer is authorized to reduce an employee's wages upon receipt of a signed agreement between the city and the employee to reduce income by a stated amount in connection with such employee's participation in the supplementary retirement program. 
(Res. of 12-11-73, § 5) 
Sec. 20:55. - Deferred compensation contracts to be approved by city attorney. 
    Any and all contracts to be executed in connection with said plan of deferred compensation shall be approved by the city attorney. 
(Res. of 12-11-73, § 6) 
Sec. 20:56. - Deferred compensation to be considered earned compensation for purposes of employee benefit or retirement programs. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision or definition to the contrary, any compensation deferred under this part shall be considered part of annual or yearly compensation or earned or earnable compensation, however designated, for purposes of any employee benefit or retirement program. 
(Res. of 12-11-73, § 7) 
Secs. 20:57-20:99. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER C. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 20:100. - Police pension and relief fund created. 
    This subchapter shall be known, shall constitute and may be referred to as "Police Pension and Relief Fund" of the City of Eunice and any and all addition and amendments to this subchapter, when adopted in such form as to indicate the intention of the board of aldermen to make the same a part hereof, shall be deemed to be incorporated in this subchapter so that a reference to the "Police Pension and Relief Fund" of the City of Eunice shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments. 
(Ord. No. 18-70, § 1, 9-24-70) 
Sec. 20:101. - Effective date. 
    All provisions of this subchapter shall be in full force and effect on September 24, 1970. 
(Ord. No. 18-70, § 2, 9-24-70) 
Sec. 20:102. - Operation of fund. 
    This subchapter is being adopted pursuant to the provisions of Sections 2221 through 2242 of Title 33 of the Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1950, as amended, and that all of the portions of said Sections 2221 through 2242 of Title 33 which are applicable to the City of Eunice are hereby adopted by reference and incorporated and made part of this subchapter as though set forth in its entirety herein. The sections may be cited and referred to as articles of such fund. 
(Ord. No. 18-70, § 3, 9-24-70) 
Sec. 20:103. - Exemption of police pension and relief fund from Act No. 585. 
    Subsection (E) of Act. No. 585 of 1982 provides that the mandatory merger requirement of Subsection (D) shall be inapplicable with respect to any municipality which, on or before June 30, 1983, enacts an ordinance exempting the municipality from the mandatory requirements of Subsection (D). Therefore, the mayor and board of aldermen of the city elect to exempt the Police Pension and Relief Fund of Eunice from the mandatory requirements of Subsection (D) of Act 585. 
(Ord. No. 63-83, 4-12-83) 
Editor's note- Being not specifically amendatory of the Code, the provisions of Ord. No. 63-83, enacted April 12, 1983, have been codified, at the editor's discretion, as § 20:103. 
Secs. 20:104-20:119. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER D. - FIREFIGHTERS 

Sec. 20:120. - Exemption of firefighters from act. No. 434. 
    The City of Eunice and its firefighting employees are hereby declared exempt from the provisions of LRS 33:2153A(1)(a), and neither said Section 2153(1)(a) nor any of the other provisions of Act 434 of the 1979 Louisiana Legislature shall be applicable to this municipality or its firefighting employees. 
(Ord. No. 19-79, § 1, 10-23-79) 
Editor's note- Sections 20:120 and 20:121 are derived from Ord. No. 19-79, §§ 1 and 2, adopted Oct. 23, 1979. Since this ordinance did not provide for a specific manner of inclusion of its provisions into the Code, it has been codified as §§ 20:120 and 20:121 of a new Subch. D at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 20:121. - Authority to transmit notice of exemption. 
    The city clerk is hereby authorized to transmit a certified copy of this ordinance [Ordinance No. 19-79] to the board of trustees of the Firefighters' Retirement System and to the Department of the Treasury, through the state treasurer, so that the board and the state treasury may be informed that this municipality has adopted this exemption ordinance pursuant to the authority of LRS 33:2153A(1)(b), and as such has elected not to participate in the Louisiana State Firefighters' Retirement System. 
(Ord. No. 19-79, § 2, 10-23-79) 
Note- See the editor's note to § 20:120. 
Chapter 21 - REVENUE AND TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Occupational license taxes, Ch. 12; liquor permits, Ch. 13. 

SUBCHAPTER A. - PROPERTY TAXES[2] 
RESERVED 
    The city's property tax ordinances were not codified in this compilation because they are limited by the Louisiana Constitution and state statutes to one year in duration. Ordinances levying these taxes must be re-adopted every year and are subject to change every year. 
    For many years, the city has also provided a special property tax exemption for homeowners. This, too, is enacted on an annual basis and therefore was not included. 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- General taxing, authority of municipalities, Art. VI, §§ 27 and 32, Louisiana Constitution (1974); similar authority, LRS 33:2801; time for levy and payment of municipal property taxes, LRS 33:2745; assessment and collection procedures, LRS 33:461 et seq. 

Secs. 21:1-21:99. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER B. - SALES TAX 

Sec. 21:100. - Sales and use tax levied; collection. 
(a)  There is hereby levied from and after June 1, 1988, a tax upon the sale at retail, the use, the lease or rental, the consumption, and storage for use or consumption of tangible personal property and on the sale of services within the city, and the levy of such tax shall be as follows: 
(1)  At the rate of two-tenths of one percent (0.2%) of the sales price of each item or article of tangible personal property when sold at retail in the city the tax to be computed on gross sales for the purpose of remitting the amount of tax due the governing body and to include each and every retail sale. 
(2)  At the rate of two-tenths of one percent (0.2%) of the cost price of each item or article of tangible personal property when the same is not sold, but is used, consumed, distributed or stores for use or consumption in the city provided there shall be no duplication of the tax. There shall be exempt from this tax any item or article of tangible personal property which is used by an owner within the City of Eunice to provide services free of charge to the city government or to any school or non-profit organization recognized or established pursuant to Article 503(C) or any other relevant Section of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(3)  At the rate of two-tenths of one percent (0.2%) of the gross proceeds derived from the lease or rental of tangible personal property, as defined herein, where the lease or rental of such property is an established business, or part of an established business or the same is incidental or germane to the business. 
(4)  At the rate of two-tenths of one percent (0.2%) of the monthly lease rental price paid by lessee or rentee, or contracted or agreed to be paid by lessee or rentee to the owner of the tangible personal property. 
(5)  At the rate of two-tenths of one percent (0.2%) of the gross proceeds derived from the sale of services, as defined herein. 
(b)  The tax shall be collected from the dealer, as defined herein, and paid at the time and in the manner hereinafter provided. 
(c)  The tax so levied is, and shall be in addition to, all other taxes, whether levied in form of sales, excise or license, privilege or property taxes levied by any other ordinance or resolution of the governing body. 
(d)  The dealer shall collect the tax levied by this section, together with all other applicable sales and use taxes, in accordance with the integrated bracket schedule or schedules prepared and furnished by the Collector of Revenue of the State of Louisiana under the authority of Section 304 of Title 47 of the Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1950 (R.S. 47:304). Such schedule or schedules shall include, in addition to the tax hereby levied pursuant to the election held on March 8, 1988, all sales taxes levied by the State of Louisiana, and any sales taxes levied by the mayor and board of aldermen and any sales taxes levied by any other political subdivision applicable in the city. The dealer will remit that portion of such total taxes representing the tax levied by this section to the collector. Copies of said integrated bracket schedules are available to dealers on request to the city or the collector. 
(e)  The collection of the tax herein levied shall be made in the name of the city by the collector. 
(Ord. No. A-246, §§ 2:01-2:03, 6-26-62; Ord. No. 2-88, §§ 2:01-2:04, 2:06, 4-12-88; Ord. No. 07-08(B), 7-8-08) 
Comment- The entire text of the city's sales and use tax ordinance was not codified herein at the request of the mayor and board of aldermen. This ordinance has been previously published under separate cover and is available at the office of the city clerk. 
Since its enactment, Ordinance No. A-246 has been amended by several acts as follows: 
(1)  Ordinance No. A-248 of August 1, 1962-Requested the state collector of revenue to collect the city's sales tax on the sale and use of motor vehicles. Proceeds from such collections are remitted back to the municipality. 
(2)  Ordinance No. A-254 of November 13, 1962-Amended Section 1:16 by deleting subsection 3 thereof, removing storage or parking privileges by auto hotels, parking lots and trailer parks from application of the tax. 
(3)  Ordinance No. A-284 of December 8, 1964-Amended Section 3:01, making isolated sales of motor vehicles subject to the tax. 
(4)  Ordinance No. A-794 of August 17, 1965-Amended Section 6, dealing with returns and payment of the tax. 
(5)  Ordinance No. 54-82 of September 30, 1982-Amended Section 9:03 providing for an increase in the penalty on delinquent taxes. 
(6)  Ordinance No. 4-88 of May 24, 1988-Added 9:04.1 granting authority to the treasurer to enforce the collection of sales and use taxes collection from purchasers of consumers; to provide an alternative means of collection; to provide for the personal liability of certain officers and directors of corporations for the total amount of such taxes withheld or collected, and not accounted for or not remitted, together with any interest, penalties and fees accruing thereon; and to provide for related matters. 
Secs. 21:101-21:174. - Reserved. 
Sec. 21:175. - Additional sales and use tax levied. 
(a)  There is hereby levied for a period of twenty-five (25) years from and after January 1, 1978, for the purposes stated in the proposition set forth in the preamble to Ordinance No. 21-77, a tax upon the sale at retail, the use, the lease or rental, the consumption and the storage for use or consumption of tangible personal property and upon the sale of services within this city as defined herein, said tax to be in addition to a sales and use tax currently being levied in the city authorized at an election held therein on May 22, 1962; and the levy of such tax shall be as follows: 
(1)  At the rate of one percent of the sales price of each item or article of tangible personal property when sold at retail in this city, the tax to be computed on gross sales for the purpose of remitting the amount of tax due the governing authority and to include each and every retail sale. 
(2)  At the rate of one percent of the cost price of each item or article of tangible personal property when the same is not sold, but is used, consumed, distributed, or stored for use or consumption in this city provided there shall be no duplication of the tax. 
(3)  At the rate of one percent of the gross proceeds derived from the lease or rental of tangible personal property, as defined herein where the lease or rental of such property is an established business, or part of an established business or the same is incidental or germane to the said business. 
(4)  At the rate of one percent of the monthly lease rental price paid by lessee or rentee, or contracted or agreed to be paid by lessee or rentee to the owner of the tangible personal property. 
(5)  At the rate of one percent of the gross proceeds derived from the sale of services, as defined herein. 
(Ord. No. 21-77, § 2.01, 12-13-77) 
Comment- As with the city's first sales and use tax, the entire text of the city's second sales tax ordinance was not codified herein because it has already been published under separate cover. Copies may be obtained from the office of the city clerk. 
Secs. 21:176-21:249. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER C. - OTHER TAXES, CHARGES AND FEES 

Sec. 21:250. - Beer tax levied; tax to be collected by state; failure to pay. 
(a)  There is hereby levied, in addition to all other excises, licenses or privilege taxes presently imposed, a tax on all beer, porter, ale, fruit juices, and/or wine having an alcoholic content of not less than one-half of one percent nor more than six (6) percent by volume, of one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) per standard barrel of thirty-one (31) gallons, or any like rate of any other quantity or for the fractional parts of such barrel sold for consumption in the City of Eunice, within the meaning and intent of the provisions of Act 190 of the Louisiana Legislature of 1946. 
(b)  The tax herein levied shall be collected by any and all Louisiana wholesale dealers from their vendees purchasing for consumption in the City of Eunice on each sale and shall be remitted by said wholesale dealers to the collector of revenue of the State of Louisiana, for each month, on or before the 20th day of each succeeding month, respectively, all in accordance with rules and regulations promulgated by the collector of revenue and as provided by Section 19 of Act 190 of 1946. 
(c)  Failure of the wholesale dealers to collect and remit the tax levied, when due, or failure to pay the tax, when due, by a purchaser for consumption in the City of Eunice shall, ipso facto, render each of them liable for the amount of taxes found to be due, together with a penalty of twenty (20) percent of the amount of tax due, plus an additional amount of ten (10) percent of the tax and penalty, as attorney's fees if referred to an attorney for collection. 
(Ord. No. A-69, 8-6-46) 
Comment- Act No. 190 of 1946, referred to in the above section, has been codified in Title 26, Chapter 2 of the Louisiana Revised Statutes. For authority of municipalities to levy this tax, see LRS 26:493. See LRS 26:341 et seq. for similar state tax levy. 
Secs. 21:251-21:259. - Reserved. 
Sec. 21:260. - Chain store tax levied; basis and rates of tax; service stations exempted; collection procedures; violations and penalties. 
(a)  There is hereby levied under the provisions of Act 487, of the Louisiana Legislature of October, 1975, Section 10, Title 47, of the Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1950, as amended, a chain store tax for the year 1975 and all subsequent years, thereafter, upon each person engaged in the business of operating or maintaining as a part of a group of the chain in a store or stores, to be collected by the City of Eunice for such stores operated within its boundaries. 
(b)  The license, herein provided for, shall be in addition to ad valorem taxes and any other licenses prescribed by the city ordinances, where goods, wares, merchandise or commodities of every description whatsoever are sold or offered for sale at retail, under the same general management, supervision, ownership or control, or who enjoy the benefits of centralized purchasing, warehousing, or advertising, commonly recognized as a member of a chain or as a branch store. 
(c)  The license tax for the business described in this section, levied upon the store or stores operated within any municipality, shall be based on the number of stores or merchandise establishments included under the same general management, supervision, ownership or control, or who enjoy the benefits of central purchasing, warehousing or advertising, whether within the levying municipality or not and whether within this state or not; the maximum license for each store or establishment shall be as follows:
