(d)  The tax for any store opened after June 30 of any year shall not exceed one-half of the annual amount. 
(e)  This section shall not apply to service stations or what is commonly known as filling stations and said businesses are exempted from the effects of same. 
(f)  Every person engaged in the business of or operating a chain store in the City of Eunice shall, on or before the first day of February of each year, render to the authorized municipal authority a report containing a true and complete statement showing the number of stores or establishments operated or maintained in the municipality, the name, location and street address of each store, the total number of such stores whether in this state or not as of the report date, and such other information as may be required by the taxing authority. Whenever a new store is opened, which was not included in the above-mentioned report, a supplemental report setting forth the required information shall be filed prior to the expiration of thirty (30) days after the date of opening. 
(g)  Payment of licenses authorized by this section shall accompany the report required by paragraph (f) above and shall become delinquent if not paid when due. Interest and penalties shall be assessed and collected together with all taxes due in the same manner as other taxes due the municipality. 
(h)  A separate license shall be issued by the taxing authority for each store for which the tax has been paid as above provided, and it shall be the duty of the licensee to post the license in a conspicuous place in each store. 
(i)  The effective date of this ordinance shall be January 1, 1976. 
(Ord. No. 2-76, §§ 1-6, 2-10-76) 
Comment- Ordinance No. 2-76 superseded Ord. No. 25-74 of December 12, 1974. 
Secs. 21:261-21:269. - Reserved. 
Sec. 21:270. - Levy of tax on telephone subscribers; exemptions. 
(a)  Beginning with billing periods commencing on or after the first day of September, 1970, there is hereby levied on telephone subscribers a municipal charge of three (3) percent of the amount paid for all monthly recurring local telephone service rendered wholly within the city limits of the City of Eunice, Louisiana; provided, that said municipal charge shall not apply to service rendered to the United States of America, the State of Louisiana, the City of Eunice, or to any agency or instrumentality of any of the aforesaid. 
(b)  The amount of said municipal charge shall be added to the bill sent to each such subscriber and the telephone company rendering such service shall collect said municipal charge as agent for the city, and remit the amount of said municipal charge to the city in quarterly installments not later than thirty (30) days after the end of each calendar quarter, beginning with the quarter ending September 30, 1970. 
(c)  The municipal charge herein levied shall be in addition to any and all payments presently being made to the City of Eunice by the South Central Bell Telephone Company. 
(Ord. No. 12-70, §§ 1-3, 7-23-70) 
Secs. 21:271-21:299. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER D. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 21:300. - Assessment and collection of interest on unpaid taxes. 
    When any taxpayer fails to pay a tax, or any portion thereof, on or before the day where it is required to be paid, interest at the rate of one percent per month shall be added to the amount of tax due and such interest shall be computed from the due date until the tax is paid. The interest provided for herein shall be an obligation to be collected and accounted for in the same manner as if it were a part of the tax due and can be enforced in a separate action or in the same action for collection of the tax. 
(Ord. No. 57-82, 10-12-82; Ord. No. 1098(B), 11-10-98) 
Chapter 22 - SPECIAL DISTRICTS 

Sec. 22:1. - Sewerage District No. One created; boundaries. 
    By virtue of the authority conferred by Article XIV, Section 14 of the Constitution of the State of Louisiana for the year 1921, as amended, Sub-Part B, Part I, Chapter 9, Title 33 of the Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1950, and any other constitutional and statutory authority supplemental thereto, a sewerage district be and the same is hereby created within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice, State of Louisiana, which sewerage district shall comprise and embrace all of that territory within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, and the boundaries of said sewerage district shall be co-extensive with the boundaries of the City of Eunice, Louisiana, as said boundaries were constituted on July 11, 1960. 
(Ord. of 7-11-60, § 1) 
Comment- The cited 1960 Ordinance superseded Ordinance No. A-10 of December 4, 1928. 
Sec. 22:2. - Sewerage District No. One, rights and powers. 
    The sewerage district hereby created shall be known and is hereby designated as "Sewerage District No. 1 of the City of Eunice, State of Louisiana", and as thus created shall constitute a public corporation and political subdivision of the State of Louisiana, and shall have all the rights, powers and privileges granted and conferred by the Constitution and Statutes of the State of Louisiana to such corporations, including the authority to incur debt, issue bonds and levy taxes and assessments. 
(Ord. of 7-11-60, § 2) 
Sec. 22:3. - Sewerage District No. One, official seal. 
    The official seal of the City of Eunice, State of Louisiana, be and the same is hereby adopted as the official seal of the sewerage district. 
(Ord. of 7-11-60, § 3) 
Sec. 22:4. - Sewerage District No. One, publication of creation. 
    The ordinance creating Sewerage District No. One shall be published as provided for by law in "The Eunice News", a weekly newspaper published in the City of Eunice, Louisiana, and within the corporate limits of the sewerage district, and being the official journal of this mayor and board of aldermen, and that within a period of thirty (30) days from the date of the first publication of this ordinance, and owner of property within the limits of the sewerage district or other party interested may appeal to the courts for the purpose of contesting the action of this mayor and board of aldermen, or urging any objections to the inclusion of his property in the sewerage district. After thirty (30) days from the date of the first publication of the ordinance, the action of this mayor and board of aldermen shall be incontestable for any cause; it shall be conclusively presumed that the sewerage district is regularly and legally created and that all properties therein should have been included within the sewerage district or will be benefited by the sewerage system or plant thereof. 
(Ord. of 7-11-60, § 4) 
Chapter 23 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND DRAINAGE 
SUBCHAPTER A. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23:1. - Obstruction of a highway of commerce prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to obstruct a highway of commerce intentionally or in a criminally negligent manner by the placing of anything or performance of any act on any railway, railroad, navigable waterway, road, street, highway, thoroughfare, alley, or runway of an airport, which will render movement thereon more difficult. 
(b)  Whoever commits this crime shall be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. A-324, Art. 50, 1-10-67, as amended by Ord. No. A-343, 9-12-65, Rev.) 
Comment- See note following Section 14:50, this Code. Ordinance No. A-324 superseded Ordinance No. A-211 of August 9, 1960 and Ordinance No. 6 of June 18, 1895. 
Sec. 23:2. - Obstruction of a public passage prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to willfully obstruct the free, convenient and normal use of any public sidewalk, street, alley, road or other passageway, or the entrance, corridor or passage of any public building, structure, watercraft or ferry, by impeding, hindering, stifling, retarding or restraining traffic or passage thereon or therein. 
(b)  Whoever commits this crime shall be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. A-324, § 51, 1-10-67, as amended by Ord. No. A-343, 9-12-67, Rev.) 
Comment- See note following Section 14:51, this Code. 
Sec. 23:3. - Operation of vehicles with lugs on city streets restricted. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to operate upon the paved or hard surfaced streets of the City of Eunice, vehicles with lugs, tracks, or other like contrivances. 
(b)  Anyone violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. A-88, § 1, Rev.) 
Comment- The penalty clause of the ordinance from which the above section derived was revised at the direction of the mayor and board of aldermen to make it conform with the ordinance adopting this Code. 
Secs. 23:4-23:29. - Reserved. 
Sec. 23:30. - Changes in streets, thoroughfares, notice required. 
(a)  No change shall be made in any street, avenue, alley or public thoroughfare except the improvement of same until notice has been published once a week for three (3) consecutive weeks in the official journal of the city, setting forth and describing the changes to be made and proof of said publication, over the signature of the publisher, has been furnished to the governing authority of the city. 
(b)  Any change made in any public thoroughfare without complying with this section shall be void. 
(Ord. No. A-311, 5-10-66, §§ 1, 2) 
Secs. 23:31-23:39. - Reserved. 
Sec. 23:40. - New streets, surface requirements. 
    Any new streets accepted by the City of Eunice, that are not now dedicated, will have to be graveled at the expense of the property owner or owners, and said streets are to be graveled with a depth of three (3) inches and a width not less than forty (40) feet. 
(Mo. of 1-11-55) 
Secs. 23:41-23:99. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER B. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 23:100. - Maintenance of sidewalks by adjacent property owners required. 
    It shall be the duty of the occupants or tenants of every house or lot within the corporate limits of the City of Eunice, fronting on any paved or unpaved sidewalk or banquette, and in the absence of any occupant or tenant the owner or agent of said house, lot or premises, to cause to be cut, uprooted or otherwise satisfactorily removed, all weeds, grass or undergrowth growing upon such sidewalk or banquette in front of the property owned, occupied, administered or managed by them, as the case may be. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 117, §§ 1, 2, 8-5-19) 
Comment- See Section 9:56, this Code, for related provision dealing with keeping sidewalks clean. 
Chapter 24 - SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- For related provisions dealing with building regulations, see Ch. 5. 

SUBCHAPTER A. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24:1. - Platting of land into squares or lots before sale; filing of map. 
    Whenever the owner of any real estate desires to lay off the same into squares or lots with streets or alleys between the squares or lots and with the intention of selling or offering for sale any of the squares or lots he shall, before selling any square or lot or any portion of same, cause the real estate to be surveyed and platted or subdivided by a licensed surveyor or civil engineer into lots or blocks, or both, each designated by number, and set stakes, which shall be permanent in nature, at all of the corners of every lot and block thereof, properly marked so as to designate the correct number of each lot and block; write the legal description of the land on the plat or map; and cause to be made and filed in the office of the keeper of notarial records of the parish wherein the property is situated and copies into the conveyance record book of such parish, and a duplicate thereof filed with the assessor of the parish, a correct map of the real estate so divided, which map shall contain the following: 
(1)  The section, township and range in which such real estate or subdivision thereof lies according to government survey. 
(2)  The number of squares by numerals from 1 up, and the dimensions of each square in feet and inches. 
(3)  The number of each lot or subdivision of a square and its dimensions in feet and inches. 
(4)  The name of each street and alley and its length and width in feet and inches. 
(5)  The name or number of each square or plat dedicated to public use. 
(6)  A certificate of the parish surveyor or any other licensed surveyor or civil engineer of this state approving said map and stating that the same is in accordance with the provisions of this section and with the laws and ordinances of the parish in which the property is situated. 
(7)  A formal dedication made by the owner or owners of the property or their duly authorized agent of all the streets, alleys and public squares or plats shown on the map to public use. 
(LRS 33:5051) 
Comment- As indicated by the source notes, the above section and the remaining sections of this subchapter were not derived from local ordinance, but from the Revised Statutes. Since these provisions are self-operative and provide minimum standards to be met in subdividing land, they were incorporated herein for the convenience of the user at the direction of the mayor and board of aldermen. 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to revoke and set aside dedications, LRS 33:4718. 
Sec. 24:2. - Enforcement of requirements. 
    All clerks and ex-officio recorders and notaries public in all the parishes, the Parish of Orleans excepted, shall refuse to place on record any deeds of sale of property to which Section 24:1 applies until the provisions of Section 24:1 have been complied with. They shall report to the district attorney all violations thereof coming within their knowledge. 
(LRS 33:5052) 
Sec. 24:3. - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person, agent or attorney in fact who violates Section 24:1 or Section 24:2 shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. 
(LRS 33:5053) 
Sec. 24:4. - Plan correcting discrepancy between prior plan and lots sold thereunder; objections; registration of corrected plan. 
    Whenever land, divided into town lots and sold in conformity with a plan, is not of the same extent as that mentioned in the plan, and the difference is more than one thousandth part, the surveyor, commissioned for the parish where said land is situated, shall apportion, in conformity with the civil code, the surplus or deficit of the land, and make a plan pointing out, according to the appointment, the correct dimensions of each square and the breadth of each street. The plan shall be deposited by the surveyor of the parish in the office of parish recorder. Public notices shall be given by the surveyor in a newspaper published in the parish designated as the official journal, or in an adjoining parish if there is none published in the parish, during thirty (30) days, directing all persons interested to present their opposition to the plan deposited as aforesaid with the parish recorder, which oppositions shall be referred to and decided by the district court. The plan, when not opposed within the delay aforesaid, or when modified in the opposition filed, shall be registered by the recorder in his office, and shall be authentic evidence of the description and dimensions of the property. 
(LRS 33:5054) 
Sec. 24:5. - Assistance to developer proposing to open new residential subdivisions. 
(a)  Upon proper written application by a developer for assistance from the city in opening a residential subdivision being filed with the mayor, and said application meets all of the qualifications of this section, the mayor shall submit same to the board of aldermen for consideration at the next meeting of the board of aldermen, and decision, along with the mayor's comments, favorable or unfavorable, and the certification by the city engineer and the city attorney that the application meets the qualifications. The cost of preparing any documents required for subdivision of the application shall be at the cost of the developer. 
(b)  The mayor, with the advice of the city engineer and city attorney, shall formulate an application for setting forth the necessary requirements thereof. In no event, however, shall an application be considered unless the developer warrants that the proposed subdivision shall have available for hook-up to the city sewer system at least ten (10) separate and individual users or hook-ups, and that all occupants of the subdivision shall be connected to the city sewer system, and further that any such subdivisions if located outside the city limits, it shall be immediately annexed into the city. The application shall be accompanied by a complete plat and description of the assistance being requested, including the cost of the particular item for which such assistance is requested, together with proof that the developer has solicited at least five (5) price quotations, if required by the public bid law for municipalities. Additionally, the developer shall provide satisfactory evidence that the proposed subdivision meets all EPA, DEQ or other environmental requirements, along with evidence that it also meets all city requirements for street construction, sewer connections, etc. 
(c)  If the application for assistance meets the foregoing qualifications, and all other qualifications contained in the application form formulated by the mayor, the board of aldermen shall have the authority to approve assistance to the developer in constructing sewer facilities, enabling connection to the city sewer system, such as a lift station, or comparable facilities, in financial aid up to fifty (50) percent of the cost thereof, but not to exceed the sum of twelve thousand five hundred dollars ($12,500.00), in any event. If the assistance is in kind, the value of the assistance shall not exceed a total of twelve thousand five hundred dollars ($12,500.00). The value of the in kind assistance or the financial assistance shall be certified to the board of aldermen by the city engineer prior to approval. If the project is subject to the public bid law, all proper procedure shall be complied with. 
(d)  If the board of aldermen, by majority vote, approves the application for assistance and specifically authorizes the mayor to provide the assistance, either in funds or in kind, the mayor may proceed to consummate the agreement, unless the circumstances have changed since the approval by the board of aldermen. In such event, the mayor shall resubmit the application to the board of aldermen at the next regular meeting or special meeting of the board, detailing the change in circumstances which gave him reason not to consummate the agreement, at which meeting the board may reconsider its original approval. 
(e)  Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this section, the mayor and/or board of aldermen may at anytime make the requirements for assistance more stringent or less stringent, depending upon the structure presented, and if dictated by changes in the law, or rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 3-97(A), §§ 2-6, 4-8-97) 
Secs. 24:6-24:19. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER B. - CITY SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Sept. 10, 1985, enacted new subdivision regulations which, being not specifically amendatory of the Code, the editor, at his discretion, has codified under Subch. B. Provisions formerly codified as § 24:20 have been redesignated by the editor as § 24:24 in order to provide better classification. 
Cross reference- Planning and zoning, Ch. 18. 

PART I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 24:20. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of this subchapter, a "subdivision of land" is the division of land into two (2) or more tracts, sites or parcels of three (3) acres or less in area, or resubdivision of land heretofore divided or platted into lots, sites or parcels. Any sales or contract of sale or agreement to purchase any lot or division of land either by lot description by metes and bounds shall constitute a subdivision of land and require, prior to sale or contract of sale or agreement to purchase and before the delivery of a deed, the submission of a plat to the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 9-10-85, § 1) 
Sec. 24:21. - Exemptions from subchapters. 
    This subchapter shall not apply to: 
(1)  Land in subdivisions previously legally recorded; except in the case of resubdivisions; 
(2)  The subdivision of land to be used for orchards, forest or the raising of crops; provided, that the city clerk certifies upon the plat that such land is to be used only for orchards, forestry or the raising of crops. 
(Ord. No. 9-10-85, § 2) 
Sec. 24:22. - Scope of jurisdiction. 
    From and after September 10, 1985, this subchapter shall govern all subdivision of land within the corporate limits and police jurisdiction of the city. 
(Ord. No. 9-10-85, § 3) 
Sec. 24:23. - Submission, approval of plat required prior to subdivision of land. 
(a)  Any owner of land within the limits of the subdivision jurisdiction described in Section 24:22 wishing to subdivide land shall submit to the mayor and board of aldermen a plat of the subdivision which shall conform to the minimum requirements set forth in Part II of this subchapter. 
(b)  No plat of a subdivision lying within such territory or part thereof shall be filed or recorded in the office of the clerk of court of the parish, and no subdivider may proceed with improvement or sale of lots in a subdivision until such subdivision plat shall have been approved by the mayor and board of aldermen and such approval entered in writing on the plat by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 9-10-85, § 4) 
Cross reference- For plan approval procedure, see Part III of this subchapter. 
Sec. 24:24. - Copy of subdivision restrictions to be filed with city. 
    All subdividers shall submit to the City of Eunice at the time property is subdivided a copy of all restrictions applicable to the property. 
(Res. of 7-13-76) 
Cross reference- Special requirements for subdivisions in flood-prone areas, § 5:42; special requirements for water supply and sewage system in flood-prone areas, § 5:43; general standards for flood hazard reduction in subdivision proposals, § 5:63(d). 
Sec. 24:25. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Whoever, being the owner or agent of the owner of any land in the city, transfers or sells or agrees to sell any land which constitutes a subdivision of land as herein defined by reference to or exhibition of or by other use of a plat by the description therein of such lot or parcel by metes and bounds before filing a plat thereof with the mayor and board of aldermen and obtaining the approval thereof as hereinabove set forth prior to the filing and recordation thereof shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punishable by a fine not exceeding two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). The sale, transfer or agreement to sell of each lot or parcel shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  The mayor and board of aldermen shall have the right to institute civil proceedings for injunctive relief against any individual who transfers or sells or agrees to sell any land which constitutes a subdivision of land as herein defined by reference to or exhibition of or by other use of a plat or by the description therein of such lot or parcel by metes and bounds before filing a plat thereof with the mayor and board of aldermen and obtaining the approval thereof prior to the filing and recordation thereof as hereinabove set forth to enjoin and/or restrain such individual from further violating the provisions hereof. 
(Ord. of 9-10-85, § 5) 
Secs. 24:26-24:39. - Reserved. 
PART II. - REQUIREMENTS AND MINIMUM STANDARDS 

Sec. 24:40. - Conformance to city plan. 
    All proposed subdivisions shall conform to any city plan which has been officially adopted by the mayor and board of aldermen and to the city zoning ordinance. Whenever a tract to be subdivided embraces any part of a highway, major street, secondary street or parkway so designated on any city plan which has been officially adopted by the mayor and board of aldermen, such part of such proposed public way shall be platted by the subdivider in the same location and at the same width as indicated on such city plan. 
(Ord. of 9-10-85, § 20) 
Cross reference- Planning generally, Ch. 23. 
Sec. 24:41. - Streets. 
(a)  Relation to adjoining street system. Proposed new streets shall extend existing streets or their projections at the same or greater width, but in no case less than the minimum required width, unless variations are deemed necessary by the mayor and board of aldermen for reasons of topography or design. Where, in the opinion of the mayor and board of aldermen, it is desirable to provide street access to adjoining property, proposed streets shall extend to the boundary of such property. Half streets along the boundary of land proposed for subdivision will be permitted but shall not be opened. 
(b)  Widths. The minimum right-of-way width of proposed streets measured from lot line to lot line shall be as shown on the major street plan, or, if not shown on such plan, not less than eighty (80) feet for major streets and sixty (60) feet for other streets. Alleys of not less than twenty (20) feet shall be provided to serve business lots; provided, however, that if street curbs and gutters are provided, the minimum width shall be fifty (50) feet. 
(c)  Intersections. Insofar as practical, acute angles at street intersections shall be avoided. Where an acute angle of less than seventy-five (75) degrees occurs between streets at their intersections, the mayor and board of aldermen may require the property lines to be rounded or otherwise set back to permit curb construction of desirable radius without curtailing the sidewalk at the street corner to less than normal width. Submission of a grading plan showing existing and proposed contours at one-foot intervals and a detailed design for the intersection may be required by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(d)  Dead-end streets. Streets designed to have one end permanently closed (cul-de-sac) shall be provided at the closed end with a turnaround with a minimum right-of-way radius of seventy (70) feet, and a minimum driving surface radius of fifty (50) feet. A cul-de-sac shall not be more than six hundred (600) feet in length unless approved by the mayor and board of aldermen for specific reasons of topography or design. 
(e)  Names. Proposed streets obviously in alignment with existing and named streets shall bear the names of existing streets. In no case shall the name for the proposed street duplicate existing street names irrespective of the suffix used. 
(f)  Improvements. Street improvements shall be required as set forth in Section 24:60. Street improvements may be constructed with curb and gutter sections, with subsurface storm drainage or open-ditch-type construction. 
(Ord. of 9-10-85, § 21) 
Sec. 24:42. - Blocks. 
    Blocks shall not be more than eight hundred fifty (850) feet in length, unless there is provided a public crosswalk with not less than a ten-foot right-of-way. If such crosswalk is provided, blocks may be not longer than one thousand five hundred (1,500) feet. 
(Ord. of 9-10-85, § 22) 
Sec. 24:43. - Lots. 
(a)  Arrangement. Insofar as practical, side lot lines shall be at right angles to straight street lines or radial to curved street lines. Each lot must front upon a street which is connected with the public street system. 
(b)  Minimum size. Within the subdivision jurisdiction limits of the city, the size and shape of residential lots shall be such as the mayor and board of aldermen deem appropriate for the type of building development contemplated. In no case, however, shall lot sizes and widths at the building line be less than minimum standards established by the zoning ordinance. Corner lots shall have extra width sufficient to permit establishment of a building line at least fifteen (15) feet from the side street property line. The distance from the side street property line shall be measured from the street right-of-way paralleling the long dimension of the lot. 
(Ord. of 9-10-85, § 23) 
Sec. 24:44. - Public use and service areas. 
(a)  Easement for utilities. Except where alleys are provided for the purpose, the mayor and board of aldermen will require easement(s) not exceeding twelve (12) feet in width for poles, wires, conduits or other utility lines with six (6) feet each side of the common rear lot lines and/or along side lot line unless it is not feasible in the opinion of the mayor and board of aldermen. It is possible that utility companies may require additional right-of-way than set forth in this subchapter. This shall be coordinated with the individual utility companies. 
    Water and sewer lines shall be constructed within the dedicated right-of-way for streets and alleys with one line on one side of the street or alley and the other line on the other side of the street or alley, unless it is not feasible in the opinion of the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(b)  Storm drainage. Whenever any stream or improved surface drainage course is located in an area that is being subdivided, the subdivider shall dedicate an adequate right-of-way along each side of the stream for the purpose of widening, deepening, sloping, improving or protecting the stream, or for drainage maintenance. The total minimum width of the open channel drainage right-of-way shall be eight (8) feet wider than the top width of the drainage channel. However, in no case shall the drainage right-of-way width be less than ten (10) feet. The total permanent minimum width of subsurface storm drainage right-of-way shall be the outside diameter of pipe plus eight (8) feet. 
(c)  Dedication to public use. There shall be no reserve strips except those which are conveyed to the government having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. of 9-10-85, § 24) 
Sec. 24:45. - Comprehensive group housing development. 
    A comprehensive group housing development including the construction of two (2) or more buildings together with the necessary drives and ways of access and which is not subdivided into the customary lots, blocks and streets may be approved by the mayor and board of aldermen if in their opinion any departure from the foregoing regulations can be made without destroying the intent of these regulations. Plans for all such developments shall be submitted to and approved by the mayor and board of aldermen whether or not such plat is to be recorded, and no building permit shall be issued until such approval has been given. 
(Ord. of 9-10-85, § 25) 
Sec. 24:46. - Variances. 
    Where a subdivider can show that a provision of this part would cause an unnecessary hardship if strictly adhered to, and where, because of topographical or other conditions peculiar to the site, in the opinion of the mayor and board of aldermen, a departure may be made without destroying the intent of such provision, the mayor and board of aldermen may authorize a variance. Any variance thus authorized is required to be entered in writing in the minutes of the City of Eunice and the reason which justified the departure to be set forth. 
(Ord. of 9-10-85, § 26) 
Sec. 24:47. - Enforcement. 
(a)  No street number and no building permit shall be issued for the erection of any building in the above limits of any piece of property other than on an original or resubdivided lot in a duly approved and recorded subdivision without the written approval of the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(b)  No sewer, water, gas, electrical or other public utility improvement shall be connected nor shall any public money be expended within the lands laid out until the final plat of such land shall have been accepted by the mayor and board of aldermen and recorded in the office of the clerk of court. 
(c)  It shall be illegal to sell by lot and block where the final approval plat has not been recorded in the office of the clerk of court. 
(Ord. of 9-10-85, § 27) 
Secs. 24:48-24:57. - Reserved. 
PART III. - PLAT APPROVAL PROCEDURE 

Sec. 24:58. - Preliminary plats-Required information. 
    To prevent undue hardship on the subdivider through possible required plat revisions, a preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision at a scale not smaller than one hundred (100) feet to the inch shall first be submitted to the mayor and board of aldermen in duplicate and shall give the following information: 
(a)  The subdivision name, the names and addresses of the owners and of the designer of the plat, who shall be a registered professional engineer; provided, that wherever no improvements are required of the sub-divider, the designer may be a land surveyor. 
(b)  Date, approximate north point and graphic scale. 
(c)  The location of existing and platted property lines, streets, buildings, watercourses, railroads, sewers, bridges, culverts drainpipes, water mains and any public utility easements, both on the land subdivided and on the adjoining land, wherever in the opinion of the mayor and board of aldermen it is deemed necessary or desirable; the names of adjacent subdivisions and the names and addresses of record owners of adjoining parcels of land as they appear on the current tax records. 
(d)  The names, locations, widths and other dimensions of proposed streets, alleys, easements, parks and other open spaces, reservations, lot lines and building lines. 
(e)  Statement of proposed street improvements, including contour map where terrain might affect the location of streets. A contour map should be prepared for the area comprising the subdivision and all additional area necessary to include watersheds which drain into the property to be developed. Such a map is not required for preliminary approval, but will be needed for the design of storm drainage. 
(f)  Preliminary sketch plans or proposed utility layouts (sewer, water, natural gas, telephone and electricity) showing feasible connections, where possible, to existing and proposed utility systems. 
    Prior to approval pursuant to ECC 24:59, the preliminary plat shall be submitted to an engineer designated by the building inspector to determine its compliance with the provisions of this subchapter. Said engineer shall advise the mayor and board of aldermen regarding the preliminary plat's compliance with this section and the subdivider shall be responsible for all fees of the engineer designated herein, which actual fee shall be paid on or prior to approval of the preliminary plat being granted as set out below. 
(Ord. of 9-10-85, § 38; Ord. No. 01-10(A), 1-12-10) 
Sec. 24:59. - Same-Approval. 
    Upon receipt of the preliminary plat, the mayor and board of aldermen shall review such plat and make recommendation. The approval of the preliminary plat shall not be deemed final acceptance but rather an expression of approval of the layout as submitted on the preliminary plat; such approval shall be noted on the preliminary plat. One copy of the preliminary plat shall be retained in the files of the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Ord. of 9-10-85, § 39) 
Sec. 24:60. - Final plat-Certain improvements prerequisite to approval. 
(a)  Prior to construction, the developer shall furnish two (2) sets of construction plans and specifications and any pertinent design data requested by the city engineer to the city clerk's office for inspection by the city engineer. In addition, the developer will be requested to post a two hundred dollar fee ($200.00), plus two dollars ($2.00) per lot, to cover the cost of inspection of all proposed facilities by the city engineer. Unless this information is submitted within one year of approval of preliminary plans, the preliminary plan approval shall lapse. 
(b)  Review of drawings and specifications by the city engineer does not relieve the developer, his engineer and surveyor of design and construction practices. It is understood the city engineer is not responsible for actual design of the subdivision, surveys, utilities, drainage or streets, unless the developer employs him to perform said services. 
(c)  The improvements listed in this section shall be installed prior to approval of the final plat; provided, however, that in lieu of installation of these improvements, the subdivider may post a bond to cover the cost of improvements as provided in Section 24:61. 
(d)  Plans and specifications shall contain: 
(1)  Title sheet 
(2)  Appropriate plan drawings 
(3)  Details 
(4)  Typical sections 
(5)  Appropriate profiles 
(6)  Complete technical specifications for applicable types of construction designating descriptions of procedures, materials, construction procedures, any special details or drawings 
(7)  Copy of executed construction contracts, including applicable prices, minimum of one-year guarantee, time of construction. 
(e)  Specific improvements are: 
(1)  Permanent markers: Wherever improvements are constructed under this section, all subdivision boundary corners and the four (4) corners of all street intersections shall be marked with permanent monuments. A permanent marker shall be deemed to be a steel pipe which extends a minimum of two (2) feet below the ground line. Should conditions prohibit the placing of monuments on line, offset marking will be permitted; provided, however, that exact offset courses and distances are shown on the subdivision plat. Two (2) permanent bench marks, the elevation of which shall be based on N.G.V.D. (M.S.L.) of 1929, shall be accessibly placed and accurately noted on the subdivision plat. 
(2)  Street improvements: 
a.  Riding surface and base course: 
1.  The depth and type of riding surface shall be based upon a pavement design. Borings and soil samples to a depth of five (5) feet at a minimum of eight-hundred-foot intervals along street centerlines (minimum two (2) required) and projected traffic flows shall be utilized in the design. Lime treatment will be required to a depth of two (2) inches below the bottom of a soil cement base course if soils have a pH greater than 15. 
2.  The minimum riding surface width for a street without curb and gutter shall be twenty (20) feet with four-foot-wide shoulders where no parking is allowed and eight (8) feet wide where parking is allowed. (Shoulder material shall be three-inch minimum thickness compacted crushed limestone.) 
3.  The minimum riding surface width, excluding curb and gutter width, for a street with curb and gutter shall be twenty-four (24) feet with no parking allowed and thirty (30) feet with parking allowed. 
4.  Where no parking is allowed, proper signing shall be provided. Signing shall be in conformance with the Louisiana M.U.T.C.D. and must be shown on plan drawings. 
b.  Grading. The full right-of-way shall be graded. 
c.  Ditches. If curbs and gutters are not provided, swale ditches shall be provided having at least 3:1 side slopes; that is side slopes having at least three (3) feet of horizontal distance for each one foot of vertical drop. 
d.  Sidewalks. On all streets designated as major streets by the mayor and board of aldermen, provisions shall be made for concrete sidewalks. As a minimum, the subdivision shall have a restrictive covenant requiring the construction of a sidewalk at the time the building(s) are constructed. 
e.  Profiles. Profiles of all streets showing natural and finished grades, drawn to a scale of not less than one inch equals one hundred (100) feet horizontal and one inch equals ten (10) feet vertical, shall be furnished. 
f.  Seeding, etc. of right-of-way width. The entire rights-of-way width shall be seeded, fertilized or sodded with grass growth prior to acceptance by the city. Erosion of soil into ditch grade shall be regarded and seeded by developer. 
(3)  Sewers: 
a.  The subdivider shall connect with sanitary sewer lines and provide adequate sewer lines accessible to each lot. Sewer lines shall be installed in conformance with Exhibit B [3] of this subchapter. 
b.  Allowable information into the system from the piping installed in the subdivision shall be three hundred fifty (350) gpm per inch diameter per mile of pipe installed. 
(4)  Water supply: An approved water supply shall be provided in street rights-of-way to each lot. Provisions for this shall be made with the utility company and locations of the water lines and appurtenances shall be shown on the plan drawings. 
(5)  Storm drainage: 
a.  Generally. All storm drainage, whether open ditch or subsurface, shall be designed in accordance with the Louisiana Department of Transportation and Development's Hydraulics Manual except as modified herein. 
    A contour/drainage design map shall be provided depicting slopes drainage areas and existing and proposed drainage features that affect the site or are affected by the site improvements, whether on or off site. 
    One set of drainage calculations shall be furnished in a booklet form. 
    Minimum culvert size shall be fifteen (15) inches in diameter. 
b.  Open ditch drainage: 
1.  Street ditches and minor drainage channels: Street ditches and other minor drainage channels shall be designed for a five-year storm with the exception of street crossings which shall be designed for a ten-year storm. 
    Where culverts are to be installed for lot access by others, the minimum size shall be shown on the plans. Unless designed as a subsurface drainage system, the maximum length of culvert per lot shall be one-half the length of the lot adjacent to the ditch. 
2.  Major channels: Channels that drain in excess of eighty (80) acres shall be designed for ten-year storm. Drainage structures (including bridges) crossing major channels shall be designed for a twenty-five-year storm. Maximum side slopes on major channels shall be (11/2) horizontal to vertical. 
c.  Subsurface drainage: 
1.  Subsurface drainage shall be designed for a two-year storm. Curb and gutter street with "over the curb" drainage will not be permitted in flood hazard areas. 
2.  Where subsurface drainage is to be installed by others, details and elevations of catch basins shall be shown on the plans. 
3.  The depth of roadway flooding at the edge of the travel lane will be a maximum depth of four (4) inches. 
4.  Appropriately designed outfall channel, to receive drainage facilities in subdivision, shall be constructed prior to acceptance. 
(Ord. of 9-10-85, § 40) 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Exhibit B, referred to in subsection (e)(3) above, and setting out requirements for sanitary sewer lines, manholes and pumping waste stations, has not been included herein, but can be found on file for inspection in the office of the city clerk. 

Sec. 24:61. - Same-Approval. 
(a)  The final plat shall be submitted to the mayor and board of aldermen in triplicate, one copy of which shall be a reproducible matte film or mylar. Unless this is done within one year of approval of the construction plans and specifications by the mayor and board of aldermen, such approval shall lapse. 
(b)  It is the intent of this section that the sale of building lots should be contingent upon at least a minimum of public improvements being made within the dedicated streets of the plat, as follows: 
(1)  Hard-surfaced streets shall have been constructed; 
(2)  Sufficient storm drains to adequately drain the streets; 
(3)  Water and sanitary sewer mains when these facilities are practicable; and that all these should be installed to the size and quality acceptable to the city department agency having jurisdiction. 
(4)  Other utilities shall be installed or a written agreement from the utility company must be included stating that they will furnish the utilities as required and will be installed in conformance with locations shown on plan drawings. 
(c)  With the foregoing in mind, the mayor and board of aldermen will consider approval of the final plat only after receipt of: 
(1)  Certification by the city clerk that all improvements have been installed in accord with these regulations and with the action of the mayor and board of aldermen giving conditional approval of the preliminary plat; or 
(2)  Certification by the city clerk that bond has been posted, available to the city, in sufficient amount to assure the completion of the required improvements. 
(d)  The final plat shall be drawn on matte film or paper on sheets twenty-four (24) inches by thirty-six (36) inches and shall be at a scale of one hundred (100) feet to one inch or larger. Where necessary, the plat may be on several sheets accompanied by an index sheet showing the entire subdivision. The final plat shall show the following: 
(1)  Primary control points, or descriptions and ties to such control points, to which all dimensions, angles, bearings and similar data on the plat shall be referred. 
(2)  Tract boundary lines, right-of-way lines of streets, easements and other rights-of-way, and property lines of residential lots and other sites; with accurate dimensions, bearings or deflection angles, and radii arcs and central angles of all curves. 
(3)  Name and right-of-way width of each street or other right-of-way. 
(4)  Location, dimensions and purpose of any easements. 
(5)  Number to identify each lot or size. 
(6)  Purpose for which sites, other than residential lots, are dedicated or reserved. 
(7)  Minimum building setback line on all lots and other sites. 
(8)  Any areas which have been designated as 100-year flood prone. Until final determination of flood areas and elevations by U.S. Corp of Engineers, the flood areas may be as shown on the F.E.M.A. Flood Hazard Boundary Map. 
(9)  Location and description of monuments. 
(10)  Names of record owners of adjoining unplatted land. 
(11)  Reference to recorded subdivision plats of adjoining platted land by record name, date and number. 
(12)  Certification by surveyor or engineer certifying to accuracy of survey and plat. 
(13)  Statement by owner dedicating streets, rights-of-way and any sites for public use. 
(14)  Title, scale, north point and date. 
(15)  Certificate of approval by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(16)  The exact location of all water and sewer taps provided for each lot within the subdivision from two (2) different intersecting angles. 
(17)  Certification from the engineer that improvements were constructed in accordance with plans and specifications. This certification shall be based upon having a qualified inspector on site for necessary phases of construction, such as is normally considered good engineering practice in assurance of good construction. 
(e)  Upon approval of the plat, the original drawings shall be returned to the subdivider and one matte film positive furnished by the developer shall be retained in the files of the city clerk. The developer shall submit to the mayor and board of aldermen all final plats a minimum of fifteen (15) days prior to the regular monthly council meeting. 
(f)  If the plat is disapproved, the grounds for disapproval shall be stated upon the records of the mayor and board of aldermen and a letter transmitted to the subdivider stating the reasons for such disapproval. 
(Ord. of 9-10-85, § 41) 
Chapter 25 - UTILITIES[1]

SUBCHAPTER A. - GAS

Sec. 25:2. - Gas rates for residential service established for customers within corporate limits. 
    Service from existing gas distribution facilities located within corporate limits for all domestic purposes in private residences and individual family apartments. Service will be supplied at one (1) point of delivery measured through one (1) meter and shall not be shared or resold. 
Residential Service 
Monthly Rate:

Sec. 25:5. - Fuel adjustment cost. 
    All increases in the cost of natural gas charged by the supplier will be automatically passed on to the consumer in the form of a fuel cost adjustment charge at the actual cost per million cubic feet (MCF). 
(Ord. of 7-30-81; Ord. No. 4-93; 8-27-93) 
Sec. 25:6. - Collection and payment of natural gas bills. 
(a)  The city shall each month, bill or invoice each consumer for the gas consumed during the previous billing date, covering his consumption as indicated by meter. 
(b)  If this invoice or bill is not paid for natural gas consumed, during the previous billing date, within ten (10) days after same is mailed, [sic] unless within that period the consumer presents a complaint of erroneous billing to the mayor of the city or the designated officer of the city, who by this section is empowered to review disputed bills and to rectify errors should there be any. 
(c)  If after a review of the billing, the consumer should fail to immediately pay for the gas consumed, according to meter, or pursuant to determination by mayor, then the city will have authority to discontinue service to delinquent consumer. 
(d)  The city, following the disconnection of service, may take any legal means at its disposal to collect the unpaid gas bill. 
(Ord. No. 20-78, §§ 1-4, 7-31-78; Ord. No. 10-87, §§ 1-4, 6-16-87; Ord. No. 4-93, 8-27-93; Ord. No. 08-03(B), 8-12-03) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 20-78, §§ 1-4, adopted July 31, 1978, was not enacted as a specific amendment or addition to the Code, and hence is included herein as § 25:6 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 25:7-25:19. - Reserved. 
Sec. 25:20. - Repair of natural gas lines on private property; notice to owner; failure to respond. 
    Wherever the private natural gas line of a customer or owner is discovered or found to be in disrepair, resulting in leaks, loss of gas, and possible attendant danger to life and property, the city shall inform the customer or owner of such leaks, and notify owner or customer to repair such in fifteen (15) days, and if such private line of the customer or owner is not so repaired, the city will discontinue service, and shall not renew service until such repair or installation has been made, tested, and found to be leak free. 
(Ord. of 9-13-77) 
Comment- As an explanation for the need, the above-cited ordinance was prefaced with the following provisions: 
"WHEREAS, there are many customers or consumers whose gas meter[s] within the city limits of the City of Eunice, which[,] for a number of obvious reasons, are located at the dwelling or at a point where the customer's line enters [a] place or building where the gas is to be used or consumed; and 
"WHEREAS, the private line of a consumer or owner from the city's supply line to the meter is often in a state of serious disrepair, which results in a loss of much gas to the City of Eunice, which is uncompensated for, and which may result in danger of accident; and 
"WHEREAS, [the] city has no right to enter upon the private property, and excavate and repair the line of a consumer or owner, and it is[,] of course, not the obligation of the city to do so; and 
"WHEREAS, in order to eliminate such loss and any related danger, the city has elected to notify the consumer or owner[,] as herein provided for, where such disrepair and danger is discovered to give the customer fifteen (15) days' written notice in which to renew or repair the customer's line to a state that it will be loss free, and in the event the consumer[s] or owners failure to do so, the city will discontinue service. 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED..." 
Sec. 25:21. - Repair of natural gas lines outside of corporate limits; location of meters; allocation of costs. 
(a)  The City of Eunice, having recently completed a study of its gas distribution system beyond the city limits, shall replace or extensively repair gas line or lines belonging to the city and located beyond the city limits and will make certain replacements or extensive repairs to certain line or lines to comply with the findings and recommendations of the experts employed by city to conduct such survey or surveys. 
(b)  On such outside of corporate limits, lines or meters shall be moved and/or installed on the main line belonging to city at the point where the service lines of a customer joint to the main line, insofar as possible. 
(c)  An accurate accounting of the cost of installation and operation of the line shall be maintained to the end that the expense for the installation of any such lines or extensive repairs shall be employed in the regulation of price or prices of the gas to the customers, and such adjustment shall be that necessary to reimburse the city for such expenditure or expenditures within that period for installation or repair through December, 1996. 
(d)  The necessary and proper devices and check meters shall be installed and maintained so as to be accurate throughout the period from installation to and through December, 1996. 
(Ord. of 9-13-77) 
Comment- The above-cited ordinance contained the following preface explaining the need for its adoption: 
"WHEREAS, the City of Eunice for some 40 years has owned and operated its own natural gas utility system, which includes the ownership of pipelines and the distribution of natural gas to its customers; and 
"WHEREAS, as authorized and permitted by law, the system lies both within the corporate limits and without the corporate limits; and 
"WHEREAS, some portion or portions of the lines lying outside of and beyond the corporate limits of the City of Eunice are deteriorating and the installation of new lines or repairs must be made on such lines lying beyond the city limits, as [the] city is experiencing the loss of much gas, and consequent revenues; and 
"WHEREAS, such operation is not sound financial practice, and is not a conservation of our energy, natural resource; and 
"WHEREAS, the contract whereby the City of Eunice acquires its natural gas needs and requirements in order to serve its customers expires in December of 1979, and it would not be sound business practice, nor responsible fiscal management on the part of the mayor and board of aldermen of the City of Eunice to expend sums in the relaying of new lines, the cost of which would not be paid for or liquidated during the remaining two-year period for the contract; and 
"WHEREAS, there are consumers upon a line or lines owned by the City of Eunice, and which lie beyond its corporate limits, whose meters or gas-measuring devices are not located at the city's main service lines, but are some distance away, and leaks in the private line of the consumer are resulting in financial loss to the City of Eunice, and good business practice renders it imperative that services be discontinued until the meters are moved and installed to the gas mains belonging to the City of Eunice; and 
"WHEREAS, the foregoing being true, the city must discontinue service, make major repairs, or install the new lines and increase rates to the end that the expenditures needed in the installation of the new lines will pay out for the installation and operating cost within the life of its present gas purchase contract, which expires in December, 1979. 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED..." 
Sec. 25:22. - Placement and location of meters. 
(a)  All service meters or master meters used or employed by the city in the operation of its natural gas system shall be located at the city's main or supply line at the most reasonable point of access for both city and customer. 
(b)  If, within ten (10) days after the city has called upon the customer to permit entry for the purpose of locating or relocating meters in accordance with the provisions of this section and according to safety standards in the industry, customer refuses such entry, then the city shall have the right and privilege to discontinue service to such customer. 
(Ord. No. 21-78, §§ 1, 2, 7-31-78) 
Sec. 25:23. - Changing and maintenance of natural gas service lines. 
(a)  The City of Eunice, before the commencement of the installation of plastic pipe or its equivalent, shall obtain a right-of-way from the landowner to go upon the property, make the necessary excavation or trench, and the installation of pipe, meter, regulator or any other service required apparatus. 
(b)  In the event of the refusal of landowner to execute such right-of-way agreement, the city may make installation of the meter and other like necessary installations upon public property abutting private property, in which case the city will, upon request of the property owner or consumer, furnish the necessary service line pipe which property owner will, himself, install under the supervision of the city, and the city, before supplying service, will test the line. In this case, the city may go upon the property for the purpose of repairing the line. 
(c)  Should the property owner refuse to grant right-of-way, including the necessary trench and installation essential to service, or should the property owner refuse to make installation of plastic line or its equivalent upon his property, the city may refuse natural gas service or the city may move or locate the meter, regulator and other necessary apparatus to the property line common to private ownership and public ownership, and furnish service, but not until the consumer or property owner, as the case may be, executes an instrument of release exempting the city from all liability for any injury to himself, his family, invitees or guests on his properties that may occur upon the property as a result of the furnishing of gas. In any event, the city shall not be liable for any injury of any kind to persons or property which occurs or originates downstream of the meter. 
(Ord. No. 5-79, §§ 1-4, 3-27-79) 
Secs. 25:24-25:49. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER B. - SEWERAGE 

Sec. 25:50. - Connection or tap charges for sewer system. 
(1)  For installation of new sewer service taps to the city's sewer facility or to a main line there shall be a charge as follows: 
(a)  Residential and commercial tap for service lines up to six (6) inches in diameter: 
1.  Standard: $400.00. 
2.  Requiring the breaking of part of street: $600.00. 
3.  Crossing street: $900.00. 
(b)  Commercial, industrial and institutional tap for service lines in excess of six (6) inches in diameter: Fee determined by direct and actual cost of the job. 
(c)  All taps on lines outside the city limits will be double the above rate. 
(2)  Cost for connection to an existing tap will be $200.00. 
(a)  All connections on lines outside the city limits will be double the above rate. 
(Ord. No. 26-74, § 1, 12-12-74; Ord. No. 27-80, 9-8-81; Ord. No. 04-04(B), 4-13-04) 
Sec. 25:51. - Payment of charges, issuance of connection permits. 
(a)  Before anyone connects to the sewer, he will make application to the city clerk for a sewer connection permit and shall pay to the city clerk for such permit the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) whereupon a sewer connection permit will be issued. 
(b)  The plumbing inspector shall not permit any connection to the sewer system until he has been furnished evidence that the sewer connection fee provided for herein has been paid. 
(Ord. No. 26-74, §§ 2, 3, 12-12-74) 
Sec. 25:52. - Violations, penalties. 
    Anyone violating the provisions of this subchapter shall be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1:21 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 26-74, § 4, revised, 12-12-74) 
Secs. 25:53-25:59. - Reserved. 
Sec. 25:60. - Public policy established for sewer extensions. 
(a)  There shall be no funds belonging to the city expended for extensions to the sewer system in excess of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(b)  The provisions and prohibitions shall not apply to extensions to public institutions, i.e., Louisiana State University-Eunice, to public schools, to municipally owned buildings, plants or institutions. 
(c)  This section shall not prohibit the formation and implementation of sewer districts nor shall it prohibit extensions paid for by private capital, constructed or installed under the supervision of the city engineer. 
(d)  This section shall not prohibit the city from agreeing to incur the costs of extending the sewer system to the boundary of newly annexed property or property already annexed into the city if there exists or upon which there will be constructed a commercial enterprise that will produce sales tax and property tax revenues to the city, but only after conducting a cost benefit analysis and determining that the benefit to the city in terms of increased sales tax revenue, property tax revenue and/or other ascertainable revenue will result in a timely recovery of all costs expended to extend the sewer system to said property and that collection of sales tax, property tax or other revenue after the recovery of all costs expended will inure to the city's benefit. 
(Ord. No. A-302, §§ 1-3, 11-9-65; Ord. No. 10-08(B), § 1, 10-28-08)
